MEMORANDUM

Res Electrical Alterations and Additions,
Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ontario.

Ottawa, April 9, 1949.

In reply to your marginal notation of the 5th instant appearing on Major Mackay's memorandum to you of April 1st, in connection with the above, we comment as follows:

Under cover of a memorandum to you from Major Mackay, dated October 29, 1948, we received two tenders for carrying out the electrical work at the Mohawk Institute based on plans and specifications provided by this Division. One was submitted by the Savory Electric on a cost plus 15% basis, the other was submitted by J.H. Turvey Electrical Co., and was a firm bid in the amount of $7,331.00. Major Mackay pointed out in his memorandum, that he was advised by Indian Superintendent Randle, that the United Electrical Co., Ltd., would forward their tender within a few days. Since that time, we have contacted officers of the Indian Affairs Branch by telephone on numerous occasions concerning this matter, requesting that action be taken to procure this tender so that we could make our comments and remove this job from our list of work on hand. We were advised that Mr. Randle would be requested to investigate the situation at an early date.

The last paragraph of Major Mackay's memorandum to you of the first instant, to which was attached the tender of the United Electrical Co., Ltd., in the amount of $6,620.24 together with their deposit cheque in the amount of $662.02, is not clear in that no mention is made of the two firms whose tenders, referred to in the foregoing, were forwarded to this Division.

Commenting on the three tenders received, that of the J.H. Turvey Electrical Co., is the lowest lump sum bid and we believe it would be in the best interest of the Department to have the Indian Affairs Branch award a contract to this firm; however in view of the fact that no reference is made to the tender submitted by this firm, in Major Mackay's memorandum of April 1st, we suggest that Mr. Randle be requested to contact the J.H. Turvey Electrical Co., and ascertain if they are prepared to undertake the work at the price quoted in their tender dated October 13, 1948, and if a price change is indicated they should be requested to submit a revised quotation for consideration before awarding the contract.

In connection with Major Mackay's memorandum to you of March 22nd last, in which he points out that it is the intention of the Indian Affairs Branch to utilize present unused space on the top floor of the building to provide adequate accommodation for the pupils at the institute, we would point out that electrical work, in addition to that shown on our plans, will be necessary when it is decided what architectural changes are necessary in this area.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
In order that the electrical work may be started as soon as possible, we would suggest that the contract be awarded and the costs for the electrical work, in connection with the architectural changes to the top floor, be covered by an Extra Work Order which will be issued when we know the extent of the work involved. We estimate that the cost of additional electrical work in this area will not exceed $700.00.

We will retain the deposit cheque of the United Electrical Co., Ltd., until the Indian Affairs Branch receives further advice from Mr. Randle in connection with the tender of the J.H. Turvey Electrical Co.

[Signature]

for Chief Engineer.

In reply to your marginal notation of the 5th instant appearing on Major Mackay's memorandum to you of April 1st, in connection with the above, we comment as follows:

Under cover of a memorandum to you from Major Mackay, dated October 29, 1948, we received two tenders for carrying out the electrical work at the Mohawk Institute based on plans and specifications provided by this Division. One was submitted by the Savory Electrician on a cost plus 15% basis, the other was submitted by J.H. Turvey Electrical Co., Ltd., who made their bid in the amount of $6,331.90. Major Mackay pointed out in his memorandum that he was advised by Indian Superintendent Randle, that the United Electrical Co., Ltd., would forward their tender within a few days. Since that time, we have contacted officers of the Indian Affairs Branch by telephone on numerous occasions concerning this matter, requesting that action be taken to procure this tender so that we could make our comments and remove this job from our list of work on hand. We were advised that Mr. Randle would be requested to investigate the situation at an early date.

The last paragraph of Major Mackay's memorandum to you of the first instant, to which was attached the tender of the United Electrical Co., Ltd., in the amount of $6,620.24 together with their deposit cheque in the amount of $662.02, is not clear in that no mention is made of the two Firms whose tenders, referred to in the foregoing, were forwarded to this Division.

Commenting on the three tenders received, that of the J.H. Turvey Electrical Co., and ascertain if they are prepared to undertake the work at the price quoted in their tender dated October 13, 1948, and if a price change is indicated they should be requested to submit a revised quotation for consideration before awarding the contract.

In connection with Major Mackay's memorandum to you of March 22nd last, in which he points out that it is the intention of the Indian Affairs Branch to utilize present unused space on the top floor of the building to provide adequate accommodation for the pupils at the institute, we would point out that electrical work, in addition to that shown on our plans, will be necessary when it is decided what architectural changes are necessary in this area.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
In order that the electrical work may be started as soon as possible, I would suggest that the contract be awarded and the costs for the electrical work in connection with the architectural changes to the top floor be covered by an Extra Work Order which will be issued when we know the extent of the work involved. We estimate that the cost of additional electrical work in this area will not exceed $700.00.

We will retain the deposit cheque of the United Electrical Co., Ltd., until the Indian Affairs Branch receives further advice from Mr. Randle in connection with the tender of the J.H. Turvey Electrical Co.

[Signature]

for Chief Engineer.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LANDS & NATIVE WELFARE SERVICE

Re: Electrical Alterations and Additions,
Mohawk Institute, Brantford, Ontario
Your File: IA 1356-12

With reference to your memorandum of April 9th regarding the above, we are now informed by Superintendent E.P. Randle that the J.H. Turvey Electrical Company are prepared to carry out the work at the Mohawk Institute at the price stated in their tender, which was forwarded to you under cover of our memorandum of October 29th, 1948.

We have noted that any additional electrical work that may be required as a result of altering the top floor of the building, will be covered by an extra Work Order, and that you estimate the cost of this extra work will not exceed $700.00.

FP/ST Director.
April 20, 1949.

Lt. Colonel E.P. Randle,
Indian Superintendent,
Brantford, Ontario.

Re: Mohawk Institute.

It is our intention to carry out the following improvements at the above school during 1949, and if possible, we would like to have the work completed by September 1st:

(a) Electrical alterations and additions
(b) Alterations to the top floor of the building
These are under direction of Lands and Development Services Branch

(c) Painting the exterior of the building

We would like you to make immediate inquiries with a view to obtaining a tender for the labour. The name and address of the person who tenders should also be forwarded for our information.

We understand that you have on hand a quantity of paint (reference your letter of March 24th and our reply dated March 29th). Please forward a requisition for any additional material that is necessary.

We note that it is your intention to move another building from the former Army Camp to the Mohawk School property. We would appreciate being advised when you expect to move this building.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.

OTTAWA April 19, 1949.

Re: Mohawk Residential School, Six Nations Indian Agency, Brantford, Ontario.

We have a memorandum dated March 22nd from Director of Indian Affairs Branch to yourself regarding possible alterations at the above school.

You ask marginally if a report can be made. One of our Engineers, Mr. R.R. Ross, currently making an inspection trip in Western Ontario was requested, before leaving Ottawa, to examine the school with Superintendent Randall and to prepare field sketches from which tendering documents can be prepared.

[Signature]
for Chief Engineer.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
April 25, 1949.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT.

Labour Saving Devices.

As you are aware, we are limiting each school to a number of labour saving devices each year. The Reverend Mr. Zimmerman of the Mohawk Residential School feels that the appliance which will best suit his purpose is the floor polisher requested herewith.

He feels that this will enable him to have his children spend more time in the classroom and less time on school labour.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Ref Mohawk Institute

Your letters 466-5 (E.1) of the 20th and 25th instant are acknowledged re the above and though your letter of the 20th was not quite clear, it was assumed your reference to a tender for labour was with regard to the top floor alterations and your letter of the 25th means us to disregard this, in view of the Examination by the Lands and Development Services Branch.

As you state, we have the paint on hand for the exterior painting and it is assumed the tender of Robert Styres to do the work for $1100.00 which was accepted last year, is still good.

Mr. Styres is prepared to start as soon as the children go on holidays, which is felt wiser, as with ladders and paint supplies around, with the children there, they could get up to a good deal of mischief.

With regard to moving the former Chapel Building at the Army Camp, which Mr. Zimmerman requires for additional staff quarters, Mr. Rispin says he would have to charge $1000.00 for the operation.

Rispin states the building will, owing to its length and shape, have to be cut and moved in two sections and maybe three. You will realize, that the time taken in movement from point to point is not the expensive part of such operations, it is the time taken to cut, jack up, brace up open ends and get ready for movement, followed by the time taken to lower the portions on their new site, line them up and repair roof where cut.

Consequently, the price quoted is reasonable, somewhat higher than previously, but wages and other costs have moved up since the quotations of two years ago.
Rispin can only move it and place it for the $1000.00 stated, he cannot take the time to finish it off for occupation, as he states he has too much private work ahead to do so, which he has neglected somewhat for two years, moving our many buildings.

It is suggested, therefore, that you approve of his offer, so he can proceed at once, as he is almost through with the hospital and Council buildings, then this office will submit a further recommendation concerning what is necessary and the costs of making it into two apartments, so we can get the work done ready for occupation in September.

May we also receive the authority to go ahead on the Domestic Science Building, so we can get it in operating order now, rather than wait to the summer holidays when so much other school work is done.

You have already approved of the installing of kitchen cabinets, etc., at a cost of $496.08, but there is the siding, painting and building of partitions.

We have the insul brick siding on hand, but it will cost about $60.00 to have it put on by an Indian carpenter.

While we did not reline the floors of the other army buildings used as schools, in this case, in view of the nature it is to be used for, it is felt a new floor should be placed in to give a first rate appearance and some cupboards, also a partition around the kitchen part.

Labour and material for this will cost approximately $400.00. The cost of paint and labour for painting will cost approximately $200.00.

If the work painting, siding and carpentering can now be authorized, please send an accountable cheque for $300.00, then it will be possible to proceed at once and we can employ workmen who will then carry on with other school repairs after the holidays commence.

Lt.-Col. E. P. Randle,
Indian Superintendent
4th May, 1949.

Mr. E.P. Randle,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Brantford, Ontario.

We have your letter of April 29th with reference to the Mohawk Institute. As stated in official letter of April 20th, the electrical alterations and changes in the top floor of the building will be carried out under the direction of the Lands & Development Services Branch.

With reference to the painting of the exterior of the building, this work may be done by Mr. Robert Styres on the understanding that the total amount to be paid for labour will be $1,100.00.

We are requesting the Minister's approval for the tender of $1,000.00 from Mr. Rispin to move the former chapel building at the Army Camp to the site of the Mohawk Residential School. As soon as we receive approval, you will be advised.

From the last four paragraphs of your letter, we understand that material and labour for repairing the Domestic Science building will amount to $660.00. You should forward a requisition immediately for the material.
required so that purchase can be made through our Purchasing Branch. Under separate cover we will forward you an accountable cheque for $300.00 for labour.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education
Ottawa, May 4th, 1949.

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Mohawk Indian Residential School

Additional accommodation is required at the above mentioned school for staff quarters.

The chapel building at the former Army Camp is our property, and it can be moved to the Mohawk Residential School. Owing to its length and shape, the building will have to be cut and moved in two sections. It requires considerable time to cut, jack up, and brace upon ends, and also get ready for movement. It also takes considerable time to lower the portions on their new site, line them up and repair the roof where cut.

Mr. T.J. Rispin of Brantford, Ontario, who has moved several other buildings from the former camp site to different locations on the Six Nations Reserve, offers to move the chapel building to the site of the Mohawk Residential School for an amount of $1,000.00. Indian Superintendent Randle states that this price is reasonable.

We would appreciate it if the Minister would approve acceptance of Mr. Rispin's quotation, in order that the building can be moved at an early date.

PP/ST Director.
Department of Mines & Resources,
Land and Development Services Branch,
Engineering and Construction Division.

SUBJ.: Revisions, Alterations & Additions to Electrical System, Mohawk Institute, Brantford, Ontario.

Dear Sirs:

Enclosed please find plans and specification papers for Electrical work to be done at the Mohawk Institute, Brantford, Ont.

We have followed the specifications and plans in arriving at the sum of ($6,620.24) Six thousand six hundred and twenty dollars and twenty four cents, which covers all revision, alterations and additions required in your Specifications.

We are enclosing a Certified cheque for the sum of Six hundred and sixty two dollars and two cents ($662.02) as laid down in your specification papers.

Yours Very Truly,

[Signature]
Sacy-Treas.,
United Electric Co Ltd
SAVORY ELECTRIC
18 HEAD STREET
BRANTFORD, ONTARIO

Dept. of Mines & Resources, Lands & Development
Engineering & Construction Division, Ottawa, Canada

Dear Sirs,

I have studied the plans & specifications for the above buildings, and being well acquainted with them, as I have kept the old system going for the last four years, I find with shortages & substitutions & price increases, that under existing conditions I could not give a definite quotation.

Up to the present I have had no labour troubles & do not anticipate any as my men have been with me for a considerable time and are good men. At the present time I have no contract work, it is all on a cost plus 15% basis and I render duplicate invoices from my suppliers. At the present time I have under construction on the above terms:

1. Job for Brant Farm Supplies of approximately $12000.00
2. Jobs for Brantford Oven & Rack Co. " $15000.00
3. " " Refrigerator Co. " $10000.00
4. New Plants " Stainless Steel Co. " $6000.00
SAVORY ELECTRIC
18 READ STREET
BRANTFORD, ONTARIO

Last year I rewired the largest Dept. Store in Brantford at a cost $23000.00 for the T. Eaton Co. of Toronto; on the same basis. Any of the above firms will supply you with a recommendation in regard to myself, my men and the way we do our work.

If you could see your way clear to accept the above terms I would be very pleased to look after this job for you and carry it through in the shortest possible time and would abide by the specifications.

In closing may I point out to you section 6 clause(8) of specifications? Our local inspection dept. informs me that steel conduit or flexible steel conduit cannot be used in horse barns or swine barns. Therefore this clause must be changed to come up to standard.

Hoping to hear favourably from you,

I remain, Yours Truly,
Lawrence G. Savory.

3/5/49

Ottawa May 2, 1949.

Res: Electrical Alterations and Additions, Mohawk Institute, Brantford, Ontario.

With reference to your memorandum of the 29th ultimo in connection with the above, we are enclosing herewith for transmission to the Indian Affairs Branch for their necessary action, tenders forwarded to this Division under cover of Major Mackay's memorandum of October 29, 1948, and United Electric tender and deposit cheque in the amount of $662.02 forwarded under cover of Major Mackay's memorandum of April 1st last.

Due to the nature of the work, we intend to have an officer from this Division visit the site with the contractor at the time of the commencement of work to discuss the rewiring, the running of new feeders, and other alterations in detail, to assure that the new wiring is installed in a manner most suited to the building construction.

We would appreciate advice as to when the contractor expects to start the electrical work so that we can make arrangements to have our officer leave Ottawa on or about the time the contractor is prepared to start the work.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands & Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, May 5th, 1949.

TO THE CLERK OF THE IRVY COUNCIL

Requesting authority to accept tender of J.H. Turvey Electrical Company, of Brantford, Ontario, amounting to $5,331.00, for wiring the Mohawk Indian Residential School, in the Six Nations Indian Agency, in the Province of Ontario.

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources desire to wire the Mohawk Indian Residential School, in the Six Nations Indian Agency, in the Province of Ontario;

THAT the following tenders have been received for the work required:

| Name                  | Amount of Tender |

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Mohawk Indian Residential School,
Electoral District of Brant,
Province of Ontario.

Some months ago, following receipt of a report submitted by the District Electrical Inspector on the wiring of the Mohawk Indian Residential School, we requested the Lands & Development Services Branch to have one of their engineers visit the school.

The engineer from the Lands & Development Services Branch found the wiring throughout the building to be in very poor condition, and plans and specifications were prepared for the extensive wiring required. Prices have been obtained from three firms, namely United Electric, Brantford, Ontario, Savory Electric, Brantford, Ontario, and J.H. Turvey Electrical Company, Brantford, Ontario.

The tenders from the three firms were reviewed by the Lands & Development Services and they recommend that the tender of J.H. Turvey Electrical Company be accepted. Enclosed is Memorandum to Council requesting authority to accept the tender of the firm just mentioned.

PP/ST Director.
May 5, 1949.

Memorandum

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Mohawk Indian Residential School

Additional accommodation is required at the above mentioned school for staff quarters.

The chapel building at the former Army Camp is our property and it can be moved to the Mohawk Residential School. Owing to its length and shape, the building will have to be cut and moved in two sections. It will require considerable time to cut, jack up and brace up the open ends preparatory to its removal. It will also take considerable time to re-erect the building on the new site and to make the necessary repairs to the roof, where cut.

Mr. T.J. Rispin of Brantford, Ontario, who has moved several other buildings from the former camp site to different locations on the Six Nations Reserve, offers to move the chapel building to the site of the Mohawk Residential School for an amount of $1,000.00. Indian Superintendent Rendle states that this price is reasonable.

We would appreciate it if the Minister would approve acceptance of Mr. Rispin's quotation, in order that the building can be moved at an early date.

[Signature]
Director.

PP
DML/824
Ottawa, May 4th, 1949.

Colonel B. F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

My dear Colonel:

You will find enclosed descriptions of milk cooler units. There is no doubt in my mind about the wisdom and necessity of such a unit.

Mr. Hawarth and I feel that the portable unit is the most desirable. If ever for one reason or another one wishes to move the unit it would not be necessary to build another tank. The cost of building a tank is rather considerable and tricky. There is an inside layer of cement, cork and another layer of cement. The portable units have insulated tops. The Victor or the Champion would be most acceptable. The Wood machine is very well known but more costly. Many farmers around Brantford are using these machines and in fact if one sends to a dairy they are compulsory.

The Champion unit costs $75.00 as I told you in Toronto. There would be the extra cost of building the tank. We can build a tank but I question whether it will be as satisfactory as the ready made.

Yours sincerely,

Rev. W. J. Zimmerman, M.A., B.D.
Principal.

P.S. The Champion has one advantage since it is longer and narrower. It would fit better into our milk house.

To Mr. Philan:

Technical advice approve all makes.

Mr. Zimmerman practically narrows the ultimate selection to the Champion 4-can self-contained "portable" (500lt.) offered by Ballantine for $400.00 plus something for wiring.

Mr. Z should supply figures as follows:
Cow milked: Milkings per day: Gallons produced: Gallons used; Gallons added daily.

C.A.I.C.
10 May
11th May, 1949.

Rev. W.J. Zimmerman,
Principal,
Mohawk Indian Residential School,
Brantford, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Zimmerman:

We received your letter of April 30th with reference to a milk cooler unit.

It is our intention to submit the matter to the officials of the Agricultural Department, but before doing so we require the following information:

(1) Number of cows milking.
(2) Number of gallons of milk produced daily.
(3) Number of gallons of milk used at the school daily.
(4) Number of gallons of milk sold daily.

As soon as we receive this information, your request will receive further consideration.

Yours sincerely,

PP/ST

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education
Ottawa, May 10, 1949.

My dear Colonel:

In reply to your letter of May 12, 1949.

(1) Number of cows milking... May 12/49... 23.

(2) Number of Gallons of milk... May 12/49... 966 lbs. produced daily.

(3) Milk supplied to school... May 12/49... 375 lbs.

(4) Number of gallons sold... No milk sold... During Month of April sold 448.9 lbs of butter fat.

One gallon of milk weighs roughly 10 lbs.

The custom at the Institute has been to use skim milk at the school. Besides the skim milk there is sent to the Institute 2 qts. of cream and 6 qts. of milk each day. Six qts. of milk is supplied to the families employed by Institute but living out.

I do hope that these figures will help to clarify the situation. Once again may I say with all sincerity that we do need very badly a milk cooler or some method of controlling the bacterial count. The health authorities will not permit us to use ice off the river. City water which has a temperature of roughly 70 degrees in the Summer is useless.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

To Mr. Phelan:

Milk supplied to school 375 lbs. and skim milk at that! This would fill the 4-can cooler (48 gal.) The other 600 gal. produced on May 12 were shipped to... But the amount of butterfat sold is not stated. This is a problem for experts. [Signature] 1949-05-13
21st May, 1949.

Mr. E.P. Randle,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Brantford, Ontario.

Attached are copies of letters dated April 30th and May 13th received from Reverend Zimmerman, Principal of the Mohawk Residential School, and also a copy of our letter of May 11th to Mr. Zimmerman. Also please find attached a copy of a letter received by Mr. Zimmerman from D.J. Ballantine.

We have made some enquiries, and if we supply a cooler we believe it will be necessary to purchase the one costing $400.00. Please let us have your comments on the matter as soon as possible.

PP/ST
Attache.

Certified to be a true copy of a Minutes of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 17 May 20175.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report dated May 5, 1949, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

THAT the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources desire to rewire the Mohawk Indian Residential School, in the Six Nations Indian Agency, in the Province of Ontario;

THAT the following tenders have been received for the work required:

| Name                                      | Amount of Tender |
|-------------------------------------------|------------------|
| United Electric, Brantford, Ont.          | $6,620.24        |
| Savory Electric, Brantford, Ont.          | Cost, plus 10%   |
| J.H. Turvey Electrical Company, Brantford, Ont. | $5,331.00       |

THAT the above tenders have been examined by Departmental Engineers and it is found that they are based on the plans and specifications as prepared by the Lands & Development Services Branch;

THAT the Departmental Engineers recommend the acceptance of the tender from J.H. Turvey Electrical Company, of Brantford, Ontario, in an amount of $5,331.00;

THAT funds are available for this purpose in Vote 230, 1949-50, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted for the acceptance of the tender of J.H. Turvey Electrical Company, of Brantford, Ontario, for the wiring of the Mohawk Indian Residential School, in an amount of $5,331.00.

Clerk of the Privy Council.

The Honourable
The Minister of Mines and Resources.
Ottawa, May 23, 1949.

Mr. E.P. Randle,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Brantford, Ontario.

Ottawa, October 8th, 1949.

Memorandum

Re: Electrical work - Mohawk Institute, Brantford, Ont.

You are advised that our electrical engineer visited the Mohawk Institute on September 26th last to inspect electrical work which is now being carried out and with the exception of the installation required in the attic storage space, which is to be converted into additional dormitory areas, it is approximately ninety per cent (90%) complete.

The Contract price for carrying out the electrical work let to the J.H. Turvey Electric Company of Brantford is in the amount of $5,331.00, and we recommend that the Indian Affairs Branch pay the Contractor the value of his work done to date, which amounts to $4,790.90.

Changes to our plans, requested by the Indian Affairs Branch to suit specific applications of certain areas, involved re-arrangement of the distribution system, type of lighting, and extra electrical work was required which was authorized on the job by our electrical engineer. The cost of this extra work amounted to $975.87, which, along with the Contractor's invoice for wiring new dormitory space, will be treated as extra work to be paid from funds made available by the Indian Affairs Branch. The Contractor will submit his claim for the balance of the Contract price, plus the value of the extra work mentioned above, for payment after final inspection is made upon completion of the work.

Plans are now in the process of preparation for the alteration of the attic storage space into dormitory areas and will be forwarded to the Indian Affairs Branch in the near future.

We are writing the J.H. Turvey Electric Company advising them to present a Progress Estimate in triplicate to Col. E.P. Randle, Indian Superintendent at Brantford, for payment of ninety per cent (90%) of their Contract price.

For your information and necessary attention, please,

Chief, Engineering and Construction Division.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
October 19th, 1949.

Mr. E.P. Randle,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Brantford, Ontario.

Re: Mohawk Indian Residential School

I enclose for your information a copy of a memorandum which we have just received from the Lands & Development Services Branch, in connection with the electrical work being done at the above school.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Education Division

formed, in the manner hereafter described, in connection with

IT IS THEREFORE AGREED that the said parties
hereto, hereby covenant, promise and agree, each with the other
as follows:

ARTICLE I: The covenants, clauses, revisions and conditions
of the Tender, General Instructions to Bidders, and
Specifications, (embracing the General Conditions, Labour
Conditions, General Specifications and Trade Specifications)
together with the drawings and such additional detail drawings,
shop drawings and instructions, as may from time to time be
furnished, shall be as fully part of this Agreement as if

or Minister fail to sign them, they shall nevertheless be

ARTICLE II: The Contractor undertakes and agrees:

(a) to do, furnish and perform, the works, materials, matters and things required to be done, furnished and performed, in connection with the following work or works namely: revisions, alterations and additions to electrical system, Mohawk Residential School, Brantford, Ontario, in accordance with the plans and specifications prepared by the Lands & Development Services Branch of the Department of Mines & Resources.

(b) to complete substantially, and to the satisfaction of the Minister, all the work, on or before the date or dates following, viz:-

the thirty-fifth day of August Nineteen Hundred and Sixty-Four A.D.

(c) Time shall be deemed to be material and of the essence of this contract.

ARTICLE III: The Minister undertakes and agrees, in consideration of the premises, and subject to the performance and observation on the part of the Contractor, of all covenants, provisos and conditions in the specifications contained:
(a) To pay the Contractor in current funds, for the performance of the contract in an amount of Five Thousand, Three Hundred and Thirty-One Dollars subject to additions and deductions as provided for in the Specifications governing the work.

(b) To make progress payments on account thereof, as provided for in the Specifications, equal to ninety per cent (90%) of the value, proportionate to the amount of the Contract, of labour and materials incorporated into the work, as estimated by the Engineer, less the aggregate of previous payments.

(c) On completion of the entire work, and on full performance of the covenants and clauses of the Specifications, to make full payment of the balance due under the Contract, as set out in the Specifications.

ARTICLE IV: The Contractor and the Minister for themselves, their successors, executors, administrators and assigns, hereby undertake and agree, to the full performance of the covenants contained herein.

With reference to your File 466-5 (E), this office is now returning the Contract Agreement in triplicate in connection with the work awarded the J. H. Turvey Company at the Mohawk Institute.

We regret the delay in returning same, but the contractor mislaid them for a considerable time and since they were overlooked at this office.

The work is virtually completed, except where it ties in with the new dormitory work, but as the latter has not yet been authorized, the contractor cannot proceed and is anxious for confirmation as soon as possible in order to clean up the work at the Institute.

A progress estimate report covering 90% of the original contract is enclosed in triplicate and payment is recommended.

Lt.-Col. E. F. Randle,
Indian Superintendent

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Mohawk Indian Residential School,
Six Nations Indian Agency, Province
of Ontario, Electoral District of
Brant

The above school is located just outside
the city limits of Brantford, and provision was
made in the current year's appropriation for renovations
that are required on the third floor of the building.

The Lands & Development Services Branch
have prepared drawings which will enable us to call
for tenders. It is estimated that an expenditure
of $6,000.00 to $7,000.00 will be required.

I would appreciate it if you would let
me know as soon as convenient, the names and
addresses of those from whom you desire quotations
to be obtained.

IN THE MATTER of the Application of the Corporation of the City of Brantford, under subsections (11) and (12) of section 94 of "The Public Health Act," as enacted by section 10, Chapter 41, Ontario Statutes, 1918, for an Order prescribing the manner in and the terms and conditions upon which there may be carried on the construction of a main trunk sewer on Mohawk Street and a sewerage system for the Bellview and Parkdale subdivisions of the said City (both of which extend into the Township of Brantford).

APPOINTMENT FOR HEARING.

The Ontario Railway and Municipal Board hereby appoints Thursday, the second day of February, A.D., 1922, at the hour of a quarter of Three o'clock in the Afternoon, at the Board's Chambers, 47 Queen's Park, in the City of Toronto, for the hearing herein.

Dated at Toronto this Twenty-third day of January, A.D., 1922.

(Signed) H.C. Small,

SECRETARY.
Re: Services

Application to the City of Brantford.

[Signature]

[Date]

January 12th, 1922.

Dear Major Smith,

I have your letter of the 5th instant reporting the trespass on the Globe property by an Indian named Harold living at Brantford. Action should be taken to prevent his moving either wood or soil and he should be treated as a trespasser as provided in the Indian Act. You will be good enough to see that the matter is attended to by the forest bailiff or by someone deputed by you.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Gordon J. Smith,
Indian Superintendent,
Brantford, Ont.
To The Ontario Railway and Municipal Board,
47 Queen's Park,
Toronto, Ontario.

APPLICATION is hereby made on behalf of the Corporation of the City of Brantford under the provisions of the Public Health Act, Section 94, Subsection II, for an Order prescribing the manner in which the works herein referred to may be carried on.

The works referred to are the construction of a main trunk sanitary sewer to be constructed as follows:

On the Mohawk Road from the intersection therewith of Cayuga Street to the intersection therewith of Fifth Avenue in the City of Brantford of a diameter of thirty-six inches and thence continuing along the Mohawk Road to a point approximately one hundred and fifty feet Northerly from the Northerly boundary of the Mohawk Church yard and thence across certain lands presumed to be the property of the Mohawk Institute and under the jurisdiction of the Department of Indian Affairs of Canada, in a direction parallel to the Northerly boundary of said Mohawk Church yard to the Grand River, such last mentioned portion of the sewer to be of a diameter of forty-two inches. The latter portion of the work so described being in the Township of Brantford.

Also the construction of a sewerage system for the subdivisions of Bellview, Parkdale and Hyde Park, all in accordance with the plans filed with the Board and also with the Department of Indian Affairs and with the Corporation of the Township of Brantford, a portion of the sewer system extending along Fifth Avenue which forms the boundary between the Township...
of Brantford and the City of Brantford at this point.

The reasons for the construction of the proposed works are, as to the work first mentioned, the necessity of providing additional outlet for the present general sewerage system of the City of Brantford and also for the increased sewerage which will require to be taken care of on account of the construction of the works secondly mentioned, and the reason for the construction of the works secondly mentioned is the necessity for the provision of a sewerage system for the subdivisions mentioned.

A general reason for the construction of these works in addition is the extreme desirability during this present season of affording relief work for the unemployed in the City of Brantford.

In the construction of the works mentioned it is not necessary that any highways should be closed except that it is desirable to have permission, if necessary in the construction of the work and for a temporary period only, to close a portion of the Mohawk Road approximately five hundred feet in length in front of the Mohawk Church and another section of the said Road approximately five hundred feet in length commencing at a point where this Road is crossed by the Mohawk Creek and extending Westerly along Mohawk Road.

If it becomes necessary to close these portions of the Mohawk Road a period of approximately ten days will be sufficient for the closing of each section.

In the opinion of the applicant the Township is not affected except by the temporary closing of Mohawk Road.
as above set forth, and the only land owner effected is the Department of Indian Affairs across whose lands it is proposed to construct the sewer and who have consented to the construction upon terms that they are to be protected from being called upon for any damages in consequence of its construction.

Application for the approval of the Provincial Board of Health of the said works has been already made and an Order of the Board approving of same has been received.

DATED at the City of Brantford this 24th day of January, 1922.

[Signature]

Solicitor for the City of Brantford.

DATED at Brantford this 24th day of January, 1922.

Sir,

I have the pleasure to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th instant enclosing Notice of Application of Mr. J. H. of Brantford to the Ontario Railway and Municipal for permission to construct a trunk line sewer through the Mohawk Institute grounds, and note your enquiry as to whether it will be necessary for you to attend on behalf of the Department at Toronto on the 2nd proximo.

15th July, 1922.

Dear Sir,

I am obliged for your letter of the 25th ultimo, enclosing a plan of lands connected with the Mohawk Institution, Brantford, Ontario, on which the sales of parcels from the Globe Farm, Babcock Lot and Manuel Labour Farm are set forth, and giving information in respect to the Canal and Tow-path through the Globe Farm in reply to Departmental letter of the 2nd June last. It is observed that the amounts received for the various parcels of the Globe Farm, which were assessed by the Company, are set forth in red ink on the said plan.

You are aware that judgment was given against the Company by the Exchequer Court of Canada in respect of the Manual Labour Farm. The formal judgment has not yet been settled, but the draft of the formal judgment, which has been submitted to the Company's solicitor, Mr. H....Sawyer, L.C., of Brantford, Ontario, provides as follows:

"And this court doth further order and adjudge that the Defendant the Company for the preparation of the Gospel in New England and the parts adjacent in America, commonly called the New England Co. may be account to the plaintiff for all moneys received by said Company as the proceeds of sales of any portions of the lands described in the Information filed herein."

I would be glad accordingly if you could state what amount was received by the Company in respect of each of the

Ottawa, Sept. 12, 1922.

Dear Mr. Smith:

As you are aware, it has been decided that the manual training farm used by the Mohawk Institute belongs to the Six Nations Indians. I feel that we should pay to their band funds a fair rental for the use of this property.

Would you have two or three competent men of Brantford fix a fair rental to be charged to our appropriation for the acreage used by the institute. It should be explained to those assisting you in this matter that the rental fixed should be based not on any fictitious value of the property but on its usefulness as an adjunct to the school.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.

Gordon J. Smith, Esq.,
Indian Superintendent,
Brantford, Ont.
A decision has been handed down that the manual training farm in use at the Mohawk Institute belongs to the Six Nations Band. This parcel of land is 163.90 acres and does not include the old church and cemetery or the 9.93 acres on which the school stands.

The land as laid out for the school does not take in any of their largest barn, and it cuts through the second largest barn and does not take in the pig house. I would therefore recommend that if possible the shape of the parcel granted to the New England Company for school purposes be altered so as to include their buildings, which could be done without increasing the area.

Sept. 12, 1953.

I noticed that there was considerable mustard in the large field near the road. I was informed that it is practically impossible to keep mustard out of this field as the field is generally flooded every spring. I feel, however, that a determined effort should be made to eradicate this weed and it might be well to direct the new Principal's attention to the matter.

November 8, 1929.

MEMO FOR FILE:

I have made a brief study of the lands used by the Mohawk Institute, and I believe they are as follows:

A. The site of the school buildings, owned by the New England Company, 9.93 acres.

B. 163.9 acres, which is part of Lot 5, the Eagle's Nest tract. This parcel is apparently Lot No. 5, with the exception of the New England Company lot and a railway right of way. It evidently includes the roads to and from the school, the Mohawk Church and cemetery. The plan of Lot 5 shows a 11.07 acre parcel to the west of the school. I believe this is included in the 163.9 acreage. For this property, the Department is giving the Band, who own it - subsequent to litigation in 1921-2 - a rental of $500 per annum. This is known as the manual training farm.

C. The Mohawk Institute is also using approximately 90 acres of the Glebe Lot, which is to the north of the school and across the railway right of way.

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

I am enclosing accounts certified for the building of a line fence between us and the Cockshutt Co. property. This expenditure has not been authorized and no application has been made for it. This is because nothing was said to me by the Company prior to the building of the fence. I saw the work proceeding but as all repairs had been made by the Company I did not know that we should be expected to bear a share of the cost. Mr. Scaife, the purchasing agent of the Company, told me that he did not know of it either until the payment was brought to his attention.

Had I been consulted I should have been inclined to take the position that an ordinary wire fence would suit our purposes as well as the high board fence that was erected. However, since it is an expenditure that will not likely recur for another thirty-three years and since the Cockshutt Co. have borne the expense of repairs and painting ever since the fence was erected it does not seem unreasonable that the account which I am forwarding should be paid.

Your obedient servant,

Horace W. Swell,

Principal.
Ottawa, December 2, 1935.

Rev. Sir:

Referring to your letter of the 16th instant, you may pay the account of the Cockshutt Plow Company Limited, Brantford, if you consider it reasonable. Funds for the purpose are being forwarded to you under separate cover.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

ENC.

We have received a memorandum from the Treasury Office, referring to John Van Mossell occupying a portion of the Glebe Lot and also to his payment of $10.00 in May last, on account of rental. We were informed that this payment will be held in suspense until the issue of formal lease to Mr. Van Mossell, and I would ask you, therefore, to be good enough to furnish a description of the property and the date the lease should bear in order that the transaction may be completed.

Yours very truly,

J. C. Caldwell,
Chief, Reserves Division.

Major E. P. Randle,
Indian Superintendent,
Brantford, Ontario.
THIS AGREEMENT entered into this 8th day of January 1938

BETWEEN

E. P. Handle, Superintendent Six Nations Indians,
representing the Six Nations Council, of the City of Brantford, in the
County of Brant, herein called Locutee of the first part

AND

John Van Mossell of the Township of Brantford in the
County of Brant, herein called lessee of the second part.

THE PARTIES agree to lease to the lessee part
of the above property, more correctly described as being on the east
side of the Canal and on the banks of the said Canal, containing about
one-half acre more or less for the term of 10 years from the 1st of
April 1937 at the clear yearly rent of $15.00 per annum, payable in
advance on the 1st of April in each year.

The Lessee has erected a small dwelling house on the said
property and is to be allowed to remove the building on the expiration
of the lease.

The Lessee to have the privilege of removing the same at the
end of the lease.

The Lessee will be responsible for maintaining and keeping his
property.

The Locutee retains legal jurisdiction.

hands.

from thenceforth ensuing, and fully to be completed and ended, SUBJECT NEVERTHELESS, to a determination or cessation of the said Term before the expiration thereof, under the proviso or condition hereinafter mentioned, yielding and paying yearly during the said Term, unto the said party of the first part, the clear yearly rent or sum of Ten dollars without any deduction whatsoever, the first payment of the rent now to accrue and become due, to be payable and paid in advance, on the Fifteenth day of April in each year of the term.

And the said party of the second part doth hereby for himself, his heirs, executors and administrators, covenant with the said party of the first part, his successors and assigns, that he the said party of the second part, his heirs, executors, administrators, or assigns,

Form No. I.A.307
It is hereby further understood and agreed that the lessee shall be allowed to remove the small dwelling house erected by him on the property hereby leased, at the expiration of lease, and that he shall be responsible for fencing to protect his crops.

Nor shall he, except under licence of the Minister of Mines and Resources or the duly appointed agent for the Reserve of which the lands duly leased form a part, cut, or allow to be cut, any wood or timber, except for fuel or fencing of lands covered by this lease, or sell or otherwise dispose of any wood or timber standing or lying upon the said lands.

And further, that the said party of the second part, his executors, administrators, or assigns shall not, nor will do, suffer or commit, any unlawful or voluntary waste, spoil or destruction whatsoever upon the said premises, nor shall he remove any manure therefrom, either during the term or at the expiration of this lease, but shall and will in all respects use and manage the said lands and premises in a fair and husbandmanly manner. And further, that the said party of the second part, his executors, administrators or assigns, shall and will from time to time and at all times during the said term keep the fences, barns, houses, and buildings thereon erected and being used during the said term to be erected, in good and tenable state of repair; and the said fences and barns, houses and buildings, so being repaired, shall and will at the end, expiration, or other determination of the said term, which shall first happen, peaceably and quietly leave, surrender and yield up, all and every part thereof, unto the said party of the first part, his successors or assigns, without the payment or allowance, by the said party of the first part, of any sum of money whatever, to the said party of the second part, his executors, administrators, or assigns, or any tenants or occupiers of the said lands for any fences or buildings, or improvements, erected or used by the said party of the second part, his executors, administrators and assigns, or any tenants or occupiers of the said lands and premises, or any part thereof; and the said party of the first part, for himself, his successors, doth hereby covenant to and with the party of the second part, his executors, administrators, or assigns, that the said party of the second part, his executors, administrators, or assigns, well and truly paying the said yearly rent hereby reserved and observing and performing the covenants hereinbefore contained, shall quietly and peaceably hold and enjoy the said lands and premises, with the appurtenances, during the said term, without any disturbance whatever by the said party of the first part, his successors or assigns.
PROVIDED ALWAYS, and it is hereby agreed that, if the rent hereby reserved, or any part thereof, shall at any time or times during the said term be in arrear or unpaid for the space of Thirty days next after the days or any of them whereon the same shall become due, according to the reservations thereof heretofore contained, whether the same be demanded or not, or in case of breach or non-performance of any or either of the covenants herein contained on the part of the said party of the second part, his executors, administrators or assigns, to be observed and performed, then and in such cases or either of them, it shall be lawful for the said party of the first part, his successors or assigns, or any of them, at any time after the expiration of the said Thirty days, into and upon the said lands, tenements, and premises, or any part thereof, in the name of the whole to re-enter, and the same to have again, repossess and enjoy, as if this indenture had never been made, and in case of such re-entry, this present indenture, and every clause, matter, and thing herein contained, and the term hereby granted, shall cease, determine and be absolutely void to all intents and purposes whatever, and the said party of the first part, his successors or assigns, shall thereupon hold the said lands and premises with the appurtenance, utterly discharged of this lease, and of all covenants and provisions herein contained, without the payment or allowance by the said party of the first part, of any sum of money whatever to the said party of the second part, his executors, administrators, or assigns, or any tenants or occupiers of the said land, for any houses, buildings, and improvements, erected or made by the said party of the second part, his executors, administrators and assigns, or the tenants or occupiers of the said lands and premises or any part thereof.

Provided further that if the rent hereby reserved or any part thereof shall be unpaid for thirty days after becoming payable (whether formally demanded or not) or if any covenant, provision, stipulation or condition on the part of the lessee herein contained shall not be performed or observed, then and in any of the said cases it shall be lawful for the Minister by notice in writing under his hand to cancel these presents and terminate the estate or term hereby demised and thereupon these presents and everything therein contained and the estate or term hereby created shall, from the time of the giving of such notice, absolutely cease, determine and be null and void without any re-entry or any other act and without any suit or other legal proceedings being brought or taken, provided further that His Majesty shall nevertheless be entitled to recover from the lessee the rent then accrued or accruing, and provided further that any right of action of His Majesty against the lessee in respect of any antecedent breach of any of the said covenants, provisions, stipulations, or conditions, shall not be thereby prejudiced.

And provided further that any notice affecting the tenancy hereunder which the lessor may desire to serve upon the lessee shall be sufficiently served on the lessee if left addressed to him on the demised premises or posted to him addressed to his last known address, or if left at the said address. A notice sent by post shall be deemed to be given at the time when in due course of post it would be delivered at the address to which it is sent.

PROVIDED ALWAYS that if any portion of the tenements or hereditaments hereby demised shall be under a lease to any other person, then this lease shall be considered as excluding such land, without thereby causing any diminution of rent.

IN WITNESS WHEREOF the Director of the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources, on behalf of the Minister, and the Lessee have hereunto set their hands and seals the day and year first above written.

Dear Sirs,

We are a charitable organisation and work in conjunction with the Indian Department in connection with the Mohawk Institute, Brantford, Ontario.

We have recently received a letter from the Principal of this Institute saying that he has been approached by the Bayne-Barry Oil Co., of 250 Nelson Street, Brantford, with a view to the New England Company granting them a lease of 14 acres of land which we hold in freehold for the purpose of sinking wells for gas and oil.

Before proceeding in the matter we are writing to ask if your Department would be good enough to pass on to us any information which you may have as to the reliability and standing of this Company. Your reply will, of course, be treated in the strictest confidence.

Thanking you for your assistance,

We are,

Yours faithfully,

NEW ENGLAND COMPANY

Dear Sir,

Enclosed herewith is copy of a letter received in this office through the Commissioner of European Emigration for Canada in London from Mr. Isaac Jones, Treasurer of the New England Company, 26 Bloomsbury Square, London, W.C.

It will be noted that Mr. Jones states his Company is a charitable organization working in conjunction with the Indian Department in connection with the Mohawk Institute, Brantford, Ontario. I should appreciate being advised whether the matter is one with which you are in a position to deal and, if so, whether you will reply to Mr. Jones direct or if you desire to forward to this office such information as may be secured in order that same may be transmitted through our Commissioner in London.

August 26, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of August 21st, concerning the request received from the New England Company of London in connection with the application of the Stayne-Barry Oil Co. of 230 Nelson Street, Brantford, for the right to drill for oil and gas on a twelve acre parcel of land belonging to the Mohawk Institute.

If this parcel of land is not part of the Six Nations Reserve and is not included in what may be described as the Michener lease, then of course we would have no administrative control over such a situation. In any event, as it has already been demonstrated that oil does not exist in any quantity in that district and the gas production is quite limited, it would be our view that the New England Company would be better advised to refuse the application. The necessary disturbance in connection with such a proposition would be considerable in such a small area and the results by way of royalties or rentals would, no doubt, be insignificant.

In so far as the financial standing of the applicant is concerned, that is a matter which, of course, the New England Company must investigate themselves.

Yours very truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

Major L. P. Randle,
Indian Superintendent,
Brantford, Ontario.

Sir:

With reference to your 38-0-9 of the 3rd instant concerning the New England Company, and the Staysse-Barry Oil Company, your attention is directed to this office letter IOB-1671/40 the 21st August.

As you will see, this form is not particularly reliable, consequently it is not considered likely the Department would wish to recommend to the New England Company to enter into contract with them.

In any case the New England Company property only consists of 9.53 acres, considerable of which is occupied by buildings, consequently it would hardly be a wise plan to have drilling operations carried on in the immediate vicinity of the school and outbuildings.

Lastly, it is unlikely oil in any worthwhile quantities will ever be located in this area.

Yours truly,

E. P. Randle,
Indian Superintendent.

Major E. P. Randle,
EPR/CB;
Ottawa, September 12, 1940.

Dear Sir,

Your letter of June 22 last addressed to the Mines Department, Office of the High Commissioner for Canada, reached this Branch about a month ago and a little later we also received that of August 1, addressed to the Superintendent of Welfare and Training.

In the meantime we have had careful inquiries made with regard to the question asked by you concerning the Staysse-Sarry Oil Company's application for leasing of twelve acres of your land.

Reports on the subject have been received from the Indian Superintendent at Brantford and they are to the effect that your land in question comprises only some 9.93 acres, instead of 12 acres as mentioned in your letter; that a considerable part of it is occupied by buildings and, consequently, it would hardly be a wise plan to have drilling operations carried on in the immediate vicinity of the school and outbuildings.

Furthermore, from such information as we have it seems unlikely that the prospects of success for the proposed undertaking would be very great either from the viewpoint of the capacity of the firm in question or the likelihood of oil being obtained. These last observations, of course, are a little outside of our purview in the matter and, therefore, are made only for your confidential information.

Yours very truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Director.

A special meeting of the Six Nations' Council was held in the Council House at Chsweken on the above date, with seven members present. The meeting was opened in due form by Major E. P. Randle, the Indian Superintendent.

Moved by William C. Johnson, seconded by Herbert Jamieson, that with regard to the request of the Cockshutt Plow Company, as conveyed by a letter dated the 17th of June 1942, requesting this Council on behalf of the Six Nations Indians to lease them some 3.5 acres of land now used by the Mohawk Institute, that this Council is prepared to consent to same, subject to the conditions laid down in the discussion at this meeting and outlined hereunder:

1. The said lands to be leased for the duration of the present war and a period of five years thereafter.
2. The rental to be $150.00 per acre per annum.
3. The entire cost of removing, rebuilding and replacement of fences now, and on termination of the lease, to be at the expense of the Cockshutt Plow Company.
4. At the expiration of the lease, the land leased to be placed in its former condition and suitable for cultivation.
5. Rental to be paid on the signing of the lease and on the same date thereafter each year.
6. The rentals received to be used for the benefit of maintenance of the Mohawk Institute.
7. A draft of the lease containing the above conditions and others that may be necessary to be submitted to the Council for final approval.

Carried.

Dear Major Randle:

I have now received instructions from Cockshutt Plow Company, Limited, that the terms and conditions embodied in the Resolution of the Six Nations' Council, dated June 17th 1942, are acceptable.

Would you be kind enough, therefore, to proceed with all possible haste to have the Lease drafted for ratification by the Council, and execution by the parties. Anything you can do to expedite this matter at the present time would be greatly appreciated, and if you feel the writer can be of any assistance in this regard do not hesitate to call upon me.

Yours sincerely,

J.A.D.Slemin
D. J. Allan, Esq.,
Superintendent, Reserves & Trusts,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Sir:

Six Nations Council Resolution, 17th of June, 1942.

This office is enclosing for the action and consideration of the Department, a resolution passed by the Council on the 17th instant consenting to lease under certain terms to the Cockshutt Plow Company, 3.5 acres of land, now used by the Mohawk Institute and adjacent to that Company's property.

The Cockshutt Plow Company have been requested by the Government to produce certain important aeroplane parts, which makes it necessary for them to build immediately additional factory buildings and acquire more yard space.

Their original request to the Council was for the purchase of approximately 6 acres of land, but the Council at a special meeting declined to consider this proposal, as it entailed surrender of most valuable property.

Also, the Principal of the Mohawk Institute, the Rev. H.W. Snell, was present at the Council Meeting, and pointed out that the loss of the particular 6 acres requested by the Company would deprive the Institute of practically all the garden land worked in conjunction with the greenhouses, and make it necessary for the latter to be removed, and that the only suitable place the garden and greenhouses could be relocated was at a considerable distance from the school buildings, creating many disadvantages.

However, Mr. Snell said he could manage without the 3.5 acres, so the Council, in order to assist the war effort, informed the Cockshutt Company they would be prepared to lease the designated land under the terms and conditions laid down in the Resolution attached.

-over-
The Cockshutt Company advised today that they are prepared to accept the Council's terms and lease the land and a copy of their letter of acceptance is attached.

As the production of the parts which the Company have to manufacture are of vital importance to the war effort, and all possible speed is necessary, - may this matter be laid before the Director immediately, in order that approval may be obtained to the proposals, so that a lease may be drawn up covering the Council's terms and any necessary additions the Department may consider advisable, and forwarded here for formal approval by the Council and for signature of the Cockshutt Plow Company.

This office understands that all the Mohawk Institute farm land is under lease to the New England Company, and if this is so the Department will know what action, if any, is necessary to inform them of this proposal.

A map is attached showing the land it is proposed to lease, and it might be advisable to state that no permanent buildings will be erected on it by the Company, but it will be used mostly for yard space and storage.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Major E. P. Randle,
Indian Superintendent.

Encl.
Ottawa, June 24, 1942.

I have received your letter of June 19th, your file 1864/43, in which you report the application of the Cockshutt Plow Company for permission to occupy three and one-half acres of land of the property now occupied and used by the Mohawk Institute.

As your records will indicate, this Mohawk Institute property is held by the Superintendent General under lease from the New England Company and the lease now in effect contains a very specific condition to the effect that no part of this property shall be occupied without the consent of the New England Company. We have, therefore, sent the New England Company requesting such consent and when reply is received you will be further advised, but in the meantime it will not be possible to approve the application of the Cockshutt Plow Company, although we do not anticipate any difficulty or avoidable delay in bringing the matter to a satisfactory conclusion. I hope to be in a position to advise you more definitely within the course of the next day or two.

Yours very truly,

D. J. Allan,
Superintendent,
Reserves and Trusts.

Major E. P. Randle,
Indian Superintendent,
Brentford, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

This will acknowledge your letter of the 16th instant on behalf of the Cockshutt Limited Aircraft Company containing the information that one of the buildings of the Company have been erected on the property leased from the Six Nations Council.

As you request, this information will be brought to the attention of the Council at the next meeting, but in the meantime you will perhaps place before the Board of Directors the following comment.

Your Board will remember that from the commencement of the negotiations with the Indian Council, they were without question or doubt, adverse to disposing by sale of the small parcel of land you required, and only consented to lease it with considerable reluctance.

In view of this known attitude of the Council, the writer - as personally responsible to them for the protection of their interests, is astonished that a Company of the integrity and standing in this community, such as the Cockshutt Company is, should not have taken every possible precaution to see that there was no chance of any violation of the agreement with the Six Nations, by the placing of any permanent building on the property leased. Never was it contemplated for one instant that your Company would be negligent and go beyond their just rights in using the land leased.

The Indian people generally are particularly sensitive over their title to land, as experience over the past two hundred years with the "white man" has not been conducive to a belief in the sincerity of our purpose.

Yours truly,

Lt.-Col. H.F. Bundle,
Indian Superintendent.
Brantford, Ontario  
December 15th, 1944.

Lt. Col. E. P. Randle,  
Superintendent, Six Nations' Indians,  
Brantford, Ontario

Dear Sir:

You will recall that in the summer of 1942 the Six Nations' Council consented to lease to Cockshutt Loulded Aircraft Ltd., a small parcel of their lands (3.06 acres), being part of the Mohawk Institute farm, adjacent to lands owned by Cockshutt Plow Company Limited.

It is with deep regret that the Board of Directors of our Company have recently learned that in the construction of this war plant, one of the buildings was, without the Board's knowledge, inadvertently erected upon the lands so leased comprising an area of 167' x 80'.

The Board of Directors, upon learning of this desired that the Council should have knowledge of this fact. I have been authorized on behalf of the Board to express to the Council their sincere regret at this unfortunate occurrence, which is only explainable by the urgency and haste that was necessary, at the time, to get the plant into production of essential materials and equipment for the war effort.

I would appreciate your bringing this matter to the attention of the Council at the earliest opportunity and convey to them the earnest desire of the Board to make a generous settlement of this most unfortunate affair in whatever manner might mutually be agreed upon.

I am enclosing herewith a plan showing this encroachment.

Let me once again express through you to the Council our sincere apologies and grave concern in this matter, and trust that the very cordial relationship existing between the Company and the Council will not be disturbed.

Yours faithfully,

(signed) J.A.D. Slemin

HALEY, SWEET & SLEMIN,
Barristers and Solicitors.

JAD:js
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

This office is enclosing for your information a copy of a letter received from Messrs Harley, Sweet & Clemin, Solicitors, on behalf of the Cockshutt Moulded Aircraft.

The letter is self-explanatory, and its contents were placed before the Council at their meeting last Thursday.

However, they took no definite action, but showed considerable cold resentment and decided to contemplate upon the matter until their next meeting.

They did request this office to forward the facts to the Department and see if the Department had any advice to offer.

This office considers the action of the Cockshutt Company as beyond excuse and utterly negligent and they deserve every condemnation.

It is not so much the value of the land, but the principle of the thing, and can only increase the Indians' belief in the unreliability of our own people in matters effecting Indian land and title.

A plan showing the encroachment is attached, also a copy of a letter the writer sent to the Solicitors of the Company on being advised, - and as the Council meet again on the 1st of February your reply to the Council would be appreciated by that date.

Lt.-Col. E.P. Randle,

Indian Superintendent.

Six Nations Council Resolution No.2, April 5/45.

This resolution deals with the dispute over the land leased from the Mohawk Institute property to the Cockshutt Moulded Aircraft Limited - and reported in this office letter 209/45 of the 25th of January 1945.

The Council after listening to the explanations of the General Manager and Solicitor of the Company, decided they would dispose of the parcel for $7,000.00 subject to the consent of their people.

It was assumed by the Council that they could not dispose of this parcel of land without going through the procedure laid down in Section 61 of the Indian Act.

This Cockshutt Company have now agreed to pay the $7,000.00 asked for by the Council, and a copy of their letter of acceptance is attached.

It would be appreciated if the Department would review this matter immediately, so that the Department's decision over the matter can be given to the Council at their next meeting on the 3rd of May, - and also advise the exact procedure that will be necessary to take the vote - and what form the agreement to transfer the land to the Cockshutt Company should take.

Lt.-Col. E.P. Handle,

Indian Superintendent.

Dear Sir:

Re: Cockshutt Plow Company Limited
and Indian Lands. (3.05 Acres)

The offer to sell to the Cockshutt Plow Company Limited, as set forth in a resolution passed by the Council of the Six Nation Indians at their recent meeting for the sum of Seven Thousand Dollars ($7000), a parcel of land consisting of 3.05 acres more or less, has now been considered by the directors of the Company.

Although, the Company had felt that the sum of Five Thousand Dollars ($5000.) was a generous offer for the lands in question, and also more than the lands were really worth, they, nevertheless, desire to arrive at a price which is satisfactory to the Council. Accordingly, I have been authorized on behalf of the Company to accept the proposal made by Chief Miller, and confirmed by resolution of the Council, wherein, the Company agrees to pay the sum of Seven Thousand Dollars ($7000) for the said lands now under lease by the Company from the Council of the Six Nation Indians being 3.05 acres more or less, and which lands are more particularly described in a Blue Print made at the time the said lands were leased by the Company.

In consideration, and upon delivery of a good sufficient Deed conveying the said lands clear of encumbrance, the Company agrees to pay the sum of Seven Thousand Dollars ($7000).

Would you, therefore, advise the Council that their offer has been accepted by the Company, and just as soon as the Deeds of the said land have been properly executed, I shall obtain a cheque of payment of same in the above sum.

May I express through you to the Council, the sincere appreciation of the Directors, Mr. Lee, and the writer for the friendly and courteous treatment accorded in these negotiations.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

(signed) J.A.D. Slemin
MEMORANDUM FOR FILE

In 1835 the Indians gave a surrender and in 1859 the Governor General granted lands to the New England Company.

In 1922, in the Crown vs. New England the Exchequer Court adjudged that the Crown recover possession of Lot 5, Eagles Nest excepting the Mohawk school lot of 9.93 acres and five other parcels patented to different parties. The judgment makes no reference to the Six Nations Indians. It was registered in Brantford Registry Office in 1924 and appears to affect title in the crown as Dominion lands.

Following the judgment in 1922, the New England Company gave a lease to the Superintendent General of 10 acres, (the school lot) for 21 years, which lease expired January 1st, 1943.

In 1942 when Cockshutt proposed to lease three acres at $150.00 per acre per year, it was considered that this was part of the school lot, and a cablegram was sent to the New England Company requesting them to consent to the sublease and reporting that rental of $500.00 would be available for their purposes. The Company consented. Preparing of the lease to Cockshutt was held up apparently until after the renewal of the New England lease.

In December, 1944 Cockshutt advised that they had built on the three acres, and following negotiations
between the Company and the Band Council the latter resolved in April, 1945 that Cockshutt's offer of $7000.00 be accepted subject to the approval of the Six Nations people. Cockshutt's solicitors now write to Colonel Randle that on delivery of a good and sufficient deed they will pay $7000.00.

One way of giving title would be to take surrender, but in view of the voting membership of more than 1200, it would be difficult to obtain a favourable vote.

Another way of conveying title would be by submission to council to authorize sale under the Dominion Lands Act. Such a submission would have to recite sufficient of the history to satisfy the purchase price being paid into the Band's fund.

Though I discussed with Mr. Cory making title by surrender, in view of the difficulty of obtaining a surrender I would now suggest the latter method of giving title.

[Signature]

[Handwritten note: Poor Copy]
Ottawa, 22nd May, 1945.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL:

The undersigned has the honour to report—

THAT by judgment of the Exchequer Court of Canada in 1922 the hereinafter described lands were declared the property of His Majesty in right of Canada;

THAT following the said judgment the land has been held by His said Majesty for the benefit of the Six Nations Band of Indians as public lands of the Dominion and not as Indian Reserve lands;

THAT Cockshutt Moulded Aircraft Limited has occupied a portion, approximately three acres, of the said land and has offered to purchase the said portion for the sum of Seven Thousand Dollars ($7000.00);

THAT as the Six Nations Band of Indians have received all benefits and profits from this land since the aforesaid judgment a resolution from the said Indians was requested and received recommending the proposed sale for the sum of Seven Thousand Dollars ($7000.00).

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that he be and is hereby authorized to sell the lands hereinafter described for the sum of Seven Thousand Dollars ($7000.00), and that letters patent granting the said land may be issued under the Public Lands Grants Act, Chapter 114, R.S.C., 1927.

DESCRIPTION

Respectively submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.
Ottawa, May 23rd, 1948.

Lt.-Col. E. P. Randle, Indian Superintendent, Brantford, Ontario.

Ref. your file 755/48.

The surrender of 1885, "Indian Treaties and Surrenders", vol. 1, pg. 26 covered 48,000 acres which is understood to include Lot 5, Eagle's Nest. A judgment in the Exchequer Court dated 14th January, 1922 provided that the crown recover possession of Lot 5, Eagle's Nest with certain exceptions. Following these, the land might be considered as Indians lands rather than part of the Six Nations Reserve, and Letters Patent might be granted to Cockshutt Moulded Aircraft Limited for the 8,08 acres which they wish to purchase.

However, the Indians consider the land as part of the Reserve and we would rather not rely on the surrender given 110 years ago.

The price of $7000.00 is acceptable. However, there does not seem to be any need on the part of the Indians or the Department to rush completion of the deal until it can be put through in the regular manner. The Band Council resolution of April 5th accepted the Cockshutt offer of $7000.00 "subject to the approval of the Six Nations people". It might be inadvisable to proceed to issue a grant under the old surrender and judgment if it would give the Indians the impression that we would be usurping...
their authority to give surrenders. The same situation might arise again in connection with other land in the Eagle's Nest tract and it is considered advisable to retain the good will and confidence of the Indians by asking for a surrender of the Band, as the Council considers that necessary.

The mistake of building on the land was made by Cockshutt and they should be content to wait until a regular surrender can be obtained. In the meantime, they should pay rent at the rate of $457.60 per year from the date of occupation until the purchase can be completed.

Could not a surrender be submitted to the Band at the next election of councillors? If you agree, please advise and the surrender will be drawn and forwarded to you. When will the next meetings for nomination and election be held?

D. J. Allan,
Superintendent,
Reserves and Trusts.
Attended, with Mr. Cory, to discuss the draft submission with Mr. Jackson. He does not like using the authority of the old surrender of 1835 unless it is necessary. He suggested that a vote on a surrender could be obtained at the next election of Band Councillors. In the meantime the Cockshutt Company should pay rent. The Indians might criticize the use of the old surrender, and it would be better to try to get a new surrender, keeping the old surrender in reserve; it might be necessary to invoke the authority of the old surrender, to make title.
Ottawa, May 23rd, 1945.
