Lt. Col. E. P. Randle, Indian Superintendent, Brentford, Ontario.

Re: Cockshutt Plow Purchase

The matter of the purchase of the land encroached upon by the Cockshutt Plow Company has been fully considered and Band resolution No. 2 of the Six Nations Council passed at their meeting of April 5th is approved. In this connection it is noted that the resolution accepting the offer of the Cockshutt Plow Company has been made subject to the approval of the Six Nations people and it is the desire of this office to comply fully with their expressed wishes in this respect.

The matter which gives us, and no doubt gives you, some concern is as to how and when this approval of the Six Nations people can be obtained. Under the Act it requires a clear majority assent of the voting members of the Band. As this is not a clear majority of those attending the meeting called for the purpose, the effect of the Section is that every qualified voter who does not attend the meeting and does not vote at all is held to have voted against it. Would you anticipate difficulty in getting a majority vote under these conditions?

Anticipating the difficulty of obtaining a clear majority affirmative vote, we have considered whether or not there is another way out of the difficulty and we think there is. This particular land, as your Council will recall, was recovered from the New England Company to His Majesty in the right of Canada by a judgment of the Exchequer Court of Canada dated the 14th January, 1922. The land so vested in Canada by the order of the Court has always been recognized and treated as land held in trust by His Majesty for the Six Nations Indians. There never was, however, any
rededication of the same land as forming part of the Six Nations Indian Reserve. It might, therefore, be regarded as Indian land surrendered to the Crown for disposition by the surrender of 1835, as part of the 48,000 acres surrendered at that time and, therefore, subject to alienation by His Majesty on such terms as in his judgment was in the best interests of the Indians for whom it was held in trust.

As in this instance the elected representatives of the Band have made the bargain themselves and are satisfied, as are we, that the bargain so made is advantageous to the Band, it might be possible to conclude the arrangements made with Cockshutt Flow without reference to the Band. It is suggested, however, that, in order that no improper motives or arbitrary action may be charged against the Department, the most representative meeting of the Band members possible should be held and the vote recorded and submitted. It is, therefore, suggested that such a meeting should be called and the matter disposed of with the least possible delay.

Acting Director.
Ottawa, Ontario,
May 24, 1945.

Lt. Col. E. P. Randle, Indian Superintendent, Brantford, Ontario.

Mr. W. M. Cory,

Herewith is our file 32-0-9. Col. MEMORANDUM:

Mr. A[illegible]

Please see your memorandum of the 4th instant, immediately hereunder on file 32-0-9, forwarding a proposed public notice calling a meeting of the Six Nations Band for the specific purpose of obtaining a surrender to His Majesty for sale of 3½ acres of the "Mohawk Farm" to the Cockshutt Moulded Aircraft Limited for the sum of $7,000.00.

Upon a careful and thorough study of this problem it is quite clear that the lands in question are Indian Reserve lands. The judgment of the Exchequer Court of Canada in 1922, when this matter was being dealt with, declared that this property was the property of His Majesty in right of Canada and had the effect of taking away any rights that the New England Company might have had in these lands by reason of the license of occupation granted it prior to the said judgment. In other words, the judgment had the effect of placing these lands in its original status, that is Indian Reserve lands held in trust by His Majesty for the Six Nations Band of Indians.

In view of the legal position of these lands I would suggest a slight amendment to the penultimate clause of your submitted draft public notice and have redrafted the proposed notice with my suggested change incorporated therein.

I have discussed this matter with Mr. Jackson and have pointed out our difficulty. He is of opinion that we should proceed and obtain, if possible, a formal surrender in accordance with the Indian Act. If we find that we have not obtained a proper surrender in accordance with the Indian Act we will have to give this matter further consideration and determine just what action the Department is going to take herein.

Solicitor.
Ottawa, Ontario,
June 8, 1945.

Lt. Col. E. P. Randle, Indian Superintendent, Brantford, Ont.

Re: Cockshutt Moulded Aircraft Limited,

D. J. Allen,

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Cockshutt Moulded Aircraft Ltd., Mohawk Farm Lands.

This will acknowledge your 32-0-9 of the 8th instant with regard to the procedure to be used to obtain the consent of male members of the Six Nations to the proposed sale of land to the Cockshutt Company.

This office appreciates the advice and assistance given, but would also like if possible, a clearer interpretation of sub-section 2 of Section 61 of the Indian Act.

As this sale is bound to arouse controversy, and the right of persons to vote may be challenged, it is felt the wording of sub-section 2 is somewhat wide and not too easily determined.

The words "habitually resides on or near" is not easily defined. Brantford, Hamilton, and Simcoe are all near, where many members of the Six Nations reside, but none of these places are as near as Hagersville, Caledonia, or Hartford. So it would appear best to be reasonably certain as to the bounds of the word "near".

All members of the Six Nations living off the Reserve can be said to be "interested" in the Reserve, as they have a common interest in their capital funds, apart from land. An Indian may have lived in Brantford ten years or so, and while not registered on any land, may on the death of his parents inherit theirs, and thus have a definite interest in the Reserve.

Any comments the Department care to forward to simplify this wording of sub-section 2, will be appreciated.

Lt.-Col. L.P. Handle,

Indian Superintendent.
Ottawa, June 29, 1945.

Mr. W. M. Cory,

Can you suggest any principles that might be of assistance to him?

D. J. Allen,

Memorandum:

Mr. D. J. Allan,

Please see your memorandum of the 29th ultimo immediately hereunder on file 32-0-9, directing my attention to Superintendent Randle's letter of June 27th, in which he asked for assistance in interpreting Section 51, Subsection 2, of the Indian Act, wherein the words 'habitually resides on, or near,' appear.

The interpretation of the words 'habitually resides on, or near' is, as Superintendent Randle points out, difficult of interpretation. The word 'near' has been held by the courts to mean 'close or at no great distance'. 'Near' is a relative term and its precise meaning depends upon circumstances. In various authorities reference to distances from two to ten to fifteen miles have been held to be 'near'.

As this word has no precise meaning, and all circumstances must be considered, I would suggest that the word 'near' as used in Section 51, Subsection 2, of the Indian Act, would be any point within a radius of ten or fifteen miles from the outer boundaries of the Indian Reserve in question. Ten or fifteen miles under present day circumstances - that is, car transportation, etc., - would, in my opinion, be considered by the courts as being within the meaning of the said word 'near'. Superintendent Randle might consider the said mileage not 'near', due to certain local conditions. His discretion in the matter, I think, should rule.

(over)
I trust that the above observations will be of some assistance in Superintendent Randle's difficulty, and I may add that I have made a note of this section so that appropriate wording may be substituted when the new Indian Act is considered.

Solicitor.
In the circumstances

It is suggested that under circumstances of his case every member who qualifies for local membership, who is sufficiently near and sufficiently interested in the cause to be interested in meeting should be permitted to vote, whether or not being made or having nothing to do with the stated organization. It is done both by act of congress and volume found to be undesirable and it should be done even though it is not. It is said nothing can be given at the end and that by the time decision is made the vote cannot be carried out was lost.
Ottawa, Ontario,
July 10, 1945.

Lt. Col. E. P. Randle, Indian Superintendent, Brantford, Ont.

Your letter of June 27th, your file 1235/45, asking for assistance in interpreting subsection 2 of Section 51 of the Indian Act was duly received and referred to the solicitors who have replied as follows:

"The interpretation of the words 'habitually resides on, or near' is, as Superintendent Randle points out, difficult of interpretation. The word 'near' has been held by the courts to mean 'close or at no great distance'. 'Near' is a relative term and its precise meaning depends upon circumstances. In various authorities reference to distances from two to ten to fifteen miles have been held to be 'near'.

"As this word has no precise meaning, and all circumstances must be considered, I would suggest that the word 'near' as used in Section 51, subsection 2, of the Indian Act, would be any point within a radius of ten or fifteen miles from the outer boundaries of the Indian Reserve in question. Ten or fifteen miles under present day circumstances - that is, car transportation, etc., - would, in my opinion, be considered by the courts as being within the meaning of the said word 'near'. Superintendent Randle might consider the said mileage not 'near', due to certain local conditions. His discretion in the matter, I think, should rule."

It is suggested by the writer that, in the circumstances of this case, any male person 21 years of age whose name appears on the Band list and who is sufficiently near to the Reserve and sufficiently interested in the affairs of the Reserve to be present at the meeting should be permitted to vote, a special note being made at the time as to any possible or suspected disqualification under the Act. If it should
It is of importance that the eligibility of such voters should be investigated and if on such investigation such voters should be found by the Superintendent General to be unqualified under the terms of the Act, then such finding could be given its proper legal effect by the Superintendent General in deciding whether the vote in question was carried or lost.

The writer agrees with you that the Section in question is extremely difficult of interpretation, but as it is in the Statute we have to do our best to interpret it in accordance with the spirit of the Act.

D. J. Allen,
Superintendent,
Reserves & Trusts.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: File 32-0-9. Sale of 3.05 acres of Mohawk Farm to Cockshutt Moulded Aircraft Limited.

This office would advise you that the Public Meeting was held and the vote taken on the above question, on Thursday the 26th instant, after proper notices had been posted for a month in the public buildings throughout the Reserve.

The attendance at the meeting was disappointingly small, only 26 people voting - 21 in favour of the sale and 5 against.

Naturally at this time of the year everyone, particularly the farmer, is busy, and would find it difficult to get away.

The Department will appreciate it will be a very serious blow to the prestige of the Six Nations Council if the majority given by those attending is not allowed to stand. Particularly as the Mohawk workers posted notices all over the Reserve asking people not to vote, and their ever increasing activities to influence their people over all matters.

After all, everyone qualified to vote had the privilege to do so, and if they failed to use their right that is their own fault, particularly if they were opposed to it. It is commonly said that silence gives consent.

As is noted from your letter of the 26th of May, the contention is that the Act requires a clear majority assent of the voting members, rather than a clear majority of those attending the meeting.

To the writer this appears a drastic interpretation of Section 51, as it would be supposed by most people reading that section that it actually means a majority of the male members at the meeting. It would be difficult under any circumstances to ensure the attendance of a majority of the eligible male voters.

--- If such
If such a meeting as this had been called suddenly and a snap vote taken, it could be well understood if the protection of the majority vote of all male members be demanded.

But in this case there was first of all the publicity occasioned by the debate and decision of the Council over the matter - followed by the wider publicity of notices displayed for 30 days prior to the voting in every public building and store available, advising the voter of the time and place where he could assemble and show his approval or disapproval of the contemplated sale of land.

In the recent Dominion Election, according to the press, less than 50% of the voters exerted their right to vote, and it is doubtful if anyone would suggest that those who did not vote, were against the party elected, for if so, Government could not go on.

Personally the writer is of the opinion it is far sounder to approve of the sale on the basis of the majority given by the voters who actually were present, as any other way might certainly be considered improper and arbitrary and utterly contrary to the Indian Act - whereas approval of the voting as it was given, is only one way of interpreting Section 51 of the Act.

It would make the Indian voter aware of his duty in the future so that he would turn out and show definitely one way or other what he really wishes, in the only way possible.

If the Department finally feel it is impossible to approve of the sale on the basis of the vote taken, it would be appreciated if before any other decision is taken, that the Council be fully informed of the contemplated action so that their viewpoint receives every consideration.

Lt.-Col.E.P.Randle,

Indian Superintendent.
Ottawa, August 8, 1945.

MEMORANDUM:

MR. W. M. CORY,
Departmental Solicitor.

Re: Mohawk Farm, Six Nations Indian Reserve.

In your memorandum of June 6th to the writer, you advised that this office should proceed in the usual way to attempt to obtain a formal surrender of the 3.05 acres of the Mohawk Farm which it is the wish of the Six Nations Council to sell for $7,000.00 to the Cockshutt Moulded Aircraft, Limited, whose buildings occupy it.

In accordance with those instructions an attempt was made to obtain the surrender and a special meeting was called for the purpose. Immediately on the posting of the notices certain members of the Band circularized the membership advising them not to attend the meeting, to such good effect that only 24 Band members attended and of that 24, 21 voted in favour of the surrender and 3 against. The surrender was not approved.

In the concluding paragraph of your memorandum of June 6th you suggested that in the event of failure to obtain the surrender further consideration would be given to determine just what action could be taken in the matter. May the matter now be further considered and this office advised as to what the next step is in the process of giving the Company title to the land they have agreed to purchase on terms already approved by the Six Nations Council.

D. J. Allan,
Superintendent,
Reserves and Trusts.
MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Allan,

Re - Mohawk Farm, Six Nations Indian Reserve.

Please see your memorandum of the 8th instant, immediately hereunder on file 82-69, in connection with the above.

I have discussed this matter fully with Mr. Jackson and in view of all the circumstances it is suggested that due to the unreasonableness of the Indians generally the Indian Band Council would be upheld by the Minister in issuing a permit to occupy the land under the provisions of Section 34. The form of permit recommended in this case is on file 24-109 which was sent to your Branch under cover of my memorandum of the 8th December, 1944.

Mr. Jackson, as you will recall when he was discussing this matter on the telephone with you this morning, thinks it would be equitable to charge a rental based on 5% of $7000.00 which was the agreed purchase price, the permit to be from year to year with a provision for immediate cancellation by the Minister.

MEMORANDUM:

Re - 3.5 acres, Six Nations Indian Reserve.

The Cookshutt Company inadvertently erected a building on the above land worth approximately $100,000.00. This land is Indian Reserve land within the meaning of Section 2 (j) of the Indian Act which reads as follows -

"'Reserve' means any tract or tracts of land set apart by treaty or otherwise for the use or benefit of or granted to a particular band of Indians, of which the legal title is in the Crown, and which remains so set apart and has not been surrendered to the Crown, and includes all the trees, wood, timber, soil, stone, minerals, metals and other valuables thereon or therein".

Indian Reserve lands are held in trust for the Indians by the Dominion Government and the Minister of Mines and Resources has, by virtue of the provisions of the Department of Mines and Resources Act, Chapter 33, l, Edward VIII, the control and management of the lands and property of the Indians in Canada.

Section 51 of the Indian Act provides, briefly, that except as in this part otherwise provided, no release or surrender of a reserve or a portion of a reserve held for the use of the Indians........shall be valid or binding unless the release or surrender shall be assented to by a majority of the male members of the band of the full age of twenty-one years, at a meeting, etc.

Section 54 of the said Act provides as follows -

"All Indian lands which are reserves, or portions of reserves, surrendered, or to be surrendered, to His Majesty, shall be deemed to be held for the same purpose as heretofore; and shall be managed, leased and sold as the Governor in Council directs, subject to the conditions of surrender and the provisions of this Part".
Indian lands in this section are defined in the Indian Act as follows -

"Indian lands" means any reserve or portion of a reserve which has been surrendered to the Crown.

The Cockshutt Plow Company have asked for title to the above land which was inadvertently built upon, and all efforts have been made to obtain a surrender of the land in question in accordance with the provisions of Section 51. By reason of the fact that the Indian Band members are not all present on the Reserve it is, therefore, impossible to get a surrender as required by Section 51.

The Cockshutt Plow Company, upon discovering that the Company's building was built on Reserve lands, offered to purchase from the Indians the land upon which the building stood for the sum of $7,000.00 which is considered a very fair offer and would more than compensate the Indians for the loss of their land, but no sale may be legally made of the land applied for by reason of the fact that a surrender cannot be obtained. The duly elected council of the Indian band have passed a resolution recommending the sale of this land to the Cockshutt Plow Company for the said sum but such resolution cannot be acted upon until the surrender as aforesaid is obtained.

After full consideration of the facts and of the present difficulties of obtaining a proper surrender, the officials of the Department of Mines and Resources are willing to place before the Minister for his approval and signature a permit to occupy the land under the provisions of Section 54 aforesaid, the rental to be 6% of the capital sum of $7,000.00, the purchase price offered by the Cockshutt Plow Company. This matter has been discussed with the Minister of Mines and Resources and such permit will issue at an early date.

Solicitor.
MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Allan,

Mr. Slavin, Solicitor for the Cockshutt Plow Company, discussed with Mr. Jackson the problem of his Company's building being on Indian Reserve lands at Brantford. Mr. Jackson has agreed to place before the Minister for his approval and signature a permit to occupy the land under the provisions of Section 34 of the Indian Act, the rental to be 5% of the capital sum of $7,000.00, the purchase price offered by the Cockshutt Plow Company.

Mr. Jackson is of the view that the permit should be for one year with a provision for immediate cancellation for non-payment of rentals. At the end of the permit year this matter is to be reviewed and consideration given towards the advisability of placing before Parliament a special act which would authorize the issue of title to the Company for the 32 acres.

Would you, therefore, have prepared such a permit and submit it to Mr. Jackson for his consideration and execution by the Minister. You may also wish to consider the advisability of including in this permit additional conditions preserving the rights of the Indians.

Re: Occupation of 3.05 acres of Indian reserve land by the Cockshutt farm.

This will acknowledge your letter 32-0-9 of the 4th instant in connection with the above matter.

The writer after consideration of the contents of your letter and the memorandums attached, has serious doubts as to the advisability of the contemplated action.

In the opinion of this office, if the sale as recommended by the Six Nations' Council cannot be legally carried out under the provisions of Section 51 of the Indian Act, through the failure to secure the approval of the majority of the male voting members, the whole question of the sale should be dropped, and the Company permitted to continue their occupation of the land under the leasing terms laid down in the Council resolution of the 17th of June 1942, with the exception of Clause 4, which has been voided by the action of the Company by their building a permanent structure on the land leased. Then prior to the expiration of the lease in 1950 - the matter can be referred back to the Council and the people for re-consideration.

The Council in recommending the sale by their resolution of the 5th of April last, definitely substitute the sale must receive the approval of their people. The vote was only taken and it has been officially ruled that the results of that vote cannot be accepted as approval of the voting members under the legal interpretation of Section 51 of the Indian Act.

Consequently the Council's right to sell becomes void, and it is certain they would not wish to proceed with the matter if it cannot be carried out legally under the provisions of Section 51.
To place a special bill before Parliament to enable
the sale to go through, would certainly not meet with the
approval of the Council, and would undoubtedly raise grave
concerns and suspicions among the Indian people.

The failure to proceed with the sale may of course
cause some inconvenience to the Cockshutt Company, but this
troublesome matter is entirely within their own hands, so
they can hardly expect to escape without some a notice.

This office trusts that on no account will any
arrangement be entered into with the Cockshutt Company, that
has not first been referred to the Council for their consider-
ation, and the contents of your letter of the 4th instant will
be placed before them at their next regular meeting on the 1st
of November, as it came too late for their October meeting.

In regard to your question as to the date upon which
the Cockshutt Company first occupied the 2.65 acres, it can be
assumed they proceeded to make use of the land immediately follow-
ing the passing of the Council resolution on the 17th of June,
1942, as at that time it was assumed the company would prepare
and forward at an early date, the leasing agreement under the
terms set by the Council at that time.

S. R. Kendall,

Lt.-Col., Secretary,
Indian Affairs.
October 29th 1945

I would, therefore, appreciate any suggestions that you might care to make with regard to additional conditions which could be incorporated in this proposed permit, at your earliest convenience, as this matter has been pending for some time.

BY [signature]
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Occupation of 3.05 acres of Indian Reserve Land by the Cockshutt Plow Company Limited.

This will acknowledge your 32-0-9 of the 29th of October in connection with the above, and this office fails to understand your observations contained in paragraph two.

At the present time there are a number of leases in existence effecting land held in the name of the Indian Council, which have been rented on the application signed by the Chief Councillor, after which a formal Government lease between the Crown and the tenant has been issued.

In none of such cases has a formal surrender been obtained under Section 51, calling for a vote of the male members.

If it is the Department's contention that under Section 51 Council land can only be leased with the assent of the majority of the male members, this would also be true of the land held by individuals, as Section 51 definitely refers to the latter as well.

Actually there are dozens of individual owners' land rented, without a formal surrender as laid down in Section 51.

This office has always supposed that either the Councils concerned, or an individual could rent land for a period of years upon an application by the parties concerned, and upon approval of the Department and the issuance of a formal lease between the Crown and lessee, and that it was only upon surrender of land for sale, that the assent of the majority of male members had to be obtained.

----- The Department's
The Department's attention is directed to your File 32-0-9 of the 24th of June 1942, in reply to this office report on the Council's Resolution of the 17th of June 1942, assenting to leasing the land to the Cockshutt Company. In that letter the Department do not anticipate any difficulty, or mention the necessity of obtaining a formal surrender.

The essential contents of your letter of the 4th of October were read to the Council at their meeting on the 1st of November, as proposed in my letter of the 25th of October, and they by Resolution No.12 express the opinion that the occupation of the land by the Cockshutt Company should continue under the conditions laid down in 1942 - and though those conditions through no fault of the Council have not been incorporated into an official lease, they have been accepted in principle by the Department and the Company, as the payment and acceptance of annual rental each year since, of $457.50 is proof of.

The Council cannot see any fairness or justice in permitting the Cockshutt Company to occupy the land at $350.00 per annum, when by their letter of acceptance of the 19th of June 1945 they agreed to lease the land until 1950, under the conditions laid down by the Council Resolution of the 17th of June of that year.

It is the Cockshutt Company who failed to observe the terms and conditions of that arrangement, and the resentment of the Council and people of the Six Nations will be great if the Department permit them to occupy the land for $350.00 instead of $457.50.

Further, the Department are reminded that the rentals received from the Company were not to be used to swell Six Nations Funds, but by the generous and kindly consideration of the Council to be handed over to the Department for the benefit of the children of the Mohawk Institute, some of whom come from other Reserves.

------ The writer
The writer is still of the opinion that the only satisfactory solution of this matter is contained in the suggestion offered in paragraph two of my letter of the 25th of October; and by past precedent, and with all due respect to the Department it is impossible for me to see this cannot be carried out.

On the other hand if the Department insist on issuing the Cockshutt Company a permit, against the wishes of the Council, based on a rental of 5% of $7,000.00, there appears little for this office to suggest, as you request, for the further protection of the Indians.

A Company of their standing will undoubtedly pay the rental when due, and it is presumed here that if the land is finally surrendered to them, they will still have to pay in full $7,000.00 - that is the rental or rentals paid from now on would not be considered as payments on the $7,000.00 principal.

They should also be responsible permanently for the repair or rebuilding of any fences adjoining the Six Nations land used by the Mohawk Institute.

Or, if only the land occupied by the building were finally surrendered, then the balance of the 3.05 acres should be returned to the Indians in its former condition, that is in shape for immediate cultivation.

This office hopes that whatever is finally decided over this most unfortunate matter, that no permit or leasing arrangement will be entered into, without being submitted first for the Council's consideration.

Lt.-Col. E.P. Randle,
Indian Superintendent.
Ottawa, Ontario,
November 15, 1945.

Lt. Col. E. P. Randle, Indian Superintendent, Brantford, Ontario.

Following our discussion in your office in Brantford on Wednesday, the 28th instant, regarding the Cockshutt Plow Company and the authority of occupation to the National Defence Department and the Brantford Recreational Area, I wish to advise that I have discussed with Mr. Jackson the Cockshutt Plow Company matter and have placed your observations before him. It is proposed, as agreed upon, to issue a permit to the Cockshutt Plow Company and this permit will go forward very shortly.

The authority permitting the occupation by the National Defence of Reserve lands is in order as it was done under the War Measures Act. A report to Council has gone forward which, when passed, will authorize the Minister to issue a lease to the Chairman of the Brantford Board of Parks Management. This lease can be issued under the authority of Section 48 of the Indian Act without a surrender as the city of Brantford has the power of expropriation.

I trust that the points which were bothering you are now clear. If, however, you wish any further information, please write me.

Solicitor.
MEMORANDUM OF AGREEMENT made this day of A.D. 1945.

BETWEEN:

His Majesty the King, in the right of Canada, represented herein by the Minister of Mines and Resources, hereinafter called the "Minister"

of the first part

and

Cockshutt Plow Company of the City of Brantford, in the Province of Ontario, hereinafter called the "permittee"

of the second part.

WHEREAS in 1942 the permittee inadvertently erected a building costing approximately One Hundred Thousand Dollars ($100,000.00) on the Six Nations Indian Reserve adjacent to the said City of Brantford and consequently is occupying without authority 3.05 acres of the said Reserve;

WHEREAS the said building was erected in haste as a war measure and is occupied by Cockshutt Moulded Aircraft Limited, a subsidiary of the permittee;

WHEREAS the permittee, on being advised that it was occupying Indian Reserve lands as aforesaid, paid rental at the rate of One Hundred and Fifty Dollars ($150.00) per acre per annum to the Minister as compensation to the Indian Band concerned, which said rental is fully paid to date;

WHEREAS the permittee has applied to purchase the said land for the sum of Seven Thousand Dollars ($7,000.00), which sum is considered by the Director of Indian Affairs as a very fair offer and would more than compensate the Indians for the loss of their land;

WHEREAS the Council of the said Indian Band have passed a resolution recommending the sale of the land as authorized by law for the sum offered;
AND WHEREAS no sale may be made of the land applied for by reason of the fact that a surrender, as provided by the Indian Act, cannot be obtained as many members of the said Indian Band are off the Reserve in private endeavour at distances that make it impracticable to obtain a surrender at this time as provided by the said Indian Act.

NOW THEREFORE WITNESSETH that in consideration of the terms and conditions hereinafter set forth the Minister to the extent of such power and authority as legally exists and to the extent of such power and authority and no further doth hereby grant permission to the permittee to use and occupy the following land in the Six Nations Indian Reserve in the Province of Ontario, namely:

All that portion of lot numbered five in the Eagle's Nest Tract in the Township of Brentford in the county of Brant in the Province of Ontario containing three acres and five hundredths of an acre more or less as the said portion is shown on a plan of survey thereof by C. C. Fairchild, Ontario Land Surveyor, dated the twenty-first of August, nineteen hundred and forty-two, of record number M. twenty-nine hundred and sixty-six in the Indian Affairs Survey Records, Department of Mines and Resources, at Ottawa. A blueprint from the said plan is attached hereto.

The permittee agrees to the following terms and conditions:

That this permit shall run from the 17th day of June, A.D. 1945, to the 16th day of June, A.D. 1946;

That the permittee shall pay a permit fee of One Hundred and Fifty Dollars ($150.00) per acre, which said amount is Four Hundred and Fifty-Seven Dollars and Fifty Cents ($457.50), the receipt of which is hereby acknowledged;

That the permittee will not assign its rights under this permit.
It is expressly stipulated that any renewal of this agreement shall be at the pleasure of the Minister and that the permission hereby granted may be withdrawn at any time by the Indian Agent or other official of the Department of Mines and Resources by notice in writing given to the permittee.

It is further hereby stipulated and agreed that notwithstanding anything to the contrary herein contained, this agreement shall not be deemed to set up any tenancy by implication or otherwise.

IN WITNESS WHEREOF the parties hereto have duly executed these presents.

Signed, Sealed and Delivered by the Deputy Minister of Mines and Resources

In the presence of

And by the Permittee

Ottawa, November 30, 1945.

MEMORANDUM

Mr. C. W. Jackson,
Chief Executive Assistant.

Herewith please find draft permit to Cockshutt Plow Company for 3.05 acres of the Indian Reserve lands at Brantford. You will recall the details in connection with this matter. Mr. Slemin, solicitor for the Cockshutt Plow Company, was in town recently and it was agreed under the circumstances to issue a permit to occupy this land to Cockshutt Plow Company for one year at a permit fee of $350.00, which is 5% of the capital value of $7,000.00 agreed to be paid for this land if and when the Crown can give title to this Company. Since this arrangement, representations were made by Lt. Col. Randle that Cockshutt Plow Company should pay an amount of $150.00 per acre, which is the amount that this Company has been paying since 1942 for this land.

Mr. Cory has discussed this matter with Mr. Slemin in Brantford and with Mr. Stuart Lee, Vice-President of Cockshutt Plow and the Company has agreed to pay at the rate of $150.00 per acre, which amounts to an annual permit fee of $457.50.

Upon reference to the proposed permit it will be noted that this permit is for one year from the 17th day of June, 1945, to the 16th day of June, 1946, and is not assignable. Also, a provision is contained therein that this permit may be withdrawn at any time by notice in writing given to the permittee. Further, as this authority is being issued under Section 34 of the Indian Act, it will be noted that it is issued by the Department only to the extent of the power and authority as legally exists and to the extent of such power and authority and no further. If this proposed permit meets with your approval, would you please place it before the Deputy Minister for execution.

Director.

of the second part.

WHEREAS in 1943 the permittee inadvertently erected a building costing approximately One Hundred Thousand Dollars ($100,000.00) on the Six Nations Indian Reserve adjacent to the said City of Brantford and consequently is occupying without authority 5.06 acres of the said Reserve;

WHEREAS the said building was erected in haste as a war measure and is occupied by Cockshutt Moulded Aircraft Limited, a subsidiary of the permittee;

WHEREAS the permittee, on being advised that it was occupying Indian Reserve lands as aforesaid, paid rental at the rate of One Hundred and Fifty Dollars ($150.00) per acre per annum to the Minister as compensation to the Indian Band concerned, which said rental is fully paid to date;

WHEREAS the permittee has applied to purchase the said land for the sum of Seven Thousand Dollars ($7,000.00), which sum is considered by the Director of Indian Affairs as a very fair offer and would more than compensate the Indians for the loss of their land;

WHEREAS the Council of the said Indian Band have passed a resolution recommending the sale of the land as authorized by law for the sum offered;
AND WHEREAS no sale may be made of the land applied for by reason of the fact that a surrender, as provided by the Indian Act, cannot be obtained as many members of the said Indian Band are off the Reserve in private endeavour at distances that make it impracticable to obtain a surrender at this time as provided by the said Indian Act.

NOW THEREFORE WITNESSETH that in consideration of the terms and conditions hereinafter set forth the Minister to the extent of such power and authority as legally exists and to the extent of such power and authority and no further doth hereby grant permission to the permittee to use and occupy the following land in the Six Nations Indian Reserve in the Province of Ontario, namely:—

All that portion of lot numbered five in the Eagle's Nest Tract in the township of Brantford in the county of Brant in the Province of Ontario containing three acres and five hundredths of an acre, more or less, as the said portion is shown on a plan or survey thereof by C. C. Fairchild, Ontario Land Surveyor, dated the twenty-first of August, nineteen hundred and forty-two, of record number M. twenty-nine hundred and eighty-five in the Indian Affairs Survey Records, Department of Mines and Resources, at Ottawa. A blueprint from the said plan is attached hereto.

The permittee agrees to the following terms and conditions:—

That this permit shall run from the 17th day of June, A.D. 1945, to the 16th day of June, A.D. 1946;

That the permittee shall pay a permit fee of One Hundred and Fifty Dollars ($150.00) per acre, which said amount is Four Hundred and Fifty-Seven Dollars and Fifty Cents ($457.50), the receipt of which is hereby acknowledged;

That the permittee will not assign its rights under this permit.
It is expressly stipulated that any renewal of this agreement shall be at the pleasure of the Minister and that the permission hereby granted may be withdrawn at any time by the Indian Agent or other official of the Department of Mines and Resources by notice in writing given to the permittee.

It is further hereby stipulated and agreed that notwithstanding anything to the contrary herein contained, this agreement shall not be deemed to set up any tenancy by implication or otherwise.

IN WITNESS WHEREOF the parties hereto have duly executed these presents.

Signed, Sealed and Delivered by the Deputy Minister of Mines and Resources

In the presence of

Deputy Minister of Mines and Resources

And by the Permittee

In the presence of

Permittee

Mr. C. W. Jackson,

Herewith please find draft permit to Cockshutt Plow Company for 3.05 acres of the Indian Reserve lands at Brentford. You will recall the details in connection with this matter. Mr. Slemin, solicitor for the Cockshutt Plow Company, was in town recently and it was agreed under the circumstances to issue a permit to occupy this land to Cockshutt Plow Company for one year at a permit fee of $350.00, which is 6% of the capital value of $7,000.00 agreed to be paid for this land if and when the Crown can give title to this Company. Since this arrangement, representations were made by Lt. Col. Rendle that Cockshutt Plow Company should pay an amount of $150.00 per acre, which is the amount that this Company has been paying since 1942 for this land.

Mr. Cory has discussed this matter with Mr. Slemin in Brantford and with Mr. Stuart Lee, Vice-President of Cockshutt Plow and the Company has agreed to pay at the rate of $150.00 per acre, which amounts to an annual permit fee of $457.50.

Upon reference to the proposed permit it will be noted that this permit is for one year from the 17th day of June, 1945, to the 16th day of June, 1946, and is not assignable. Also, a provision is contained therein that this permit may be withdrawn at any time by notice in writing given to the permittee. Further, as this authority is being issued under Section 34 of the Indian Act, it will be noted that it is issued by the Department only to the extent of the power and authority as legally exists and to the extent of such power and authority and no further. If this proposed permit meets with your approval, would you please place it before the Deputy Minister for execution?

Memorandum:

MR. D. J. ALLAN,
SUPT., RESERVES and TRUSTS,

On June 17, 1942, the Six Nations Council passed a Resolution which provided that the rentals received from the Cockshutt Plow Company for the 3.05 acres of land which they are using should be used for the benefit of the maintenance of the Mohawk Institute (see Lt.-Col. Randle's letter of June 19, 1942).

At that time there was an impression that the land being used by the Cockshutt Plow Company was owned by the New England Company and as we had not renewed the lease with that Company it was felt that the money could not be paid to the Mohawk Institute.

The portion of land being used by the Cockshutt Plow Company is land owned by the Six Nations Band. The Six Nations band has allowed this land to be used for many years for the purposes of the Mohawk Institute.

At the present time there is an amount of $1,830.00 which has been paid as rent by the Cockshutt Plow Company and which amount should, I feel, be sent to the Principal of the Mohawk Institute, in accordance with the wishes of the Six Nations Council. Owing to present conditions at the Mohawk Institute the Acting Principal, under the guidance of the Indian Superintendent, could spend the amount to good advantage in improving conditions at the school and thereby benefit the children attending the school, the majority of whom come from the Six Nations Reserve.

I would therefore appreciate it if you would issue instructions to have this money sent to Rev. W. J. Zimmerman, Mohawk Institute, Brantford, Ont.

I discussed the above with Mr. Hoey yesterday and he suggested that I make the recommendation given above to you.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, March 2, 1946.

With reference to your 32-0-9 (R.l) of the 1st of November last, advising us that the permit to the Cockshutt Plow Company had been renewed for one year from the 17th of June last, for the 3.05 acres, part of the Mohawk Institute farm.

It is noted that according to the permit the year's rental of $457.50 has been paid, and this office would like confirmation of this, as the Six Nations Council are enquiring about it. Also, as you will remember, the said rental was to be paid to the Principal of the Mohawk Institute, to be used for the general benefit of the Indian children, and he does not appear to have received it.

This office would also like to point out that in this day and age, we do not consider it fitting for this permit to have been renewed without the Indian Council being advised ahead of time of the intention of the Department to do so - in case the Council had any viewpoint they wished to express.

The Department's action in this matter only arouses doubt in the minds of the Council and their people, and increases the mistrust that always exists in the Indian mind over their dealings with the powers that be - and it makes it appear at least that the Cockshutt Company receive greater consideration in the matter than those who own the land, and whose particular rights the Department is guardian of.

The Cockshutt Plow Company's action in this matter cannot be condoned under any consideration, as with any reasonable care or checking, the permanent structure they raised on the property...
property leased from the Six Nations, would never have been built, particularly in view of the fact that, from the very first discussion over the leasing of the ground, it was understood no permanent building should be erected.

Further, to prove that the Company have little regard for their obligations, you are advised they have recently completed the erection of a further building on the same land.

The writer contacted their Solicitor over this matter and after some delay received a verbal acknowledgement that this was the case, - with a promise that the matter would be dealt with in a letter to the Council.

To date, though some time has elapsed, no communication has been received, and so far, in view of this, the Council have not been informed.

It would appear that this Company, ignoring all decencies or rights in the matter, are determined rightly or wrongly, to acquire that land, - though from the very beginning of negotiations over it, they knew clearly that the Six Nations' Council did not wish to dispose of it, and only reluctantly recommended the sale to their people, after the Company had erected the first permanent building.

Your early reply to this letter would be appreciated, including information as to if the rental has been actually paid direct to the Department.

Lt.-Col.E.P.Randle,

Indian Superintendent.
Ottawa, January 23, 1947.

Six Nations Council Res. No. 7, Feb. 6/47.

The Council by this resolution registered their protest at the renewal of the Cockshutt Company's permit for one year, by the Departmental Solicitor, without their knowledge or consent, and they ask for an explanation.

As the writer previously pointed out over this matter, it is not in the interest of harmony and good will for things to be done in the manner the Council complain of, and it is felt that as an elected and authorized Council, they should be advised beforehand of the Department's intention over property belonging to their people.

Lt.-Col. E.F. Kendall

Indian Superintendent.
Champlain Ont.

Feb. 6th, 1947

Minutes of Six Nations Council meeting

Moved by Leonard Stants seconded by James Davis, that it has been brought to the attention of this Council that the Indian Department, through its Solicitor, has extended a lease of a portion of the Six Nations Reserve, on the property occupied by the Mohawk Institute, to the Cookshutt Plow Company, without the knowledge or consent of this Council.

Therefore this Council wishes to enter a protest against this action on the part of the Department, and requests an immediate explanation of same.

Carried.
Chawaken Ont.
March 6th 1947.

Minutes of Council Meeting

Moved by James Martin seconded by Herb. Jamieson, that in the application of the Cockshutt Plow Co. to lay a railway Spur line and erect a further building on the 3.05 acres already leased them, from the Mohawk farm at a rental of $457.50, that this Council agrees to permit the Company to carry out their proposals on condition that the rental be increased to $600.00 per annum, as from March 1st, 1947.

Further it is to be understood that on the expiration of the original agreement, in 1950, the whole matter will be reviewed by this Council and the Company, as to a new agreement, unless the sale of the said lands to the Company is approved by our people at that time.

Carried.

Col. E.P. Handle
Superintendent of Indian Agencies
Ottawa, March 26, 1947.

Lt. Col. E. P. Rendle, Indian Superintendent, Brantford, Ont.

We acknowledge receipt of your letter of April 9, 1947, in which you state that the Council of the Six Nations Band and the Cockshutt Plow Company have agreed to an increase in rental of the latter's permit from $457.50 to $600.00 a year as of March 1, 1947.

As this permit does not expire until June 16, 1947, it will be necessary to cancel the same as of March 1, 1947, and issue a new permit for one year from the latter date at the increased rental. This will call for an adjustment in favour of the Company of 3½ months' rental, viz. March 1, 1947, to June 16, 1947, paid in advance under the existing permit. This rental will be credited to that payable under the new permit.

Before this action can be taken it will be necessary for you to forward a letter from the Company requesting such cancellation and the issue of a new permit on the new terms.

for D. J. Allan,
Superintendent,
Reserves & Trusts.

Gentlemen:

Respecting the 3.05 acres of land adjoining the Mohawk Institute which are under lease to ourselves, we find it necessary to put up a building for the manufacture of tractors and to lay a spur track from the T. H. & B. Railway to serve it. This spur track would transverse about 160 ft. of the northwest corner of the land in question.

These installations are required for the manufacture of tractors, and we wish to point out that an increase of continuous employment in the County will result.

We offer in view of the installations necessary to bring this about, to pay a rental at the rate of $600 per year, starting March 1st.

Yours very truly,

COCKSHUTT FLOW COMPANY LIMITED

(signed) G. M. Thomson
Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

This office is in receipt of your letter 32-0-9 (R.6) of the 26th of May and regrets it cannot see the necessity or the wisdom of your suggestion of cancelling the existing permit which anyway expires on the 17th of June.

It is suggested the existing permit be endorsed to show that the rental as from the let of March last, was increased to a rate of $600.00 per

We can then collect the difference, which we figure at $41.55, from the Company, and a new permit can be issued to them for the year 1947-48 as from the 17th of June, which will keep the permit within the dates of the original agreement to lease in June 1942.

A copy of the Company's offer to increase the rental to the rate of $600.00 per annum, is attached.

This office would appreciate this matter being speedily settled, as much of the trouble with this Company in the past has come about by the long delays in the issue of official documents.

Lt.-Col. E.P. Randl

MEMORANDUM OF AGREEMENT made this Twenty-third day of October, A.D. 1946.

BETWEEN:

His Majesty the King, in the right of Canada, represented herein by the Minister of Mines and Resources, hereinafter called the "Minister" of the first part

Cockshutt Plow Company of the City of Brantford, in the Province of Ontario, hereinafter called the "Permittee" of the second part.

WHEREAS in 1942 the Permittee inadvertently erected a building costing approximately One Hundred Thousand Dollars ($100,000.00) on the Six Nations Indian Reserve adjacent to the said City of Brantford and consequently is occupying without authority 3.05 acres of the said Reserve;

WHEREAS the said building was erected in haste as a War measure and is occupied by Cockshutt Moulded Aircraft Limited, a subsidiary of the Permittee;

WHEREAS the Permittee, on being advised that it was occupying Indian Reserve lands as aforesaid, paid rental at the rate of One Hundred and Fifty Dollars ($150.00) per acre per annum to the Minister as compensation to the Indian Band concerned, which said rental is fully paid to date;

WHEREAS the Permittee has applied to purchase the said land for the sum of Seven Thousand Dollars ($7,000.00), which sum is considered by the Director of Indian Affairs as a very fair offer and would more than compensate the Indians for the loss of their land;

WHEREAS the Council of the said Indian Band have passed a resolution recommending the sale of the land as authorized by law for the sum offered;
AND WHEREAS no sale may be made of the land applied for by reason of the fact that a surrender, as provided by the Indian Act, cannot be obtained as many members of the said Indian Band are off the Reserve in private endeavour at distances that make it impracticable to obtain a surrender at this time as provided by the said Indian Act.

NOW THEREFORE WITNESSTH that in consideration of the terms and conditions hereinafter set forth the Minister to the extent of such power and authority as legally exists and to the extent of such power and authority and no further doth hereby grant permission to the permittee to use and occupy the following land in the Six Nations Indian Reserve in the Province of Ontario, namely:—

All that portion of lot numbered five in the Eagle's Nest Tract in the township of Brantford in the county of Brant in the Province of Ontario containing three acres and five hundredths of an acre, more or less, as the said portion is shown on a plan of survey thereof by C. C. Fairchild, Ontario Land Surveyor, dated the twenty-first of August, nineteen hundred and forty-two, of record number M. twenty-nine hundred and sixty-nine in the Indian Affairs Survey Records Department of Mines and Resources, at Ottawa. A blueprint from the said plan is attached hereto.

The permittee agrees to the following terms and conditions:—

That this permit shall run from the 17th day of June, A.D. 1946, to the 16th day of June, A.D. 1947;

That the permittee shall pay a permit fee of One Hundred and Fifty Dollars ($150.00) per acre, which said amount is Four Hundred and Fifty-Seven Dollars and Fifty Cents ($457.50), the receipt of which is hereby acknowledged;

That the permittee will not assign its rights under this permit.
It is expressly stipulated that any renewal of this agreement shall be at the pleasure of the Minister and that the permission hereby granted may be withdrawn at any time by the Indian Agent or other official of the Department of Mines and Resources by notice in writing given to the permittee.

It is further hereby stipulated and agreed that notwithstanding anything to the contrary herein contained, this agreement shall not be deemed to set up any tenancy by implication or otherwise.

IN WITNESS WHEREOF the parties hereto have duly executed these presents.

Signed, Sealed and Delivered by the Deputy Minister of Mines and Resources

In the presence of

And by the Permittee

In the presence of

Ottawa, July 15, A.D., 1947.

It is agreed between the parties to the above permit that the rental thereunder is increased to the rate of $600.00 per annum as from March 1, 1947.

Signed, Sealed and Delivered

In the presence of

And by the Permittee

In the presence of

COCKSHUTT PLOW COMPANY

General Manager

COCKSHUTT PLOW COMPANY LIMITED

BRANTFORD, CANADA

June 15th, 1948.

The Honorable James A. MacKinnon,
Minister of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Jim:

It happened very quickly after I saw you but is no doubt a first-class solution to the whole matter.

Our problem is that we purchased land from the Six Nations amounting to approximately 3 acres, upon which we erected permanent installations which would amount to more than a quarter of a million dollars in value. Unfortunately, because of the peculiarities of Section 51 of the Indian Act the release of the land was not subsequently confirmed by the band.

From what I can hear the new Act makes it practically impossible to obtain a confirmatory vote of the band.

In the circumstances a Special Act seems to be the only solution.

Having in view the fact that the New Act is not likely to be brought down at this session, but will be introduced at the next session, we plan on deferring any requests for a Special Act until after the New Act is passed.

With best regards, I am,

Yours faithfully,

COCKSHUTT PLOW COMPANY LIMITED

(sgd.) G. M. Thomson
Secretary.
Department of Mines and Resources

MINISTER'S OFFICE

July 7, 1948.

DEPUTY MINISTER:

Attention - Mr. Hoey

Under date of June 18th I passed to you a letter from Mr. G.M. Thomson of the Cookshutt Plow Co., Ltd. to the Minister regarding property which they apparently are occupying for part of their plant and which was owned through the Indian Affairs Department. It would be appreciated if a reply could be made available for the Minister's signature in connection with this case.

A.C.L. Adams,
Private Secretary.

Mr. Hoey:
For draft reply as requested.
Ottawa, Ontario,
July 18, 1948.

Dear Mr. Thomson:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of June 15th with reference to the 3.05 acres of the Six Nations Indian Reserve which is encroached upon by your plant.

You will recall that when the temporary settlement was made in July, 1947, a temporary permit was issued to your Company for one year expiring June 16, 1948, at an annual fee of $600.00. That permit by its terms contemplated a renewal at the pleasure of the Minister, on the same terms, if a final solution had not been found.

As that permit has now expired and as it is not yet possible to conclude the matter on a permanent basis, I propose for your approval that I grant to your Company a further permit on the same terms covering the period from June 17, 1948, to June 16, 1949. The issue of this permit would give us a year in which to negotiate a permanent settlement of the matter, if and when the necessary statutory authority can be obtained.

If, therefore, you will forward to the Indian Affairs Branch of this Department your Company's cheque for $600.00, a new permit for one further year will be forwarded to you for signature and return, on receipt of which I would be only too pleased to complete this temporary arrangement to tide us over for the present.

Yours sincerely,

G. M. Thomson, Esq.,
Secretary,
Cooksman Flow Company Limited,
Brentford, Ontario.

HEAD OF BRANCH

TREASURY OFFICE APPROVAL

DEPUTY HEAD
Ottawa, 8 December, 1948.

Dear Mr. Boyce -

Mohawk Indian Residential School,
Brantford, Ontario.

The above school has been under lease by the Crown from the Company for the Propagation of the Gospel in New England and its parts adjacent in America commonly called the New England Company for a number of years, in fact from 1931. During the above leasehold the New England Company has carried insurance on the building and has paid the premiums. Recently we have been informed by the Treasurer of the Company that it has been decided to allow the fire insurance on the building to lapse. There is no obligation in the lease to insure, consequently if the school should be destroyed by fire during the term the Crown would be liable to replace it.

The question of the Crown insuring this building, you will recall, was discussed between us on the phone the other day and you advised that in your opinion the Crown should not insure. The Company is being notified to this effect.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
for Deputy Minister.

R. B. Boyce, Esq.,
Acting Deputy Minister,
Department of Education,
Ottawa.

ROYAL CANADIAN MOUNTED POLICE
HEADQUARTERS

Ottawa, 12 February, 1949.

Report dated Ohsweken, 2-2-49,
forwarded to: your information, re: Indian Act (Truancy), Mohawk Res. School, Brantford, Ont.

Enclosure Officer i/c Criminal Investigation Branch,

per
This will acknowledge your file No. 466-1 (E. 1) of the 23rd instant, with regard to the truancy at the Mohawk Institute.

In reply you are advised that early Sunday morning, the 23rd of January, it was found that two girls had left the building, all in the teen age group, subsequently it was found they had left their dormitories about 4 A.M. that morning, and by picking a door lock and removing some inside the evening, had made their way into the reserve.

The principal visited the R.C.M.P. and local police, in charge of the matter, and also telephoned the school committee members in order to have them put the proper pressure on the parents, making sure the students go to bed before midnight so that they may be awake in the morning.

I think it is safe to say as a result of the R.C.M.P. and police efforts, not only the principal and his staff, but the pupils were back except two, one from Canada and one from Ontario.

I am glad to add, of course, principal, contacted the representatives of outside reserves informing them what girls from their respective reserves were missing.
On the return of the school, if they were instructed to their duties for the day, and their names not listed under the following:

(1) Avi to school (not late), and a helper (evidently coming by outside influence) that they did not have to obey the order of the principal or his staff.

(2) So many over there in our corner, in an own - like, I'm not sure, to rough.

(3) Home bound.

(4) Wanting for no particular reason - other than one or two other things going.

The first reason is understandable - as it happens often by everyone - the children dislike for discipline - rules or regulations of any kind, and an inclination to disobey if not kept in check.

There is some evidence that certain elements on the reserve are anxious in the children in the belief that do not have to obey orders, but to give the time to the "little kids."

Mr. Anderson could do something Mr. Anderson has in any way suggested. As powers of punishment, child on, the only question is how much using any form of punishment - whether it looks like force - while not intended to be - Anderson declared he had not done any harm, or hurt anyone.

There is naturally a lack of some kindness, by none of it to the parent's fault or that of their own could, often he feels, visit them children for we know the time.

This is a matter the local council, we some attention to - by contacting, in a friendly manner, even if he could and yet cannot visit their children.
It rather appears that two or three girls of the "friendly" mob group were the ringleaders, who more or less had the bulk of the others on.

The principal is of the opinion that some, if not all of the summer hall girls often stay late at night. Their parents or relatives allow them unlimited freedom, so they often naturally enough go to the park where there are many young people from the school, and are permitted to roam around or ride there.

All the summer hall girls were invited on their return, and I have heard that the majority of them would come regularly if they could settle down and get themselves into a fitting manner.

But it is unfortunate to have to report that ten of the same girls were away again last Saturday, although they are now back.

One of the members, contrary to my instructions, has let her horse go free, and some of the other girls have been found out. It is a matter of concern to the authorities.

This is the report on reporting the fact that they are still away, and I am sure that the situation will improve when your attention is called to it. We must do our best to keep them in line.

However, the recent outbreak like the letter is a more serious, and it is an intention to follow up the matter when the girls are back for the harvest work.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Lt.-Col. E. F. Steele, Indian Superintendent.

Date: Feb. 19 1949 Time of day: 3:30 P.M.

M.D.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Admission to Indian Residential School - Brantford,

Enclosed please find application forms for admission of four children of the Mohawk Band, to the Mohawk Institute at Brantford, Ont., namely Marlene, Russell, Anna and Ellen Culbertson.

The home conditions of these children are not satisfactory; the parents are not compatible and live together only sporadically. The father is a veteran and has some difficulty controlling his appetite for liquor. I believe the mother tries to get along but at times finds it impossible, so leaves home. The children then lack adequate care. Both parents are agreeable to placing the children in the Institute.

Rev. Zimmerman has intimated that he will find accommodation for the four children, in his letter to us of Feb. 1st.

It will be necessary to provide transportation for these children to Brantford, and I suggest that permission be given to use the nurse's car.

D.R. Cassis,
Supt. Tyendinaga Agency.

2nd March, 1949.

Mr. F. Brisebois,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Caughnawaga, P.Q.

The following letter has been received from Angus Horne, 424 Washington Avenue, Dunkirk, New York:

"I want release for my daughter Mildred Horne, she is at Mohawk Institute, she is restless at school and seem to lost interest there. I have a good place over here for her, kindly give me early reply."

Our records show that this girl was placed in the Mohawk Institute on 1st September, 1944, and her age on the return is stated to be 11 years. Do you think it advisable to discharge the girl? In any case, we would not send her home until the end of June.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division
2nd March, 1949.

Mr. D.H. Cassie,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Deseronto, Ontario.

With reference to your letter of the 21st ultimo, the Department approves the admission of the following children to the Mohawk Institute:

Russell Culbertson
Mary Ellen Culbertson
Anne Culbertson
Marlene Culbertson

We believe that the best method of taking these children to Brantford is by train. You can place them on a through train and notify the Principal and he will meet them on their arrival at Brantford. It might be preferable for you to accompany them to Toronto so as to make certain that they are placed on the proper train.

Payment of the cost of transporting these four children and the expenses incurred by yourself will be paid on receipt of the usual account in duplicate. If you wish an advance for this purpose, please let me know.

We only require one copy of the application forms and the duplicates are, therefore, being returned.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

4. One of the four Indians mentioned in the earlier report was located by questioning until noon today when the visitor had succeeded in locating Mr. Fred Smith and Mr. John Lee. Both these Indians admitted that they had been in the area over night with two other young girls previously mentioned. They both admitted having slept on the same bed with Louise LeBlanc, knowing that she was a young girl and a truant from the Mohawk Institute in Brantford, Ont. They stated having had intercourse with Louise LeBlanc or with either of the other two girls who had spent the entire month of October at his home.

It is only mentioned that he had not been willing to do any of the things that were done but admitted having slept on the bed with Louise LeBlanc or another girl on the bed in the house located off a few feet from here.

5. On the basis of the evidence thus far there are no charges to be laid against Mr. Smith or Mr. Lee. It is recommended that each of them be given a warning and that Section 18(1) of the Indian Act be invoked against each of them for their conduct and behavior while residing at the home of Mr. Smith.

6. In conclusion, I would like to express my satisfaction with the cooperation and assistance extended by Mr. Smith and Mr. Lee throughout this investigation. Their willingness to assist and cooperate has been most helpful and I am grateful for their cooperation.

S. U. L.

On the 7th of February last various members of this detachment were out on the Six Nations Reserve endeavouring to locate and apprehend a number of young female truants from the Mohawk Institute at Brantford, Ontario. Information on hand at this office at that time suggested that six girls had escaped from the Institute on the 5th of February and four more had departed for parts unknown on the 7th of February.

Subsequent investigation revealed that on the night of February 9th three of these female truants had remained overnight in a house on the Six Nations Reserve, occupied by one Leonard Staats. Staats is a single man, aged about twenty-two years. Further enquiries disclosed that three other Indians of this reserve, namely - John Fraser, Mitchell Hill and Emerson Loft, all pals of Leonard Staats had stayed in the Staats' home on the night of the 9th of February and had remained there for the entire night, along with three of the young girl truants.

On the 11th of February the writer questioned one Minnie George, aged 15 yrs. and a truant from the Mohawk Institute at Brantford, Ont. From the 7th to the 10th of February, this young girl admitted to the writer that she, along with Ramona King and Alfreda Schuyler, also 15 year old truants from the Institute, had stayed all night at the home of Leonard Staats; That they had gone to the Staats' home during the early evening of the 9th of February and had remained there until the afternoon of the 10th when arrested by members of this detachment and returned to the Institute at Brantford, Ontario.

Minnie George stated that she had slept in a bed with Leonard Staats and eventually admitted having had intercourse with him during the night. Further questioning by the writer disclosed that this young girl had first been on the bed with Mitchell Hill but she maintained that she had not had intercourse with Hill. She then stated that at one time during the night she had slept on this bed with Staats and that Hill and Emerson Loft were also asleep on the same bed. This young girl further stated that Ramona King had slept on a cot in the same bedroom and that this girl had slept alone. When questioned as to the whereabouts of the other girl, Alfreda Schuyler, Minnie stated that this girl had slept in the kitchen which adjoins the bedroom and that she had slept on a couch there with John Fraser.

On the 5th of February last a total of six young girls left the Mohawk Institute at Brantford, Ont., without permission. On the 7th of February, four more young girls left the Institute under similar circumstances. About three weeks prior to this a total of twenty-five young girls left the Institute without permission. Investigation into this matter revealed that a large number of these girls were making their way direct to the home of Hilliard Fraser where they were staying for a few days before leaving for other parts.

On Feb. 16th, this matter was gone over with the County Crown Attorney, Mr. C. C. Slemin when he instructed that an information be laid, charging Fraser under section 34 of the Juvenile Delinquents Act.

On the 16th ultimo the writer laid an information against the above named under section 34 of the said Act and he was summoned for trial before Magistrate Gillen at Brantford, Ont. on the 28-2-49.

On the 28-2-49 Fraser appeared in Brantford Court and entered a plea of "Not Guilty" to the charge. He was represented by Counsel, Mr. H. A. Lickers. At the request of the Prosecution, the hearing was adjourned to March 2nd. In the interval, Summons to Witness were obtained for the following persons - Rev. Zimmerman, Principal of the Mohawk Institute - Lois Hess, Alfreda Schuyler, Minnie George and Romana King (All young girls of the Institute and former truants). The writer was successful in serving Rev. Zimmerman and two of the girls with summonses but the other two girls, Alfreda Schuyler and Lois Hess again left the Institute and to date have not been located.

On this date, March 2nd, Fraser again appeared in Brantford Court when it was necessary for the Prosecution to obtain still another adjournment due to the fact that two of the main Crown witnesses could not be located. The Case was further adjourned to March 9th. Every effort will be put forth to locate and serve these two girls with summonses in time for their attendance at Court in Brantford on the 9th. inst.

A further report in this case will be submitted to comply with the under noted diary date.

So U. I.,
DeDo 21-3-49.

Mrs. Battrelle, 27, Carnia Band had three daughters, Loraine, Marilyn and Doris, in the Mohawk Institute at Okauchee during the 1947-48 term. In July, 1948 she was visited by the office and informed me that she did not intend to send Loraine and Marilyn back to residential school in September. She agreed to send her youngest daughter, Doris. In a letter dated July 16th, 1948 she informed me of the school's refusal to accept the discharge of Loraine and Marilyn, however I do not believe that the Department can be permitted to allow the above mentioned children to escape their responsibilities.

I am not able to give you any further information regarding the situation. In October, 1948 I wrote to Mrs. Battrelle to explain our position and to request that she return her daughters to the school. We tried to make it clear that we would not tolerate any further attempts to run away, etc. In January, 1949 the situation was still unresolved. The Department has been unable to reach an agreement with the parents regarding the return of the children.
charge of all three of this man's children.

When Mr. Doucet visited Sarnia Agency about one month ago the matter of truancy of three or four Indian girls from Mohawk Institute was investigated. One of the girls is Marilyn Rogers, daughter of #210, William Rogers, Sarnia Band. I have given this girl temporary permission to attend St. Clair Indian Day School until a Departmental decision has been received regarding her return to Brantford. I do not think it would be advisable to force Marilyn to return to Mohawk School as she would no doubt run away again. I therefore recommend that she be officially discharged.

When Marilyn Rogers left Mohawk School two Kettle Point girls, namely Eunice and Helen George, daughters of Simpson George, #301 and Miss Evelyn George, #302, Kettle Point Band, accompanied her. These two girls are running loose on Sarnia Reserve at the present time. I see no use in forcing them to return to Brantford but am taking no action on the matter pending instructions which I understood Mr. Doucet was going to send on his return to Ottawa. These girls are about fourteen or fifteen years of age. I recommend that they be officially discharged and allowed to attend Kettle Point Indian Day School if they wish to do so.

An early reply with regard to the above will be appreciated.

M. W. McCracken,
Superintendent, Sarnia Indian Agency.

We have received a self-explanatory letter from Mr. Indian Superintendent McCracken reading as follows:

"Alfred Cottrelle, #76, Sarnia Band had three daughters, Loraine, Marilyn and Dorothy, in the Mohawk Institute at Brantford during the 1947-48 term. In July, 1948 this man visited the office and informed me that he did not intend to send Loraine and Marilyn back to residential school in September. He agreed to send his youngest daughter, Dorothy. In a letter dated July 12th, 1948 the Principal of the school, Mr. Zimmerman, agreed to the discharge of Loraine and Marilyn. However I do not believe that the Department has been notified re the above and therefore official discharge has never been obtained.

"As mentioned above Dorothy Cottrelle was supposed to return to Mohawk Institute in September, 1948. I put considerable pressure on the father to return her at various times throughout the fall. He tried to persuade his girl to go back to Brantford but she refused and would run away, etc. In January, 1949 the father was successful in getting her back to Brantford, but she remained there only one week and ran away. She returned to Sarnia Reserve where she is living at the present time. In my opinion it would be advisable to agree to the discharge of all three of this man's children.

"When Mr. Doucet visited Sarnia Agency about one
month ago the matter of truancy of three or four Indian girls from Mohawk Institute was investigated. One of the girls is Marilyn Rogers, daughter of #210, William Rogers, Barnia Band. I have given this girl temporary permission to attend St. Clair Indian Day School until a Departmental decision has been received regarding her return to Brantford. I do not think it would be advisable to force Marilyn to return to Mohawk School as she would no doubt run away again. I therefore recommend that she be officially discharged.

When Marilyn Rogers left Mohawk School two Kettle Point girls, namely Funica and Helen George, daughters of Simpson George, #301 and Miss Evelyn George, #302, Kettle Point Band, accompanied her. These two girls are running loose on Barnia Reserve at the present time. I see no use in forcing them to return to Brantford but am taking no action on the matter pending instructions which I understood Mr. Doucet was going to send on his return to Ottawa. These girls are about fourteen or fifteen years of age. I recommend that they be officially discharged and allowed to attend Kettle Point Indian Day School if they wish to do so.

An early reply with regard to the above will be appreciated."

I presume that these are the children about whom we talked at Munsey recently and that you do not wish to recommend their dismissal from the Mohawk Institute as recommended by Mr. McCracken.

Bernard F. Murray,
Superintendent of Education.

Mohawk Institute - Discharge of Pupils

This office appreciates your letter 416-10 (E) of the 22nd instant with regard to the above matter.

The writer hesitates to interfere in the decision of a Superintendent of another Agency, but as Mr. Doucet was informed when here, our policy with regard to the children belonging to the Six Nations Superintendency is that if they play truant by running away they must be found and returned.

Otherwise, we should soon have chaos at the School, as any child with a notion that he or she dislikes the school for some reason or other, could make up their minds to run away, knowing that no action would be taken and it was an easy way to rid themselves of the school and its discipline.

Many parents would also be up in arms over such a lax policy, as it is not unknown for a child to run away to some relative, who is sympathetic and stay there, rather than go home to parents who will send them back to the Institute.

On the other hand, while hesitating to intervene in the decisions made by another Superintendency, not knowing the local facts as he does, it is a fact that once children arrive at the Mohawk Institute, they become, in a way, my responsibility and under my jurisdiction, for when such outbreaks occur, the Principal phones me and on each occasion it has been necessary to institute energetic action as the Principal is inclined to be lost in a fog.

So, it is my opinion that all Superintendents sending children to distant schools outside their own Agency, should, unless very special reasons exist, be willing to cooperate and have runaway children immediately returned.
You will be glad to know that with regard to the action taken in Court against the young men for contributing to juvenile delinquency of the runaways, that each was convicted and given a $50.00 fine or two months in gaol.

The case took considerable time, but it is my opinion that both the girl pupils and the young men, learned a mighty good lesson, as they far from enjoyed the stern examination they went through in the witness box from the Crown Attorney and the Principal informs me the girls concerned have been very much subdued since that experience.

The young men engaged a lawyer and pleaded not guilty, so that the full rotten story was disclosed and they certainly looked shamefaced.

The case against the married couple who harboured some of the runaways is not yet concluded.

Lt.-Col. E. P. Randle,
Indian Superintendent
