April 14, 1949.

Dear Doctor Palmer,

The Superintendent of Indian Education has forwarded this office a copy of Dr. J.M. McDougall's letter to you of April 4 concerning the above mentioned girl.

Our records give us very little information on the patient and a report from you would be appreciated. Would you please comment on Dr. McDougall's recommendation and advise if you know of a Convalescent Home where she could be accommodated.

May we also be advised as to what reserve and agency she belongs, if you have this information.

Yours truly,

30th March, 1949.

Mr. W.J. Zimmerman,
Principal,
Mohawk Residential School,
Brantford, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Zimmerman:

Owing to very unsatisfactory home conditions, Superintendent Brisebois, Caughnawaga, P.Q., wishes to place Gloria Joan Splicer in a residential school. This girl is 14 years of age, and has been attending the Caughnawaga United Church Day School. Her father is dead and her step-father does not wish to keep her in his home as the girl's mother is in the hospital with a very serious heart condition.

Please wire me on receipt of this letter, stating if you are willing to accept her. Arrangements will then be made to have her go to Brantford immediately.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Heary,
Supt. of Indian Education

Caughnawaga, Que.,
April 29, 1949.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

This will acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 21st instant enclosing the original of a communication from Miss W. Roberts, Teacher at the local U.C. Indian Day School, dealing with the case of Gloria Morris of this Reserve who recently had birth to a child. Miss Roberts suggested that she be sent to Brantford at Rev. Mr. Zimmerman's school.

In reply I wish to say that I concur with you in that you consider inadvisable to send Gloria to the Mohawk Institute. She is not the type of girl to mix with other girls of her age at school.

I understand Miss Roberts together with a Social Worker are working on this case.

As soon as the submit some plan for the girl's future, we will communicate with you.

ENCL.

Frs. Brisebois
Supt., Indian Agency.

[Handwritten note:]
She turned in still of school age. Rev. Zimmerman was willing to accept her at Brantford.
April 7th

Booth Caughnawaga, Que.

Col. B. Henry
Dept. of Mines & Resources
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

It was a pleasure to meet Mr. Zimmerman of the Board School last week while he was in Caughnawaga.

In our conversation he inquired about the Miller family whom I knew had two girls in attendance at his school.

Visited the case of the third girl Gloria, age 15, who has just returned home from the Catholic Booth Hospital where she had been under care for a month. Gloria is at home with her baby. The parents demanded the child but they have no means of taking care of it. The children's Aid Committee were willing to accept the baby.

As Gloria is still of school age, Mr. Zimmerman was willing to accept her at school.
to attend school there and to help on the staff. I suggest you contact you for your advice and sanction on this case.

Yours sincerely,

Miss Evelyn Roberts

P.S. I have a Social Worker from the Children's Aid working on this case. She has visited the home twice recently to observe going into the hospital and found conditions very unsatisfactory for raising a child. So far as the baby is concerned she may take the case to Juvenile Court.

S.K.

(H.F. Matheson) Insp.
I/C C.I.B.
Ida GEORGE & Helen GEORGE (Indians)
Kettle Point Indian Reserve
Indian Act.

9-4-49

1. On the early afternoon of the 9-4-49, Albert OLIVER (Indian), from Barnia Reserve reported that two Indian girls, originally from Kettle Point Indian Reserve, had run away from the Bradford Industrial School and were leading an immoral life in this district.

2. Investigation showed that this was quite true. The girls, Ida GEORGE, age 15 and Helen GEORGE, age 14, came to Barnia Indian Reserve around the beginning of March 1949 and were taken in by Mrs. L. Later these girls began to run away from these homes and stay away for a few days at a time. They were known to spend nights in cabins with any men that would ask them in and tried to get other girls on this reserve to do the same. The parents of other girls on the Reserve began to complain and desired that these girls be sent away from the Reserve.

3. This matter was referred to the Indian Agent who stated that he had informed the Superintendent of the Bradford Industrial School as to the whereabouts of these two girls and directed that they be returned to the Father, Simon GEORGE, at Kettle Point Indian Reserve.

4. On the evening of this date, the writer accompanied by Police Matron, Mrs. Sarah FRUM, located the above mentioned girls and proceeded to Kettle Point Indian Reserve where they were left at the house of Simon GEORGE. Simon GEORGE was advised of the misdeeds of the girls and it was suggested that he try to keep the girls under surveillance.

Expense Incurred
CONCLUDED HERE

THE COMMISSIONER:

FORWARDED for your information
and that of the Indian Affairs Branch.

CONCLUDED.

Toronto
28-4-49
(H.F.Matheson) Insp.
I/O

Dear Miss Roberts:

We have received your letter of the 17th ultimo regarding Gloria Morris. As such matters should be handled through the office of the local Indian Superintendent, your letter was forwarded to Mr. Brisebois for his comments. At the same time we advised him that we were not prepared to consider placing Gloria Morris in the Mohawk Residential School.

I presume that the matter has been discussed with Mr. Brisebois, as he states in his reply that he will communicate with us again.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
PP/ST

Dear Sir,

I, William Solomon, member of the Six-
gum Band of Indians at Shippawa Hill, Ontario,
and at present employed here in Hamilton, am
making an application for a transferal of my
three children, Audrey Bertrude (sic), William
Rodrick, and Orin Wilmer Solomon, whom
are at present in Mohawk Institute
in Brantford, Ontario to the Shingwauk
Indian Residential School at Sault Ste.
Marie, Ontario as soon as possible, if possible
at the beginning of the Fall Term, Sept. 1st, 1947.
This matter I would very much appreciate
if it could be executed immediately so that I may
have knowledge of this matter before the school
close for the holidays.

The reasons of this desire for the said trans-
feral of my children can be stated by me shown
the Dept of Indian Affairs require these reasons.
Write me if more information regarding this matter
should arise. Thanking you.

Yours Truly,

William Wm. Solomon
16th May, 1924.

Mr. D. Robertson,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Chippewa Hill, Ontario.

We are in receipt of a letter from William Solomon, 204 Mary St., Hamilton, Ontario, requesting the transfer of his three children from the Mohawk Residential School to the Shingwauk Residential School at Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

He did not give any reason for wishing this transfer, and we would appreciate it if you could communicate with Mr. Solomon and let us have your views on the matter as soon as possible.

Bernard S. Heary,
Supt. of Indian Education
PERSONAL:

May 13, 1949.

Dear Sir:

Please find attached a self-explanatory letter from Dr. Falconer together with one from Dr. Palmer.

As you are aware, it is not our responsibility to maintain Indian girls or boys who should be in convalescent homes. However, I presume that Dr. Palmer has discussed this situation with you, and I would be glad to hear your reaction to Dr. Falconer's proposal. If you are not prepared to accept his suggestion, please do not hesitate to let me know.

In replying would you kindly return the attached letters.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Brantford, Ontario.

June 3rd, 1949.

Mr. V.M. Eastwood,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
385 Water Street,
Peterborough, Ontario.

We have received your letter of May 31st, your file 25-5 (25), with reference to the family of John Knott, and careful consideration has been given to its contents.

I note from the last paragraph that you express the opinion that they would not be suitable candidates for a residential school. We are inclined to agree with you in that regard, but we feel it would be difficult if not impossible to place them in any white institution.

Our suggestion is that Margaret, age 10, and Joyce, age 9, be placed in the Mohawk Institute at Brantford, and that Ethel, age 12, and Betty Joan, age 6, be placed in the Shingwauk Residential School at Sault Ste. Marie. It is realized that in making this suggestion we are separating the family, but we do not feel that this would cause any great difficulty.

If you agree with our suggestion, you might forward application forms for the schools mentioned above.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division

Reverend Sir:

I have written to Indian Health Services concerning Rose Atkinson as I feel she is, in the main, their responsibility.

I am pleased to note your floor polisher has arrived and hope it continues to give satisfactory service. We are badly delayed at the present time in the passing of Order-in-Council due to the absence of the various Ministers from Ottawa. However, we do hope for improvement in the situation after Election Day.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard P. Denby,
Superintendent of Education.

Re: Dept'l Letter, File 466-10(E1),
dated July 8, 1949.

In acknowledging the above-mentioned letter please be advised that Mr. William George, father of the children, was questioned as to why his children should receive institutional care.

He stated that both he and his wife are, and have been, working out attempting to save money to build a bigger and better home for their family. The children have been left in the care of an aged lady for whom the task is too heavy and the children are sometimes left more or less on their own which is a worry on the parents.

This Office is quite ready to corroborate his statements as Mr. and Mrs. George are an excellent type of Indian and should be encouraged in their worthwhile ambition.

Fred Hall,
SUPERINTENDENT.

Mr. Fred Hall,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,

July 25, 1949.

Rev. W.J. Zimmerman,
Principal,
Mohawk Indian Res., School,
Brantford, Ontario.

Your June Quarterly Return for the Mohawk Indian Residential School has been received along with the request for a part-payment on the June Quarter.

I trust that you will be receiving the part payment cheque for $5000.00 shortly.

On checking the quarterly return it is noted that pupils 01163, 01251, 1116, 1153, 1180, 1192, 1223, 1228 and 1279 are shown to have been in residence for less than the prescribed number of days. In most of the cases you showed absence to be caused on account of truancy, but you failed to show the date when the pupils left the residence or returned thereto.

For checking purposes the Treasury Branch and the Auditors insist that all necessary dates be shown. Therefore, it is requested that this information be provided for this return and all dates be shown on future returns.

Following § 1293 you have shown Winston Seth who is fourteen years of age and was in residence for thirty days. He was also shown on the March quarter for thirty-six days. Would you kindly supply more information on this boy, as we do not appear to have an application for admission for him. He is not shown on the Admission and Discharge form for March. We have not received an admission and discharge form for June.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.

Reference is made to official letter of January 24th 1948 Department file No. 38-0-10 approving of the admittance to Mohawk Residential school of four children of McAlpine Stonefish of this Agency.

Mr. Stonefish has been on the Reserve for the past several months where he has purchased a house and is caring for the children returned from school for the summer vacations.

He has requested their discharge from the Residential school claiming that he can care for them and the oldest girl can assist him in their care. Mrs. Peters his sister and an aunt of the children live close by and can assist in their care.

I recommend the approval of their discharge.

Stuart Spence,

Reference is made to official letter of August 22nd, 1949 file No. 32-0-10, approving of the admittance to Mohawk Indian Residential school of five children of David Watson widower of the Moravian Indian Reserve.

Mr. Watson was married of June 10th last, and he and his wife are prepared to care for the children at their home on the Reserve.

I recommend that these children be discharged from the Mohawk Residential school.

Stuart Spence,
Agency Superintendent.
August 2nd, 1949.

Mr. S. Spence,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Highgate, Ontario.

We are in receipt of your letters of July 25th with reference to the discharge of certain children from your Agency who have been attending the Mohawk Residential School at Brantford, Ontario.

We are prepared to grant the discharge of the five Watson children, and we are so advising Mr. Zimmerman, the Principal.

With reference to the Stonefish children, I think it would be advisable to defer action on them until the end of August. If at that time you still feel the same about their discharge, we are prepared to approve such action. By deferring their discharge we simply wish to make certain that Mr. Stonefish is willing to provide a proper home for his children.

Bernard F. Henry,
Supt. of Indian Education
August 2nd, 1949.

Rev. W.J. Zimmerman,
Principal,
Mohawk Residential School,
Brantford, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Zimmerman:

Indian Superintendent Stuart Spence has informed us that David Watson was remarried on June 10th, and that he and his wife are prepared to care for Mr. Watson's five children who are now enrolled at the Mohawk Residential School. Mr. Spence considers that Mr. Watson will provide a suitable home for his children, and consequently, the discharge of pupils #1249, #1280, #01280, #01282 and #01283 is approved.

Sincerely yours,

PP/ST

Bernard F. Henry,
Supt. of Indian Education
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I wish to refer to Department letter No. 466-10 (E.I.) dated May 10th, regarding the transfer of the three Solomon children from the Mohawk Residential School to the Shingwauk Residential School.

I have had a reply from Mr. Solomon and he states that he intends moving from Hamilton, Ont., to Northern Ontario, as these children have attended the Mohawk School for a number of years I would think it would be to their interest to remain there at least until Mr. Solomon is settled in his new home.

Don. Robertson,
Superintendent, Indian Agency.
August 4th, 1949.

Mr. D. Robertson,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Chippewa Hill, Ontario.

We are in receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo with further reference to the 3 Solomon children.

The Department does not see any special necessity for transferring these children to the Shingwauk Residential School at the present time. Even though the father obtains work in Northern Ontario, there is no guarantee that he will be close to the Shingwauk School which is located at Sault Ste. Marie.

Under these circumstances, the children would be better to remain in the Mohawk Residential School.

PP/ST

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education
August 2, 1949.

Rev. W.J. Zimmerman,
Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

The above mentioned was discharged from the Mountain Sanatorium, Hamilton, in December 1948 and has been convalescing since that time.

Her treatment consisted of bed rest and a left upper thoracoplasty. Patient has a small amount of disease in the right apex which appears well healed.

At the present time, patient's condition is satisfactory and I do not believe that she is infectious. However, there is always the probability of a break-down and this is greater because of her nationality. Even though she is not infectious now, it is my opinion that it would be much safer for all concerned if some other accommodation were provided for her other than at the Mohawk Institute where she is in contact with many small children.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

John M. McCauley, M.D.
Superintendent.

Dear Colonel Neary:

You will find an enclosed medical statement from the Brant Sanatorium re-Rose Atkinson.

The problem has been accentuated by the fact that Miss Atkinson feels well and refuses to take the required rest. She has been advised by the San. Doctor to retire by 8:30 P.M., but remains up until 10:30 etc. I do feel that I must insist upon this person being transferred elsewhere. The results may be such as we shall all deplore later.

Yours very truly,

Principal.

WILLIKEN, Adrienne AGE 6 HEIGHT 48

TO Dr. E. C. Card, Sarnia, Ontario

PREVIOUS TREATMENT THE BECK MEMORIAL SANATORIUM - Jan.11/48 - May 21/49

LABORATORY: I.C. SPUTUM /RAY Report attached

EXPOSURE & SUSCEPTIBILITY

The above mentioned was discharged from this Institution in May 1949. Her mother states she has been well since that time and apparently she has no symptoms at present. Her appetite and strength are good. She has apparently lost about three pounds in weight.

Examination of the chest was essentially negative.

X-ray report is attached.

Diagnosis: Childhood type tuberculosis, combined, apparently arrested.

Conclusion: There appears to be no change in this girl's condition which appears to remain satisfactory. She should probably get some increased rest for the time being, having an hour to an hour and a half rest in the afternoon.

Return to Clinic: Would recommend further return to the regular clinic in three months' time. It is noted that this girl may be going to school in Brantford next fall. If this is so the Medical Officer of Health in that locality should be notified in order that she may be called to attend clinic there.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

JHB/HB
QUEEN ALEXANDRA SANATORIUM

Name: MILLIKEN, Adrienne

OTTAWA, Ontario.

Enclosed please find Applications for Admission for four children belonging to Mrs. Bruce (Clara) Milliken, #277, Kettle Point Band.

About one month ago I wrote to the Principal of the Mohawk Institute to ascertain if he could accommodate these four children in September. He replied in the affirmative and I have therefore completed the Application for Admission and Physical Examination forms.

The mother of these children is having a difficult time in supporting them on the Kettle Point Reserve. Her husband died about three years ago in Byron Sanatorium. Since that time all of these children have on one occasion or another been in the Sanatorium. According to the medical reports they are now arrested cases.
Muncy, Ontario,
Aug. 18, 1949.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Canada.

Re. Admission to Residential Schools.

The following children attended the Mohawk residential School for the 1948-49 term and were brought home by their guardians for the summer holidays and will be returned to the school by sane in September.

Edward Monague, Ethel, Fred and Beverley King and Garto Monague.

Doris, Carl, Sheila, Erle and Dennis Assance, Caroline McCue, Vivien Rice, Rena and Connie Monague attended the Shingwauk school at Sault Ste. Marie and were also brought home by their parents and are to be returned at their expense. However as the Mohawk School at Brantford is much closer than the Shingwauk school the parents and guardians would like to know if these children could be sent to Brantford instead of the Sault. Doris Assance will not be returning having attained the age of 16 and failed in Grade 9 last term.

Enclosed are 2 new applications for admission, Dorothy Monague, sister of Rena and Connie and Eric Assance brother of the Assance children.

Please advise if admission to the Mohawk School in Brantford is possible for these children, the parents having taken the children at their expense.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Indian Superintendent.
September 1st, 1949.

Mr. H. Gauthier,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Christian Island, Ontario.

We are in receipt of your letter of August 26th, your file 6/25-2, with reference to the admission of certain children from your Agency to residential schools. The Department desires that those children mentioned in your letter who attended the Mohawk Residential School should return to that school.

We also wish the children who attended the Shingwauk Residential School to return to Sault Ste. Marie for the academic year 1949-50.

The admission of Dorothy Monague and Eric Assance to the Mohawk Residential School is approved.

Philip Phelan,
PP/T Chief, Education Division

Mr. F. Hall,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Muncey, Ontario.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division

Mr. M.W. McCracken,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Jarnia, Ont.

We have your letter of the 1st instant,
your file 80-2 (29) with reference to the
children of William Joseph.

It is not usual to place such young
children in a residential school, but in view
of the family conditions outlined in your letter
and the further fact that the Principal of the
Mohawk Residential School is prepared to accept
them, you may arrange to have the two oldest
children, Shirley aged five, and Eloise aged
three, placed in the Mohawk School, provided
they are physically fit.

You should have the usual application
forms and certificates of health forwarded for
our file.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division

cc Mr. Zimmerman
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

William Joseph, #170, Sarnia Band, is living apart from his wife. There are three children in the family aged ten months, three and five years. Mr. and Mrs. Joseph have never been able to get along together. In the past few years they have had various reconciliations, but none have been permanent. Mrs. Joseph deserts the family quite often and lives with Negroes and Mexicans in Port Huron, Michigan, U.S.A. William Joseph is frequently in jail on intoxication charges. At the present time Mrs. Joseph is in Port Huron and her husband is trying to look after the three children with the aid of his sister-in-law.

It is obvious that the children are badly neglected and undernourished, etc. After discussing the matter with William Joseph I have decided to recommend that the two oldest children be admitted to Mohawk Residential School. He wishes such action taken, although we both realise that the admittance of the three year old one is exceptional. I have contacted the Principal of the school on the matter and he is quite willing to take the two children if the Department approves. As mentioned above the home conditions are deplorable and in this instance I recommend that an exception be made by admitting the Joseph children to Mohawk Institute. Their names are Shirley, aged five and Eloise, aged three.
Would you please advise at an early date if it will be in order to send these children to Brantford? The father states that he will pay transportation charges. He also informs me that he can place his youngest child in an Indian home on the Saugeen Reserve if the two eldest are admitted to Mohawk.

M. W. McCracken,
Superintendent, Sarnia Indian Agency.
| DATE    | SERVICE                                                                 | AMOUNT |
|---------|------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------|
| Sept 9  | Transportation of Mrs. Nelson Ashkew's children to Mohawk Residential School, Brantford Ontario. Total Mileage 332 miles @ 9¢ per mile | $29.88 |

This expenditure was approved by the Departmental Letter, File No. 66-1811, dated Sept. 2, 1949.

Voucher No. 222

Date September 13th, 1949
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa Canada.

Re: Children admitted to Residential Schools.

In reply to your letter of September 1st, file 466-10(E.1), I wish to advise that on September the 3rd, not having as yet received a reply to my letter of August 26th, re. placing the 13 children from this Reserve all at the Brantford School (Mohawk). I took the liberty of phoning the Principal of this school and was advised that he could take all the children, but that he wished to have them not later than the 6th of September.

As the children were all ready and due to the fact that the Parents and guardians did not have the money to send them at the moment and that it was also felt that separating the children would have been imposing hardship on both the children and the teacher, I arranged with a brother of mine to transport them to Brantford with my light truck, the Indians agreeing to reimburse me and the driver in the near future.

I might add that the children arrived safely and that I received your letter the following day.

I explained this to Mr. Morris on his visit here on the 7th and he concurred with my opinion that the children would be better off all together.

Hoping the above receives your approval,

Yours truly,

Henry Gauthier,
Indian Superintendent.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Kenneth Maness, son of Mrs. Gordon (Evelyn) Jacobs, #371, Sarnia Band, was admitted to Mohawk Institute at Brantford in September, 1948. His mother, who was divorced, remarried Gordon Jacobs, an Indian member of Sarnia Band, on July 9th, 1949. She is now able to give her child the proper care in her own home and requests permission to have him discharged from Mohawk Institute.

I have discussed the matter with the Principal of the school and he agreed to the discharge. Kenneth is now attending day school on Sarnia Indian Reserve and I recommend that the Department approve of his permanent release from residential school.

M. W. McCracken,
Superintendent, Sarnia Indian Agency.
September 16, 1949.

Mr. H.W. McCracken,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Sarnia, Ont.,

Your file 205-1 (29)

In view of the information contained in your letter of September 13th, the Department approves the discharge of Kenneth Maness from the Mohawk Indian Residential School.

It is noted that this boy is presently attending the day school in Sarnia.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.

Miss Lillian Blaker, daughter of Walter S. Blaker, #167 Alnwick Band, who is 14 years of age was placed in the Mohawk Institute at Brantford under authority of file 32-0-10 dated 23 of January 1946. During 1948 she was admitted to the hospital for sick children, 67 College Street, Toronto and diagnosis was "investigation re limp". Accounts were received here for May, June, July, August, September, October, and November, amounting to $1208. Apparently the previous accounts were rendered direct by the Mohawk Institute, as the date of the first account received here was dated May 1, 1948, and she was still in hospital as far as I know on November 30, 1948. Since then no further accounts have been received.

I received a letter from the hospital during October stating that she was being returned to the Mohawk Institute and there were certain directions as to her care and a request to have her report at a further date for re-examination. I forwarded this letter to Rev. W.J. Zimmerman, principal of the Institute. In a letter from Rev. Zimmerman dated November 23rd he states that he does not feel that in Lillian Blaker's present condition that the institute is able to care for her. Dr. Palmer, who has been appointed to care for these children, does not feel that the Institute should accept Lillian as he does not possess the staff to handle patients of this type.

I do not think it possible for her to return home as her mother died several years ago and her father re-married and apparently there is now another family. This family has been the subject of Children's Aid Society investigations from time to time. They are living at Sturgeon Falls from my last information. There are no immediate relations on the Alnwick Reserve, nor do I know of any place she can stay. If she remains at the hospital it will be at a cost of $150.00 a month.

May I please be advised. I know nothing of the ailment from which the child is suffering or what care she requires.

(sgd) V.M. Eastwood

Rice and Mud Lakes Agency
November 30th, 1949.

Memorandum:

DR. PROCTER
INDIAN HEALTH SERVICES

Attached for your information is a letter just received from Superintendent Eastwood.

In view of the information contained in this letter, we are inclined to agree with the Principal of the Mohawk Residential School, when he states that they are not equipped to properly look after this girl.

It would be appreciated if you would make other arrangements for her maintenance.

PP/ST

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division

Attach.
The Brant Sanatorium

Mr. Philip Phelan  
Chief, Education Division

Miss Lillian Blaker

Following receipt of your recent communications, your file 466-10 (El), concerning the difficulty of fitting this girl into the school at Brantford, we have been attempting to learn something of her past and present condition. This is rather difficult from our files and further complicated by the fact that she appears to have been under the jurisdiction of Mr. Eastwood during 1948 up to November and subsequently her hospital accounts have been certified by Mr. Devlin. We are, therefore, quite confused as to what superintendent is in charge of the group to which Miss Blaker belongs.

It would appear from our records that Lillian Blaker was discharged from the Sick Children's Hospital on 25 May '49. We do not, therefore, quite understand Mr. Eastwood's reference to a notice from the hospital in October '49 and we are at a loss to know exactly where Miss Lillian Blaker is at the present time.

If Miss Blaker is now at the Mohawk Institute the most suitable arrangement would be for her to visit Dr. Davis at Chawaken and Dr. Davis from his long experience can assess her disability and recommend the best procedure in her case.

We regret the delays in dealing with this case but you will see that it is far from clear cut on our files.

P. E. Moore, M.D., D.P.H.  
Director,  
Indian Health Services

c.c. to Dr. Davis
December 29th, 1949.

Mr. V.M. Eastwood,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
385 Water Street,
Peterborough, Ontario.

Re: Lillian Blaker

On receipt of your letter of November 26th regarding the above girl who was a former pupil of the Mohawk Residential School and who was returned to that school following her discharge from hospital, we communicated with the Indian Health Services and expressed the opinion that in view of the information contained in your letter, we did not feel that the girl should be kept in the Mohawk School.

I now enclose for your information a copy of a memorandum received from Dr. Moore, Director of Indian Health Services. It would be appreciated if you would write us another letter clarifying the case in order that we can inform Dr. Moore.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division
December 29th, 1949.

Mr. E.P. Randle,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Brantford, Ontario.

Re: Lillian Bleker

Enclosed for your information is a copy of a letter dated November 26th received from Superintendent Eastwood. We communicated with the Indian Health Services and expressed the opinion that the girl should not have been returned to the Mohawk Residential School, as it is felt that her re-admission to the school involved extra care on the part of the school staff.

We have now received a memorandum from Dr. Moore, copy of which is enclosed. I am bringing this matter to your attention so that you can discuss it with the Principal.

I am writing to Mr. Eastwood to obtain further information regarding this girl's background.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division

Re: Lillian Blaker, daughter of Walter S. Blaker #167 Alhwick Band

On receipt of your letter file 466-10 (El) dated 29th of December 1949 on the 31st of December, I telephoned Rev. Zimmerman of the Mohawk Institute and wrote the Hospital for Sick Children, Toronto. Not receiving a reply to my letter I wired the Hospital on January 14th and now attach letters received from the Hospital for Sick Children and the Daughters of the Empire Hospital for Convalescent Children at Toronto. These may serve to clear up the records in regard to Miss Blaker. The originals are forwarded; I have retained copies of each.

Part of the confusion as to what band Miss Blaker belonged to possibly originated due to Mr. Samuel Devlin completing final arrangements for Miss Blaker's admission to the Mohawk Institute. Miss Blaker was living with her family at Parry Sound at that time. Arrangements were made at that time in accordance with my letter to the Department of January 2nd, 1945.

Miss Blaker was admitted to hospital from the Mohawk Institute as she is 14 years of age and has no home to return to. I submit that she should return to the Institute if there is any way in which she can be taken care of. Her father Walter Blaker takes no responsibility towards the child. Her mother is dead and Walter Blaker has remarried.

No accounts have been received from the Daughters of the Empire Hospital for Convalescent Children in connection with Miss Blaker.

V. M. EASTWOOD,
Superintendent,
Kiss and Mud Lakes Agency.
January 19th, 1950.

Memorandum:

DR. P.E. MOORE,
DIRECTOR, INDIAN HEALTH SERVICES

Miss Lillian Blaker
Your File 50-10-3

With reference to your memorandum of December 23rd regarding the above girl, I enclose for your information a copy of a letter received from Superintendent Eastwood, Peterborough, Ontario, and also letters received from The Hospital for Sick Children and Daughters of the Empire Hospital for Convalescent Children.

Mr. Phelan of this Division was at the Mohawk Residential School last week, and at the present time the school has its full quota of pupils for whom the per capita grant is allowed. If Lillian Blaker's condition has improved to the extent that she will be able to enter the school as a regular student, we might be able to arrange for her accommodation. However, if she requires special attention, I cannot see how the Mohawk Residential School can accept her in view of the full enrollment they have at the present time.

Bernard F. Henry,
Supt. of Indian Education
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Lillian Blaker

With further reference to your 466-10 (E.1) of the 29th December, we are enclosing a copy of a letter recently received from the Department of Public Health, Toronto, together with medical report.

You will note they wish to discharge her from the I.O.D.E. Hospital in Toronto for re-admittance to the Mohawk Institute.

As according to the medical report she is still a bed patient, except for 2 hours each day, it would not appear the Mohawk Institute is a suitable place for her at the present time for more than one reason.

Also, with our limited bed accommodation at Lady Willingdon Hospital, it would hardly be fair to the large local Indian population to be served, to take up a bed there, as Miss Blaker is not a member of this Superintendency.

This office regrets we can offer no solution to keep this unfortunate girl, but we feel it is really up to the Superintendent of her own Reserve.

Would the Shingwauk School, which has not the overcrowded condition of the Mohawk Institute, be a suitable place for this girl?

Lt.-Col. E. P. Randle,
Indian Superintendent

Enc.
January 31st, 1950.

Re: Your File 22/25-1-460

We are in receipt of your letter of the 31st ultimo enclosing a letter received from Mrs. Eleanor George, with reference to conditions at the Mohawk Residential School.

Mr. Phelan of this Division visited the school within the last three weeks, and he has expressed the opinion to me that the statements made by Mrs. George are greatly exaggerated. All the children in the school are inspected regularly by the medical officer, and if any of Mrs. George's children require dental care, it would be given immediately.

We would like to know the present circumstances of Mrs. George. It is noted that she writes from a Toronto address, and possibly she and her husband are in a position to look after their children, and if so, we would be pleased to discharge them from the Mohawk Residential School so that she can look after them in a manner she considers proper.

PP/ST

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education
February 7th, 1950.

Mr. E.P. Randle,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Brantford, Ontario.

Re: Mohawk Indian Residential School

Enclosed is a letter which is self-explanatory. There is no question but that the statements made by Mrs. George are greatly exaggerated. However, you might make enquiries regarding the dental work to which she refers.

You will note the statement in the letter reading "I brought Carole down for an eye examination, as she needs it very bad, and I'm working hard now cleaning her up." We have reviewed the December Quarterly Return for the Mohawk School, and the only child by that name is Pupil 01323. Are we to understand that the Principal allowed the mother to take one of her children out of the school in the middle of the term simply because she needed attention to her eyes?

Please let me hear from you regarding this particular point. When replying, you should return the enclosed letter.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education
of money and could not finance the trip with the result that Dorothy is still on Sarnia Reserve and Helen and Ida have now gone to Kettle Point. This is the second time these same children have run away from Mohawk School. From reports it appears as though they intend to run away again if forced to return to Brantford.

After giving this matter careful consideration I believe the best policy would be to arrange their permanent discharge. I do not know whether the Principal of Mohawk School would agree with this action. Before taking any further action in the matter I would appreciate your advice and instructions.

M. W. McCracken

Superintendent, Sarnia Indian Agency.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship and Immigration,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

On or about January 1st, 1950 four children of
the Sarnia Agency ran away from Mohawk Residential School.
Their names and ages are as follows:--Marilyn Rogers,
aged fifteen, Dorothy Cottrelle, aged fifteen, Helen George,
aged fourteen and Ida George, aged fourteen. Marilyn and
Dorothy are from Sarnia Reserve. Helen and Ida belong to
Kettle Point.

Marilyn Rogers stopped briefly at Sarnia and then
continued on to Detroit, where she is living with an older
sister. Dorothy Cottrelle is living in her father's home
on Sarnia Reserve. Helen and Ida George are with relatives
at Kettle Point.

The two George children stayed with Dorothy Cottrelle
on Sarnia Reserve for about three weeks. I interviewed
these children on January 16th. They claimed that the
Principal had punished them unjustly and that they were un-
willing to return to Brantford. A day or so after my inter-
view Dorothy's father, Alfred Cottrelle, appeared at this
office. He stated that he was making immediate arrange-
ments to return them to Brantford. Apparently he was short
February 15th, 1950.

Superintendent, Indian Agency,

March 2, 1950.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration, OTTAWA.

Re: Admission to Mohawk Residential School, Brantford, Ontario.

The principal of the above school informed me by telephone that Harold Thompson, age 17, a Member of the Amalgamated Band of Walpole Island had returned to the school to stay until June.

This boy's father has no home on this reserve and is employed at Casual labour off and on the reserve. Harold left school last year and has stayed with various friends here but has not been able to obtain employment.

Since the Principal reports that he was a good worker at his school and is willing to take him back until such time as he can obtain work, it is recommended that his re-admission be approved, please.

Robert J. Stallwood,
Superintendent, Walpole Agency.
March 22, 1950.

Sarnia, March 6th, 1950.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship and Immigration,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Enclosed please find Application for Admission and Physical Examination forms for three children of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Walker, #319, Sarnia Band.

These children have been badly neglected during the past few months. The father and mother have been in jail on various occasions and both are very irresponsible. These three children have attended school irregularly due to home conditions. The father has been unemployed and the home life of these children was deplorable.

In view of the above I contacted the Principal of Mohawk Institute to find out if he had vacancies for these three children. He informed me that he could accommodate them and as the parents were penniless I took the children to Brantford in my car on Saturday, March 4th.

The matter was quite urgent and I trust that the Department approves of the action I have taken in having these children admitted to Mohawk Institute at Brantford.

M. W. McCracken,

M. W. McCracken,
Superintendent, Sarnia Indian Agency.

Re: Mohawk Residential School

On file 29/18-24, there is report from R.C.M.P. with reference to Emerson and Herbert ROGERS who have truanted from the above school, and Supt. McCracken requested the R.C.M.P. to return the boys to the Mohawk Residential School if possible.
With reference to the above may the writer inform that in the A.M. of the 3rd instant, a patrol was carried out on the Six Nations Reserve in an effort to locate one Vernon HILL who had been missing from the Mohawk Institute Brantford, Ontario for some time.

The writer accompanied by an Instructor from the Mohawk Institute patrolled to the home of HILL where it was learned that he was living with his foster-father on another part of the Reserve. It was also learned that he had been attending school at No. 10 School here on the Reserve. The school was visited and HILL was located. He was taken into custody by the Instructor and returned to the Mohawk Institute at Brantford, Ontario. HILL is fourteen years of age.

In view of the above this matter will be considered closed at this Detachment unless otherwise instructed.

FORWARDED for your information.

(H.P. Matheson) Insp.,
I/C C.I.O.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship and Immigration,
Ottawa Ontario.

Re: Isaac Peters No.22 14620
Caldwell Indian

The above noted Caldwell Indian living at North Buxton, Ontario, formerly at Dresden Ontario, who's wife (Common Law) left him in 1948 with two small boys, at which time the case was reported to the Children's Aid Society of Chatham Ontario, due to the condition under which the father was living, with the results, the children were placed, with an older brother and his wife and an older sister and her husband at North Buxton, this seemed a satisfactory arrangement until early this Spring when the writer found them living with the father in a shack at North Buxton and from my observations and information from neighbours in dire circumstances, at which time relief was supplied, the father is shiftless and a drinker, and I planned at the time to obtain authority to have the children enrolled in an Indian Residential School, at the time of my visits I was unable to locate Mr. Peters, but the two boys was in school, I wished to obtain Mr. Peters views and consent to send the boys to a Residential School, unable to find Mr. Peters, I interviewed the Children's Aid Society, with the understanding that the children was under their cut this was not the case, but they did notify Mr. Peters to come to Chatham, of which he did, and signed a statement, consenting to have the boys placed in a Residential School, at Sault Ste. Marie Ontario, four days later the mother came from Detroit and took the boys back to Detroit with her.

To-day I am advised by the Children's Aid Society, that the boys was let out of a car on No. 2 Highway west of Chatham, and walked to their sisters home at North Buxton, these boys are Ernest Peters II, Rolly Peters age 10. The sisters husband is a Negro, their brother has a wife and two children, and as I see it has all he can do to care for himself and family, the sister states she does not wish to, and is unable to care for the boys.

Therefore I recommend
Therefore I recommend authority be granted to place these two children in Mohawk Residential School. In a telephone conversation with the Rev. Dr. Zimmer Principal, this morning he stated that he has room and can accommodate these boys.

Stuart Spence
Agency Superintendent.
June 14th, 1950.

Mr. S. Spence,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Highgate, Ontario.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, OTTAWA, Canada.

Please be advised that for the past two years we have had thirteen children belonging to six different families attending the Mohawk Residential School at Brantford. All of these children have been taken out for the summer months by the guardians or parents and I am advised and requested by the parents and guardians to ascertain whether these children could be admitted to Shingwauk Residential School at Sault Ste Marie for the coming term.

The parents and guardians and the children are not satisfied with conditions at Mohawk Residential School but realize that the return of the children to this Residential School is their responsibility and are aware of the fact that sending them to Shingwauk Residential School will cost more money but still desire to have them attend Shingwauk.

Please advise in the near future whether openings will be available.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

H. Gauthier,
Indian Superintendent

[Stamp] JUL 27 1950
REGISTERED
RECORDS INDIAN AFFAIRS
July 31, 1950.

Mr. H. Gauthier,
Supt., Indian Agency,
Christian Island, Ont.,

We are in receipt of your letter of the 25th instant in which you point out that children from Christian Island who have been attending the Mohawk Residential School wish to be transferred to the Shingwauk Residential School.

The Department is not prepared to favourably consider allowing these children to change. There are qualified teachers at the Mohawk school and during the current summer we have expended a considerable amount of money in repairs and improvements to the building.

The children of Christian Island who were enrolled at the Mohawk Residential School during the academic year 1949-50 and whose parents are unable to support them and send them to a day school on the reserve, should return to the Mohawk Institute on September 1st.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Indian Education.

Re: Mohawk Institute, Brantford, Ont.

You will find herewith an "Application for Admission" to the above institution on behalf of Thomas Whitebeam, son of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence Whitebeam, Indians of the St. Regis Band, living at Caughnawaga since several years.

The parents have a family of seven children, and the mother being sickly cannot properly care for her family. Some children being looked after by some of her relatives. Thomas frequently missed School last year and was not a good influence while attending, this due to lack of parental supervision; the father being away working often. The Principal of the U.C. Indian Day School claims that one or two years in a Residential School would be beneficial to the boy.

Please take this application into consideration.

(Fr. Brisebois)
Supt., Indian Agency.

Mr. and Mrs. Grant James, #331, Sarnia Band,
wish to have their three children, namely Larry, 8,
Ronald, 10 and Ervin, 6, admitted to the Mohawk Institute
in September.

These children are being badly neglected on
Sarnia Reserve as the parents are irresponsible. School
attendance has been irregular and it would be in the
best interests of the children for them to be enrolled
in residential school.

Recently I wrote to Reverend Zimmerman regarding
vacancies for these three children in September. He
replied that he could provide accommodation for them.

I am enclosing application for admission forms
in connection with the above and recommend that the
Department approve of the admission of these three
children to Mohawk Institute.

M. W. McCracken,
Superintendent, Sarnia Indian Agency.
September 6th, 1950.

Re: Admission to Mohawk Residential School,
Grenville Cyril and Woodrow Garnet Snake
of Munceys of the Thames Band.

I hesitate to recommend approval of the attached
applications since we have such good educational facilities
at the Caradoc Agency Schools. However the father of
these children spends a large portion of his time in jail,
and at present their mother has deserted them and the family
of six are left at various homes to be cared for. We are
now attempting to take action against the parents.

Under these conditions I am submitting the
applications for your consideration.

Fred Hall
SUPERINTENDENT.

Re: Applications of Irene and Delbert Riley,
Chippewas of the Thames Band,
to Mohawk Residential School.

Irene lives with an aunt who although married to an Indian spends much of her time at the home of a white man. The conditions are bad and besides the child is often left alone at the white man's home. She is a big girl for her age and I am fearful of what the future has in store for her.

The boy, Delbert, does not seem to have any definite home.

I would ask that these applications be given serious consideration and approved if possible.

Fred Hall,
SUPERINTENDENT.

September 13, 1950.

Mr. F. Hall,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Muncey, Ontario.

Re: Mohawk Residential School
Your File 7/25-2-466

We are in receipt of your letters of September 6th and 7th submitting applications for the admission of children to the Mohawk Residential School. We approve the admission of the following children:

Dolores Doxtator
Irene Riley
Delbert Riley
Woodrow Garnet Snake
Grenville Cyril Snake

In view of the information which you have supplied regarding the 3 Jamieson children, the Department is not prepared to approve their admission to a residential school at the present time. It is noted that both parents are living, the father is working and the children have a suitable home. Under these circumstances, they should attend the day school on the reserve.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship and Immigration,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

I wish to refer to your letter 466-10 of March 22nd, 1950 approving of the admittance of Herbert, Carol and Ernest Walker, children of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Walker, #319, Sarnia Band, to Mohawk Institute at Brantford.

Two of these children did not remain at Brantford very long. They ran away twice and as the end of the term was approaching I could not persuade the parents to return them to Brantford. The parents brought the youngest child home for summer vacation and they are now refusing to return any of their children to residential school.

In view of the truancy of the Walker children and the attitude of their parents, and also the fact that they are attending day school on the Reserve, I recommend that they be permanently discharged from Mohawk Institute.

M. W. McCracken,
Superintendent, Sarnia Indian Agency.
September 14, 1950.

Mr. M.W. McCracken,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Sarnia, Ontario.

Re: Mohawk Residential School
Your File 23/25-4-466

In view of the information contained in your letter of the 12th instant, the Department approves the discharge of Herbert, Carol and Ernest Walker from the above school.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division

Re: Mohawk Residential School
Your File 7/25-2-466

We have your letter of the 11th instant enclosing application for the admission of Martha Alice Turgeon of Chippewas of the Thames Band to the above school.

We have noted the contents of your letter, and it appears that this girl will not receive proper attention from her relatives, and consequently, it is believed that it would be in her best interests to place her in a residential school. If Mr. Zimmerman is willing to accept her, we approve her admission.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division

Bernard F. Henry,
Supt. of Indian Education.
These two Rogers boys are entirely out of control, both at home and at Mohawk Institute. I hesitate to recommend their permanent discharge as I know it will be impossible to persuade them to attend day school on the Reserve. I telephoned Mr. Zimmerman, Principal of Mohawk Institute, concerning this and he states that they are a bad influence on the rest of the pupils at the school. He suggests, and I strongly recommend, that Ivan and Emerson Rogers be transferred from Mohawk to Shingwauk Residential School. The boys have heard rumours that they'll be transferred to Shingwauk and apparently threatened to run away from there the same as they have done at Brantford. However, Mr. Zimmerman and I are of the opinion that they should be immediately transferred to Shingwauk Residential School.

The problem of transportation to Shingwauk will be difficult, but Mr. Zimmerman suggested that possibly I could take the two Rogers boys and the Green boy back as far as Brantford and he might then take them in his car to Shingwauk.

Kindly advise by wire if I am authorized to take these children from Sarnia Reserve to Brantford in my car. Mr. Zimmerman also wishes your permission to transfer them to Shingwauk as soon as they arrive back at Brantford.

M. W. McCracken

MWM/D

M. W. McCracken,
Superintendent, Sarnia Indian Agency.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship and Immigration,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Ivan and Emerson Rogers, aged fourteen and twelve, sons of Mr. and Mrs. William Rogers, #210, Sarnia Band, have run away from Mohawk Institute. They arrived at their parents' home on Sarnia Reserve last Thursday, accompanied by another boy from Tyendinaga Reserve whose surname is Green. This is the second time since September, 1950 that Ivan has been truant. About one month ago he ran away and was escorted back to Brantford by the Provincial Police. Mrs. Rogers reported their arrival to me this morning. She states that the boys told her that they will run away again if they are returned to Brantford and give as the reason the fact that older boys in the school are mistreating them. At the moment the boys do not know that I am aware of their presence on the Sarnia Reserve. I have no guarantee that they will remain at the Rogers home very long, particularly if they discover that I am aware of their presence.
Ottawa, November 13, 1950.

M.M. McCracken,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Sarnia, Ont.

YOU MAY RETURN ROGERS BOYS TO MOHAWK ON DISTINCT UNDERSTANDING
PRINCIPAL WILL ARRANGE IMMEDIATE TRANSFER TO "HING' AUX HOME" -stop-

On the 20-11-50 a call was received at this detachment from the Mohawk Institute, Brantford stating that three boys namely Milford Gibson, Lorne Gibson and James Aylas were missing from that Institute and all efforts on their part to apprehend same had met with negative results.

On the 21-11-50 a patrol was carried out by the writer to the home of the above named Aylas where he was located and taken into custody. He was escorted to the barracks at Chawton and from there returned to the Mohawk Institute at Brantford by officials of the Institute.

FORWARDED for your information.

(J.B. Crooksbank) Insp.,

On the 20-11-50 a call was received at this Detachment from the Mohawk Institute at Brantford stating that three boys namely Wilford Gibson, Lorne Gibson and James Keys were missing from that Institute and all efforts on their part to apprehend them had met with negative results.

On the 21-11-50 a patrol was carried out by the writer to the Gibson home here on the Reserve where the above named was found in a bush approximately one-half mile to the rear of his home. Dear Doctor Davis:

This child had a chest film at the Preport Sanatorium on August 26, 1950. At that time, heavy hilar shadows were noted especially on the right and it was felt that there was some possibility of primary tuberculosis. The patch test was repeated at the time of the present film.

10 x 12 film #2066, December 5/50:
Film is satisfactory.

Right lung: Is free of disease. The hilar shadows appear prominent.

Left lung: Is free of disease.

Conclusions: There is no evidence of active pulmonary tuberculosis.

Remarks: The patch test done December 5th was reported as negative. We suggest a repeat film in six months.

Yours very truly,

H.A. Minnelly, M.D.
Acting Superintendent.

Sir:

Enclosed is Dr. Bragg's statement—
Hazel Elliott, 17 years of age—a pretty
bright girl—very musical—she has not been
well for some time. Dr. Palmer has been
treating her—the doctor advised burning off
her tonsils and adenoids. She is a strange
of new credit. Her father has been an
invalid for years, partly paralyzed—her
mother ran away with another man and
has a large family. A grandmother who
has a large family & her own is the
only person who takes any interest in
the girl. She had her for a holiday
summer before last.

Ariel Staats—She Scott may
remember, has the lining of her upper
lip hanging down—making a great
disfigurement to an otherwise pretty girl.
She is 14 years of age—her father was killed overseas—her mother supports her family. The Council of Six Nations requested me to take in three of her children. She is an Upper Mohawk.

I hope you will accede to the request. I am sure its operation to take place soon—and Ariel Blais for next summer.

This is the best servant,

[Signature]

POOR COPY
Indian Office, Brantford,
January 21st., 1922.

Sir,

I have to enclose a statement received from Mrs. Boyce of the Mohawk Institute in regard to some of her pupils who require medical treatment.

Nazel Elliott, 17 years old, a member of the Mississaugas of the Credit whose father is an invalid and her mother is living with a member of the Six Nations. She has a friend who is particularly interested in her. Dr. Briggs, specialist, advises having her tonsils and adenoids removed.

Ariel Straats was shown to Mr. Scott when on a recent visit to the Reserve, she has an upper lip hanging down making a great disfigurement; her father was killed overseas and her mother neglects her family. Mrs. Boyce would like to have Nazel Elliott's operation take place soon. Ariel Straats sometime during the summer. I beg to recommend that this be done. I also enclose a report from Mrs. Boyce in regard to supplies of various kinds which she has received. I enclose a report of Dr. Briggs on these two cases.

I am

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

OTTAWA, January 24th, 1922.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 21st instant, enclosing a communication from the principal of the Mohawk Institute regarding the case of two pupils, viz: Hazel Elliott and Ariel Staats, who require medical treatment, and enclosing, as well, a statement from Dr. Bragg reporting on the treatment each requires, and the cost of same.

In reply I beg to say that the principal may arrange to have the medical treatment required undertaken in the case of both these girls. It is noted that the cost of the operation in the case of Hazel Elliott would be $25.00, and that of Ariel Staats would be $30.00, and the Department will approve of an expenditure to the above amounts in each case.

When the operations have been performed, properly certified vouchers should be forwarded covering the expenditures in both cases.

The principal can arrange for these operations when most convenient.

It is also noted in a report from Mrs. Boyce that she will be in need of about $2000 to pay salaries for the current month and some accounts for supplies. I may say that, if it be of any assistance to her, the Department would be prepared to make in advance of $2000 on the current quarter's grant to the school. If this is satisfactory, I will be pleased to have a communication from Mrs. Boyce to that effect.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

OTTAWA, January 24th, 1922.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 21st. in which enclosing a copy of a circular from the principal of the Mohawk Institute regarding the case of two pupils, viz: Hazel Elliott and Ariel Staat, who require medical treatment, and enclosing, as well, a statement from Dr. Brass reporting on the treatment now required in the case of the two.

In reply I have to say that the principal may arrange to have the medical treatment required undertaken in the case of both these girls. It is noted that the cost of the operation in the case of Hazel Elliott would be $75.00, and that of Ariel Staat would be $50.00, and the Department will approve of an expenditure to the tune of $125.00 in each case.

When the operations have been performed, properly certified vouchers should be forwarded covering the expenditure in both cases.

The policy I am carrying for the present is one when in doubt conveyance.

It is also noted in a report from Mrs. Royce that she will be in need of about $200 to pay off her current month's rent and some accounts for a little. I may say, that if it would be of any assistance to her, the Department would be prepared to make an advance of $200 on the current quarter's grant to the school. If this is satisfactory, I will be pleased to have a communication from Mrs. Royce to that effect.

Your obedient servant,

6th October 1923.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

I enclose a letter from the Dominion Artificial Limb Co., Toronto covering a statement of account with reference to Leo Winnie.

Acting upon your instructions I took this boy to Toronto and visited various stores with a view to selecting a suitable chair and ascertaining prices. When I called at the above firm they strongly advised me to give up the idea of a wheelchair and to bend my efforts to making the boy walk. They very properly argued that crutches would be a far less handicap than a wheelchair.

Finally they offered to keep the boy and to inform me as soon as he was able to move around and should they have been unsuccessful they would register no charges.

As this seemed a very reasonable offer and the boy was willing to remain in Toronto I left him. Ten days afterwards I received word to fetch the boy home and he has since been able to get around a considerable part of the day on his crutches. He has rapidly improved in his walking and can now go up and down stairs.

In connection with his education, I find that he is barely beyond the primary stage but we are unable to keep him at school all day as he soon tires of sitting still and begins to complain of headaches. On this account I have had a bench suitably placed in the workshop and he is learning to use tools. This week he has fitted new handles to beat-knives, etc., and judging from the work he has turned out I think I will be able to arrange for him to learn a trade.

This week we received a cheque from the local Indian Office as payment of his pension. As he is a very deceitful boy and provides tobacco for other boys whenever he has money I have returned this cheque with the request that it be allowed to accumulate for the boy here as he will probably need some funds when he leaves us.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Library and Archives Canada / Bibliothèque et Archives Canada
www.bac-lac.gc.ca
Ottawa, Oct. 10, 1923.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your report on the activities and progress of the work at the Mohawk Institute during the quarter ended September 30th, last.

In reply I beg to say that this report has been read with interest and we are pleased to note that the general work at the school has progressed satisfactorily. We note that the children returned promptly from their summer holidays and have now settled down to the regular classroom activities and routine work of the school. We are pleased that the improvements which were carried out to the building during the past summer have greatly added to the comfort and convenience of the staff and pupils.

Regarding the account which you submitted, from the Dominion Artificial Limb Co., Toronto, for the equipment supplied by them for Leo Winnie, I have to inform you that this is being forwarded to Lt. Col. C. H. Morgan, Indian Agent at Brantford. He is being requested to have the account attached to proper voucher forms, certified and returned to the Department, when payment will be made. We are pleased to note that, as a result of the equipment supplied by the above firm, this boy's condition has been very greatly improved and that he is bending his efforts to walk. The securing of the equipment for this boy is approved, as well as your action in having his pension money retained for him until he leaves the school.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

S. Rogers, Esq.,
Principal, Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.

25th October 1924.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

I have now had the honour to report to you, the medical officer, who has been called upon to report their case.

George Hill (807 Upper Mohawk 188.) This boy has been badly crippled by rheumatism and has not improved under treatment or proper care. A further examination today revealed that his condition was worse than at first sight. The doctor recommended further treatment and alterations in the environment to be made.

Alexander Allen (67, Upper Mohawk) has been suffering from rheumatism for many years and has been unable to work for some time. His condition has deteriorated and he is now in need of immediate attention.

In conclusion, I would urge you to take prompt action to ensure the welfare of these individuals.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Mohawk Institute
Brantford, Ont.
26th October 1924.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

I have to report that today it was necessary to call the doctor to Paulah Snake (0865, Moravian 157) who has been suffering ear pains since a slight attack of measles about three weeks ago.

A careful examination resulted in an ear specialist being called who pronounced a serious mastoid infection and the necessity of an immediate operation. Owing to the emergency of the case I immediately sent the child to the hospital.

I have just talked to Dr. MacIntosh who recommended the child's admission, and asked him to inform the parents.

Will you please let me have instructions to complete the settlement of expenses incurred.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

[Seal]
Ottawa, October 29th, 1924.

/Sir!

Replying to your letter of the 26th instant, I beg to inform you that your action in having Pupil No. 0562, Beulah Snake, who has developed a serious mastoid infection, sent to the hospital for an immediate operation is approved.

I have also your letter of the 25th instant, regarding the case of two boys, viz., George Hill, #807; and John Alexander Olley, #781, who require operations, the former for the removal of enlarged tonsils and the latter for hernia. You may arrange to have these two boys placed in the hospital and the necessary operations performed.

I shall be pleased if you will state what terms you were able to arrange with the hospital and the fees charged, also the fees that will be charged by the doctor who performs the operations. Accounts covering the hospital charges, doctor's fees, etc., should be obtained in duplicate, and you should certify thereon that the services mentioned have been performed, and the prices charged fair and just. You should then forward the accounts for payment. In future, when requesting authority in cases of pupils requiring operations, please state the fees charged by both the hospital and the doctor who operates. It is considered that all operations of a minor nature should be performed by the regular doctor without extra cost.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

With reference to some of these items, you ask for,

2000 - A.B.S.& C. Pills - We have quoted you chocolate coated Compressed Tablets. The same applies to Blauds Co. pills.

LaGrippe Pills - We have quoted you on chocolate coated Coryza Tablets. There is no such thing as C.C. LaGrippe pills that we know of.

Wampoles Cod Liver Oil - We are quoting our own Morrh-Vin-Ol with Hypophosphites and Malt, which we believe to be equal to anything manufactured.

Aspirin Tablets - You ask for 2 lbs. These are sold by the thousand. There are 1000 tablets to the lb.

Sterile Gauze - You ask for 3 lbs. - We are quoting 5 yd. packages Gauze is not sold by the lb.

Bed Bug Poison - You ask for one gallon and we are quoting special preparation Bichloride of Mercury, Wood Alcohol and Turpentine.

Aluminum Hot Water Bottles - We cannot supply you with Aluminum, we can supply you with Composition Metal Water Bottle, almost as light as Aluminum and this is what we are quoting on.

We hope the above prices will secure us your business, which will have our prompt and careful attention.

Yours very truly,

INGRAM & BELL LIMITED,

30th January 1925.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

With further reference to 861 Reuben Fox who underwent an operation for Mastoid infection the latest reports from the Doctor is that although this operation was successful there is little hope for the boy's recovery as it has been discovered that the lad is suffering from Tubercular Meningitis.

You will remember that some weeks ago I wired to the effect that Reuben was in very grave condition. Following your reply wire the father arrived and stayed for two days. So much did the boy improve that the Doctor thought a complete recovery would result but for about ten days Reuben has been puzzling everyone as although the mastoid healed well he made no improvement physically. A septic condition was indicated and I asked Dr. Morrison to join in consultation with Drs. Brear and Palmer. After a complete examination it was decided to draw some fluid from Reuben's spine and the tests show him to be subject to the above malady. In this case, there is nothing can be done to result in recovery. I am sending a copy of this letter to Agent McCookin in order that he may inform the father and should any emergency arise pending your instructions I will wire him to arrange for father's presence at bedside.

As this is the first case of its kind that has occurred during
my time at the Mohawk would you be good enough to give me your instructions as to procedure in case of death.

Nothing that could have been done for Reuben has been left undone and I am very grateful to the nurses at the hospital who have been extremely kind.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Ottawa, January 31, 1925.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 30th instant, I may say the Department regrets to learn of the serious illness of Reuben Fox, a pupil from the Caradoc Agency. I observe you state you are sending a copy of your letter to Mr. McCookin in order that he may inform the boy's father in the matter. In the event of Reuben Fox's death, his remains may be sent to his home, in which case you should communicate immediately with Mr. McCookin.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean
Acting Deputy and Secretary.

S. Rogers, Esq.,
Principal,
Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.
Ottawa, January 31, 1925.

Sir,

(Incld.)

Enclosed herewith you will find copy of a letter of today's date which the Department has written to Mr. Rogers, Principal of the Mohawk Institute, as the result of his report that Reuben Fox, an Indian boy from your Agency, who is ill, is not likely to recover. If the boy dies and action such as arranged for is taken, you may submit a voucher in due course to the Department for payment.

I may add that no unnecessary expense should be incurred in connection with the funeral; and if the father is in a position to bear such expense he should be required to do so.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Thos. McGookin, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Nunney, Ont.

February
First
1925.

Re Buelah Snake, Mohawk Institute.

The above named girl on admission to Hospital was undoubtedly suffering from acute mastoiditis of the right ear. Temperature 102, resp. 22, pulse 100. The right ear was displaced downwards and forward, marked swelling over whole of the mastoid region which fluctuated tenderness on pressure over the mastoid antrum and tip. From the external auditory meatus there was a very profuse purulent discharge and the posterior canal wall was sagging.

After necessary preparation the patient was taken to the operating room, the usual mastoid incision being made which disclosed a large subperiosteal abscess leading from a fistula in the bone. On removing the body of the mastoid bone it was found to be very necrotic and communicated freely with the antrum. All the diseased bone was removed and free drainage established, the wound was then packed with gauze and a paracentesis of the drum was done to permit of drainage from the middle ear.

The wound healed per primum and was quite closed in about two weeks time.
February
First
1925.

Re Buelah Snake, Mohawk Institute.

The above named girl on admission to Hospital was undoubtedly suffering from acute mastoiditis of the right ear. Temperature 102°, resp. 22°, pulse 100. The right ear was displaced downwards and forward, marked swelling over whole of the mastoid region which fluctuated, tenderness on pressure over the mastoid antrum and tip. From the external auditory meatus there was a very profuse purulent discharge and the posterior canal wall was sagging.

After necessary preparation the patient was taken to the operating room, the usual mastoid incision being made which disclosed a large subperiosteal abscess leading from a fistula in the bone. On removing the body of the mastoid bone it was found to be very necrotic and communicated freely with the antrum. All the diseased bone was removed and free drainage established, the wound was then packed with gauze and a paracentesis of the drum was done to permit of drainage from the middle ear.

The wound healed per primum and was quite closed in about two weeks time.
The Mohawk Institute,
Brantford.

S. Rogers, P.Q.,
Principal,
Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.
14th June 1926.

The Superintendent,
Indian Education.
Ottawa.

Sir,

I have to report that 0795 Gladys Staats a pupil of this school is, according to our Medical Officer, in a very serious stage of tuberculosis.

This girl has for some time given us considerable anxiety and we have had the M.O. thoroughly examine her on several occasions. Until today he has found no cause for anxiety but now he states that there are very definite symptoms of the malady and he advises her speedy removal from the institution.

We have made enquiries and find that this girl's grandparents are in very poor and needy circumstances, the mother is dead and the father worthless.

May I please have your instructions regarding the disposal of Gladys. We are continuing to give her every opportunity to be out of doors and finding her light occupation in the garden and flower beds.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Rogers.
Ottawa, June 18, 1926.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 14th instant, reporting the serious condition of health of pupil No. 0795, Gladys Stans, of the Mohawk Institute. We note the medical officer states that she has very definite symptoms of tuberculosis and advises her removal from the institution.

We are making enquiry as to what arrangements can be made to have this girl placed in a sanitarium. You will be informed, either by the authorities of the sanitarium or the Department, as to when she can be accepted. Her discharge from your institution is granted and will take effect from the date she leaves the school.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN
J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

P. Rogers, Esq.,
Principal,
Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.
Ottawa, June 19th, 1926.

Sir—

I beg to say it has been reported to the Department that an Indian girl named Gladys Watts, who is a pupil of the Mohawk Institute, recently developed symptoms of tuberculosis, and it has been suggested that she be afforded treatment in a sanitarium. The Department, therefore, is desirous of having her enter the Mountain Sanitarium at Hamilton to receive the attention which her case requires. Kindly state whether she can be received as a patient and if so upon what date she will be admitted, it being understood that the Department will be responsible for payment in the case.

It is of course desirable to have the child placed in the Sanitarium as soon as possible. Kindly, therefore, let me hear from you without delay.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Assistant Deputy & Secretary.

Superintendent,
Mountain Sanitarium,
Hamilton,
Ontario.
Ottawa, June 19th, 1926.

Sir:-

Referring to letter to you of the 18th instant I may say that the Department is endeavouring to make arrangements to have Gladys Stants receive treatment for tuberculosis in the Mountain Sanitarium, Hamilton. If arrangements to this end can be made you will be advised without delay. In the meantime the child should remain at the school, but if the doctor considers it necessary she should be isolated from the other pupils.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Assistant Deputy & Secretary.

S. Roberts, Esq.,
Principal,
Mohawk Institute,
BRANTFORD,
Ontario.

Above mentioned was operated on July 26th,
1926. Diagnosis - an acute Appendix. Appen-

Ottawa, November 6th, 1926.

Sir:

Referring to letter to you of the 29th October 1924 in which the Department granted authority to have John Alexander Olley, a pupil of the Mohawk Institute, placed in the hospital, and referring also to an account dated the 6th November, 1924, from the Brantford General Hospital where the boy received treatment, I beg to say the Department is in receipt of an account of $100.00 from Dr. Morrison who apparently performed an operation for hernia. In a case of double hernia the Department allows a fee of $90.00. In other cases of hernia where operation is necessary a fee of $75.00 is allowed. Seemingly a double operation was not performed in this case and, therefore, it would seem that the charge should not exceed $75.00. You should submit a certified voucher to the Department covering the amount payable. The Doctor's account should be attached thereto.

The Doctor has stated in a report attached to his account that Dr. Palmer, Sr., acted as Anesthetist in this case and that Dr. Palmer, Jr., assisted. If these doctors are entitled to payment for services rendered, the Department should be informed. I may remark that the fee payable for an assistant surgeon at a major operation is $10.00, and the fee for the administration of an anesthetic at a major operation is $10.00.

Dr. Morrison has forwarded also an account of

S. Roberts, Esq.,
Principal,
Mohawk Institute,
BRANTFORD,
Ontario.
$100.00 for services to J. Montour who was operated upon for Appendicitis. The fee which the Department allowed for an operation of this nature is $75.00. You may submit a certified voucher for that amount to which the Doctor's account should be attached. It is stated that Dr. Palmer assisted at the operation and that Dr. Calder administered the anesthetic.

The Department is prepared to consider making payment to these doctors when in receipt of certified vouchers on their behalf.

The accounts above referred to which were submitted by Dr. Morrison are transmitted herewith.

INCL.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Assistant Deputy & Secretary.

Dear Sirs:

In answer to your communication Sept. 14, we are pleased to quote you Drugs for Mohawk Institute, Brantford, per enclosed list.

We hope to be favored with your valued order which will have our prompt and careful attention.
