15th March 1928.

The Superintendent,
Indian Education,
Ottawa.

Sir,

876, Jesse Cayuga, a pupil of this school, has for some time been in poor health. Yesterday, Dr. Alexander, of the Trent Sanitarium kindly examined him and discovered traces of tuberculosis.

The boy's condition is not by any means grave but the doctor states that he should have three months Preventorium treatment as he is proving very rapidly and is in a weakened condition. At the present time his parents are separated. If this were not the case I would think that three or four months sick leave with instructions for his care would be sufficient to re-establish his health. I understand the parents are at loggerheads but the Local office will have to make a decision regarding the custody of the children.

As both parents are visiting the boy I will endeavour to arrange for them to get together and try to arrange for the boy's care. I will let you twice of the result of this meeting.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

[Stamp: Schools Branch MAR 19 1928]

BRANTFORD ONT 25 1123A

SECY DEPT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

OTTAWA ONT 1/21

EVA LICKERS SERIOUSLY ILL DOCTORS ORDER HER TO BRANTFORD HOSPITAL

IMPOSSIBLE TO SEND TO OHSWEKEN

S ROGERS MOHAWK INSTITUTE.
January 25th, 1929

S. Rogers, Esq.,
Mohawk Institute, Brantford, Ont.

Send Eva Lickers to Brantford Hospital.

J.D. WoLean
Chg. Indian Dept.
25th January 1928.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

With further reference to my wire today relative to Eva Jane Lickers Oq77, a pupil of this school, I have to report that this pupil was admitted to the Brantford General Hospital and I have just had a message that she has recovered from the state of coma in which she had been for several hours prior to her admission.

This girl has been under treatment and observation for diabetes for eighteen months and yesterday was brought to me apparently suffering from a slight attack of pleurisy. She was immediately given medicine and sent to bed. Last evening she was again treated but this morning she was found to be in an serious condition. The Doctor was summoned and was here immediately; insulin was administered and her removal to hospital arranged.

Owing to the fact that Mrs Rogers is in bed again it was impossible to provide the necessary care and attention that Eva needed, hence my wire for approval for her admission to the local hospital. Ice storms and bad roads and the girl's condition made it impossible to take her to the Lady Willingdon Hospital.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

32-0-13
January 29th, 1929.

Incl.

Dear Sir,

I have your letter of the 25th instant, reporting on the case of Eva Jane Lickers, recently admitted to Brantford Hospital.

I enclose account forms to be used by the hospital in this connection. You should inform the authorities that the Department desires accounts at the end of each month, and in this instance you should certify them before they are forwarded to Ottawa for payment.

Yours very truly,

J.D. McLean
Assistant Deputy and Secretary

Rogers, Esq.,
Principal,
Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.
26th January 1929.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs.

Sir,

Eva Jane Lickers (0877) passed away at the Brantford Hospital at 5 o'clock last evening. Through the assistance of Mr. Winger of Hagersville we were able to get in touch with her uncle John Herkimer who was able to reach the Hospital in time to see her. Owing to the storm all telephone communications in this district were out of commission and the uncle proceeded to make his own funeral arrangements.

I am taking a party of the girl's friends to the funeral on Sunday at 2 p.m.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

There are a number of pupils here who have defective eyes or teeth. There is also a lad who was taken by the school physician to have his arm X-rayed. Please inform me as to how I should proceed in such cases.

Yours truly,

Horace W. Snell,
Principal.

An amount is paid $100 from School funds & Principal.

Account for X-Ray Ottawa Dept will let him have the names of eye affected district.
September 19th, 1929.

Dear Sir,

Your letter of September 16th asking for drugs in regard to medical and dental services has been referred to me. You will receive under separate cover a package of circulars and forms which will indicate the regular procedure in such cases. Under ordinary circumstances any pupils who go to hospitals should, of course, go to the Brantford Reserve Hospital and will there be attended by Dr. Davis. In emergency cases, or where the pupil's disease requires the attention of a Specialist in Brantford, he should be admitted to the Brantford Hospital and the account forwarded as indicated on the hospital account form.

You may expect to receive special further instructions within a short time as to the procedure to be followed in the case of children with defective eyes and teeth.

Yours truly,

E.L. Stone, M.B.,
Director of Medical Services

Rev. Horace W. Snell,
Principal,
Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.
Oct. 1-29.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

We have a pupil, Mary Batiste, who was brought in last Wednesday with a sore eye. She had just been examined by Dr. Davis who gave her a wash for the eye. The nurse has been attending to her regularly, but yesterday the eye had become worse so I took her to Dr. Palmer, who ordered her to be taken immediately to Dr. Brass, a specialist. He found a very bad infection which will need a course of treatment to save the eye. I would like authority, therefore, to continue the treatment.

There are a number of pupils who have defective eyesight. Some of them are very bad so that the teachers have noticed it. Will you please authorise the securing of glasses for them? I am enclosing list of names.

I would suggest that we should have Dr. Brass come down and test all the children's eyes as is done in the Public Schools.

I have to report, also that we have a few mild cases of Mumps. They have been reported and are being treated according to instructions from Dr. Palmer.

Yours faithfully,

Horace W. Smith,
Principal.
LIST OF CHILDREN WITH DEFECTIVE EYESIGHT.

Neil Garlow
Raymond Garlow (very bad)
Lorne Cayuga
Alma Henry
Phoebe Clause
Isabel Hill
Lottie Gibson
Dorothy Vanevery
October 8th, 1929

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,

Dear Sirs— "Eyes and teeth of children at Mohawk Institute and reserve schools":

When in Ottawa recently I brought to the attention of Dr. Stone and Mr. Perrier the urgent necessity of some action being taken to provide treatment for eyes and teeth to Six Nation children.

I have received a call this morning from Rev. Mr. Snell of the Mohawk Institute who states that he has several urgent cases of both eyes and teeth which he considers can be saved by immediate treatment.

One girl has an infected eye which is so serious that he has assumed the responsibility himself of having it treated by Dr. Bragg. There are about twelve children in the Institute whose eyes are so defective that
The teachers have discovered that they are unable to read the figures on the blackboard and there are also numbers of children who are in danger of losing permanent teeth almost as soon as they appear.

I would therefore ask for authority in such cases to send these children to Dr. Bragg and some qualified dentist or have appointments made for an establishment of permanent clinics.

Your obedient servant,

Lt. Col. C.E. Morgan,
Supt. Six Nations.
Ottawa, October 10, 1929.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the last instant, with reference to Mary Batiste, a pupil of the Mohawk Institute, whom you found it necessary to take to an eye specialist in the city. Your action is approved, and this specialist may continue the treatment.

As indicated in letter of the 19th ultimo, the Department has taken steps to ascertain the name of a dentist and eye specialist who can be given the work required by the pupils of the Mohawk Institute. As soon as possible, you will receive instructions in this matter.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. Horace W. Shell,
Principal, Mohawk Indian Res. School,
Brantford, Ont.
Ottawa, October 10, 1929.

Sir:

I have your 10B/29/942 of the 5th instant, with reference to a dentist and an eye specialist for the pupils of the Mohawk Institute. This matter is being attended to by the Department and, as soon as possible, instructions will be directed to the Reverend Principal. I have already written him approving of his action in taking one girl, whose case was urgent, to Dr. Bragg, an eye specialist of Brantford.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Ottawa, October 16, 1929.

Mr. [signature]

When the services of a dentist are required for the pupils of the Mohawk Institute, at Brantford, Dr. C. T. Moyle, 7½ Market St., Brantford, may be employed, and if an eye specialist is required at Brantford Dr. H. R. Miller, s/o Brantford Clinic, Brant Ave., Brantford, may be employed.

D. S. G. I. A.
Ottawa, October 17, 1929.

Reverend Sir:

I wish to refer further to your letter of the first instant, regarding the services of an eye specialist. Whenever the pupils of the Mohawk Institute require the services of an eye specialist, please call in, or take the pupils to Dr. H. R. Miller, of the Brantford Clinic, Brant Ave. When the services of a dentist are necessary, you may engage Dr. C. T. Moyle, 7½ Market St.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. H. W. Small,
Principal,
Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.

BRANTFORD CLINIC
34 BRANT AVENUE

BRANTFORD, ONT., January 7, 1930.

The Minister of Interior,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

In rendering my account for work done at the Mohawk Institute, Brantford, I find no scheduled price for examination of patients. I have examined each patient to ascertain what he may need. My charge in private practice is $3.00 for similar examination. Will you please let me know what you think a fair fee would be in this case.

In mailing the report, should we list each individual's name, or just the number of children examined?

Thanking you in anticipation of an early reply, we are,

Sincerely yours,

The Brantford Clinic.

HRM/HT.
January 17th, 1930.

Dear Sir,

Your letter of January 7th addressed to the Minister of the Interior has been referred to me for reply.

I find it difficult to know just what you refer to by an examination. The Department's fee for an ordinary office call is $2.00, for refraction without mydriatic $4.00, and for refraction with mydriatic $5.00. I do not know how many pupils you have examined, nor how complete your examination was in each case. A cursory look over a large number of children to see whether they had enlarged tonsils or some obvious trouble in the ear or nose would not, I should think, call for a very large fee for each child, but if the children were brought to you suffering from some defect and you made a thorough examination of each one, I should think it might be worth $2.00 each. In a case where the examination led to an operation, it might well be included in the fee for the operation. If you will put down in your account the services you performed for each child, I will try to do justice to you in my recommendations.

Yours very truly,

H.R. Miller, Esq., M.D.,
The Brantford Clinic,
54 Brant Ave.,
Brantford, Ont.

E.L. Stone, M.B.,
Director of Medical Services.

Dear Sir,

I am enclosing an account from Dr. Fraser for services rendered for some time back. I have submitted the statement to Mr. and Mrs. Rogers and they state that the services were rendered and that from time to time accounts were forwarded to Ottawa.

Principal.
Ottawa, February 20, 1930.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the first instant, enclosing an account from Dr. Bragg for services rendered to the pupils of the Mohawk Institute. I regret that the Department cannot consider payment of accounts for services prior to 1929. All of the items for the period, but one, are small. The mastoid operation for the pupil Beniah Snake was paid for by cheque No. 2853 for $100, dated September 19, 1925. The cheque was sent direct to Dr. Bragg. If he believes he did not receive this cheque, please inform the Department and I will be glad to have it returned to him for examination, showing his endorsement.

With reference to the services for the year 1929, you may inform Dr. Bragg that he should bill Mrs. Rogers personally for her visits. The treatment for Mary Baptiste was authorized and it will be in order to submit an account, in duplicate, for this service and also for the two office calls for the two Cayuga boys, provided they were sent by the Mohawk Institute. Concerning the mastoid operation for Ralph Stewart, which I believe should read Ralph Smart, the fee allowed by the Department is $100; but the circumstances concerning this operation must be explained for the Department's consideration. You should indicate who sent the boy to Dr. Bragg. After you have seen Dr. Bragg and when your reply is before the Department, consideration to the last items on the account will be given.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. H. W. Snell, B. A.,
Principal, Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.

February 26th, 1930.

Sir,

The Department has received an account from Dr. Miller for examination of the eyes of several pupils at your school and from this account it appears that Dr. Miller is undertaking to examine all the pupils. I may say that it was not the intention that there should be an examination of this kind at the present time. The instruction which was sent you on October 17th had reference rather to send pupils who might be referred to Dr. Miller by recommendation of Dr. Palmer. Dr. Miller's present account will be dealt with, but I must request you to defer future work of this kind until authority is issued.

Your obedient servant,

A.P. MacKenzie
Acting Assistant Deputy and Secretary

Rev. H.F. Snell,
Principal,

Brantford, Ont.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter No.32-0-13-36th inst.

I regret that I misunderstood the authorization of Oct. 17th.

I might explain that all the children were examined in the Autumn for eye and nose affections and while many were found to have bad tonsils very few suffered from afflictions as to their sight.

If I remember rightly, Dr. Miller's bill did not specify a fee for this general examination but left that to the discretion of the Department. Dr. Bragg examined several of the pupils but, as the appointment went to another Doctor, he made no charge for the services he had rendered in this regard. When I was in Ottawa I mentioned to Dr. Stone that I had had the children examined and that those who had bad throats, to the number of about 30, were being sent to Lady Willington Hospital for tonsillectomies and he approved heartily. There were only about ten who were found to be in need of glasses. These have been all attended to and I think all but two or three are included in the accounts already forwarded by Dr. Miller.

I may say that Dr. Moyle has similarly examined the teeth of all the children and several of them have already had their teeth attended to. There are some still who are badly in need of attention. I shall send no more until I have further authority though I hope it will be given as they suffer a good deal when the teeth are not looked after. Am I supposed to have authority from Dr. Palmer for attention to teeth too?

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Principal.
Mr. Smith,

I think there are no receipts now.

[Signature]

[Signature]
Ottawa, March 6, 1930.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 28th ultimo, with reference to treatment for eye trouble and dental attention in connection with pupils at the Mohawk Institute. Whenever Dr. Palmer believes that pupils should go to the eye specialist or to the dentist, you may send them to Dr. Miller and to Dr. Moyle, respectively. The accounts which you have forwarded are being paid. If, at any time in emergencies, there is no convenient opportunity for the medical officer to examine a pupil who is in need of immediate attention, you may use your own judgment, of course. The point I wished to make in my letter of the 28th ultimo is that it is not the intention to have specialists examine all pupils in a school.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. H. W. Snell, B.A.,
Principal,
Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Ottawa, March 11, 1930.

Dr. Stone,

We are advised that Dr. C. T. Moyle, of Brantford, is unable to continue the dental work for the pupils of the Mohawk Institute, and, therefore, when any such work is required at this institute or at Brantford, kindly note that either Dr. Edward Hart or Dr. Wilfred Hart should be employed. These dentists are father and son and their offices are in the Bank of Hamilton Chambers.

D. S. G.-I. A.
Ottawa, March 13, 1930.

Sir:

Referring to official letter to you dated the 6th instant, I have to inform you that the Department is advised that Dr. G. T. Moyle is unable to continue the dental work for the pupils of the Mohawk Institute, and, therefore, when Dr. Palmer believes that any of the pupils require dental attention, either Dr. Edward Hart or Dr. Wilfred Hart should be employed under the same arrangement and terms as allowed Dr. Moyle.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. H. W. Snell, B.A.,
Principal,
Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.

September 30th, 1930.

Sir,

All authorized dental work required for Indians of the Six Nations Reserve should be referred to Dr. Frederick ... Landymore, of Brantford, and those requiring the services of a specialist for diseases of the eye, ear, nose and throat should be referred to Dr. Gordon Hanna, Brantford.

Yours very truly,

Lt. Col. C.B. Morgan,
Indian Superintendent,
Six Nations Reserve,
Brantford, Ont.
Ottawa, October 2, 1930.

Reverend Sir:

In future, when the Department authorizes the services of an Eye, Ear, Nose and Throat Specialist for pupils of the Mohawk Institute, you should engage Dr. Gordon Hanna, 58 Brant Avenue. In the event of emergency purchase of drugs, you may deal with either A. W. Smiley, 116 Market St., or N. M. Lee, 103 Dalhousie St. Of course, your regular supply of medicines, etc., should be the subject of requisitions to the Department.

I also wish to make a new arrangement for dental services for pupils of the Mohawk Institute. At your convenience, will you please interview Dr. F. W. Landymore, 70 Eagle Ave., and explain the nature of the services required. When there are a number of children who should visit the dentist, the Department expects special rates. In the case of other schools, we allow $1.00 per amalgam filling and 25¢ for each extraction when considerable work is necessary. Of course, we charge only when work is done on pupil to the dentist; we are prepared to pay $1.50 for fillings and 50¢ for extractions. Dental services other than extractions and fillings are not authorized, except in special cases, which should be brought to the Department's attention. In the case of temporary teeth, extractions only are allowed. After you have seen Dr. Landymore, you might report to the Department, indicating if he is willing to undertake the work.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. H. W. Smith, B.A.,
Principal,
Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir,

I have interviewed Dr. Landymore in connection with dental work as suggested in your letter No.32-0-13, Oct. 2, and he is willing to accept the work of the school.

In view of the fact that decayed teeth in children are not brought to our attention until they are so far decayed as to ache, and that then they are often too far gone to be preserved I would request that all the children should be examined so that both the teeth and the pain may be saved. There would also be a saving in money as the pupils could be sent in groups thus securing the lowest price for the work.

Your obedient servant,

Principal.
Ottawa, October 23, 1930.

Rev. Sir:

Secretary.

Dear Sir,

Regarding dental services for the Indians of Holton I quote:

I have received the circular from H.W.S., copy of which is attached. The dental service is needed, but I do not think it will be necessary at this time. The dental work should be done by a dentist who is experienced in this type of work.

In conclusion, I believe that the dental service should be continued, but I do not think it will be necessary at this time.

Sincerely,

J.W. Landymore
Ottawa, October 30, 1930.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 20th instant, with reference to dental services for the pupils of the Mohawk Institute. For your first examination of all pupils, the Department is pleased to allow a nominal fee of $10. If synthetic porcelain filling is required in the case of anterior teeth, $1.50 per filling will be allowed. With reference to root treatment and the filling of roots of permanent teeth, I may say that the Department has never authorized this work to any extent - extraction is generally suggested. The Reverend Mr. Snell is receiving a copy of this letter, for his information and guidance.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKinnon,
Secretary.

Dental Surgeon,

Brantford, Ont.

Ottawa, November 21st, 1930.

Reverend Sir,

Dr. Landymore, dentist for the Mohawk Institute, has reported on his examination of the children. He informs me that a copy of his letter of the 15th instant has been forwarded to you. While it is not the general practice of the Department to allow root treatments or treatments for gum lesions or pyorrhea, the dentist's remarks in this instance have been noted and the Department is prepared to make an exception. You may authorize Dr. Landymore to proceed with the work as recommended. We note that the work previously authorized will cost, approximately, $600., and that the special work which is being authorized at this time will cost, approximately, $100. It is entirely probable that Dr. Landymore will not be able to complete this work in the immediate future and, as our funds are extremely limited this fiscal year end, in fact, are overassigned, I wish to suggest that he undertake the work at his convenience and forward his account, in duplicate, to you for your certificate on or about April 1st, next. Our new Vote will then be available and the account will be promptly paid. I am not corresponding with Dr. Landymore direct as, now that the arrangements are complete for this work, it can be handled entirely through your office.

Please instruct Dr. Landymore that his account, in duplicate, should show the amount of work done for each pupil - the pupils to be named.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. H. W. Snell, B. A.,
Principal,
Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.

I visited the Mohawk Institute unexpectedly at dinner time, taking Mr. Hilton Hill with me, on account of a report in circulation that the children were insufficiently fed. We found their dinner to consist of an abundance of good and tastefully cooked liver with brown gravy and I am of opinion that there is no truth whatever in the rumour.
Mohawk Institute.

Ottawa, February 2nd, 1931.

Reverend Sir,

With reference to Ida Isaacs - No. 0861; and Theresa Vanevery - No. 0962, I beg to say that the Department approves of the authority already given to you to have these children placed in a sanitarium at the earliest possible date. Please advise me when you have been successful in this regard.

They should be considered discharged from the Mohawk Institute from the date on which they are placed in the sanitarium. If, after treatment in the sanitarium, their condition improves to such an extent that they can return to school, application can then be made for the Department's approval of their readmission.

The accounts received in favour of the Brantford General Hospital for the chest plates will be paid.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Russell T. Harris,
Dept. of Indian Education.

Rev. H. W. Snell, B. A.,
Principal,
Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.
MEMORANDUM:

RE: Ida Isaacs - No. 961; and Theresa Vanevery - No. 962.

When I was at the Mohawk Institute on the 29th ultimo, the Principal, Rev. Mr. Snell, stated that the above two girls had not been well and he was sending them to the clinic to have them examined. Later in the day, Dr. Alexander, Superintendent of the Brant Sanitarium, requested authority to have a chest plate taken of each girl. I authorized these at a cost of $6.00 (regular charge $10.00) and I enclose the accounts, which I have signed.

Following examination of the plates, Dr. Alexander reported that these girls were suffering from T.B., their condition being rather serious and a menace to the health of the other pupils in the school. I, therefore, authorized the Principal to make immediate arrangements to have them placed in a sanitarium and he phoned the Superintendent of the Queen Alexandra Sanitarium, London, and it is hoped to have them placed in that institution early this week.

On File 32-0-10, a letter is being directed to Rev. Mr. Snell approving the placing of the children in the sanitarium mentioned and advising him that they are to be considered discharged from the Mohawk Institute from the date on which they are placed in the sanitarium.
February 6-31
Replying to 32-0-10, Feb. 2-31

Secretary, Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear sir:

Dear Sir,

I have to request you to furnish on repayment and send by freight prepaid the supplies mentioned in the attached list. The supplies are intended for the use of Indians of the Mohawk Institute, Six Nations Agency, and should be addressed to Rev. H.W. Snell, Principal, Mohawk Institute, Brantford, Ont.

[F.H. Paget]
Chief Accountant and Purchasing Agent

The Officer-in-Charge, Medical Stores, Department of Pensions and National Health, Ottawa.
Feb.20-31.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I took Ida Isaac No.0661 and Teresa X Vansvery No.0962 to the Queen Alexandra Sanatorium London, Ont. yesterday Feb.19th. I have therefore discharged them as from that date.

We have also found one boy definitely affected with T.B. Dr. Alexander recommends that he be placed immediately in a preventorium.

Two other pupils have been taken to the T.B. clinic but as one of them had been recently vaccinated and the other was suffering from a mild attack of pleurisy a definite diagnosis could not be made at the time, though the physician is suspicious of the presence of the disease.

I shall send them again to the clinic and report immediately if the report should be unfavourable.

Your obedient servant,

Horace W. Smith
Principal.
February 26th, 1931.

Reverend Sir,

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of February 20th reporting the admission of Ida Isaac and Teresa Vanover to sanatorium. If you can find accommodation for the boy referred to in the second paragraph of your letter, it will be advisable to have him admitted also. The Department will await further report on the cases of the other two pupils whom you have taken to the clinic.

Yours truly,

A.F. MacKenzie
Secretary

Rev. H.S. Snell,
Principal,
Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

There are at least five pupils who need attention to their eyes, 962 Herman Henhawk, 898 Raymond Garlow, 902 Neil Garlow, 943 George Lewis, 930 Jonas Smith, 9960 Phoebe Claus, 9964 Lovtia Gibson, and 9995 Eva Hill.

The teachers report that these children cannot see the blackboard. I would, therefore request authority to have their eyes examined and, if necessary, to have them fitted with glasses.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal.
Ottawa, March 28, 1931.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, informing the Department that at least eight pupils of the Mohawk Institute require to have their eyes examined and glasses supplied.

In this connection I have to say that, as advised in official letter dated October 2, 1930, you may have the pupils requiring attention examined by Dr. Gordon Hanna, 56 Brant Avenue, Brantford, and he should also arrange to supply the necessary glasses. It is not intended that an expensive type of glasses be supplied. It is considered that spectacles in strong mountings of cheap material, with flat lenses, would be satisfactory. The fee charged for the examination should also be as low as possible.

The Doctor should prepare an account, in duplicate, giving the names of the pupils examined, the fees charged in each case and also the cost of the glasses supplied each pupil. This account you should certify in the usual manner and forward to the Department for payment.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. H. W. Snell, B.A.,
Principal,
Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I am enclosing account from the Hospital re Dorothy Harkimer.

In explanation I may say that she was not fit to move to Lady Willingdon at first and at the order of Dr. Palmer she was put in the city hospital for three days shown. She was then taken to the Lady Willingdon on 15th inst.

I am exceedingly sorry to have to report that she died there on the 15th inst., from Tubercular Meningitis. She was one of our nicest and most promising pupils.

Your obedient servant,

Brantford, Ont., June 1st 1931.

A. P. MacKenzie, Esq.,
Secretary, Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Re: Dental Examination of pupils at the Mohawk Institute.

On April 15th and 22nd, dental examination was made of all pupils of the Mohawk Institute.

Out of 134 pupils examined, 37 required dental treatment.

Dental restoration for those 37 pupils as follows:

Amalgam fillings - 26
Amalgam fillings with root treatment - 5
Extractions - 6

42 percent of the work found necessary was among new pupils, 28 percent among pupils who were found O.K. on my first examination last October, the balance of the work was made up of simple pit or fissure cavities that had since developed.

The five defective teeth requiring special root treatment were among the new pupils.

There were no gum lesions, or unusual conditions found. Those pupils that received any treatment last fall, showed improvement in their general mouth condition, especially among the older pupils.

Since my second examination in April, all necessary work has been completed.

All of which is respectfully submitted.

[Signature]

[Stamp]
Dr. Gordon M. Hanna
BRANTFORD, ONTARIO

June 6, 1931

Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

By authorization of your department and at the request of Mr. Smith, I have recently examined thirty-three children of the local school in this town.

I am pleased to report that they are examined free from defective vision.

The expense incurred in connection with this case would be your burden.

As a token of my appreciation, may I request the grant of an additional reimbursement for each examination?

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

G.M.H.
Ottawa, June 11, 1931.

Rev. Sir:

The Department has received a communication from Dr. Gordon M. Hanna, Brantford, in which he states that he recently examined 13 children, pupils of the Mohawk Institute, and requested to be informed as to the fee allowed for such examination. Dr. Hanna is being informed that the fee usually allowed in the case of each child examined because of defective vision is not in excess of the sum of $5, and that he is to forward his account, in duplicate, covering the cost of the examination and, if any glasses were supplied by him, the cost of the glasses in each case. You should then certify the account and forward it to the Department for payment.

In connection with the examination for defective vision of any pupils in future, I have to request that, before any work of this nature is performed, you will first refer the matter to the Department and receive the necessary authority. You will be informed at that time of the name of the optician whose services you should employ.

The account of Dr. Landmore covering the cost of dental services recently performed by him has been received, and will be paid in due course. It is noted from the Dentist's letter accompanying the account that all necessary dental work has been completed. I may say that our funds for the present fiscal year are limited and no further dental or optical work should be carried out until the authority of the Department is first received.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. H. W. Snell,
Principal, Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.

Preston, Oct. 21st 1931.

To the Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir,

Re semi-annual Dental exam notice of natives of Yellow Point.

This examination was completed in April 1931, and the results are attached, Mr. Smith.

S. ....:

Number of natives examined: 184.
Number of natives treated: 88.

Work completed:
Number of new or existing cavities removed: 711
Number of incomplete fillings removed: 26
Number of extractions: 66
Number of teeth examined and no action taken: 11
Number of new fillings: 4
Number of new fillings filled: 1
Number of new fillings in need of repair: 2

Results:
Out of 184 natives examined, 121 had cavities.
44% of the cavities were filled.
The 15% of the cavities were removed.
The remaining 41% were left untreated due to lack of funds.

The following recommendations are made:
1. Increase the budget for dental work.
2. Provide more dental personnel.
3. Encourage regular dental check-ups.

G. L. Armstrong,
Acting Medical Officer.

[Signature]

F. W. Sandymore,

Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

In accordance with instructions in your letter No. 32-0-13, October 23rd, 1930, I have the teeth of the pupils examined and enclosed herewith Dr. Landrymore's report. I shall await further instructions before having the work indicated proceeded with. I would call attention to the fact that the cost of work required this time is about $200.00. Last year was recorded at the last examination and that I report the teeth of most of the pupils well cared for.

Your obedient servant,

Horace W. Smith
Principal.
Ottawa, November 7, 1931.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 31st ultimo, enclosing the report of Dr. Landymore on his examination of the pupils of the Mohawk Institute, and stating the dental work required by them.

In reply I have to say that you may arrange with Dr. Landymore to perform the dental work absolutely necessary at the present time. He will be allowed remuneration for this service at the same rate as previously paid. He should prepare a list giving the name of each pupil treated and the number of fillings and extractions performed in each case. He should also prepare his account, in duplicate, covering the cost of the dental work performed by him. This account you should certify in the usual manner and forward to the Department, along with the list showing the work carried out. This work may be undertaken at a time convenient to the Dentist and yourself. Please keep all costs for this work as low as possible.

I am returning herewith the duplicate copy of Dr. Landymore's report, together with a communication from the London Soap Company which you enclosed in your letter.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. H. W. Snell,
Principal, Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.

To The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

The semi-annual Dental examination of the pupils of the Mohawk Institute was completed in two half-days. Mr. Smith and Miss Margaret Snell assisted.

Summary of the examination follows:

Pupils examined 143.
requiring treatment 47.

Work required:
Amalgam fillings 71.
Porcelain 13.
Extractions 38.

The general mouth condition of the pupils is very bad, particularly among the girls. The children have each been given a toothbrush, their interest and cooperation, Mr. Smith, Nurse Mrs. Smith and Miss Snell in charge. The chair-side instruction the pupils have received in the care of the teeth and gums, is largely responsible for the interest and marked improvement that has taken place.

The approximate fee for work outlined, including examination - $100.

All of which is respectfully submitted.

[Signature]

J.M. Sanderson
The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Dr. Landymore has completed the examination of the teeth of the pupils and I am enclosing his report and hope that I may receive authorisation for the carrying out of the treatment necessary at an early date, so that the work may be completed before school closes. You will note that the amount of treatment required is decreasing with the regular attention being given and the children are also taking better care of their teeth.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal.
Ottawa, June 7, 1932.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the last instant, enclosing a report from Dr. Landymore regarding the pupils of the Mohawk Institute who require dental attention.

In reply I have to say that you may arrange with Dr. Landymore to carry out the work required as mentioned in his report, viz., 71 amalgam fillings, 13 porcelain fillings and 35 extractions. The fees allowed will be at the rate of $1 per amalgam filling, $1.50 per porcelain filling and 25 cents for each extraction. In the case of temporary teeth, extractions only are allowed.

The Dentist should prepare an account, in triplicate, giving the name of each pupil treated and the work done in each case. This account should be certified by you and forwarded to the Department for payment. The total expenditure for dental services at this time should not exceed approximately $100.

You should arrange to have the dental work completed before the summer holidays begin.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. H. W. Snell, B.A.,
Principal, Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.
Ottawa, June 10, 1938.

Sir:

The report of Dr. J. J. Wall, trachoma specialist engaged by the Department, shows that Gladys Curley, No. 0940, of the Mohawk Institute, is the only one at the school that is suffering from active trachoma. It is highly desirable that this school be kept free from this disease, and the Department wishes to arrange for her discharge. The Director of Medical Services states that she may be placed temporarily in the Lady Willington hospital. Will you explain to the Reverend Mr. Snell and take this action, not later than the end of the school year. Dr. Stone is corresponding direct with Dr. Davis in the matter.

This pupil was the subject of your 102/27/1800, of October 25, 1927. It appears that her parents were Benjamin and Rachel Curley, who, at that time, had not been living together for several years. Della Curley, pupil No. 0939, a year or two older, is a sister. In 1927, the children were living with their grandmother, Mrs. Nancy Curley, who was then a housekeeper for a white man by the name of Robinson, who lived on the borders of the reserve. I find that in July last an 11-year-old brother of these girls, Alvan, was admitted to the Mohawk Institute and is now pupil No. 960. He was taken from the Onida Reserve. He had been living with David Williams for 4 years, having been left there and deserted by the mother. The application for Alvan was forwarded from your office some time in the latter part of July, last. I think you will find on your files a letter to David Williams, of Munsey, in the matter.

The Department wishes you to give some thought regarding where this girl could be placed upon discharge from hospital. You might report in due course in this connection.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Russell F. Parrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Lt. Col. G. K. Morgan,
Indian Superintendent,
Brantford, Ont.
June 13-32.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

On the order of Dr. Palmer, I have sent Thelma Powless, No. 0974 to the Brantford Hospital. She was playing at the Maypole and the girls stood up on her in some way and she had her leg broken.

The break is in the femur about three inches above the knee and is riding. An X-Ray was necessary and the physician reports that she will have to be kept at the Hospital for some time. As soon as she can be moved we shall bring her back here or transfer her to the Lady Willington Hospital as may be recommended by the doctor.

Your obedient servant,

Nov. 4th 1932.

To The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Re Dental Service for pupils of the Mohawk Institute.

The semi-annual Dental examination of all pupils was completed in three half-days, with the assistance of nurse, Mrs. Smith.

Summary:

Number of pupils examined . . . 150.
Number requiring Dental treatment . . . 66.

Following Dental Work necessary:

Amalgam fillings . . . 236.
Porcelain . . . 14.
Extractions . . . 71.
Amalgam filling and root treatment . . . 52.
Porcelain . . . 3.

One pupil with pyorrhea will need two or three gum treatments.
Three pupils with gingivitis will need each one gum treatment.

Remarks:

Of the 66 pupils needing dental work, 25 are new pupils.
The remaining 41 pupils show one, two or three small or "lesser" cavities, which have developed during the year.
About 65% of the work outlined above is among the new pupils.
All teeth examined showing root involvement, also the four cases of gum trouble are among the new pupils.
The examination, just completed, shows a marked contrast in the mouth condition of the old and new pupils. The 125 pupils that have received Dental attention, and instruction in the care of the mouth and teeth, show, generally, a splendid result of this service. Much credit is due to the nurse, Mrs. Smith, and the teachers for their efforts in the follow-up work of instruction in the daily care of mouth hygiene.

The contrast between the old and new pupils is more noticeable this year, than on former examinations, and is due to the fact that the new pupils this fall are of a more advanced age, and show, clearly, the results of mouth neglect and the ravages of dental decay. Only one girl examined showed no dental defects. Ten of the 25 new pupils show an exceptionally bad mouth condition. These ten need immediate attention, and are a menace to the health of the other pupils. Their mouth conditions are in such a state, that it is impossible for them to prevent spreading infection in the classroom and dormitory. One boy in particular, Oswald Henry, age 15, shows 7 permanent teeth in a more or less putrescent root condition. Unless this boy receives immediate and careful dental treatment, he will be in line for artificial dentures.

The approximate fee for the work outlined, including examination, would cost $400.00.

All of which is respectfully submitted.

[Signature]

F. W. Landymore, D.D.S.
Brantford, Ontario,
November 5, 1932

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing the report from Dr. Landymore, the school dentist, re semi dental clinic for pupils of the Institute.

You will observe that so far as the new pupils are concerned, these 23, some of whom have teeth in very bad condition, are responsible for two thirds of the work required to be done. As for the pupils who have been here, the examination shows very satisfactory conditions and a vast improvement.

I should like to mention that Dr. Landymore takes a special interest in our pupils and recently he arranged for the showing of a very interesting and helpful film to the children, along with an address from Dr. Wilson who is visiting most of the city schools in Ontario on this health campaign.

As some of the pupils have conditions which need immediate attention if the teeth are to be saved, I trust that I may receive authorization to proceed with the work at the earliest date possible.

Had we not had a number of new pupils this year the amount required would have been considerably below that of former years.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Principal
Ottawa, November 16, 1932.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, enclosing the report of Dr. Landymore regarding the pupils of the Mohawk Institute who require dental attention. It is noted that the greater number of pupils in need of dental attention are the new pupils who entered the school since the beginning of the present school year.

Our funds this year for dental work are extremely limited, and the total amount that can be authorized for this purpose at the present time is $200. You may arrange with Dr. Landymore to carry out the more urgent work, giving special attention to the new pupils. The fees allowed would be at the rate of $1 per amalgam filling; $1.50 per porcelain filling and 25 cents for each extraction. In the case of first teeth, no dental attention with the exception of extraction can be allowed. You may arrange with Dr. Landymore to have the dental work carried out when convenient to the Dentist and yourself.

The Dentist should prepare an account, in triplicate, giving the name of each pupil treated and the work done in each case. This account should be certified by you and forwarded to the Department for payment. As stated above, the dental work carried out at the present time must not exceed the above stated amount, as any expenditure in excess cannot be paid.

I might point out that the sum of $60 was paid for dental work performed by Dr. Landymore for the pupils of your school during the period - April to August last, last.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. H. J. Snell,
Principal, Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.

Dear Sir,

May 6th., 1935.

To The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Re Dental Service for pupils of the Mohawk Institute.

The semi-annual Dental examination of all pupils was made during April, and the results found summarized as follows:

| Description                          | Count |
|--------------------------------------|-------|
| Pupils examined                      | 151   |
| Number requiring dental attention    | 81    |
| Extent of work needed:               |       |
| Amalgam fillings                     | 195   |
| Porcelain                            | 18    |
| Extractions                          | 58    |
| Amalgam filling with root treatment  | 10    |
| Porcelain                            | 5     |

With a few exceptions, the general mouth conditions of the pupils are very good. During the six-month period just past, the children were given an object lesson, by means of a motion picture entertainment, in the care of the teeth, showing them the necessity of daily care, by brushing and cleaning, etc.,

Owing to the Department being able to authorize only 50% of the work mentioned in my report last November, the dental work during the October-March period was spread over, so as to reach as many pupils as possible, only the more advanced caries being treated.

The work outlined above, includes treatment for five new pupils, as well as the 50% carry-over from last six-month period. Approximate estimate of cost of work, including fee for examination — $275.

Copy of this report to Rev. Mr. Snell.

Respectfully Submitted,

[Signature]

F. W. Landymore, D.D.S.
Ottawa, May 12, 1933.

Rev. Sir:

The Department has received a report from Dr. F. W. Landymore on his semi-annual dental examination of the pupils of the Mohawk Institute. He states that eighty-one pupils require attention, consisting of one hundred and ninety-three fillings and thirty-six extractions.

Our funds this year for dental work have been considerably reduced, and the total amount that can be authorized for this purpose at this school at the present time is $125.00. You may arrange with Dr. Landymore to carry out the more urgent work. Extractions and fillings only are to be performed. The fees allowed will be at the rate of $1 per amalgam filling; $1.50 per porcelain filling, and 25 cents for each extraction. In the case of first teeth, no dental attention with the exception of extraction can be allowed. Dr. Landymore is to carry out this work when convenient to him and yourself.

The Dentist should prepare an account, in triplicate, giving the name of each pupil treated and the work done in each case. This account should be certified by you and forwarded for payment. As stated above, the dental work carried out at the present time must not exceed the above stated amount, as any expenditure in excess cannot be paid.

In the carrying out of the dental services, new pupils are to receive the preference.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

F. W. Landymore, Esq., D.D.S.,
70 Leslie Ave.,
Brantford, Ont.
Ottawa, May 15, 1933.

Sir:

Referring to the report which you submitted regarding your semi-annual dental examination of the pupils of the Mohawk Institute, I have to say in this connection that you were forwarded, in error, a communication dated the 12th instant which should have been addressed to Rev. H. W. Snell, Principal of the Mohawk Institute, stating the funds that are available for dental services at the present time. I would request that you hand this letter to Rev. Mr. Snell.

I may add that the Department will be pleased if you will carry out the more urgent dental work required at the present time.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

F. W. Langmore, Esq., D.D.S.,
70 Eagle Ave.,
Brantford, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Re Dental Services - Mohawk Inst.

The work authorized by your department, following my report of examination of May 6th., is now completed.

The 81 pupils reported requiring dental treatment, have all been re-examined at my office, and the more advanced cases have been taken care of. This procedure is the same as followed in the previous six-month period. Besides giving preference to the new pupils, this method reaches as many pupils as possible, and prevents excessive use of treatments in permanent teeth.

The statement of work and fees is herewith enclosed.

Dear Sir,

Dental Service - Mohawk Institute.

The semi-annual Dental inspection of all pupils just completed, shows the following:

Pupils examined 143.
" requiring treatment 71.

Nature of work needed:

Amalgam fillings 241.
Porcelain " 26.
Amalgam " with root treatment 11.
Porcelain " " " 6.
Extractions 76.

There are 41 new pupils on the list this fall, 36 of which are in need of dental attention.

The inspection made in October last year, showed 25 new pupils needing dental attention; and the amount of work required was greater than for the 36 new pupils this fall. This favourable comparison is due largely on account of the younger average age of these 36 new pupils.

Following the inspection made in April, this year, the work needed amounted to $275. Of this amount $125. was authorized and completed, leaving a balance of unfinished work of $150. This was further reduced by $27. by pupils who left school during the summer.

The total cost of the work outlined above, including fee for inspection is $370. This amount is made up of $125. carry-over from last April, $158 for the 36 new pupils, and $79 for work among the older pupils which has developed during the past six months.

Copy of this report to Rev. Mr. Snell, all of which is respectfully submitted.

[Signature]

F. W. Landymore, D.D.S.
Ottawa, November 3, 1933.

Reverend Sir:

The Department has received a report from Dr. F. W. Landymore on his semi-annual dental examination of the pupils of the Mohawk Institute. He states that, after examining 143 pupils, he finds 71 require dental treatment.

Our funds for dental services this year are extremely limited, and, as it was necessary to assign the amount available among the various residential schools, the total amount that can be allowed for this purpose for the pupils of the Mohawk Institute at the present time is $200.

You may arrange with Dr. Landymore to carry out the more urgent work only. Extractions and fillings only are to be performed. The fees allowed will be at the same rate as previously paid him for this service, viz.: $1.00 per amalgam filling; $1.50 per porcelain filling; and 25¢ for each extraction. In the case of first teeth, no dental attention with the exception of extraction can be allowed.

Dr. Landymore should prepare an account, in triplicate, giving the name of each pupil treated and the work done in each case. This account should be certified by you and forwarded for payment.

The dental work should be carried out when convenient to Dr. Landymore and yourself. It is to be distinctly understood that the cost of the dental attention at this time must not exceed the above stated amount, as any expenditure in excess cannot be paid. In performing this service, new pupils are to receive the preference.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. H. W. Snell, B. A.,
Principal,
Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.

Re Dental Service - Mohawk Institute.

The semi-annual dental inspection of all pupils has been completed, and the following is a summary:

Pupils examined 140
requiring treatment 74

Since the previous inspection made in October, last year, there are six new pupils on the list.

The total cost of the work outlined above is approximately $245.00, which includes fee for examination. This amount is made up of a carry-over of $170.00 from the previous period, $35.00 for work among the six new pupils, and $30.00 for work developed among the other pupils during the six months.

30-0-34
Ottawa, May 5, 1934.

Rev. Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a letter from Dr. F. W. Landymore with reference to the dental work required at the Mohawk Institute. Dr. Landymore estimates the cost of the work at $245.

In reviewing our files it is found that $574 was expended for dental work at the Mohawk Institute in the calendar year 1931; $300 in the year 1932 and $324.50 in 1933. These amounts are much larger than at any other Indian residential school in Canada. Under these circumstances, the Department finds it necessary to curtail expenditure in connection with dental services.

At practically all other Indian residential schools a dentist is engaged by the day. It is found that, for a school of the same size as the Mohawk Institute, two days' work a year is sufficient to keep the pupils' teeth in good condition.

The Department is prepared to allow Dr. Landymore $30 a day for two days' work. A day's work is estimated at seven hours, during which the dentist is expected to apply himself diligently. He must furnish his own materials, but is not required to provide gold fillings or any artificial teeth at this rate. Presumably, composition fillings are sufficiently good and no artificial teeth will be required. He must use anaesthetics sufficiently to avoid unnecessary pain. You are expected to assist by organizing the clinic and seeing that the dentist is kept supplied with patients.

You may inform Dr. Landymore regarding the above instructions from the Department, and it is hoped that you can arrange with him to carry out the work along the lines suggested above. If Dr. Landymore is not prepared to do this, you should at once advise the Department.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. H. W. Snell, B.A.,
Principal,
Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.
To the Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Re Dental Services Mohawk Institute.

Rev. Mr. Snell has advised me of the proposed suggestions for the curtailment of dental services.

While the installation of a dental clinic at the school has some advantage over our present arrangement, it will not, in view of the amount of work needed to "put the pupils teeth in good condition", accomplish that which the department desires viz., economy and less outlay.

The examination of the pupils during last month showed 77 requiring dental attention in varying amounts. The preparation of a cavity for amalgam and insertion of filling will average twenty minutes, or three per hour. This is averaging simple and compound cavities. The amalgam work alone among these 77 pupils would take approximately six days to complete it, working seven hours per day. Porcelain work averages a longer time, and there would still be extractions and the odd root treatment, therefore, if the department really want to put the teeth of these children in "good condition" it would be impossible to do so in two days work.

It has been the practice under our present arrangement to give the children proper attention with the minimum expense. There is no other board or department paying less for dental service. The Workmen's Compensation Board allow from $1.00 to $4.00 for an amalgam filling, and $1.00 for extractions. The Board of the College of Dental Surgeons in submitting the schedule of fees for the Workmen's Compensation Board advised the profession that these fees were considered to be only two-thirds of an average fee set by an average dentist in regular practice. The Ontario Government in administering dental relief allow $1.00 for extraction of the first tooth, and 50 cents for each subsequent tooth. Your department is paying 25 cents per tooth. I have merely mentioned the foregoing schedules to show that the department also is receiving dental services at the lowest possible outlay.

To lessen the cost, your department has suggested the use of composition for fillings. The cost of a filling is due to the time taken in preparing the cavity. The same preparation holds for either amalgam or composition. The cost to the dentist of either of these materials is...
F. W. LANDYMORE, D.D.S.
70 EAGLE AVENUE
BRANTFORD

the same, and because composition is not considered a permanent material,
its use is confined to regular practice to some cases for the temporary
teeth. The preparation of a cavity for an Indian is exactly the same as
for any one else, therefore, I cannot see how the expertise in this regard
can be lowered.

When I took up this work for the Mohawk Institute, my first
examination revealed the mouth conditions of these children — in a most
deplorable state, and since that time there has been a gradual improvement
with a decrease in the volume of work required. My last examination
made last month, showed only $65 in cost of services needed, which
included four new pupils. The balance of $170, was work which had
accumulated over the past two years, and $10, for examination, making a
total of $245.00.

If your department would, at this time, make a special concession
to this school, and permit me to clean up this outstanding work, and
further, authorize the regular examination next October, in order to
include any new pupils entering the school during the coming summer,
I believe it will be possible to continue the work, thoroughly and
completely under our present system at approximately the same outlay that
a two-day clinic at the school would incur.

However, if your department are still desirous of installing a
clinic in the school at this time, I shall be glad to continue to give of
my time and talents to the best of my ability. I presume the department
would arrange for the purchase of the necessary equipment, chair, engine
etc., and would suggest that the more modern the equipment, the more
efficiently the work can be carried on.

Respectfully yours,

[Signature]

Copy of this letter to Rev. Mr. Scott.
May 25th, 1934

Reverend Sir:

The Department has received a letter from Doctor F. W. Landymore on the subject of the proposed dental work for the pupils of your school. Doctor Landymore goes to a good deal of length in describing the work he has done in the last three years and what is now required, but he does not convince the Department that an outlay of £1200 in three years is reasonable expenditure for dental attention to 150 pupils.

As an example I may quote an Agency where there are about an equal number of pupils all in day school. About ten days dental work has been done for these children during three years and their teeth are in such good order as to lead the dentist to invite comparison with white children under provincial care. If two days is not sufficient during the present year, the Department is prepared to allow three, but Doctor Landymore must find his own equipment and materials. Much of the letter which he writes has no reference to the matter under discussion as the Department is not concerned with any arrangement made by the Workmen's Compensation Board, or any other organization. It has arrangements similar to those proposed in this case with many dentists who appreciate the work and take pride in it.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant

T. R. L. MacInnis

Rev. H. W. Snell, B.A.,
Principal Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.

Acting Secretary
June 11-34

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

I have taken up the matter of Dental further with Dr. Landymore and he is willing to undertake the work on a time basis as you suggested. Owing to the expense involved he will be unable to install equipment at the school for the work but will do it at his office giving three full days as convenient.

It is only fair to point out in connection with the comparison with dental full day schools on a Reserve that there would be very few new pupils as compared with the Institute and that the greater part of the work required each year is for new pupils admitted in the Autumn. It would be much less, once the teeth were put in good condition, if we had practically the same pupils year after year.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal.
June 15th, 1934

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of June 11th, and observe that Doctor Landymore is willing to undertake the dental work for the pupils of Mohawk Institute on the basis supplied by the Department. I think you will find this to be quite satisfactory, particularly if you are able to detail some member of your staff to act as assistant in the clinic room and another to attend to the children after they have received treatment. In referring to work done in certain day schools an Agency was mentioned which has a greater number of pupils attending the school given this service than there are pupils in the Mohawk Institute. Another point of similarity is that each year there are new cases coming up for attention, not only among the younger children, but among older children whose parents have just returned to the Reserve. It was not possible to obtain the maximum benefit the first year this arrangement was adopted, but as the clinic became better organized, better results were obtained and I feel sure that you will be well pleased after this method is given a good trial.

Yours truly,

Rev. H. W. Snell, B.A.,
Principal Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.

LM.

A. F. MacKenzie
Secretary

In 1931 I examined and fitted a boy by the name of Ted Jameson with glasses at the Indian Institute at that time.

The matter brought him to me and after referring him back, I found that he was very improve. He was in the care that was his own to the matter and he said he didn't need glasses, which was very untrue.

Sir:

It is noted from your letter of the 30th ultimo that in the year 1931 you supplied a pair of glasses for an Indian pupil of the Mohawk Institute on the request of the child's mother.

It does not appear from your letter that you were authorized to supply these glasses either by the Indian Superintendent or the Principal of the Mohawk Institute, and I regret that it will not be possible for the Department to pay your account.

Your obedient servant,

August 17-34.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

I have received your letter No.32-0-13, 10th inst. In reply I may say that I am sorry I neglected to quote the authority for the general examination. This was authorized in your letter No.32-0-13, Oct. 23, 1930, which provided for a semi-annual examination. We have been proceeding under this authorization for the past four years.

It should also be mentioned that this service, at $10.00 is very reasonable. Dr. Landymore spent, at each semi-annual examination, three afternoons of three hours each. It is evident that the actual work of repairing the teeth is much expedited by this previous examination as none but those needing attention need be sent to him.

I trust, therefore, that the Department will not only pay him the small fee involved, but also authorize the continuance of the examination. I do not see how we can get satisfactory results from the time authorized for work on the children's teeth without the previous examination.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal.
Ottawa, August 22, 1934.

Rev. Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 17th instant, I beg to say that the Department is not prepared to continue allowing Dr. Landymore a fee of $10 for examination of the teeth of the children at the Mohawk Institute.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. H. W. Snell, B.A.,
Principal,
Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.

October 29-34.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

With reference to Wilma Hill No. 01059, I have been holding the application until I received the report from Dr. Alexander of the Brant Sanatorium. I may say that I have just had a telephone conversation with him and he says that she is definitely tubercular. He recommends that she be placed in a Preventorium immediately. He is sending his written report tomorrow and I shall forward it to you.

I might say that Dr. Davis and Dr. Stone examined her the day Dr. Stone was here and thought she was clear, but as I had already made an appointment with Dr. Alexander, I took her to him. With the better facilities at his disposal he has detected definite symptoms of the disease. Of course I cannot keep her here permanently but during her stay we shall isolate her and keep her in bed.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal.
November 7th, 1924.

Reverend Sir,

The report on Wilma Hill, contained in your letter of October 29th, would indicate that this child should not be accepted as a pupil in your school. Your best course is to transfer her to the care of Doctor Davis for such disposition as he may think necessary.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Reverend H. W. Snell, B.A.,
Principal,
Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ontario.
The Brant Sanatorium
BRANTFORD, ONT.
October 31st, 1934.

Rev. H. Snell,
The Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Re: Wilhelmina Hill, Age 5 ?, Mohawk Institute.

History of family or other exposure to tuberculosis: no information. History of previous illness: negative. Present illness: It was noted that this child was somewhat quieter and more easily tired out than the average.

Physical examination: The eyes were bright with dark circles underneath. The child has an appearance of sub-normal health. Having waited a short time before the examination, the left side of the face became flushed. Glands are palpable along both sides of the neck. The excursion of the right side of the chest is slightly more easily controlled by bi-manual pressure than is the left. In the lower half of the right side the percussion note was noticeably impaired at the time of the first examination on October 22nd. On October 29th there was a suggestion of increased dullness in this region. An important finding was the prolonged expiratory phase to respiration in the right lung and in the left axillary region. The fact that this change in respiratory sound was in the lower half of the chest caused me to hesitate in the diagnosis even with a temperature of 100.2 at 10 A.M.

I considered the child too ill to employ an I.C. test and suggested that she return for re-examination on October 29th. When she returned on October 29th, Mr. Snell reported that the child had had complete rest for the past week. Her temperature was 99.4. The face was flushed and she had a listless tired out expression. The previously noted physical findings continued and in addition a very few fine moist sounds were heard at the level of the nipple line in both axillary regions. Accompanying these were wheezing sounds throughout both lungs. These wheezing sounds were only occasionally present. The prolonged expiratory phase of the respiration undoubtedly indicates a congested inflamed condition of lung tissues. The fact that this has not subsided with a week's rest and the various other findings in this case imply justify a suspicion of tuberculosis as the causative factor in the child's abnormal condition of health.

An I.C. test was given and reported to be positive +++.

The expense of taking x-ray plates was not consider-
THE BRANT SANATORIUM

Rev. H. Snell,
Page -2-
Oct. 31, 1934.

ed justifiable as sufficient evidence had been obtained to substantiate a diagnosis of tuberculosis.

This little girl's best prospects for recovery would be in a Preventorium. Certainly she is not a fit subject to continue in residence at the Mohawk Institute.

NOTE: The tonsil and adenoid condition warrants a continuance of observation.

Yours truly,

CHAS. C. ALEXANDER, M.D.
The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

With further reference to Wilma Hill, 01059, I am enclosing report from Dr. Alexander, of the Brant Sanatorium. You will note that he states that she is not a fit subject to continue in residence in the Institute, and that she should be placed in a Preventorium. Pursuant to suggestion from Mr. Phelan, I have interviewed the authorities of the Brant Sanatorium and they will admit her to their Preventorium provided, of course, her admission is authorized by the Department with the assurance that the usual fee of $1.00 per diem charged to municipalities will be paid. I am, therefore asking for authority to place her in the Brant Sanatorium as this seems to be the only chance of her recovering her health. Dr. Davis assured me that she would have no chance of recovery in her own home as her mother is dead and conditions are bad.

Your obedient servant,

Horace W. Smith,
Principal.

The Secretary,

Dear Sir,

We have not had our dental work this Autumn and there are several pupils whose teeth are in very bad condition.

I am, therefore, asking authority to have Dr. Landymore three days work for them as was arranged last Spring. An examination of his report shows that we secured more service for the money expended under this plan than under the former fee system.

Your obedient servant,

Horace W. Smith

Principal.
Ottawa, December 27, 1834.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, relative to the dental services required by the pupils of the Mohawk Institute.

In this connection I have to say that the Department is prepared to allow Dr. F. W. Landymore $30.00 a day for not more than three days' work. A day's work is estimated at 7 hours - during which the dentist is expected to apply himself diligently. He must supply his own materials but is not required to provide gold fillings or any artificial teeth at this rate. Presumably, composition fillings would be satisfactory and no artificial teeth should be supplied. The dentist must use anesthetics sufficiently to avoid unnecessary pain. You should assist by organizing the clinic and seeing that the dentist is kept supplied with patients.

The dentist should prepare his account, in triplicate, at the rate allowed, covering the period he is engaged, which should not exceed the time mentioned above. He should also prepare a list, giving the names of the pupils receiving attention and the work performed for each. Please certify the account and forward it to the Department for payment, with list attached of the work performed.

You should arrange with Dr. Landymore to carry out the dental services for the pupils at an early date.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. H. W. Snell, B. A.,
Principal, Mohawk Institute,
BRANTFORD, ONT.
Ottawa, January 28th, 1935.

Reverend Sir,

I am having sent to you a sample of a remedy called "Sphincterine" which is highly recommended by its makers and by one or two of our residential school principals for bed-wetting. I should appreciate your giving this remedy a careful and thorough trial and letting me know as soon as possible whether you find it effective. I am well aware of the importance of this problem in most Indian residential schools and would be pleased to find some remedy which would help to solve it.

You have probably had some of the incontinence tablets which have been used for this purpose, and I would appreciate your opinion on the relative merits of the two preparations.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

P & N.H. 60 10M-7-35 Req 367
October 10-35.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

A large number of our pupils need dental attention. As we did not have our three days last Spring I wonder if we might have six days' service from Dr. Landymore this term which would pretty well clear them up.

Your obedient servant,

Horace W. Snell,

Principal.
October 26th, 1935

Dear Sir:

This will be your authority to engage Doctor Landymore for four days dental attention to your pupils on the basis set out in the Department's letter to you of December 27th, 1934.

Kindly try to make such preliminary arrangements as will enable Doctor Landymore to put the greatest possible proportion of his time on the work. Even a casual examination by yourself or better still, by Doctor Davis who I am sure would be pleased to help, should prevent the need of a full examination of each pupil by the dentist himself.

If, after four days the necessary work is not completed, please communicate with the Department. Strictly speaking there are no funds for this work but the Department will endeavour to do as well as it can.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

T. R. Le MacInnes
Acting Secretary

Reverend H. W. Small,
Principal Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.
W. D. BROUGH
EYES EXAMINED Optometrist GLASSES FITTED
BRANTFORD

Jan. 43, 1860.

Mr. A. McGregor,
Dept. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa Ont.

Dear Sir,

I have located the boy's name and the amount of the account which I spoke to you about some time ago in my last letter. The name was Mr. John Johnson, and the amount is $25.00.

I shall appreciate it very much if you can do something about this, as it is a perfectly legitimate case, and I feel it should be paid.

Yours very truly,

W.D. Brough
February 4th, 1938

Dear Sir:

Inspector McCookin has referred to me your letter to him of January 25th, with reference to the case of Ted Jamieson, to whom you supplied spectacles in January 1938. The Department's record shows that you wrote about this case in June 1934, and that the reply was that it was not possible for the Department to recognize your claim as you had not been authorized to supply spectacles. I am sure you are aware that the Department is not responsible even for necessary articles sold to Indians without its knowledge and consent. There are so many authorities to whom a vendor at Brantford can apply that the Department does not feel able to make an exception in this case.

Yours very truly,

A. F. MacKenzie
Secretary

W.D. Brough, Esq.,
Optometrist,
Brantford, Ont.

RBK

A considerable number of the pupils are in urgent need of medical attention. May I have authority for the usual three days' work by Dr. Landymore?

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal.
December 23, 1936

Dear Sir:

I regret that the Department during the course of the present fiscal year cannot authorize dental clinics for your school as requested in your letter of December 19. The whole reason is that funds are not available for work of this kind.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes

Rev. H. N. Small,
Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.

LM
April 11-37,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

The nurse reports that the condition of the teeth of many of the pupils is in a bad state. This is largely due to the fact that we were not able to have the usual dental work done last Autumn. I do hope that at least the usual three days may be possible this Spring. Would it be possible, in view of the necessary neglect last Fall, to have five days this Spring? This would, probably, be enough to take care of all the urgent cases and contribute much to the continued good health of all the pupils.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal.
April 17, 1937

THE DEPUTY MINISTER

The Principal of the Mohawk Indian Residential School in the city of Brantford, Ontario has asked for a dental clinic which will require about four or five days. A doctor F. J. Landymore of Brantford has previously done this work. I have to inquire whether it will be in order to engage him again if funds can be found for the clinic.

MEMORANDUM

10th July, 1937.

Mr. MacInnes,

Re - Dental attendance, Mohawk Indian Residential School, Brantford.

I am returning herewith your memorandum of the 5th instant together with the letter from Dr. B.W. Linscott.

You have not dealt with Dr. Linscott's request to be remunerated for the two extra days which he claims he was forced to work attending to the dental requirements of the pupils of the Mohawk Residential School.

Will you please cover this adequately in your report.

C.W. Jackson,
Secretary.
Memoandum,

THE DEPUTY MINISTER:

Dental Attention - Mohawk Indian Residential School, Brantford.

Mr. Pratt's enquiry June 29th.

There is now available a report on Doctor Linscott's dental clinic and also his account. I am asked to make the following observations on this matter.

A three day dental clinic was authorized, on the estimate of the Principal of the school. Doctor Linscott did four days.

It is hard to see the necessity of a dentist taking time for such complete examinations and records, when there are many children obviously in need of his services. However, he does not appear to have charged for this extra time.

The point at issue is whether the Department should allow pay for four days, after authorizing three, and without being further consulted.

In this particular case, Doctor Linscott appears to have done a fair amount of work in the four days, and to have earned his four days' fee.
The funds available for this work are very limited, and we are making an effort to see to the more urgent cases in the largest possible number of schools.

It is recommended that Doctor Linnett be paid for his four days, but we should really appreciate an instruction not to allow this sort of procedure in future.

As to further work at this school this year, this will depend on how funds appear to be holding out when the fall term opens.

T.R.L. MacInnes,
Acting Director of Indian Affairs.
