Copy for the information of Dr. McGill.

Ottawa, 22nd July, 1937.

Dear Dr. Linscott,-

Mr. Crerar has asked me to reply to your letter of the 28th ultimo in which you report that you found it necessary to spend an extra two days beyond the period authorized by the Department in examining and treating pupils of the Mohawk Indian Residential School.

You will appreciate the necessity of the Department so planning the expenditure of money provided for Indian affairs that the most urgent cases will receive first attention. The Principal of the Mohawk School estimated that a dentist would be able to take care of the immediate needs of the pupils of his school in three days, and in planning the details of the appropriation sufficient funds were allotted to take care of that expenditure. He did not of course have in mind complete examination of every child or the completion of individual index cards. Whenever a greater expenditure is incurred in one locality than was planned there is the danger that some other work will have to be held over and the possibility that the postponed work is more urgent than that covered by the unforeseen expenditure.

In view of your report we are authorizing the payment of fees in your case for four days instead of three. This will cover your eight half day's work. I am explaining the situation to you so that in the event of your taking on any Indian work in the future you will not exceed the period authorized by the Department.

Yours very truly,

Bradley W. Linscott, Esq., D.D.S.,
Brantford,
Ontario.

C.W. Jackson,
Secretary.
Minister's Office

Minister of Mines & Resources,

July 26/37

Dear Sir,

I have your letter in reply to my letter to Mr. Carter re my report dental services at the Mohawk Indian School. Re the report: The Department engaged me for three days to do the most urgent work for 150 children, but never made any allowance for inspection.

It was reasonable to ask how was I to find out the most urgent cases without full inspection? It was always tough days work looking over 150 children for dental defects. I wanted a thorough and complete report for my own satisfaction which would be valuable for the administration of the school so I scoured all my own index cards.

Notwithstanding the Principal's statement there was many most urgent cases and the nurse and I agreed that it would be best to finish up some cases (which I had to) even during four days'
Dr. Bradley W. Linscott,

Brantford

Service. I was prompted a bit in the extra day as a humanitarian service and send a report to the department. I wish to thank you for the allowance for the fourth day service.

I think the department will agree the inspection was absolutely necessary to discover the urgent cases they wished me to attend to. I still believe it just in allowing me for inspection.

I rendered five days of real service attended between 40 to 50 children in four days, put in 146 fillings - 28 extractions and 10 Pneumocystic treatments. In private practice $300 worth of work; real value.

I respectfully ask a reconsideration for the allowance for this days inspection.

I am Professfully Yours,

Bradley W. Linscott

P.S. It might be wise to advise the department that there were urgent cases left undone.
Minister's Office

Sir:

Your letter of July 27 addressed to C. W. Jackson, Secretary to the Minister of Mines and Resources has been referred to me for reply. It seems difficult to add anything to the information contained in Mr. Jackson's letter of July 28. You were engaged for three days work. You rendered accounts for four days during which you did about the average amount of work accomplished by dentists engaged on a daily basis, as you were. The Department has rather exceeded its usual custom in paying for more work than was authorized and I think that you can scarcely ask that the matter be reconsidered.

Yours truly,

Dr. Bradley W. Linscott,
Brantford.

The Department of
Indian Affairs

Dear Sir,

In June I completed a
Dental Clinic at the Mohawk Institute
Brantford.

On June 30th I sent statement of
my services to your department (certified)
by the Principal of the school (Rev. H. Bull)
On July 3rd I received notice from the
local Department that I should send
the statement in duplicate on Department
forms, which I did and sent them direct
to your Department at Ottawa. However
wondering if I should have sent them
to the local Superintendent or whether
department receive them; as I never
received acknowledgment. Also enclosed
the original certified statement. Did your
department receive the same?

Respectfully yours, Bradley W. Linscott
Minister's Office

September 9, 1937.

DR. MCGILL:

I am sending you herewith a letter from Dr. Bradley W. Linscott, of Brantford, with further reference to the settlement of his account for dental services at the Mohawk Residential School.

Will you please look into this matter and furnish a draft reply for my signature.

C.W. Jackson,
Secretary.

Per. R.
EX'D.

September 13, 1937.

Dear Doctor Linscott:

I have made inquiry about your account for dental services at the Mohawk Indian Residential School as referred to in your letter of September 7. I am informed that a cheque for $150.00 has gone forward to you.

Yours sincerely,

G. W. Jackson
Secretary

Dr. Bradley W. Linscott
Brantford, Ont.
November 15, 1937.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

Phoebe Claus, No. 0960, has very bad eyes. I have had her eyes tested and am enclosing prescription from Dr. Bragg in the hope that glasses may be provided for her. I should have had glasses for her sooner but she was under treatment for a long time and has only recently arrived at the stage where glasses would be beneficial.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal.
EX'D.

November 18, 1937.

Dear Sir:

I am re-enveloping the prescription for glasses for Phoebe Claus received with your letter of November 15. These glasses may be purchased from any approved optical firm in Brantford. If the Consolidated or Imperial Optical Companies, or any wholesale manufacturing firm, has a branch there you will find it the most economical source of supply. Otherwise, if you need any information on this point, you could get it from Major Randle. Good lenses are required but the frame should be cheap and strong white metal.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

H. W. Snell, Esq.,
Principal,
Mohawk Indian Residential School,
Brantford, Ont.

THE DEPUTY MINISTER:

RE: Dental work for the Mohawk Indian Residential Schools.

Dr. B.W. Linscott, of Brantford, who looked after the above work last year may be re-engaged this season. It will be recalled that Dr. Linscott performed more work than was authorized. W.J.F. Pratt,

June 14, 1938.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

Following your visit here and pursuant of your authorization, I decided that since there had been no dental work done for the pupils this year it should be done this term and so am sending them to Dr. Linscott for four days' work as authorized.

I have a report on the special case of Laura Kontour who needs a plate which you authorized at a cost not to exceed $40.00. Dr. Linscott estimates that the plate can be supplied and her teeth put in good condition at a cost not exceeding $25.00. I have, therefore, instructed him to proceed with her work as a separate item not included in the regular four days.

Trusting that the above arrangements will meet with your approval, I am,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Principal.

Dr. E. L. Stone,
Director of Medical Supplies,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Dr. Stone:

The following articles were omitted from our June requisition:

1 pr. College Plier (with thumb rest), extra long points, 6½", finely finished, for foil or cotton, chrome plated

1 pr. Small forceps

1 qt. Alcohol - 70%

2 lbs. Utor Ointment (Wm. Pugaley, Toronto, Can.)

Each of these items is badly needed and it is sometimes difficult to get along without them so would you kindly send them as soon as possible.

Yours very truly,

Horace H. Smith
(p.s. A. E. Smith)
Principal.
November 26, 1938

Reverend Sir:

Your order of November 16 has reached the Department and in this connection would you be good enough to submit a requisition on the proper form certified by the doctor and the agent. As the doctor will understand, he must have a requisition number for alcohol which is registered with the Excise Branch.

Your description of the "College Plier" is not sufficiently clear for us to understand your requirements.

Utor Ointment is not stocked by the Department and in this connection kindly refer to the instructions for ordering drugs on the departmental drug list, which states patent medicines will not be supplied.

Yours truly,

T.R.L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

Rev. Horace W. Snell,

May 6, 1939,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

The nurse reports that there are a large number of pupils needing dental attention. May I have authority to arrange for the usual four days' dental work? As the term is nearing its end it will be necessary to begin the work soon. An early reply, therefore, would enable us to have the work done without too much haste.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Principal.
May 10, 1939

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a letter from the Principal of Mohawk Institute, dated May 6, in which he requests a four day dental clinic for the pupils of that school. Would you be good enough to find out, if possible, how many pupils require dental work and if four days would be necessary to complete the work required.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes
Secretary

Major E. P. Randle,
Superintendent,
Six Nations Indians,
Brantford, Ont.

LM
BRANTFORD May 2nd, 1939.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario,

Sir:

In reply to your 32-0-13 of the 10th instant in regard to the dental clinic at the Mohawk Institute, you are advised that as far as can be ascertained four days would not be sufficient to complete all the children who require dental work, as there are approximately 50 pupils requiring such and it would probably take five to six days.

Your obedient servant,

E. P. Randle

Major E. P. Randle.
Indian Superintendent.
May 27, 1939.

EXD

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letter, LOB-967/39, of May 22 in regard to the dental clinic at the Mohawk Institute.

This will authorize a four-day clinic at that school. If it found by all concerned to be absolutely necessary to extend it an additional day, it will be in order to do so.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

Major E. P. Randles,
Indian Superintendent,
BRANTFORD, Ontario.

May 1st, 1940.

Reverend Sir,

I regret the necessity of returning herewith a drug requisition which was received at the Department from you. All drug requisitions are now required to come through the office of the Indian Agent who, in this case, is Major E. P. Randle of Brantford, Ontario. They must also bear the signature of the Agency medical attendant, whose duty it is to scrutinize them carefully before being passed on to Ottawa. The European situation has enhanced conservation of available drug supplies and has, at the same time, placed a restriction on some as you may see from the enclosed Circular of September 2nd, 1939. It, also, is no longer possible to supply rubbing alcohol in any quantity unless the medical attendant, signing the requisition, has an alcohol registration number which must appear on the order.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. [Signature]
Secretary.

Rev. H. W. Snell,
Mohawk Indian Residential School,
Brantford, Ontario.

PJB

May 18th, 1940.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Sir:

In accordance with your instructions to the principal of the Mohawk Institute under cover of file 32-0-13 of the 1st instant, this office is now submitting in duplicate, the drug requisition of the Mohawk Institute duly signed by the Medical Superintendent and myself.

The Department will note that the medical Superintendent has reduced in some cases, the original requisition, where he felt the supplies requested were unnecessarily large and in one or two instances has eliminated certain drugs which he felt should not be supplied as requested but will supply sufficient quantities himself from the stock at Lady Willingdon Hospital.

Yours truly,

E. P. Randle,
Indian Superintendent.

Major E. P. Randle,
EPR/CH.
Ottawa, May 28th, 1940.

Dear Sir,

Rev. H. W. Small,
Mohawk Ind.Res.School,
Brantford, Ontario.

Payment will be made by this Department on receipt of your account in quadruplicate.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Secretary.

Dept. of Pensions & National Health,
Ottawa, Canada.

August 25-41.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

Attention Health Services.

A considerable number of our pupils will be in need of dental care this term. I should, therefore, like authority to have them attended to early in the term. As no dental care was authorized last year would it be possible to have five days' if the dentist's time this year. I doubt whether this would be sufficient for all of them to be attended to but it would take care of the more urgent cases.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Principal.
September 2, 1941.

Dear Sir:

Rev. H. W. Snell, Principal of the Mohawk Institution, has written the Department requesting a five day dental clinic for the school. It will be in order for you to arrange this clinic as formerly, the dentist to receive $30.00 per day for his material and services. Mr. Snell is receiving a copy of this letter.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

P. E. Moore, M.D., D.P.H.,
Acting Superintendent of Medical Services.

Major R. F. Handley,
Indian Superintendent,
Brantford, Ontario.

FAR
May 6-42.

The Secretary,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed, please find requisition for medical supplies for the ensuing year. In accordance with your request, these have been kept as low as possible.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Principal.
Ottawa June 1st, 1942.

Dear Sir or Madam,

Please note that future drug requisitions must give the amount of all drugs on hand each time you submit a requisition, otherwise, no action will be taken except to return it to you for further particulars. This, also, will apply to requisitions on which are not clearly marked the number of Indians to be served. Space has been provided for this information on the drug order form.

It should also be noted that freezable items should not be ordered during cold weather, nor is it economical to submit an order that cannot be sent by mail or freight. One hundred pounds is the minimum on which freight has to be paid and fifteen pounds the maximum of non-liquids that can be sent by mail. I must ask you, therefore, to bear these facts in mind when ordering drugs.

Efforts should be made to gain the co-operation of Indians in the matter of returning empty bottles, after thoroughly washing them, when more medicine is required.

I would suggest that this Circular be attached to your Departmental drug list for future reference.

Yours truly,

Rev. H. J. Snell,
Principal,
Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ontario.

[Signature]

I. L. Moore, D. P. H.
Acting Superintendent, Medical Services.

Cir. 1030.

Minister's Office

MEMORANDUM

12th September, 1942.

The Deputy Minister,

Dr. Linscott of Brantford, who has been doing the dental work at the Mohawk Institute, has been inquiring as to when his services would be required this year. Will you please obtain this information from the Indian Affairs Branch.

M.J.F. Pratt,
Private Secretary.

Dr. McGill -

For information as requested.
September 21, 1942.

Dear Sir:

An inquiry has been made by Doctor Linseott of Brantford, as to whether or not any dental work will be necessary this year at the Mohawk Institute.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

P. E. Moore, M.D., D.P.H.,
Acting Superintendent of Medical Services.

Major E. P. Randle,
Superintendent,
Six Nations Indians,
BRANTFORD, Ontario.

EMR
BRANTFORD Sept. 23, 1942.

Dr. P. E. Moore,
Acting Superintendent of Medical Services,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Sir:

This will acknowledge your 32-0-13A of the 21st instant regarding dental work at the Mohawk Institute.

Upon enquiring from the Principal we learn that owing to the fact that there are so many new pupils this year, and last year only the most urgent work could be done in the five days granted for the dental service, - there is considerable work which is most necessary this year and which would take at least seven days.

Last year Dr. Linscott did the five days' work for which he was paid, and in addition did two half days' work gratis, for the sake of the pupils who needed attention.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Indian Superintendent.
MEMORANDUM

Sept. 25, 1942

THE DEPUTY MINISTER (I.A.)

Dr. Linscott, Brantford,
re dental services, Mohawk Institute.

My memorandum of Sept. 12th requested that information be obtained from the Indian Affairs Branch as to when Dr. Linscott's services would be required this year.

This has not yet been furnished. Will you please have it expedited.

N.Y.F. Pratt
Private Secretary.

Dr. McGill -

For information as requested.
September 29, 1942

Re: Dental services, Mohawk Institute (Dr. Linscott, Brantford).

Memorandum:

THE DEPUTY MINISTER

Doctor Moore has had correspondence with Indian Superintendent Rendle and has been advised that a dental clinic of approximately five days will be needed there this year.

It would seem advisable to hold the clinic the latter part of October or early in November.

Acting Director of Indian Affairs
Dr. P. E. Moore, Actg.Supt. Medical Services,
I.A.Branch, Ottawa.

This office would draw your attention
to our file of the 23rd of September last with
reference to dental work at the Mohawk Institute.
May we please be advised if the necessary work
outlined can be authorized.

Major E. P. Randle,

Indian Superintendent.
January 23, 1943

It will be in order to have a seven day dental clinic at the Mohawk Institute. Doctor Linscott of Brantford is to be employed.

T. R. L. MacInnes
Secretary

E. F. Randle, Esq.,
Superintendent,
Six Nations Indians,
Brantford, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed please find requisition for drugs for 1944-45.

Ottawa, Ontario
August 9, 1944

Could you please forward me information by return mail as to whether or not a dental clinic was held at the Mohawk Institute before the close of the school year. I was under the impression that I told you over the telephone that such a clinic could be arranged. If the clinic has not been carried out, could you tell me the approximate dates that it could be arranged after the opening of the school year.

P. E. Moore, M.D., D.P.H.
Acting Superintendent of Medical Services

Lt. Col. E. P. Randle,
Superintendent, Six Nations Indians,
Brentford, Ont.

Feb.23/46
Page 2.

It has been of interest to you that since the last allotment of work I have given 16 emergency treatments for the children (extractions, fillings and relief of tooth-ache) I have asked no fee for this service, so expect none. I offer this service to Dr. Snell for the children's sake.

I wish to cooperate to the full, for the best service for the lost children.

Respectfully yours,

(signed) Stanley V. Linscott.
Dr. Bradley W. Linscott,
Brantford, Ont.
Feb. 23/46

Re our telephone conversation the "Dental treatment for the children of the... Institute."

The few years I have been doing this work it has been my endeavour and practice to give the children the best dental service possible and for the greatest number. To complete dental service for 40 or 50 children in 7 days means some very diligent attention to give this service properly. Some suitable and convenient surroundings must be at hand and that place is my Dental Office.

If it is your intention to ask for the Brantford Schools Dental Clinic outfit, and it is granted you, I may say that it takes one day to pack, move, and set up the equipment when you assist and I move. That means two days lost for working on the children. I may say that dental services are at a premium during the war and since its end, and I know for a fact that some dentist could not arrange an appointment for three months. So it is too late to ask any dentist to complete 7-day service before April 15th. That could have been arranged much earlier.

The Government have also asked the local dentists to give immediate attention to the dental service for ex-service men. We are trying to cooperate, and personally I have 15 Dental charts for 15 ex-service men and more new ones each day. These must be attended to at once.

To ask the Institution to send five children each week for a half-day for appointments is co-operating, in view of the above circumstances.

I told Mr. Zimmerman that during Easter Holidays I would give an all-day service until the seven days have been completed.

----It may be
Ottawa, March 18, 1946.

Dear Colonel Randle:

With reference to Dr. Linnett's letter to you of February 23, I discussed it with Dr. Moore, who stated that he was going to London and would stop off at Brantford. He is away this week and I hope you have an opportunity of meeting him.

I also spoke to him in regard to the situation at the Mohawk Institute in connection with the medical services. I pointed out to him that the school has been paying $2.00 a day to the doctor for several years. There is no reason why Mohawk Institute should not be treated on the same basis as other residential schools throughout Canada, the services of the doctor being made a charge against the Medical Vote. Dr. Moore promised me that he would also discuss this matter with you.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Lt.-Col. E. F. Randle,
Indian Superintendent,
Brantford, Ont.

June 21, 1946.

Dr. P.E. Moore,
Acting Sup. Indian Health Services,
Dept. of National Health & Welfare,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

During this past week I sent one of the boys to the Lady Willingdon Hospital, Chawaken. He was 10 years of age. He had a V.D. condition from birth. The test of his sister was neither positive or negative. A further test has to be made. Four more children are to be tested.

I am reporting these facts to you so that if you have any suggestions to make I shall be very happy to carry them out if possible. For example the boys have been using the common towels. This lad who is in the hospital had matter discharging from the eye at one stage. Needless to say that is not a happy condition. We have no locker space for the boys so that I cannot see how we can handle individual towels if they were acceptable. There are quite a number of points that come to my mind as preventive

Yours truly,

Rev. W.J. Zimmerman, M.A., B.D.
Principal.
Ottawa, Ontario
June 25, 1946

32 -0-13

Rev. W. J. Zimmerman, M.A.B.D.
Principal,
Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ontario.

Reverend Sir,-

I wish to acknowledge your letter of June 21st addressed to Dr. Moore concerning your report on the family and one boy ten years of age in the school. Dr. Moore is away at present so I am replying in his place.

With the information contained in your letter, it is difficult to state just what action should be taken. As the boy has been sent to Lady Willington Hospital, I think you should take the whole matter up with Dr. Davis and Indian Superintendent. I would presume that this may be possibly congenital syphilis and there is a possibility that the other members of the family might be negative.

I am sending a copy of this letter to Dr. Davis for his action.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

W. L. Palmerer, M.D.,
Actg.-A/Supt. Indian Health Services
Ottawa, Ontario
June 25, 1946

Dr. V. Davis,
Medical Superintendent,
Cheweken, Ont.

Enclosed in a copy of a letter from the Reverend W.J. Zimmerman and of my reply to him. It would be appreciated if you would take whatever action is necessary concerning this family.

Yours very truly,

Ottawa, May 14, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your 108-652/36 of the 12th instant, with reference to the accidental death of Effie Smith, a pupil of the Mohawk Institute.

I note that you are holding an enquiry into the circumstances of the accident that resulted in her death, and I enclose a supply of forms for this purpose. One copy, properly completed, should be returned to the Department.

You should make careful enquiry from the Principal regarding the swings in use at the school, and ascertain how often they are examined by a member of the staff and what steps are taken, or will be taken, to avoid any possibility of an accident in the future.

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Dept. of Indian Education.

ENQ.

Major E. P. Randle,
Indian Superintendent,
Brantford, Ont.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of

Effie Smith ..........................................., Pupil No. 8991

of the Mohawk Institute Indian Residential School at Brantford, Ontario

who died at Brantford, Ont. ..................... (place) on May 11 ............... 1936

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Form No. 414.
A. STATEMENT OF THE PRINCIPAL OF THE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

1. On what date did this pupil fall sick or suffer injury? May 11-1936.

2. At what time of day? 6:15 P.M.

3. When and to whom did he or she report this illness or accident? 6:15 P.M., May 11-36 to Miss S. Hardie

4. What means were taken to afford relief? Doctor called immediately.

5. What medicines were used for this purpose and in what dose or quantity? None.

6. When was the doctor called? 6:20 P.M., May 11-1936.

7. If the pupil was removed to hospital, at what time was this done and by what means of transport? 7:15 P.M., May 11, by ambulance.

8. If the pupil was not removed to hospital, what measures were taken for his or her care at the school?

9. Add any other useful information here.

Five girls including Effie Smith were playing on the "Giant Stride" Maypole. They had put a board through loops in the unfurled chains and were being pushed around the pole thus throwing all the weight toward one side of the pole. This caused the pole to split a piece out of the side of the pole at the top allowing the wheel to fall to the ground where it struck Effie Smith in abdomen causing the injuries from which she died.

Note: If the deceased pupil dies in hospital at a distance from the school, under the care of the physician or surgeon who attends him at the hospital, a clinical report of the patient's illness and death in the hospital is to be secured and attached to this memorandum.

Horace W. Scott
Principal.
B. STATEMENT OF THE PHYSICIAN WHO ATTENDED
THE DECEASED PUPIL

I attended Effie Smith from May 1st 6:00 PM
to 8:45 PM. The immediate cause of death was
injury with hemorrhage. Death of patient.

The contributory cause of death was
accident.

Do you consider that the Principal of the School, and the members of the School staff exercised reasonable care and judgment in regard to the illness and death of this pupil? Yes

Did they follow out your professional instructions? Yes

If in either respect, you consider them to have been at fault, it is required that you express your carefully considered views as follows:

K.K. Palmer M.D.
C. STATEMENT OF INDIAN AGENT

1. Having heard and read over the statements of the Principal and the Physician, do you consider that all essential circumstances relating to the death of Effie Smith have been recorded? Yes. If not, you are required to add here any further particulars which strike you as essential.

2. In this space record any recommendations which the Board consider should be made to the Department in relation to the health or safety of the pupils of this School.

E. P. Russell
Chairman—Indian Agent.
Ottawa, May 19th, 1956.

Dear Sir,

The Department is in receipt of your 103-688/36 of the 14th instant, enclosing memorandum of inquiry into the death of Effie Smith from injuries sustained in an accident at the Mohawk Institute.

The Department would appreciate your obtaining and forwarding to us the verdict rendered at the coroner's inquest, which you state was held on Friday, last.

Yours truly,

J. D. Butheland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Major E. P. Randle,
Indian Superintendent,
Brantford, Ont.
RECOMMENDED INSPECTION OF ALL EQUIPMENT

Intra-Abdominal Hemorrhage Cause of Death of Effie Smith

MAYPOLE VICTIM

A recommendation that the playground equipment at the Mohawk Institute be inspected every three months by a competent surgeon was made last night in the verdict of the jury at the inquest at the Police Station here today into the death of Effie Smith, 13, pupil of the institute, who died May 11 when she fell off a maypole around which she was swinging.

Dr. Harold Palmer, who conducted an examination of the victim of the accident, said death had been caused by an intra-abdominal hemorrhage.

It was stated in evidence that the wheel weighed about 100 pounds and the pole was 20 feet high and 18 feet from the ground. Molly Johnson, 14, and Louise Davis, who were riding around the maypole on a beam with the Smith child, also fell off and were badly injured.

The coroner's inquest was held yesterday afternoon and continued today. The coroner, Dr. H. H. Palmer, Ray H. W. Smith, Dr. Harold Palmer, Dr. C. H. Lager, an Institute of Technology, and Dr. D. D. Smith, a dentist, and the examination was conducted by Crown Attorney Wallace.

Rev. Mr. Snell described the playground equipment as being in good condition when the accident occurred, stating it was equipped with swings, teeter-totters, slides, and other apparatus.

The maypole was an improvised affair, he said, and had been constructed at the institute. The wheel was an automobile wheel placed on top of the pole to a hole at the top of the pole. It was attached to the pole by a chain on one side of the pole that caused the wheel to fall.

The Smith child was not under constant supervision. Rev. Mr. Snell said. He said there were no attendants who looked after the recreational period of the pupils at the institute. He was unaware of the accident when it occurred.

"How long has the pole been there?" Crown Attorney Wallace asked.

"It was there when I came seven years ago," Mr. Snell replied.

"Was it in operation before you came?" the Crown questioned.

"Yes," Mr. Snell answered.

Pointing to what appeared to be a spot where it broke, Crown Attorney Wallace asked Rev. Mr. Snell:

"Did you know anything about this?"

"I never knew it was there," Rev. Mr. Snell said.

"Was that one side of the pole where the piece is broken off or was it the whole pole?" the Crown questioned.

"From the appearance of it," Mr. Snell replied, "you do not employ a regular carpenter on your staff, do you?"

"No."

"This maypole was constructed by a malcontent."

"Was this wheel, or any part of it considered dangerous by you or your staff?"

"I don't think any of us ever thought of it as being dangerous with it."

Rev. Mr. Snell stated there were no regulations regarding the use of the maypole and that it was used by the Government for recreational purposes.

"We also recommend that the playground equipment be inspected every three months by competent inspectors."

The jurors were: R. W. Henry, Foreman; Elijah Smith, T. J. Smith, W. H. Williams, Charles Craddock, E. Conner and Mrs. Mary Proctor, Officer Girl W. Parrow in charge of witnesses and the jury.

WERE RIDING SWAN

Moff Johnson, an Institute pupil, testified that a beam, a two-by-four, had been placed across the top of the pole and was, with the Smith girl, Louise Davis, Velma Powless and Hazel Vanier, riding on it. They had hardly started when the wheel fell off and struck her in the crack in the pole before the accident. Miss Powless also stated she did not notice anything wrong.

Witnesses admitted the fact that the pole was not painted black on one side of the pole would cause the paint to come off on the top of the pole to become dangerous.

The verdict in full was as follows:

"We, the jurors, find it impossible to inquire into the death of the Smith child, a pupil of the Mohawk Institute, who died May 11, 1936, at the Brantford General Hospital, as the death was due to intra-abdominal hemorrhage caused by striking a wheel from a maypole which was constructed at the Mohawk Institute in the Town of Brantford.

"We also recommend that the playground equipment be inspected every three months by competent inspectors."

The jurors were: R. W. Henry, Foreman; Elijah Smith, T. J. Smith, W. H. Williams, Charles Craddock, E. Conner and Mrs. Mary Proctor, Officer Girl W. Parrow in charge of witnesses and the jury.
Re: Effie SMITH (Indian) - Mohawk Institute, Brantford, Ont. - Accidental Death.

4. In the evening of May 15th I patrolled to Brantford, Ont. and attended the Inquest which was held at the Police Station at 8:30 p.m. Coroner Dr. D.A. Harrison presided and the examination was conducted by Crown Attorney F.E.D. Wallace. Provincial Constable C. Farrow had charge of the witnesses and the jury. The verdict of the Jury was as follows:

"We the undersigned Jury empaneled to inquire into the death of Effie Smith, a pupil of the Mohawk Institute, find she came to her death at the Brantford General Hospital, May 11th, 1936 from an intra-abdominal hemorrhage caused by being struck by a wheel from maypole which we consider was not safe at the Mohawk Institute in the Township of Brantford, May 11th, 1936."

"We also recommend that the playground equipment be inspected every three months by a competent Inspector."

5. Major E.P. Randle, Supt. Six Nations Reserve also attended the Inquest, and is aware of all the facts in connection with this case which was purely accidental.

Expense - Nil.

To - The Commissioner, R.C.M.P.

Forwarded. A copy of this report is being furnished the Commissioner of the Ontario Provincial Police.

CASE CONCLUDED.

Toronto, 20-5-36. C.

R. E. Mercer, Insp. for Supt. A.O.D.
Comdg. "O" Div.
Division File No. 36 T 1180/8

R.C.M.P. CANADIAN MOUNTED POLICE

Division: 70°
Province: Ontario
Sub-Division: [Blank]
Detachment: [Blank]

Date: May 16th, 1936.

Re: Effie SMITH (Indian) - Mohawk Institute, Brantford, Ont.
Accidental Death.

1. In the evening of May 11th I received a telephone call from F.K.D. Wallace, Crown Attorney at Brantford advising that the above named Indian girl had been seriously injured as a result of an accident in the playground of the Mohawk Institute about 6.00 p.m. that evening, and had died some two hours later at the General Hospital, Brantford, Ont. He stated the Coroner had been advised, also Major Randle, Sept. Six Nations Reserve. Mr. Wallace requested that I come to Brantford immediately and meet him and Major Randle at the Mohawk Institute.

2. Accordingly I proceeded to the Mohawk Institute and together with the Crown Attorney and Major Randle obtained the details in connection with the accident. Owing to the lateness of the night the children who were eye-witnesses to the accident were not interviewed. Next morning I proceeded to Brantford and accompanied by Provincial Const. C. Farrow interviewed all witnesses in regard to the accident.

3. The circumstances in connection with this death are as follows:

About 6.00 p.m. on the night in question the above named together with four other girl pupils of the school were playing on a swinging affair which is known as the "Maypole". The pole itself is about 18 feet high and approximately 6 inches in diameter at the top. A automobile wheel is attached to the top of the pole by means of an axle about 15 inches long which is inserted in a hole in the centre of the pole. Four chains were attached to the wheel on top of the pole and reach to the end 2 feet approximately to the ground. Instead of swinging individually on each chain which distributes the weight evenly on the pole the five girls placed a 7 foot plank between the loops of three of the chains and the five of them sat on this plank and were swinging around the pole with the aid of two other girls who were pushing them. As a result of all the weight being on the one side the pole split at the top where the axle of the wheel fitted into the pole, which allowed the axle to come out of position with the result that the wheel fell to the ground striking the above named girl on the abdomen. The weight of the wheel itself was estimated at 100 pounds and the whole apparatus was a homemade affair. It was ascertained the pole had been split at the top previous to the accident and appeared to have been cracked for some time. The top of the pole together with the axle and wheel was taken by Capt. Farrow and myself to be used as evidence at the Coroner's Inquest.

- Continue...

May 12th, 1934

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Sir:

I very much regret to have to report to you a serious accident to Number 0991, Effie Smith which occurred last night at 6.15 p.m. and resulted in her death at the Brantford General Hospital the same evening.

The Board of Inquiry had already sat, and Major E. P. Randle will be forwarding to you a full report.

I may only say that it was purely accidental and so far as I can see no blame is to be attached to anyone.

Your obedient servant,

Horace W. Swell.

Principal.
MOHAWK INSTITUTE

BRANTFORD, ONTARIO, May 25 - 36.

Replying to
No. 32-0-1
May 22-36.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

The newspaper report of the inquest re the death of Effie Smith, while perfectly fair, hardly gives the right impression of the part of my testimony which you quote. The Crown Attorney asked me "Does the Department make a grant for playground equipment?" and, of course, I answered "NO" but added that the Department did furnish us with equipment such as balls, bats, etc. He then asked if our equipment was sometimes homemade as in the case of the Giant Stride and I answered that it was. No one who heard the evidence could possibly have inferred that the Department was niggardly in its provision for the pupils.

The court did not think Mr. Lager was remiss, inasmuch as he explained that he took it that the ring around the pole had been placed there to strengthen the pole where it was checked. The check, as was shown to the coroner and jury, did not reach completely to the top of the pole. Had the ring been nearer to the top of the pole it would have effectually prevented the split that caused the accident.

I may say that the mother attached no blame to the management. In fact, she made the request that her little boy might be admitted next term if there is room for him. I have received a very kind letter written on her behalf, thanking us for our kindness in connection with the sad occurrence.

I shall be glad to furnish any further information desired.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) Horace W. Snell.
Principal.

Ottawa, February 7, 1907.

Right Reverend Sir,

I have the honour to advise you that the Department is in receipt of returns from the schools at Moose Factory as follows:— returns from the day school for the March, June, September and December quarters, 1906; also a return giving the names of the pupils and their ages only from the Boarding school.

A cheque will be sent to the Royal Trust Co., Montreal, for $800, being the amount of the day school grant in full for the four day schools in your diocese, namely, Moose Factory, Albany, Rupert's House and Fort George. This is the total amount of grant provided for the fiscal year ending March 31, next. The Department would like you to be good enough to instruct the teachers at Albany, Rupert's House and Fort George to send in quarterly returns for this fiscal year at the first opportunity presented and regularly thereafter.

The return received from the Boarding School at Moose Factory is very incomplete, and a new return should be forwarded by the Principal made out on the proper form, a copy of which is sent you under separate cover, with all the columns of the return as called for carefully filled.

The Right Reverend George Holmes,
Bishop of Neocanoe,
Charlevoix, Ont.
filled in. This information is required by the Department and the Auditor General.

In the meantime, however, the grant for the Boarding School for the quarter ended September 30, last, is paid on the return received from the Rev. Claude Ovens, which return shows that there were twenty-three pupils in attendance. At $15.00 per capita (the amount payable quarterly) the earnings of the school were $345.00. An advance of $300 was sent you on October 30, last, on this account, leaving a balance due for the quarter of $45.00, a cheque for which is being sent you.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient Servant,

[Signature]

Secretary.
Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter enclosing cheque for $45.00, being the balance of September quarter 1906, for which please accept thanks.

I am very sorry that the returns forwarded to you from Moose Fort were so incomplete. Mr. Oxley, who was teacher last year had instructions to send in regularly quarterly returns made out in accordance with the Department's Regulations.

Did you not receive returns for the Boarding School at Moose Fort for December, March & June last (1906)?

I forwarded to the Department such returns as were made out by Mr. Oxley. The Boarding School opened in September 1906 with an average attendance all the winter through of between thirty and twenty six scholars; but the grant made by the Dept. only begins with 1st July 1906. Why the Dept. did not arrange for the grant to be made from the opening of the school is a little puzzling to me, owing to the inexperience of the workers & management of such schools, & they exceeding my orders in regard to number of scholars and allowance for school support. The account from the Hudson Bay Co. for support alone apart from equipment was the amount stated in the accounts forwarded in December last to the Department which was more than twice the amount I stipulated in my instructions to those in charge at Moose Fort.

(over)
I hope, therefore, that the Department will see its way to pay us for the number of scholars in the school, as bounded from September 1st to June 1st, 1906.

The Rev. R.J. Benson, who is now in charge of Moose Fort Mission, who is one of the cleverest and best of missionaries, informs me that they have an average attendance of 55 scholars including the founders which makes an average attendance of 35 half breed children. For this number of children in the North West, while I was in charge of Lower Slave Lake School in Athabasca, the grant for the number was $700.00, and ought not to be less in Ontario since it is self evident that no one teacher can do justice to 55 children. During the summer months when the Indians are present there will probably not be less than 150 scholars.

So far the half-breeds have received no consideration such as they have in the North West Territories. It does not therefore seem unreasonable that the Post should provide missionary means for the secular education of their children.

Will you kindly let us know the proper quarter ought to apply for an increase in this Grant & obliging

Yours very sincerely,

George Mosson,
Bishop of Moosefort.
Ottawa, 26th February, 1907.

Right Reverend Sir,

In reply to your favor of the 11th instant I have to say that it would be impossible for the Department to assist you with the maintenance grant of the Moose Factory Boarding School prior to the 1st of July 1906. You will remember that the School was opened in advance of any recognition by the Department and it did not appear as an institution for which the Government was responsible to a certain extent until the appropriation voted by Parliament became available on the 1st of July last. It was understood that you proposed to bear the full cost of the School until the Department was in a position to assist.

An application for a grant for educational advantages provided for half-breed children, and elsewhere in the Province of Ontario, should be made to the Education Department, Toronto. As Mr. D. G. Macmartin who was the Ontario Commissioner for Treaty No 9 is acquainted with the situation at that post with reference to half-breeds as well as Indians, and as the Ontario Government has already recognized the half-breed claims by granting 100 acres each, it might be well to refer to Mr. Macmartin in your communication to the Ontario Government.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Right Rev. George Holmes,
Secretary,
Bishop of Moose Cree,
Chapleau, Ont.

Dear Mr. Redley,

Knowing that the Indians are wards of the Government and that I am in charge of the Boarding School and responsible to you for the treatment the children receive while under my care, I feel it is my duty to report this fact.

On the evening of the 2nd Feb., the Rev. J. Armstrong came to the school and visited the girls' bedrooms after I had sent them to bed. He then took them out into the yard and had his men cruelly whipped so much so that their hands were swollen and discolored two days afterwards. In the same manner, they were playing outside our own door not far from where my residence is. One was Clara Sutherland, a house girl and an orphan; the other Mary Smith or Morton's Falls. Sometimes we had also at different times previously observed the girls around their bedrooms. In consequence, Clara and Jane (my eldest girl) have been withdrawn from the school. The others are unable to get in their houses during the winter, else I fear they too would be withdrawn.

I would also like to state that I cannot vouch as to the correctness of the reports of the Boarding School and to you as they have never been submitted to me for signature before they were sent, and if signed by anyone else as written it is false.
as I have been in charge here as per appointment of Bishop Anderson since October 1911.

I remain

very truly yours,

Harry A. Johnson
Ottawa, March 21, 1912.

Right Reverend Sir,

I have the honour to call Your Lordship's attention to the following extract from a letter addressed to the Department by Miss Mary A. Johnson, Matron of the Moose Fort Indian Boarding School:— "On the evening of the 2nd of February the Rev. W. Haythornwhite, Missionary in charge, came into the school, went to the girls' bedroom after I had sent them to bed, brought them down, took them over to his study and had two of them cruelly whipped, so much so that their hands were swollen and discolored for two days afterwards, for the simple reason that they were playing outside our own door not his and with my permission. One was Clara Sutherland, a Moose Girl and an orphan, the other May Shipe of Marten's Falls, motherless. He had also at different times previously chased the girls around their bed-rooms. In consequence Clara and Jane Tapas my eldest girl have been withdrawn from the school. The others are unable to get to their homes during the winter, else I fear they too would be withdrawn."

The Department considers that a thorough investigation of the alleged ill-treatment of the pupils should be made at the earliest possible date and a full report sent in, as, if there is any truth in the charges, the Principal should be removed at once.

I have the honour to be, Right Reverend Sir,

Right Rev. John G. Anderson, D.D.,
Bishop of Moosonee,
Chapleau, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

I went home inside a week after the boy and girl had been sent home, and I was summoned to see a third child die—Malcolm Cowper. I was kept in ignorance of this boy's state until five minutes before his death. You must know, Bishop, that it is hard enough to keep the school full without this kind of thing, and I have no intention of allowing children to go without any knowledge. While Miss Hudson is doing her best for her own children, she is scarcely led by Miss Bennett, who is the instigator of nearly all these faults.

The above extracts from Mr. Haydon's letter, and Miss Johnson's defense, are sufficient to show that matters between the Principal and Miss Johnson have been very unsatisfactory. In fact, the Principal is now forced to keep out of the school for the sake of peace, as Miss Johnson claims that she was given entire control of the school when Miss Johnson took over the former Principal's duties last autumn. She has complained that I sent Mr. Haydon to take charge while her own religion was being taught. The Albany Church Council has come into conflict with Miss Johnson's methods. While she has, perhaps, no cause, she accepted a new position at Moose. This happened in December last, when, of course, no change could be made, and therefore Mr. Haydon continued in charge.

My own opinion is that Miss Bennett deserves to be dismissed. She has been a constant source of trouble in the class, and we have had to deal with her behavior, which is at the bottom of most of the trouble. She seems to be acting in defiance of her residence at the U.B.C. Post Office, and the Boarding School seems to be worse.

This appears from a letter of Miss Baxter, also mentioned in above extract. She says: "I only hope Miss Bennett will go back at first open water, being a friend of Miss Johnson she spends the greater part of her time at the Boarding School; we doubtless this is the cause of the peculiar behavior."

I wish you were coming down by first open water as it is far from pleasant here.

I may say that I have planned to visit James Bay this summer, leaving as early as I can (likely about May 15th) and going via Grand Lake, Kenora, and Chipewyan House. I should reach Moose by the end of June. I will then hold a full investigation, and give you a report on my return.

The Secretary, Dept. of Indian Affairs.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of March 21st, I may say that I have received a letter from Miss Johnson containing the same charges against the Rev. W. Heathcote-Watson. But I have also received a letter from Mr. Haydon-Watson containing similar charges of misconduct against the Rev. W. Heathcote-Watson. The incident between the girls and the Rev. W. Heathcote-Watson was the climax of a long process of provocation. The girls say: "One evening as I was walking at my desk near the girls' camp, I saw something at my desk near the girls' camp. I went out into the moonlight and heard one of the girls saying in a loud voice: 'I want to go home.' I went back inside the house where I found them, but could not find them. I went home disgusted. I had not been set down half an hour before the girls came out again. I followed them into the house, and asked Miss Johnson why they were there, which she refused to do. Therefore sent them out of the house and called Miss Butler (teacher) to the day school. She then went to the girls' bedroom and told them off with a stick - that will be the same thing I had done. I went out of the house so that she had to leave a window open just as I did. Miss Butler called me to anything she wanted to do. I looked around and said, 'She was the Policeman's partner off.' The Missions premises. He replied that he had nothing to do with the mission. The day following I heard from one of the boys that the girl she had been punished had come home. Thinking the girl had run away, I went over to bring her back. It was only then I felt that Miss Johnson had asked me people to take her away because I had punished her. I got her clothes and let her come back with me. She came crying to me, telling me that Miss Johnson had sent her away again. I looked her out for a week, but she still naturally did not care for that, so she...

When Miss Bennett and Miss Taylor were temporarily ill in class, these ladies continued to get Mrs. Hackett to teach in the hospital against the wishes of Mr. Haythorne. Miss Bennett and Miss Taylor were warned against the principal because he asked Mrs. Hackett to discontinue her teaching. Miss Taylor visited in the school room and was seen taking nearly all his meals there. During the day they took at night. I may say that the reports of the things done at the school at this time reached all parts of James Bay. Miss Johnson, who is an old friend of Miss Bennett, evidently soon after her arrival complained of Mr. Haythorne's conduct against the principal, and began giving him trouble with his attitude toward the pupils and school affairs. The "playing outside our own door" was forbidden, was only one form of punishment employed by Mr. Haythorne. His wife was deliberately encouraged by those in Mr. Haythorne's study. He made the excuse of playing "new game." His Haythorne visited once from his house, summoned them to his study, Miss Johnson being present. When they reported to the provost, Mr. Haythorne visited them in his study, and visited their teacher, Miss Bennett, to punish them, which she did with the ordinary school teacher. All these facts will give me an idea of how things were carried on in the school. Miss Johnson and Miss Taylor were resigned, and have closed Mrs. Haythorne's place in order to seek Mr. Haythorne's assistance. Miss Taylor is now engaged as a teacher at Moosonee.
that he practically relinquished his duties at the school. Miss Hanson & Miss Taylor to investigate.

I found also from other sources that he, from his stay throughout being the cause of the withdrawal of Clara Buttenworth's foster children, that Miss Buttenworth had nothing but the worst to say about them. They were dismissed by Miss Hanson, so that they were not allowed to remain. I was also told by a family of Indians in Albany, Saskatchewan, that the Indian boys had their feet frozen at the school, owing to the neglect of Miss Hanson, who, with Miss Taylor, often visited among the people leaving the pupils to themselves. I myself found when at Moose, that Miss Hanson had placed a girl that I thought was fit for a maid in the Indian Bay residence (but Moose) to work as a maid without mentioning her to the Department excepting that she knew that Miss Hanson, your aunt, had her let non-Indian Indians children could not receive it in Ojibwa grant. My opinion is that it is only an excuse because she had under various pretexts dismissed the pupils. In fact she seems to have done her best to put the school off because she liked Mr. Waymouth while she had to treat him, that is, have him disqualified & discarded. It whole trouble began in the summer of 1894 when Miss Waymouth wrote to me against a certain Mr. Hackett visiting the school. I am not sure if it was during his interval between Miss Buttenworth's departure or whether she arrived after Miss Hanson.

Oct 3rd

Dear Sir,

Referring your Communication of March 21st last, I have to report that during my summer visitation of the missions and schools on James Bay, I made an investigation into the charges made by Miss Mary Johnson against the Principal, Rev. W. Haythornthwaite. The principal defended himself in person before a board which was convened by the superior, resident Bishop. It was claimed by Miss Johnson that the principal had been unfaithful to his duties and had neglected his responsibilities. After a thorough investigation, it was found that there was no evidence to support these allegations.

Miss Johnson was dismissed from her position due to her inability to perform her duties effectively. She has since been employed as a teacher at another mission.

I am enclosing a copy of the report for your information.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

CHAPLEAU, ONT
Aug. 24th, 1913

Dear Sir,

I have been informed by our missionary at Moose Factory that the Indian Department have promised upon an application to Mr. Thomas Barker, who has taken up the subject in the school. This latter, no doubt, has an air about him, but a course last year at the agricultural college at Sudbury, or is qualified for this work.

I understand that a grant of $50 per annum is allowed by the Government for this special work and also assistance toward the purchase of seed, fencing, etc. We are making a great effort in the direction of improving our farms and gardens and believe a fine stock at Moose Factory can be cleared of brush and planted in use. Notwithstanding the severe frost in the spring, which practically destroyed all potatoes near the school, a good harvest has been raised in sufficient for the needs of the school and some to sell. I say this planning has also been successful in some cases. I mention these things to show the need of such instruction for independent improvement, and because we would like to have where to apply for the plant assistance referred to above.

With best wishes, sincerely yours, [Signature]

[Signature]
Ottawa, February 1st, 1913.

Right Rev. Sir:

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your Lordship's communication of the 4th instant, in which you ask for a grant to enable the Moose Factory Boarding School to extend their farming operations, and in reply, I beg to say that the Department does not make any grant to Boarding Schools for this purpose, and any expenditure incurred must be met from the per capita grant paid by the Department. As a recognition of Miss Barker's services in connection with the Day School, the Department has decided to increase her salary by $50.00, making the total $850.00 from the 1st of current quarter, and Miss Barker is being informed accordingly.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Right Rev. John G. Anderson, D.D.,
Bishop of Moose Cree,
Chapleau, Ont.
ST. THOMAS MISSION

TO THE DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

We wish to respectfully bring before the Department the need of land at Moose in connection with the Boarding-School.

At present we occupy only a few acres of the Hudson's Bay Co.'s land, and it is very desirable that we should have enough land to farm. We should very much like to have a quarter section on "Hazey Island." This Island is the only land near enough to our present buildings to be useful for that purpose.

We have now three boys able to plow and it is highly desirable that they should have some land to practice on. It is all bush land and would be too expensive to clear unless the school had some claim on it afterwards.

At present the Indians know practically nothing about farming, and as they may be required to go onto their Reserve at anytime it is very important that the Department should prepare them for the change.

During the last two years we have been in touch with the Officials at Guelph and have made a number of satisfactory experiments on a small scale and we are anxious now to prove them on a larger.

We also think that it would be very beneficial to the Indians generally if the Department gave us some special* for this purpose. We are held back at Moose by prohibitive freight rates, and although we have spent every cent we could get, we seem to get so little for it. Many of the tools we have got out during the past two years have cost us fifty per cent more than the first cost by the time we got them here.

Then just as we are getting a few machines together the horse fails and any sort of a horse will cost us $500 by the time we get it.

We think it would be good policy on the part of the Department to secure some land for the School, lend us a team and a Stumping machine, and let us show the Indians how what can be done on their reserve. If we wait for the Indians to move, it will be a long time to wait, and of course it is not the policy of the trading Company to move in this direction. If the School does not teach them now it will cost the Department a great deal more in the future.

Trusting that this may have just consideration,

I remain

YOURS SINCERELY:

(PRINCIPAL)

Dear Sir,-

I beg to submit the following report on the work performed by me during the past summer in making the payment of Treaty 9 annuities to Indians residing in James Bay District.

I visited the Hospitals and Schools and have no adverse criticisms to offer. I am very sorry, however, to have to report the said accident which happened at Moose. On the evening of the 29th June, twelve of the boys from the Moose Factory Boarding School were crossing the Moose River to Nasely Island, when the canoe was accidentally upturned, and in spite of prompt assistance, seven of the boys were drowned, viz., Alfred Loutitt, Thomas Loutitt, Arthur Sutherland, James Sutherland, Harry Wesley, John Sailors and Sinclair Nepaneshkum. John Carpenter, a boy of fourteen years son of Jimmy Carpenter of Fort Hope Band, supported a small boy of eight years of age until assistance arrived. I feel that this boy should receive some recognition for his gallant services and I trust the Department will take up the question with the proper authorities and have the matter brought before the Humane Society for recognition.

H.M. Anney.
Ottawa, September 6, 1919.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that it has been brought to the attention of this Department by Mr. H. N. Awrey, Paying Officer for Treaty No. 9, that a very sad drowning accident happened at Moose Factory on the evening of the 25th of June, last. Twelve boys, pupils of the Moose Factory Boarding School, were crossing the Moose River to Haney Island, when the canoe they were in was accidentally upset and seven of the boys were drowned.

A gallant rescue of one of the party, a small boy eight years of age, was made by John Carpenter, who was also in the party. John Carpenter is an Indian boy, fourteen years of age, the son of an Indian named Jimmy Carpenter of the Fort Hope Band. He was in the canoe with the other boys at the time of the accident and through his efforts he supported one of the smaller boys and held him up in the water until assistance arrived.

It is felt that some recognition should be granted John Carpenter for his bravery, and it has been suggested to the Department that his case be laid before your society for recognition. Among the persons who witnessed the accident and saw the brave act made by John Carpenter was the Rev. W. Haythornthwaite, Principal of the school, and his wife. It is considered that recognition by your society of the bravery of John Carpenter would be an incentive to the Indians of that northern country and a reminder that such acts do not go unnoticed or unrewarded.

The Department will be glad if your Society can see its way to a favourable consideration of the case and will be pleased to assist in obtaining all particulars or any affidavits which you may require.

The Department will be pleased to hear from you regarding this matter.

Your obedient servant,

For Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

The Secretary,
Royal Canadian Humane Association,
Hamilton, Ont.
Ottawa, September 6, 1919.

Rev. Sir,

Mr. H. N. Awrey, Paying Officer for Treaty No. 9, who has recently returned to the Department, reports a very sad drowning accident which occurred on the evening of the 29th of June, last, whereby seven boys, pupils of the Moose Factory Boarding School, lost their lives by the upsetting of the canoe in which they were crossing Moose River.

Their death is regretted and the Department sympathizes with the parents and the school in their loss.

Mr. Awrey reports that no blame can be attached to yourself or the other members of the staff, but it is considered that to allow such a large number of boys in a canoe should not have been permitted. It is hoped that this accident will not result detrimentally to the future recruiting of pupils for the school.

The bravery of John Carpenter, one of the boys who supported a small boy of eight years of age until assistance arrived, is being brought to the attention of the Royal Canadian Humane Association, as it is considered that it is worthy of some recognition.

Your obedient servant,

FOR Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

ST THOMAS' MOOSE.
13th Oct. 1919.

The Secretary, Indian Dept.:
Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of the Department's kind letter of sympathy touching our great loss on the 29th of July last. Also respecting the Department's effort to get some recognition from the Canadian Humane Association.

In reply I beg to state that we have now received the declaration forms which will receive our prompt attention, owing to the departure of the last canoe in the morning early it will be impossible to complete them in time for this packet and it may be some weeks before another opportunity.

While we cannot concur in Mr. Arey's most charitable opinion regarding our responsibility, we do sincerely thank both him and the Department for their kindness and sympathy.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Principal of the Moose Factory Boarding School.
A translation of the attached Cree letter, which was intended for
Duncan Campbell Scott Esq.
Deputy Superintendent General
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.

A report from Moose Factory, Ontario.

I, Chief Woomastoogish, and George Hardisty, Andrew Butterfly, and John Dick.

We want to give the Government a true report of the drowning of the children.

There were twelve children in the canoe and the children were alone, and the canoe which they were using was very bad. A canoe which was not fit for anyone to use. The canvas of the canoe was half ripped.

Now these children were allowed to go crossing the river every day in it and very often twice one evening. The canoe was that far gone that the thwarts were just nailed on top of the gunwale.

There was not one boy big enough to have any sense.

I don't know if this report was sent in yet or not, but this which I say is exactly what happened, and this is the weight which I am carrying.

Now you know just the same as I do, about that which I am speaking of.

I, Thomas C. Moore, of Moose Factory do hereby swear that I have a thorough knowledge of the Cree and English languages, and that I have at various times acted as interpreter, for officials of The Department of Indian Affairs, and that the above letter is a true translation of the Cree letter attached, which was written by the Chief of the Moose Band of Indians.

Sworn to before me this 13th day of October 1919
at Moose Factory, in the Province of Ontario.

Commissioner for taking Affidavits
District of Temiskaming
Moose Factory Oct 13th 1919
Refer to No 542

Subject: Drowning accident at Moose Factory

Duncan Campbell Scott Esq
Deputy Superintendent General
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

Dear Sir,

I recently received a visit from the Chief of the Moose Band of Indians in connection with a very sad drowning accident, which occurred during the summer at Moose Factory.

He asked my advice as to what steps he should take to bring the matter to the notice of the Department and I replied that perhaps it would be well to write to you in his own language and have a translation of the letter forwarded.

He decided to do this and the attached letter is the result. It is somewhat incoherent so I beg to supplement it with a copy of the report I sent to the Fur Trade Commissioner of The Hudson's Bay Company on the subject.

It reads as follows:

Sep 19th 1919

I regret to have to report a very serious drowning accident in this District. It occurred on July 29th at Moose Factory. It appears that twelve of the school children from the Church of England Mission of which The Rev Haythornthwaite is in charge, were allowed to crowd into an old canoe, for the purpose of crossing to an Island to pick berries. It was high tide with quite a big sea running. When about in mid channel the canoe capsized and seven out of the twelve children were drowned. The remaining five were saved by an Indian named Archie Sailor who in a small canoe managed to pick them up. Mr Gaudet sent out his entire force of Servants with all canoes available, to search for the bodies, and by 6 p.m. on the 30th the seven bodies were recovered. Two of the boys drowned were sons of one of our Servants, Samuel Louttit who is employed at Fort George.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
District Manager
ST. THOMAS' MOOSE,
3rd January, 1920.

J. DeMcLean, Esq.
Assistant Deputy
Dept. Indian Affairs.

I have taken it upon myself to fill one and have requested the Manager of Revillon Frere's Loose River Post to complete the other. Most of the other witnesses could not give a clear account of the accident and rescue in English.

PATHETIC END OF ANGLICAN RECTOR

COCHRANE, Ont., Aug. 10.—The Anglican rector at Moose Factory on James Bay, Rev. W. Haythornwaite, who was wounded severely, ended his suffering with a bullet. According to word just received here from Rev. J. G. Anderson, bishop of the Anglican diocese of Moose Factory, on a trip to Fort Albany. Writing to his friend Bishop Anderson says the late rector died from a compound fracture of his shoulder while helping to move a piano and lay for weeks without medical attendance, the nearest doctor residing at Cochrane, 180 miles distant. While crazed with the pain in his shoulder and delirious from fever two weeks ago escaped from his Indian attendants and killed himself.

Rev. Haythornwaite was principal of the Indian school at Moose Factory. He was well known here where he was stationed as rector for 13 months last year. He took an active part in helping the lost American balloonists when they descended in the vicinity of Moose Factory last winter.
Ottawa, September 12, 1921.

Dear Sir,

I beg to submit a report for the year 1921 on the treaty payments made to Indians of Treaty 9 residing in the James Bay District.

I regret to have to report the deplorable death of Prin. Haythornswithe of the Moose Boarding School. For some time he apparently had been suffering from Dementia Praecox which possibly was intensified by an accident received on 3rd June. On June 19th he committed suicide. Fortunately Rev. Walton was there at the time. Bishop Anderson who was at Albany was summoned and was making satisfactory arrangement to have the work of the schools continued. He has placed in charge Rev. Griffin from Albany until more satisfactory arrangement can be made.

It was discovered that several of the children in the boarding school were very badly affected with T.B. and gland trouble, so a weeding out was necessary in order to prevent the spread amongst the other pupils. Dr. Day examined every pupil and as a result some action had to be taken.

In the school there were five Neepineskum orphan children. Lizzie died last winter with T.B., and three of the other children Mary, Peter and Henry have developed the disease. These children are orphans and Bishop Anderson has agreed to place these children with the grandmother and to be looked after and properly rationed until such time as they are able to return to school, on condition that the Department continues to allow the usual grant to be paid the school for them.

I have authorized Bishop Anderson to send George Neepineskum to the Cochrane Hospital to have his tonsils and adenoids removed.

Donald Hester aged 8 years is paralysed as result of Tubercular Spine. He is unable to walk at present is being cared for by Mrs. D. Wesley. This boy was taken from the school on 21st July. I have authorised Mrs. Wesley to take care of the child and to send in proper vouchers for same.
I authorized Bishop Anderson to purchase a tent in which to place Chas. Carpenter another orphan boy who has been several years in the school as this boy has funds to his credit in savings. I told Bishop Anderson to submit vouchers for any expenditures made. Dr. Day states this boy cannot possibly live very long.

Bishop Anderson was taking necessary steps to have the Boarding School conducted according to rules. As already stated, every pupil was examined by Dr. Day and also all new applicants, a list of whom he has forwarded to the Department. The Bishop has made contracts with parents for three years as the parents would not consent to send their children if the contract was for a longer period. Bishop Anderson considers this time limit better and I acquiesce in his idea, and would suggest that he be authorized accordingly.

H. N. Awrey.
OTTAWA, Sept. 21st, 1921.

Right Reverend Sir,

I beg to inform you that Mr. Avery, Paying Officer for Treaty 9, in a report regarding the Moose Factory School recommends that the 3 Neepinaskum orphan children who have developed tuberculosis be placed with their grandmother to be looked after and properly rationed until such time as they are able to return to the school and that the Department continue to provide the usual per capita grant for them.

In this connection, I beg to say that the Department will allow of allowing the same grant for their maintenance as will be given to them while pupils of the school. The names of these children are: Mary, Peter and Henry. Their names should be included by the Principal on his regular quarterly returns. It is noted that they are being taken care of by their grandmother, but that the Department agreed to provide the regular grant for them, which is to be used towards the cost of their maintenance and care.

The action taken by Mr. Avery in authorising you to send George Neepinaskum to the Cochrane Hospital to have his adenoids and tonsils removed is approved.

Donald Hester who is paralyzed as a result of a tubercular spine was placed by Mr. Avery in the care of Mrs. D. Wesley. The Department will pay for his care upon receipt of proper vouchers. Mr. Avery states that he informed Mrs. Wesley accordingly. This boy was removed from the school on the 21st of July, last.

Approval is also granted for the purchase by you of a tent in which to place Charles Carpenter, another orphan boy, who has been several years in the school. You shall submit a properly receipted voucher, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred for the purpose.

It is further noticed by Mr. Avery's report that you have made contracts with the parents for the admission of their children to the Moose Factory School for a period of 3 years only, as the parents would not consent to send their children if the contract was for a longer period. Your action, under the circumstances, is approved.

The Department deeply regrets the death of the late Principal, Rev. Mr. Haythorntheite. It is understood that you have made arrangements for the carrying on of the work at this school until such time as a successor to the late Principal can be appointed.

I have the honour to be, Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Right Rev. J. G. Anderson, D.D.,
Bishop of Moose Factory,
Cochrane, Ont.

Acting Asst. Deputy Secretary

Ottawa, 22nd September, 1921.

Secretary,
Royal Humane Association,
HAMILTON, Ontario.

Dear Sir,-

It gives me much pleasure to inform you of the presentation to John Carpenter of the medal so kindly donated by your Society, to him for bravery in saving from drowning an Indian, a fellow pupil of the Moose Factory Boarding School.

The presentation was made to him in the presence of Chief Wanistagoosh, his Councillors and about three hundred members of the Moose Factory Band. The Indians seemed to be greatly pleased to see the gallantry of one of their race acknowledged by your Society, and I am sure your generosity will not be forgotten, but will produce among these Indians a higher incentive to do good to others.

The Right Reverend Bishop Anderson, Reverend Mr. Walton, Dr. Day, Dr. Hughes, Mr. Neil, Men of the Hudson's Bay Company and others were present at this unique ceremony among the Northern Indians of Canada.

I am,

Sincerely yours,

Dear Sir:

In the absence of our General Secretary I beg to inform you that the Rev. Canon J. T. Griffin Principal of our Society's School at Moose Fort is proceeding on furlough this year and the Rev. J. A. Maggrah has been appointed to take his place.

Mr. Maggrah is a Clergyman in good standing in the Church of England, and has resigned the Parish of St. Mary's, Brandon, Man., of which he was Rector, in order to accept this appointment. He speaks the Ojibwa language and has had considerable experience in Indian Residential School work, having been on the staff at the Shingwauk Home and subsequently on that at the Elkhorn School, before these institutions came under the administration of our Society. Mr. and Mrs. Maggrah will leave Mattice on the 17th instant en route to the Moose Fort School via the Mississipi River.

Trusting that this provision for the oversight of the Moose Fort School may meet with your approval.

I remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,
