Dear Sir:

In a letter recently received from the Rev. J. A. Magrath, Principal of our Society's School at Moose Fort, he informs me that there were 29 pupils in residence at the time he wrote, namely, on September 17th. The pupilage allowed at this School by your Department is only 25, but you have been good enough in the past to pay the grant for a larger attendance than this, and I am writing to ascertain if you will allow the capacity of this School to be raised from 25 as it stands at present, to 30. There is ample accommodation in the class-room, which is a separate building apart from the main school building, for 50 pupils, and as the Principal states in his letter that he can accommodate the 29 pupils in the main school building I should like to have your permission to have this number and one more if necessary, to remain in residence.

When I visited this School last May I was requested by the Chief and Councillors to have a new school built as soon as possible which could accommodate 160 pupils. As it may not be possible to have such a building erected in the immediate future, it would afford some relief to the situation if the capacity of the existing School were increased in the way I have suggested.

Believe me, Sir,

Yours very truly,

Education.

It being the holiday season, I was unable to see the pupils at work in the schools.

Ottawa, July 28th, 1927.

Rev. Sir:

Mr. Avey, of this Department, who has recently returned from his annual payments of annuities to the Indians in the James Bay district, in a report on his visit to the Moose Factory Indian Residential School, states that while in the school he found that an insane woman was being kept at the school and slept in the same apartment as the girls. The Department considers that insane Indians should not be allowed to reside in Indian residential schools owing to the danger to the young children. Mr. Avey states that he understood that steps were being taken to have this woman removed from the school, and I would point out that if this action has not already been taken it will be necessary to have the school relieved of her presence at once. In future no cases of this kind should be taken into the school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

TORONTO, August 23rd, 1928.

Dear Mr. Perrier,

In this morning's issue of the Mail and Empire I find an article stating that Indian education costs have been re-arranged. May I know if this means any change with respect to the amount of cost which your Department will bear in connection with Indian education in Ontario. Or does the article refer to just the one situation which has been adjusted in keeping with general recent practice?

For a number of years a grant of £500.00 has been paid to the Bishop of Moosonee to assist in maintaining the Moose Fort and other schools in the James Bay district educating Indian children. Last year, Mr. Westgate, Field Secretary of the Missionary Society of the Church of England, claimed that the Society was educating non-treaty Indian children at Moose Fort and in several other points in that district and pointed out that for similar work the Province of Alberta paid the Society £1,000.00. The Minister authorized a grant of that amount, £600.00 of which was to be paid to the Missionary Society and £400.00 to the Bishop of Moosonee to be expended on behalf of the Indian schools under his jurisdiction.

Is it possible that the Department of Indian Affairs under a recent decision may assume the cost of education of these Indian children?

Bestly, letter placed

V.K. Greer

1-1-6 Out P.O.S.
INDIAN EDUCATION COSTS REARRANGED

Dominion Government Places All Bands on Common Basis.

FROM T. H. BLACKLOCK,
Mail and Empire Staff Writer,
Ottawa, Aug. 15.—The Dominion government will bear the whole cost of Indian education. In a recent letter to the Indian superintendent at the Six Nations Reserve, near Brantford, which was read to the council, the Indian Department announced:

"Hon. Charles Stewart has warmly supported Mr. Doucet's recommendation that all Canadian Indians be educated by the Government, and there shall be no discrimination in the treatment of Indians throughout the Dominion." This means that $20,000 formerly taken from the band fund of the Six Nations for educational purposes will be paid by the Government.

All the provinces of Ontario and Prairie Provinces have treaties with the Dominion Government, and under these treaties the Government has been obliged to provide Indian education. The same conditions did not apply to British Columbia and Saskatchewan. The Indians in these provinces all have funds and part of the interest from these funds has been used for Indian education. In the case of the Six Nations this amounted to about $20,000 annually, while the schools of Canada spent for the purpose from all the Indians was $85,000. The total amount spent annually by the Dominion government was approximately $1,000,000, so that the band fund contribution was a very small percentage of the whole expenditure of Indian Affairs. It was felt this forced contribution from the band funds of some tribes was the cause of the whole cost of education of others by the Government being discriminatory, and he recommended Hon. Charles Stewart Minister of Indian Affairs that the Government assume the whole cost of education for all the tribes and keep the band funds for other purposes. This Mr. Stewart agreed to do, and at the last session in the House of Commons the vote for Indian education was increased by $48,000, the amount formerly taken from the band funds for educational purposes.

Ottawa, August 25, 1928.

Dear Mr. Greer:

I have your letter of the 23rd instant, enclosing a clipping concerning the re-arrangement of Indian education costs and enquiring if this affects the Department's financial assistance to the Moose Fort Indian Residential School, which is conducted by the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada.

In reply I have to state that Parliamentary Appropriation has met the costs of all Indian residential schools in Canada and of practically all the Indian day schools. This appropriation now amounts to over two million dollars per annum. In the case of the Moose Fort Indian Residential School, we allow a per capita grant of $185 per Indian pupil per year.

In the past, however, a few Indian bands, largely in the settled portions of Ontario, have assisted from their band funds in connection with the expenses at Indian day schools and have provided tuition grants for the brighter Indians who wished to attend high schools and business colleges. This practice of allowing band funds to be used for educational purposes has now been discontinued.

Our payments to the Moose Fort and other Indian residential schools remain exactly as in the past, and any assistance you are giving any Indian schools on account of the education of white or half-breed children - for whom the Department of Indian Affairs is not responsible - is a matter which, of course, rests entirely with you.

With reference to the second portion of your letter, I shall write to you in due course.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

V. K. Greer, Esq., B.A.,
Chief Inspector,
Dept. of Education,
TORONTO, 5, ONT.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 10th instant, 44-6-1, requesting information with regard to the Rev. Joseph Blackburn who is filling the position of Acting Principal of the Moose Factory School, I beg to state as follows:

Mr. Blackburn is a graduate in Arts of Saskatchewan University, and received his theological training at Emmanuel College, Saskatoon. He was for some time Rector of St. Stephen's Parish, Winnipeg, and has held other similar positions of trust since his Ordination to the ministry of the Anglican Church. Mr. Blackburn is married but his wife will not proceed to Moose Factory before the Spring. He himself arrived at Moose Factory on the 24th of December last, having an exceedingly trying trip down the Abitibi and Moose rivers. Our Society in offering this appointment to Mr. Blackburn felt assured that they were offering it to a man of strong spiritual convictions which would enable him to encourage a high spiritual standard of living with those he came in contact with from day to day. His academic standing combined with practical common sense should fit him in a very marked degree for the Principalship of this School.

I regret that through an oversight you were not notified of this appointment at an earlier date, but trust that in the light of the information set forth above, it may have your approval.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Reverend Sir:

Upon receipt of your letter of the 27th ultimo, concerning a supply of fresh meat for the Moose Factory Indian Residential School, I made representations to the Commissioner of National Parks, who replies in part as follows:—

"The permission requested in this instance cannot be granted as it is contrary to the Migratory Birds Convention Act. However, this Department does not desire that the law should be enforced in remote parts of Canada in such a way that grave hardship or starvation might result and the question of strict enforcement in the vicinity of James Bay is left to the good judgment of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, who are on the ground and therefore in a position to appreciate conditions."

I may say that the Department is also writing to the R.C.M.P. in the matter. You will note that this matter will be left to the good judgment of the local Police.

MEMO FOR FILE:

Dr. Hamilton, Indian Agent, reported concerning the Moose Factory Indian Residential School. He is convinced that boarding schools in this locality are not really meeting the need and he thinks that a good day school at this point is all that is required.
The Secretary,

Dear Sir:

During my recent visit to our Moose Factory Indian Residential School, the Principal directed my attention to various requirements which should be supplied to enable him and his staff to carry on the work without unnecessary hardship, and with a fair prospect of success. I discussed these matters fully with the late Dr. Hamilton, your representative at that centre, and while we both realized the urgent necessity of keeping all expenditure at present down to the minimum, we felt that certain items were indispensable and agreed to make a strong request that they be supplied. The items required may be classified as follows:

1. In connection with the Farm and Garden.

To enable the school to grow all the hay, oats, vegetables, etc., required, more land must be broken up and brought under cultivation. The school management will look after this, and I ordered timothy and alsike seed at Cochrane, and sent it forward, along with turnip seed and mangel-wurzel.

2. In connection with the buildings.

The buildings should be replaced by new ones at the earliest date possible. Until they are replaced, they must be made to serve the purpose for which they exist. The hospital building which is about to be used as a Principal's residence required painting inside, and I had a good deal of this done at the time of my visit. New doors are required and I am asking our Commission to supply them. In addition to these requirements a special
grant of $150.00 has already been made available to provide some of the essential furnishings.

A certain amount of lumber is required also (a) to put a new roof on the work-shop (the present roof is more like the proverbial sieve than any other I have seen) (b) to make part of the store-room rat and mouse proof, and (c) to cover the log walls of the new barn. I understood that approximately 75,000 feet of rough lumber was for sale at the Moose River Crossing, about 46 miles away, and Dr. Hamilton undertook to secure the price of this and to advise the Principal accordingly. If the price is reasonable the school management would endeavour to raft it to the school free of cost. Our Commission will undertake to meet the expenditures referred to under these two classifications, but they are obliged to ask your Department to meet the expenditure for the following:

Paints

For class-room roof - 25 gals. black roof paint,
For main school building - 85 gals. black roof paint
For barn - 30 gals. red barn paint
½ doz. 2" paint brushes.

also to meet the expenditure for

3. Manual Training Equipment.

1 doz. #1 medium sandpaper
1 pkt. Assortment sandpaper
1 Edgerite iron plane
1 Hammer
10 Coping saws
7 doz. " blades.

4. Office Equipment.

½ doz. Triumph files
2 only Reliance mucilage
2 bxo Paper clips
1 only Date-stamp
4 doz. Brt Clips 3"
2 bxo Rubber bands, assorted
1 doz. Filing folders, business letter size
2 only Typewriter ribbons for Underwood Machine, black.
Liquid glue, 2 bottles.
5. 31 Mattresses for children's beds, 29" wide.

I trust that your Department may, despite the prevailing financial stringency, and from which our Society is not exempt, be able to supply the items mentioned, and forward the same by the Hudson's Bay Company's steamer due to leave Montreal early in July.

I have the honour to be,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

Our Commission have received a strong and urgent request from the Principal of their School at Moose Factory, to have the official pupilage increased from 30 to 40. When school reopened after the summer holidays the Principal was obliged to refuse admission to over 25 pupils in order that the enrolment might not exceed the official number sanctioned. As he and his family have now taken up residence in the building once used as a hospital, space is available in the main school building for the additional pupilage requested, and our Commission will be obliged if your Department will kindly authorize the same. The Principal states that he has taken up the question of the increased pupilage, with Dr. Tryer, the Indian Agent, and also with Mr. Awrey the Treaty Pay Master, and as both of these representatives of your Department have recognized the urgency of the need, our Commission see no valid reason why it should not be granted.

While writing on this subject I desire to express the strong hope which is entertained by our Society that the Residential School building which was built by our Church at this centre over twenty-five years ago, will be superseded by a fully modern structure, with a capacity of not less than one hundred pupils, during the ensuing fiscal year. As you are no doubt aware, our Church's evangelistic and educational work at Moose Factory began in the year 1861, and has been carried on at an immense cost of life and money ever since, and not without highly encouraging and creditable results. As Indian parents at Rupert House and Albany, in addition to those in the Moose River district are keenly desirous of having their children educated at our Moose Factory School, and the present building cannot accommodate them, you will understand the necessity of having a new and larger building provided at the earliest date possible. With the completion of the T. & N. O. Railway to Moose Factory, the cost of forwarding building material will be greatly reduced, and I most
sincerely trust that nothing may be allowed to prevent your Department from providing our Society next year with the new building requested, in addition to a new building to replace the existing Shingwauk Home at Sault Ste. Marie.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Sir:

It would appear that through an oversight on our part, you were not informed of the appointment of the Rev. Gilbert Thompson to the Acting Principalship of the Moose Factory School from the 20th of October last. At the moment, I find it quite impossible to explain how this matter was overlooked, and I am now taking the first opportunity I have had since my attention was directed to the oversight, to remedy the same.

Mr. Thompson is a graduate in Arts of the Western University, London, Ont., and a graduate of Huron College in the same city, in Theology. Before proceeding to Moose Factory, he was filling the position of Chaplain on our hospital ship the "Columbia", which operates along the southern part of the B.C. Coast, and around Vancouver Island. Mr. Thompson is 30 years of age, and appears to our Commission to possess in a very high degree, the qualifications necessary to fill successfully the Principalship of an Indian Residential School. Our Commission trust that his appointment may be approved by your Department.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Field Secretary, M.S.O.C.

TBRW/JF

In reply I have to say that the Department approves of this appointment.

Your obedient servant,

WINNIPEG, MAN. May 11, 1937.

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I regret to have to inform you that the Rev. Gilbert Thompson, B.A., Principal of our Moose Factory School, was admitted to the hospital in Cochrane, Ont. on May 6th, to undergo a surgical operation on the following day. During his absence from the School Mr. Wilson, the Farm Instructor, has been placed in charge. We sincerely hope and pray that Mr. Thompson's operation may be completely successful, and that he may be able to resume his duties towards the end of the current month of May.

Just before leaving the school for the hospital, he advised our Commission that four girls will be graduating this summer, and asked that they be provided with Prayer Books and Bibles. When making this request, he appears to have overlooked the instruction issued to our Principals to make application to your Department direct for the Books in question. On account of his present condition, the matter is not being referred back to him and it will be appreciated by our Commission if you will forward four Prayer Books and four Bibles, addressed to him at the Moose Factory School.

Thanking you in advance for your kindly help in this matter.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.
Ottawa, May 21st, 1937.

Reverend Sir,

Dear Dr. McGill:

Pursuant to your kind conditional consent to be present at the formal opening of the new school at Moose Factory, I have before me the train schedule of the Temiskaming and Northern Ontario Railway, which operates an extension from Cochrane to Moosonee. The railway is apparently abandoning its past practice of operating a summer schedule - two trains per week - and is carrying through its past winter schedule of one train every second Wednesday.

A train is listed to leave Cochrane on Wednesday the 20th of July, returning from Moosonee on Friday July 22nd. Subsequent trains leave Moosonee August 5th and 19th. One or other of these latter dates will probably suit your proposed visit with Dr. Tyer to the Eastern Coast of the Bay.

I am having the Aladdin Construction Company working out the plans and cost of the proposed Preventorium and should the cost be within our present means, will write to you and Dr. Stone further in the near future.

Please accept this expression of my appreciation of your sympathetic interest in, and support of, our plans for placing a worthy and complete equipment at the historic post of Moose Fort, or Factory, whichever the correct title may be. I find that authorities differ on the matter.

Believe me,

Yours faithfully,

Doctor McGill,

Dear Sir,

Mr Thompson had a letter from Canon Gould in which he stated that he expected you or some other representative of the Department to come to Moose for the opening of the new school, and asking when I was going to pay Treaty at Moose as they wanted if possible to have the opening about that time.

I was going to pay Treaty at Moose on July 14th & 15th. This could not work in with the trains as they come in on July 6th & 20th.

If you wish I could return to Moose Factory about the 2nd of July, after paying Treaty in Albany-Pay Treaty July 6th and the morning of the 7th and they could have the opening in the afternoon. Those who wished could get the train out again on the 8th.

I would do the rest of my work at Albany after paying Treaty at Attawapiscat.

The person that came up from the Department could, if they could spare the time take the trip to Attawapiscat and Albany with me and get the train out on July 22nd.

I will have my mail sent on to Albany so if you let me know your decision I will make arrangements to pay Treaty to fit in with your plans.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I was very glad to have the opportunity of making your acquaintance and discussing the matters which are of our mutual concern.

My visit to the school at Moose Factory was necessarily short, but I was much impressed by the efficient manner in which this institution appears to be operated. We have started the school year with a complete staff with the one exception of the Head Matron, and we are hoping to hear from a former worker that she is willing to take up this position.

I found the Principal much concerned by reason of the failure of a number of the pupils to return to the school after the summer holidays. From letters he has received from parents and from our missionaries at various places on Hudson Bay, it appears clear that some adverse influence has been at work. While letters of parents were often vague and spoke of "not sending back the children this year", the missionaries had written that various criticisms of the school had been circulated and several serious charges which on investigation were found to have no foundation whatever. As the last boat has now come from points to the north, there would seem to be nothing to be done now, but the Principal is concerned about the number of children of school age at Moose Factory who are out of school. In view of his very small enrollment this year he wondered if the Department could not write the Agent to exert some pressure in regard to some of these cases. Dr. Orford has apparently advised the parents that the children should be in school, but does not appear to have been able to exert any pressure. If you can do anything to influence this situation we shall indeed be grateful. I may say that I had a long conference with the Chief and some of the
Indian Affairs Branch - 2.

September 30, 1943.

Councillors who expressed themselves as very pleased with the management of the school, and I urged the Chief to use his influence towards the desired result of having all the children in school who should be there.

With kind regards,

Yours very truly,

H.A. Alderwood

Secretary.

HAA:A.
Ottawa, October 5, 1943.

Dear Doctor Alderwood:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 8th ultimo, in which you refer to the difficulty experienced by the Principal of the Moose Fort Residential School in securing his full quota of pupils for the present academic year.

You will be interested to learn that I am today communicating with the Indian Agent in respect to this matter. It is my earnest hope that the agent, by working in close co-operation with the Principal of the School, will be able to substantially increase the enrolment in the course of a few weeks. I have noted, with interest, your reference to certain criticisms of the school, that appear to have been circulated in the district. These criticisms, as you may readily suppose, arise from time to time and usually stand rectifying. In the case of the Moose Fort School, however, I am disposed to think that better economic conditions and the measure of prosperity that Indian families are now enjoying may be mainly responsible for the poor attendance at the school. In any event, I feel confident that the agent will do all he possibly can to persuade the parents to send their children to the school.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. H. A. Alderwood, D.D.,
Secretary, Indian & Eskimo Residential School Commission, M.S.C.C.,

Ottawa, October 5, 1943.

Dear Doctor Orford:

I am sending forward herewith, for your information, copy of a letter received by this Branch from Dr. R. A. Alderwood. The subject matter of this letter, you will note, is self-explanatory.

In view of the acute shortage of teachers existing throughout the Dominion and the difficulty experienced by the church authorities in securing the staff necessary to operate our schools in this crisis, it is of the utmost importance that everything humanly possible should be done to persuade Indian parents to send their children to school.

It would be very much appreciated if you would discuss this matter with the Principal of the Moose Fort School and, with him, reach a decision with respect to the best ways and means of increasing the present enrolment. In my reply to Dr. Alderwood I have stated that while adverse criticisms of the school itself in the district may retard recruiting, it is my opinion that the measure of prosperity the Indians are now enjoying may be in the main responsible for their tendency to keep children at home. You might, at your convenience, let us have any comments you may care to send forward with respect to the local situation.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dr. T. J. Orford,
Indian Agent,

via Moosonee, Ont.

Re: Pupils for Moose Fort Residential School. Your file 44-6-1.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have to thank you for your kind letter of October 5th, and for your action in enlisting the effort of the Indian Agent in this connection. I think it is fair to assume that improved economic conditions among the Indians is tending to lower pupilage in many cases, but we shall all do our best to see that as many children as possible continue their education.

With kind regards, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Secretary.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa,

Ref File 44-6-1 - Letter of October 8th., 1943.

I have read the copy of the letter you received from H.A. Alderwood, Secretary of Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission, Church of England.

I feel certain that there is no adverse influence at work anywhere in James Bay towards keeping children out of school. If anything, the reverse holds true.

The school at Moose Factory draws its children from Albany on the west coast and from the east coast as far north as Factory River. Due to the unfortunate loss of the school at Fort George during the past year a number of children at Fort George, East Main and Factory River were unable to return this year and during my visit to these posts I attempted to convince the parents to send their children to Moose Factory at least until such time as the Fort George school is rebuilt. The answer in practically all cases was that they did not wish to send their children so far away and that - "the children at Moose Factory learned bad language."

Undoubtedly the fact that the Indians along this coast are comparatively well off at the present time does have some influence on their keeping their children at home, because many of them send their children to school not because they expect them to learn anything but because they are better fed and better clothed than they themselves can ordinarily look after them.

However, I think the best answer to Mr. Alderwood's remarks lies in the record of school attendance this year for the Moose band children. More of them are attending residential school than at any other time.

(over)
Mr. Alderwood appears to consider that I have not been able to exert any pressure on parents to make them send their children to school. I think the Moose band attendance is sufficient answer to that and it stands to reason that when I see other bands only for a few days each year it is impossible to do other than to attempt to influence them by conversation. However perhaps you will recall on two or three occasions during the past term when children were either taken from school by their parents or did not return after holidays, I asked for advice from the Department as to the manner in which these children could be made to return for their education according to the Indian Act and the laws of the Province. The reply was to approve of their discharge.

[Signature]

T. L. Offord
Ottawa, Nov. 29, 1946.

Attention: Mr. R. A. Hoey,

Dear Sir:

It has seemed best that the Rev. Gilbert Thompson, who for the past ten years has been Principal of the Indian Residential School at Moose Factory, be transferred to one of the other schools. Just which one has not been decided as yet.

I am writing, therefore, to ask that the Rev. H. G. Cook, B.A., now at South Porcupine, Ontario, be appointed as his successor. Mr. Cook is a graduate of the University of Western Ontario. He has served for eight years among the Indians at Fort Simpson on the Mackenzie River. He is temporarily stationed at South Porcupine pending his appointment to Indian work for which he has expressed preference. We have confidence in his ability and have reason to think that he will prove acceptable as Principal at Moose Factory. I write therefore to recommend that he be appointed Principal as from June 1st, 1945.

Yours faithfully,

L. A. Dixon

MEMORANDUM

DIRECTOR

Re: Family Allowances

Herewith report on recent visit to some of our Northern Agencies in Quebec and Ontario.

James Bay Agency -

Dr. Orford, Indian Agent, is handling all the registration personally, coincident with his Treaty Payment Trips.

This Agency has a population of roughly 600 families. Registration has been completed for the Moose and Albany Bands, which represent about 25%. The originals of these forms have been despatched to the Regional Director in Toronto. The balance of registration is expected to be completed by the 15th of October.

All families in this Agency will receive their allowances in kind (Category B). Sub-registrars have been appointed and vouchers will be distributed as follows:

H.B. Co., Albany - monthly
H.B. Co., Attawapiskat - mostly monthly
H.B. Co., Nemaska - twice yearly
H.B. Co., East Main and Factory River - monthly
H.B. Co., Great Whale River - 2 or 3 times yearly
H.B. Co., Fort George - annually for inlanders (approx. 50%)
H.B. Co., 6 times yearly (Coastal Indians)
Moose Factory, Moosonee, and Rupert's House - by Agent Orford monthly.

It is intended also to appoint sub-registrars of independent traders - Attawapiskat - Albany - Fort George - and Factory River. It will be seen by the above that Dr. Orford intends to issue personally from him his office as many vouchers as possible, and at the same time appoint quite a few sub-registrars. He intends to experiment during the Winter with other methods of distribution.

Dr. Orford is satisfied that traders are pretty well stocked with our list of preferred foods. The writer had the opportunity of meeting Mr. Cowan of Winnipeg, James Bay District Manager of the Hudson Bay Company. He assured me that every effort was being made to stock all Hudson Bay Trading Posts with the food and clothing that we specified. He further stated that with the exception of woollen underwear he did not anticipate any trouble in having sufficient stocks of everything at all of their posts.

Mr. Cowan stated that instructions had gone out to all of his traders, that no substitutions were to be allowed unless first approved by the Indian Agent. In our conversation I could not help but be impressed.
with Mr. Cowan's desire to cooperate with the Indian Affairs Branch to the fullest extent in the administration of the Family Allowances Act. The local Hudson Bay posts at Moose Factory in charge of Factor Dunlop appear to have generous stock of various articles.

I took the opportunity of spending some time going through the Moose Factory Residential School, Mr. Cook, principal. This school appeared neat and tidy with a summer carry-over of 11 pupils. Some of these pupils would be returning home when contact could be made with their parents. The principal and Dr. Orford were asked to send to the Regional Director in Toronto, a list of all pupils that would not be returning to their parents for the summer holidays.

The writer took the occasion to inspect practically every Indian tent on the Island. I was agreeably surprised at their cleanliness which speaks well for Dr. Orford and the Public Health Nurse.

In general, this agency appears to be fairly well in hand so far as Family Allowances are concerned. Dr. Orford's registration forms have been carefully completed and checked, and I feel that it would be a matter of gratification to the Regional Director in Toronto, (W.J. Jackson).

H.M. Jones,
Supervisor - Family Allowances
Moose Factory, Ont.

Dear Dr. Orford:

With your permission I would like to dispense with the Easter holidays, save for Good Friday and Easter Monday, and take a corresponding number of days from the term end in June.

In years past it has been found that the Easter holidays usually bring a number of colds to the children due to the fact that they play outside in the melting snows and become wet and cold. Then too we find it hard to supervise their play at this time of the year and hope you can see your way clear to grant the above mentioned concession.

Yours faithfully,

**Server Training**

In the first quarter of the year 1947, the below-named pupils, under the guidance of Mr. Bel Seiler (Indian of course), received instruction in Indian methods of tracking, hunting, and winter wood life generally. This took place over a six-week period to the pupils of the school by the General Officer or, for developments, I.D. The boys left the school (for one week) Friday morning and returned Sunday noon. While absent from the school they were under the direct supervision of their instructors. Food and shelter was supplied by the school and the other equipment by the local Indian Office.

The boys attended to duties in the bush during the quarter:

- Peter Thompson
- Joseph Johnson
- Lawrence
- James Johnson
- William Johnson
- Billy Johnson
- John Johnson
- Robert Johnson

A requisition has come in from the Moose Fort Boarding School for twenty-five single iron beds, which are said to be urgently required. The Department is under no obligation to supply these beds, but as the per capita grant for the school, which is in such an out-of-the-way place, is small it is for you to say whether you will allow them anything to assist them in providing these beds, and, if so, how much.

The number of pupils provided for is 25 at a per capita grant of $72.00.

[Signature]

Harley Ross

The Moose Factory Boarding School is at present rather inadequately supplied with boys. There was consequently some time before the school was able to make any substantial progress.

There was some question raised about the suitability of the school for some time now. Before undertaking the purchase of any more land, it seems to me more advisable to see what can be done with the present land.

Ottawa Sept 8th 1909

In reference to my inspection of Moose Factory Boarding School and the request for 25 beds, I have to report as follows: there are 13 single home made beds (camp bed style) for girls good condition; 6 double beds for boys good condition; 1 single iron bed good condition.

The management has been arranging the accommodation which seems to be for (8) eight more children. I would therefore recommend 8 more iron beds for these additional pupils.

I see no necessity of replacing old ones while in present condition. I do see some objection to the double bed system, but as the institution is not likely to be filled at the time the new beds can be utilized in place of the double ones.

Our first proposal is to convert the attic into a properly equipped store-room with a stairway leading from the second floor. By so doing the convenience of carrying on the work would be in many ways increased and the first problem of keeping the children's clothing separate would then be solved. The room which now answers the purpose of a Clothes Store-Room could then be converted into a Children's Bed Room; thus our capacity would be increased from twenty-five to thirty, an increase of five.

Ottawa, November 16, 1909.

Right Reverend Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of Your Lordship's letter of the 10th inst., inclosing a communication from the Principal of the Moose Factory Boarding School, in which he asks for a grant to enable him to fit up the attic in the building as a store-room and convert the present store-room into a dormitory, the estimated cost of which is $123.50 for material and $50.00 for labour.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will be prepared to pay for the material needed to the extent above mentioned, $123.50, upon receipt of duly certified accounts, stating shewing the amount of lumber purchased with prices. In giving assistance of this kind it is the policy of the Department to require the schools to perform the necessary labour, and no grant can be made for this in the present instance.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,
Your obedient Servant,

Right Rev. J.G. Anderson,
Bishop of Moose Cree,
Selkirk, Man.,
Secretary.
Selkirk, Man.
Dec. 1st, 1905

Dear Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge your letter of Nov. 16th ult., and most thank you for the offer of $125.00 covering the cost of material required for the attic alteration at the Moose Fort Boarding School. But I must also say that I cannot understand the policy of the Dept. in refusing to pay for the cost of labour. I do not think that this is the policy of the Gov't regarding their public buildings in the Dominion. We are trying to do for the Indians what the world with much hardship, whatever that is clearly the duty of the Gov't. Government.

We are only getting a per capita grant of $60 per annum, while, I have been told, other schools in Saskatchewan & the West are getting as much as $125. I venture to say that the cost of living at Moose Fort is much higher than any place in Saskatchewan or Alberta or Qu'Appelle. From facts which I have examined recently, I find that the Moose Ft. School cost $3700 last year, exclusive of much help from the Canadian Women's Auxiliary in clothing, house linen etc. and also from the Missionary Ladies' Assoc. in England. Do let
practically the Diocese has to provide $2000 over + above the Board grant. I am in all fairness, do this right? I consider that we have at least every reason for getting as large a grant as the Western Schools. The same arguments are applicable to the Chapleau School. Though the cost of living is not quite so high at Chapleau, still $60 per capita grant falls a long way below our expenses.

I trust that your Department will give these matters their best consideration, and I am sure they will see the justice of our claims. We do not want the trouble to make any demands, but the struggle to maintain an school in these places is difficult, and I do not think that we are going beyond what we are justly entitled to in making a request for some assistance.

Yours very sincerely,

J. D. McLean
Acting Deputy Indian Affairs

John F. Macdonald
Ottawa, December 7th, 1909.

Right Reverend Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of Your Lordship's letter of the last instant, and in reply I beg to say that the Department in making a grant only for the material required for alterations at the Moose Factory Boarding School is carrying out the policy invariably followed in giving such assistance to schools which are not the property of the Department. The Moose Factory School, which is the property of the Church of England, cannot be regarded as a public building in the sense referred to by Your Lordship.

In reference to the per capita grant I have to inform you that $72.00 has been paid since the April 1st, 1907. This is $16.00 more than is paid the Chapleau School, and, with one single exception, as high a grant as is paid to any boarding school in the Western Provinces. In view of the foregoing the Department considers that in offering to assume the cost for all the material necessary to make the changes asked for by the Principal it acted liberally towards this school.

I have the honour to be, Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Secretary.

Bishop of Moose Cree,
Belkirk, Man.

Dear Sir:

Our Manager of our Montreal Branch forwards me your letter April 18th. 1910 (No. 306950-5) of which we beg to acknowledge the receipt.

Concerning our account of $106.80 for 10 beds supplied for the Church of England Boarding School at Moose Factory, and freight for same, allow me to draw your attention to the fact that you have asked us to buy these articles for you.

To be able to give you the best prices, we have enclosed your order with the bulk of ours, which we are passing now to the Manufacturers. We do not see why we should have to purchase these items now for you, and be paid back from three to six months later.

We regret to state that it is our rule not to advance money for any period of time, and that we cannot see our way of purchasing these articles for you if you do not care to pay the account when forwarded to you.

April 16th, 1912

Dear Sir,

After very careful consideration of the position occupied by the Boarding and Day Schools at Morse Park, I have concluded that the supply of the following things would most materially benefit the school, viz:

1. A Combined Sinker and Planter, which we can obtain from Steel Bros. Co., for $50.00. I suppose Messrs. Harris & Co. could also supply the machine. This would be effectual in the Potato Field Garden.

2. A Cultivator or Plow, which J. Eaton & Co., Toronto, advertise at $45.00 Complete. The depth of wood is very expensive. We have to cut it a mile or so above Morse Park, using wood on the Island, they since having returned, will be able to do the work other wise it would be too costly.

3. A one-tonne hay mower, which Messrs. Harris & Co., Toronto, have offered to supply us with, for $40.00. The Hay Mower is $5.00. The Hay supply is another thing which has been very costly here, as we have been dependent on the N.B.C. for their own, but now we are able to get it up the Island in boat. Before this year we used to send our cows to Ross's field on our property. We intend to build a shelter for the school apart from the main building, where the cows will be fed clean from our own pasture.

Yours sincerely,

John F. Woodside

[Signature]

[Address: All Hall Rd., will be No. Principal O'Hara, Macdonald College, Toronto]
to clear more land for this purpose, and believe
that we can raise almost sufficient for our own
needs. In fact last summer we were able to get
nearly half of the produce needed at home, but we
had to get the N.W.C. to cut it for us with their
scissors which meant the loss of time & man as
well. But having our own horses, we could cut
& dry ourselves at the proper time, so we have one
more of our own.

4. We must increase our live stock, both Cows,
for obvious reasons. A special reason at Moose is
that we have written we cannot get a supply of
fresh meat. Our season we may be able (not all we
need), the next year at all, as happened last winter,
being entirely on canned meat & not from anywhere,
& particular need for Indian children. We've had,
say four or five, we would soon be able to kill an
animal or two every winter. As it is, we only have
one Cow & calf and no horse. We would like to
add two cows this year.

Can the Department help us to get this important
need supplied? Mr. Wilson Ross will transport them
& horses. He needs I can send down with seed by
the first canoe down from Cochrane. You can understand
what an education the use of these machines will be for
the pupils of the school after June 1st in view of saving
expenses. We'll be glad to hear from you at your earliest
convenience.

Yours sincerely,

RIGHT REV. JOHN G. ANDERSON

Cochrane
ONTARIO
May 30th, 1914

Dear Mr. Scott,

I have just heard the news and news of the latest destruction by fire in March 26th last of the Boarding School, Clove House & Mechanics building at Moose Fort together with practically all our farming equipment, harnesses, supplies and all household furniture, bed, clothing etc. It is a most dreadful loss to us and there was no insurance so the Company would not help the victims.

The work has been continued with the boys using the Hospital and the girls the old mission residence. The Principal has bravely gone ahead and with the help of the J. & Co. and Revillon Bros. has secured lots and lumber and a new building is now well on its way. The companies mentioned have kindly advanced lumber and supplies & will give us some time to make payment. However, they will not help us much in replacing all our losses, though relieving us for the present.

What can you do for us? I should be most grateful if the Department would replace the building, at its cost, and leaving for your store via Athabasca River next Friday. I would be most happy to receive a reply from you before I leave.

John G. Moosonee
Ottawa, June 2nd, 1914.

Rt. Rev. J. G. Anderson,
Cochrane, Ont.

BISHOP
Cochrane, Ont., March 4, 1923

Honourable Mr. Scott,
Deputy Minister of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Canada.

My dear Mr. Scott,

I have been very busy these days, attending a conference at the Moose Factory for three weeks. I find that the rough charges for the school building are very heavy, but they are necessary for the future. These charges are for the school building, including land and other emergency needs of the school. Besides, we need a new school building in order to meet the needs of the students.

The government has approved a grant in view of the special case, and I am sure that the school will be able to meet the needs of the students.

With best wishes,

John G. Anderson

JOHN G ANDERSON
BISHOP
COCHRANE, ONT.

August 30th, 1915

My dear Mr. Scott,

Referring to your kind letter of March 6th last, I wish to inform you that I forwarded receipts in duplicate for freight charges by steamer fires, Montreal, on W.A. basis and special supplies for the furnishing and equipment of the Moose School after the fire, to Miss Nelson, Director, Indian Affairs, in July 1914. I also sent an receipt for W.A. freight in basis for 1913, as for some reason, steamer fires did not send in a statement of accounts for that year, but included it in their statement for 1914. Miss Nelson promised to forward these receipts to the Dept. of Finance and recording the facts. As I have had no advice from the Royal Trust Company, Moosonee, of the payment of these amounts, and as our pressing needs are calling for money, I am wondering what is the cause of delay and shall be glad to hear from you what the steamer fires have replied to the Department.

With best wishes,

[Signature]

COCHRANE, ONT., March 20th, 1916

My dear Mr. Scott,

I have just received your letter dated June 15th, 1916, and No. 306, 1916 regarding the cost of replacing buildings destroyed by fire at Moose Fort. I enclose the following statement which I have just received from Rev. W. Hay, Superintendent, missionary at that place.

The work of rebuilding has been slow as some of the materials were missing and others missing. We had the advice from Toronto, we have now come to a standstill and cannot proceed with the rebuilding due to shortage of funds.

I would be grateful therefore if the Department will decide to increase the amount to plant two trees at the cost and issue the necessary cheque. You will understand, I am sure, that the cost of the inevitable upkeep of maintenance and a total loss of funds is not evident. I know that you will do your best in no matter the circumstances. Sincerely yours — John G. Moosonee
March 23rd, 1916.

Dear Bishop Anderson -

I have your Lordship's letter of the 20th instant, with enclosure showing expenditure to date in connection with the rebuilding of the Moosonee Port Boarding School.

Although our funds for the coming year will be extremely limited I hope to be able to do something to help you. It will be necessary, however, to have pro or vouchers to present to the Auditor; these should be in detail, and in the case of labour should show the number of men employed and the rates of wages paid, and for material, quantities and prices.

I would ask your Lordship to be kind enough to obtain these at your earliest convenience.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Right Rev. Jo. A. Anderson, D.D.,
Bishop of Moosonee,

Cochrane, Ont.
MY DEAR BISHOP:

I herewith forward the details you asked for in connection with the rebuilding of the Boarding School.

Altho' I started on two occasions a separate account with the Hudsons Bay Company for the new school they would keep confusing matters by charging up things to the wrong account. I have now gone over these accounts and made a special school account for the materials used and labour employed and have given them exactly as they appear in the several accounts of Revillon Freres and Hudsons Bay Companies. I have also had these checked by the Post Managers and signed.

You will notice that the total is more than the last account I rendered as I have brought them up to the date of this letter.

It will hardly be necessary for me to remind your Lordship that we shall yet need about $1,500 (Fifteen hundred dollars) to complete the work when the money is available.

YOUR OBEDIENT SERVANT

Ottawa, Nov. 7, 1922.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 4th ultimo, regarding your requisition to be supplied with the wooden portion for the seats of 13 new desks furnished to the Moose Fort Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that the desks supplied were those known as the "Snider" school desk and were purchased from Goodwin's Limited, Montreal, in the summer of 1914. The firm which manufactured them have retired from business and it is impossible to get parts for the Snider desk.

It is considered that a carpenter could make the wooden seats and have them screwed to the metal part of the desk. If necessary, the Department would pay the expenses in having this work done, providing properly certified accounts covering the cost of the material and labour is received. The account for labour should show the number of hours or days the carpenter is employed, and should be receipted by him. The account for any material bought for the purpose should also be receipted by the person from whom the purchase is made.

It is hoped that you will be able to arrange to have the seats for the desks made, as it will be impossible for us to obtain them and have them forwarded to the school.

When these desks were shipped by Havillon Freres' boat in 1914, all parts securely packed were delivered at their warehouse in Montreal, and your letter is the first intimation we have received that all the parts did not reach Moose Fort.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

HALF-HOLIDAY ORDER

A meeting of the Agricultural Wages Board was held on Thursday in London, Sir Alfred Wollaston presiding. It was decided, as the period for holding objections to the Board's proposal to define the working day of all persons engaged in the services of 48 hours on a Saturday or on such other day (not being Sunday) in every week as may be agreed between the employer and employee, has expired, to make an Order on the basis of their proposal, subject to certain modifications in regard to time spent by horsemen, ploughmen, shepherds, team men, and other classes engaged in the care and cleansing of stock. The full terms of the Order, which will come into operation on March 1, will be published in due course.

Hastings was visited by representatives of both workers and employers to the death of Mr. Joseph Arch, and the Board decided to forward to Mr. Arch's family a copy of these resolutions expressing sympathy and to place on record their high appreciation of the work of Mr. Arch on behalf of the agricultural labourer.

At a meeting of the Grimsby Branch of the Lincolnshire Farmers' Union the following resolution was carried:

That this meeting of the Grimsby Branch of the Lincolnshire Farmers' Unions considers that the proposal made by the Wages Board to introduce a compulsory half-holiday is one which requires very careful consideration. We believe farmers should be allowed a half-holiday to agricultural labourers in the summer months, when the days are long and the weather hot, so that they may have leisure time in their gardens or in recreation, and when the stock are out at grass and do not require much attention.

A Potato Dredger (see above).
A NEW VIBRATORY POTATO SORTER

A new machine of a simple and easily worked type, with large capacity, has recently been designed by Mr. J. C. Powell. This is an automatic potato-sorting machine, using the necessary vibratory motion imparted by a set of spiral springs. The weight of the potatoes coming down the chute causes the screen to vibrate on these spiral springs, and thus separate the tubers into three grades. It appears that automatic vibratory action can be assisted by hand or foot.

The capacity of the apparatus is four tons per minute. Mr. Clarke, Trumps Green Farm, Virginia Water, says that one of his men can easily grade about two tons per day with the appliance, which works so easily that he thinks a girl should obtain as good results. He says that the grading done could not be better.

This machine is made in various forms and sizes to suit the requirements of farmers who want to keep their potatoes clean and free from dirt. The largest can be fitted in a shed or barn, and is capable of taking the load from a cart and grading it at once. A medium size is well adapted for use in the field, grading potatoes as they are collected. A small potato-grader is made in wood or wicker for grading fruit. The work is in full charge of the attendant, who is therefore able to pick and sort other vegetables. Miller, Webb and Co., 25, Finsbury Circus, London, E.C. 2, have these graders in stock.

PROPOSED M.F.A. AND CHAMBER OF AGRICULTURE AMALGAMATION IN STAFFORDSHIRE

At a meeting of the Staffordshire Chamber of Agriculture on Saturday week the question of the amalgamation with the National Farmers' Union was discussed.

Mr. T. Foster proposed the formation of an association to represent the interests of the National Farmers' Union and the Staffordshire Chamber of Agriculture. He said that the amalgamation would enable them to do more effective work in the interests of agriculture. The Chambers of Agriculture alone were not able to make the same demands as the National Farmers' Union, and in consequence the resolutions were not introduced in any advantageous spirit, but in consequence of the amalgamation there was a strong feeling in the county in favour of such an amalgamation. The negotiations, which were carried out in the preliminary stage, could not be undertaken by a single body.

In supporting the resolution Mr. J. G. Patterson said that the question connected with agriculture was one of the most important questions in connection with the parting of the ways. They were not disposed to amalgamate with the National Farmers' Union, but felt strongly that their future methods of work must be different from those of the past. The two organisations had been working together for many years, and it was thought, high time they started something to unite them under one banner. Tenant farmers were also represented at the meeting, and it was gratifying to find that they in Staffordshire were the first to commence an agitation for amalgamation. The resolution was carried with but one dissentient.

Dear Sir:—

--Re URGENT REQUIREMENTS FOR THE MOOSE FACTORY SCHOOL C.of E.

The Rev. J.T. Griffin, Principal of our Society's School at Moose Factory, has presented to our Commission, in his annual report, the following information with regard to urgent requirements at his school, and I have been instructed to direct your attention to the same and to solicit your assistance in having them as fully supplied as possible.

The part of his report referred to reads as follows:—

P-R-E-S-S-I-N-G N-E-E-D-S.

1. MAIN CELLAR. In excavating the cellar under the large dining-room of the main building in the year 1921, we found that the rafters (sills?) under the floor were rotten. This necessitated temporary rafters being placed under the flooring, which was done by the Principal and boys, and propped up by round poles. This is in a very bad way and should be attended to at once. The cost would only consist of a couple of carpenters from the Hudson Bay Co. for a short time. We would use some of the lumber which we had prepared for the new byre. The cellar has never been properly finished, and it needs lumber squared on two sides to be fitted all around the walls to keep back the clay from falling out from under the foundation. If this were done, and steps fitted on the outside of the entrance to the cellar, it would secure the building from falling in and make the place more useful for storing the large quantities of potatoes,
turnips and other vegetables during the winter.

2. BALCONY. The outer Balcony, leading off from the Girls' room, and also under-balcony of same is very much decayed and needs a complete new one. The cost of this would not be much, as the carpenters would be instructed to fill up the pillars and basins, and the remainder of the work could be done by some of the bigger boys and painted.

3. A NEW DOOR, is required for the main entrance into the Dining room.

4. A NEW LAUNDRY HOUSE. We have a large sized house (20'6"x14'6") which at present is used for holding Indian books and odds and ends. I would like this to be lined on the inside (it is only weather-boarded) and fitted up for use as a washing room, a place where the laundry of the school could be seen to. At present we use a partitioned portion of the study for this purpose in the winter, and outside on the grass in the summer. The books &c. can be put away in the top of the food store. This is certainly a pressing need and it would not cost much to turn it into a suitable laundry place, and it could be used for the Boys'washing room in summer.

5. EXTENSION OF FARM. Outside of the enclosed compound there is a very large piece of ground off which the timber has been taken, and quantities of the stumps have been pulled out and are awaiting removal. Besides this, there is an inner portion of the ground almost cleaned— I should say perhaps about 2 acres—which needs further work. I would suggest that this inner portion be further cleaned and enclosed by wire and posts and that potatoes be planted in same. The yearly standard price for one bag of potatoes is $3.

6. BYRE. Last year we were able to secure a very large number of logs which came down the Moose River from a burst boom belonging to some Pulp Company. These we had sawn up into lumber and logs squared for the purpose of building a new byre for a Hay shed. The cost of sawing this 17,000' of lumber came to $55.

In connexion with the above matters I may say that I had hoped to visit Moose Factory this summer, when I should have had an opportunity of estimating the cost of these repairs &c., after a close personal examination. As I have been obliged to postpone my visit, the estimate of the cost must be made out from the above data, and this, in the opinion of our Commission, will amount to about $1,200. I shall be obliged therefore if you
will authorise an expenditure of this amount, it being understood that the sum of $1,200 must not be exceeded, and only that portion of it expended which is actually required for the purposes specified above.

I remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

L.A.R. Westgate

Field Secretary M.S.C.C.

TBRW/K.
July 22, 1924.

Memorandum

Rev. Dr. Scott,

Rev. Dr. Westgate requests authority to expend an amount not exceeding $1200 in the carrying out of repairs which he states are urgent at the Moose Factory C. of E. Residential School buildings. He has enumerated the various repairs required.

We have no funds provided for repairs to this school in our appropriations for the present fiscal year. I would point out that these buildings are the property of the Church Authorities and we have never expended any amount for their erection or upkeep. I would recommend that Dr. Westgate be informed that there are no funds available but that the matter will receive consideration when the Estimates for the next fiscal year are being prepared. We have authorized a number of expenditures for Church of England schools, which were not provided in the Estimates - recently $2,000 was granted for urgent repairs at the Hay River Residential School - and after our full building programme is carried out this year, there will be very little left for unforeseen expenditures.

[Signature]

J.T. Scott

Dear Sir:

I should be obliged if you will kindly let me know if any appropriation has been made in the estimates for the current fiscal year for repairs etc., at the Moose Factory School. In my letter page 5 to the Deputy Superintendent General dated October 30th I suggested that the sum of $1200.00 would be required and specified the following items: (1) Main cellar, (2) Balcony, (3) new Door, (4) Laundry House, (5) Extension of Farm, and (6) Byre.

In a letter recently received from the Principal he presents a very strong request for new metallic roofing for the main buildings at the Day School. He stated that while it might be possible for the main buildings to last another year without a new roof, he felt quite certain that the Day School would suffer serious damage if the new roof were not supplied this summer.

As the grant for the Day School is by arrangement paid to Bishop Anderson, I was directed to refer the matter of a new roof to him for any action necessary. His Lordship however, is now on a visit to James Bay but it would appear that his Commissary has referred this urgent need to your Department as I have just received the following telegram from him in this connection:-
The Secretary.

"Indian Department refuse metallic roofing for Moose Factory Day School".

Although I have not been able to visit this School in person I feel well assured that every effort should be made to have this metallic roofing supplied, and if you will kindly let me know what money is available for repairs etc., for this School this year I will make whatever arrangements it may be possible and will do my best to have the roofing sent in and other improvements made so as to ameliorate the difficult and trying conditions under which I am quite satisfied our Principal and his staff at this School are carrying on their work.

I remain, Sir,
Your obedient servant,

J.A.R. Westgate

FIELD SECRETARY M.S.C.C.

TERV/JF.
Ottawa, July 18, 1925.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, with reference to the funds that are available for the Moose Factory Indian Residential School. I regret to inform you that there was no provision made in the Estimates for this fiscal year for this work. There are so many pressing needs that certain items are crowded out of the Appropriation for Indian Education. Unless exceptional circumstances are drawn to our attention, no funds are available for the residential school.

Inasmuch as the Department allows the church authorities certain considerations in lieu of rental at the Moose Factory Day School, it is our opinion that the church should make the necessary repairs. His Lordship the Bishop of Moosonee has been so informed.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Dear Sir:

Canon Griffin, Principal of our Society's School at Moose Fort, Ontario, has presented to me a very urgent request for a gasoline engine and pole saw, with saw mandrel for cutting wood at his school, and I am obliged to solicit the assistance of your Department in securing these very essential items of equipment at a school so remotely situated, and where so much firewood is consumed.

The engine which is now in use there has been in service for fully 12 years, but the Principal states that it has given a very great deal of trouble, and he has been repeatedly advised "to make junk of it". He suggests that the kind which would be most suitable would be an engine "with a make and break ignition not under 3 Horse Power", along with this he specified a saw large enough to cut through logs 18" thick, and with it "a saw mandrel". The frame for the saw he states could be made at the school, but if sent in it should be knocked down to save expense on freight.

As it would now be too late to have the above forwarded by boat from Pagwa, they should be shipped by Hudson's Bay steamer, due to leave Montreal sometime in July.

I very much hope that your Department will undertake to furnish the above, and forward the same to Canon Griffin at Moose Fort this Summer. As our Auditors report shows that the cash disbursements made by our Society for this school for the year 1925 amounted to $7,153.96, while the per capita earnings amounted to only $4,620.00, leaving a balance of $2,533.96 to be met from our Society's funds, I trust that you will be able to recognize the necessity which is laid upon us to apply to your Department for assistance in the provision of the above equipment.

I have the honor to be Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary M.S.C.C.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to your letter of June 28th, (44-6-5) my reply July 2nd, and your further letter of July 7th, (44-6-5) authorising an expenditure of $1500.00 at the Moose Port School this year, I desire to know if your Department will agree to meet the enclosed bills amounting to $63.74 for installing a new water tank at this School, provided the School management can save this amount out of the total expenditure you have sanctioned for this year.

If your Department can agree to do this, and will send me a cheque for the enclosed amount, I will inform the Principal that the total amount of $1500 which he has already been notified he may spend this year, has been reduced to $1400.00.

I saw the water tank during my recent visit to this School, and consider it extremely good value.

Trusting that you may be able to give favourable consideration to this request, Believe me, Sir,

Yours very truly,

L.B.R. Westgate

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 5th inst., re certification of accounts for engine, etc., supplied by Fairbanks-Morse Co. Ltd. to our Society's School at Moose Fort, I beg to state that the delay in this connection is entirely due to the delay in the arrival of these items of equipment at their destination. In letters received two days ago from Moose Fort and written at the end of September it was stated that the local Hudson's Bay Co.'s boat which had gone out to Charlton Island in James Bay to receive the supplies brought in by the steamer from Montreal had not returned. It was expected to return soon and as the engine and pole saw would arrive with it, we may expect to receive the certified account before the end of this month. As soon as it comes to hand I will forward the same to you.

Believe me, Sir,

Yours very truly,

T. R. R. Westgate,

Westgate, for the use of the Moose Fort Indian Residential School, I now have to say that we are informed by Dr. Westgate that he sent the account to Moose Fort to be certified by the Principal of the School. Dr. Westgate states that he expects to have this account returned to him before the end of the present month, and that, as soon as it comes to hand, it will be transmitted to the Department. When we receive the account, payment will be made. As the order was placed by Dr. Westgate, he should have certified the account, as it was not necessary for him to send it to the Principal of the school to do so.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

F. H. Paget,
Accountant & Purchasing Agent.

As no lumber was available during the year 1926 and the Hudson's Bay Co.'s steamer had sailed from Montreal before authority was given by the Department to effect repairs, extensions, etc., requested this year, none of the work authorised could be carried out. For this reason the same repairs, extensions, etc., requested for this year are repeated for 1927. They are as follows:

(a) Byre or barn.
(b) Laundry house and equipment.
(c) Repairs to balcony of school (word has been received that part of this has fallen)
(d) Carpenter's shop.
(e) ½ mile of fencing.
(f) Repairs to cellar.
(g) Painting and freight Estimated cost $ 500.00

Dear Sir:— Re: Fairbanks-Morse account for engines, etc.,
supplied to Moose Port School.

Your letter of the 18th instant has just been received
and I regret to have to inform you in reply that the certified
account of the receipt of the engine, etc., supplied by the
Fairbanks-Morse Co., Ltd., to our Society's School at Moose Port,
has not yet come to hand.

One of our lady agents who left Moose Port in September,
stated that the heavier articles of the cargo transported by the
Hudson's Bay Company's steamer from Montreal were still at Charlton
Island at that time. The next mail from Moose Port is expected,
according to information just received from the Hudson's Bay Co.,
about the beginning of the year, and the certified account will be
sent forward as soon as it has arrived here.

Regretting this delay, I remain, Sir,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

THW/JF.

Ottawa, April 8, 1927.

Reverend Sir:

I wish to refer to your letter of the 25th ultimo, enclosing certified accounts in connection with repairs at the Moose Port Indian Residential School. I wish to point out that these accounts were not accompanied by receipts or time sheets and, in future, you should arrange to support vouchers in favour of the school principal or the church authorities with such

In this instance, as the Appropriation for this school is about to lapse, the Department made out a special voucher with full explanation for the Auditor General and the payment of $497.25 is being made to you. I regret, however, that only in most exceptional cases can such action be taken.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary

Ottawa, July 4, 1927.

Reverend Sir:

I have to inform you that Dr. Westgate visited the Department on Friday. The Department is pleased to authorize you to proceed with the erection of a small barn at the Moose Fort Indian Residential School. The barn should be made of logs and the cost should not exceed $500. Time sheets, in duplicate, should be kept showing the receipts of any men engaged for the labour, and receipts, also in duplicate, showing the cost of the materials purchased should be forwarded when you are seeking refund.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Ottawa, July 4, 1927.

IMMEDIATE

Gentlemen:

This is to authorize you to supply one lineal mile of barb wire fence wire for the Moose Fort Indian Residential School, on the south coast of James Bay. This wire is for a four strand fence, one quarter mile long, at the institution. Your account, in duplicate, including freight, may be forwarded to the Department for payment.

I should be grateful if you would arrange to have this wire go in on your boat which leaves in a few days for the Hudson Bay.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Dear Sir:

In the list of requirements just submitted by the Principal of the Waseke Factory School for the current year, he has included three items which I have been instructed to solicit the assistance of your Department in providing. They are as follows:

1. McClary's Kitchen Range, hotel size, double oven, wood burner. The cost of this F.O.B. Montreal would be approximately £186.40

2. Four iron beds, six to eight with mattresses, a reasonable cost F.O.B. Montreal £44.75

3. One Hotel Laundry Machine, a reasonable cost F.O.B. Montreal £149.00

The freight on the above from Montreal to the Factory will be at the rate of £18.00 per ton. The weight of the range is 120 lbs., the total weight of all three items would not exceed one ton.

As soon as we have an order confirmed by Anderson's Bay Steamer early in July I shall be glad to have your Department fill be good enough to assist me to provide the same.

Thanking you in advance for your much needed help in this matter.

Believe me, Sir,

obedient servant,

Field Secretary

[Signature]

Rev. Sir:

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange for the purchase of the following:

1 McClary's kitchen range, hotel size, double oven, wood burner.

4 Iron beds, 6' x 3', with mattresses.

Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada

TORONTO, ONT., February 11, 1919

Dear Mr. Scott:

As the summer of 1919 will mark the 25th anniversary of the signing of the James Bay Treaty, No. 9 and also the 25th anniversary of the coming of our Society's Resident School at Moose Factory, our Committee have instructed me to inform you that we consider these anniversaries will be no occasion to leave the existing school building as it now stands.

The Department has directed our Society to erect or obtain suitable premises. We have been favorably advised by the committee of working men, and it is considered that it would be in keeping with their policy, and that we will try to have a new school erected at this centre during the coming year. The committee feel that the school will be built in connection with the new school as requested in your letter addressed to the Secretary of the Department.

After the completion of this building a new school for Moose Factory will be erected, if funds in our Society's fund cover such a request. It is hoped that the building may be referred to you for consideration by the erection of a new dormitory at this centre.

So pending this important matter to your attention, I remain, with very kind regards,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Field Secretary
February 25, 1929.

Dear Dr. Westgate:

I have your letter of the 11th instant, urging the Department to consider the rebuilding of the Moose Port Indian Residential School next year. The Department is finishing the Alert Bay Indian Residential School this year and is commencing the erection of the Old Sun institution. The earliest possible date for the proposed new school in the Lesser Slave district is 1930. In view of these pressing claims on the Appropriation for Indian Education, it is uncertain when funds could be provided for capital expenditure on James Bay.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Rev. T. B. H. Westgate, D. D.,
Field Secretary, M. S. C. G.,

Alexander Ave.,

Dear Sir:-

With further reference to your letter of the 19th instant, number 44-6-5, relative to the payment of freight charges on equipment sent last year to our Loose Factory School, I beg to state that your decision has placed our Commission in a decidedly awkward position, as they had reckoned from the wording of your letter of Feb. 27th, 1928, 44-6-5, that you would purchase and pay the freight charges on the kitchen range, iron beds and mattresses, if they purchased and paid the freight charges on the laundry washer. They closed their books for 1928 on this understanding, and now they are faced with an expenditure which they never anticipated, and which it seems to them from the wording of your letter already referred to, they should not now be asked to meet.

In the light of this explanation I shall be glad to know if you will reconsider your decision. The matter will have to be referred to our Executive Committee in Toronto, as our Commission's credit lapses at the end of each calendar year. I shall, however, withhold any further immediate action until I hear from you again.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

Dear Sir:

For some time the Acting Principal of our Society's School at Moose Factory has been pressing our Commission to provide increased accommodation for the pupils. In support of his request, he points out that during the winter months, the children's dining-room has been used as a play-room as well as a laundry and drying-room. As a temporary solution of the difficulty he first suggested that our Commission should provide the School with a number of army huts, but the Commission declined to provide these on account of the expense and asked him to submit a further recommendation.

In a letter just received, he mentions the possibility of having logs converted into lumber locally by the Hudson's Bay Company's mill for the cost of operating the mill only. He states that if the logs are on hand when the Company's mill is in operation, the cost would not amount to very much. In his letter to me he failed to submit any estimate of the cost and as it took too long to receive a reply to a letter addressed to this School I shall be glad to know if your Department will sanction an expenditure, say, $500.00 to have lumber cut in the way the Acting Principal suggests. The Acting Principal writes in this connection, in part, as follows:

"If we had a supply of ready lumber, and are allowed to use our own initiative, we could solve many of our problems with very little cost. We should have on hand our own supply of lumber at all times to avoid being at the mercy of the Company for every little piece required for repair work throughout the year."
In the list of requirements which our Society asked your Department to furnish this School this year, the sum of $1,000.00 was included for a canoe and engine. As our Commission have already purchased a canoe which will meet the School's needs until a new and larger school has been provided, and as the engine which I requested your Department to provide in my letters of March 20th. and April 4th. will not likely cost more than $200.00 delivered at the School, I trust that favourable consideration may be given to the request that $500.00 be sanctioned to provide this School with a supply of lumber which will enable the School Management to erect any smaller buildings and to effect any minor improvements which may be necessary until the new and larger school has been provided.

Should the total sum of $500.00 not be required to meet the cost of cutting the lumber, the balance could very well be utilized in paying a carpenter to help the School Management with building or repair work undertaken.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.
Ottawa, April 12, 1929.
