Food in Work and Lounge Areas

There have been many instances where persons have been observed eating food or drinking beverages in unauthorized areas. It is a known fact that mice are attracted to areas within buildings where food is prevalent.

This memo is to advise everyone within the National Library and Archives Building that food and beverages ARE NOT to be consumed in general office, stack, lounge or lobby areas. Allowances are made for boards and conferences where consumption of food and beverages is controlled.

Your co-operation in assisting in the control of the above would be greatly appreciated.

A.C. Taylor

DISTRIBUTION LIST:

Administrative Officers,
Division Chiefs,
Branch Directors,
Section Heads.

Aliments dans les zones de travail et les salles de repos

On a constaté à plusieurs reprises que certaines personnes se permettent de boire et de manger là où bon leur semble. Tout le monde sait aussi que les souris sont attirées dans les locaux où l'on garde des denrées alimentaires.

Veuillez donc prendre bonne note qu'il est INTERDIT de consommer des aliments dans les bureaux, les magasins, les salles de repos et le hall de la Bibliothèque nationale et des Archives publiques. On tolérera la consommation d'aliments dans les salles de réunions et de conférences, où le service est bien contrôlé.

Nous vous saurions gré de bien vouloir nous apporter votre collaboration à cet égard.

A.C. Taylor

RESIDENTIAL SCHOOLS & IMPROVEMENTS, WHICH THE
M. S. C. C. DESIRE TO HAVE PROVIDED DURING
THE FISCAL YEAR 1930-31.

New school for Moose Factory. The present school was established
on Sept. 5th, 1908, with funds provided by the Church of
England, and was the first "Boarding School" established in
that part of the Dominion. After 25 years of service the
building is no longer fitted to meet the increased need and
increased demand for educational facilities among the Indians
in the surrounding areas, and consequently should be replaced
at the earliest opportunity. The Indian peoples themselves
have been pressing our Society for a larger and fully modern
school building, and as the year 1930 will mark the 25th
anniversary, not only of the establishment of the "boarding"
school at this centre, but also the 25th anniversary of the
signing of the Treaty with the Indians at that centre, it is
earnestly hoped that provision may be made in the Departmental
estimates to supply this building next year.

The extension of the T. & N.O. railway from Island Falls to a
point beyond the most difficult of the rapids on the Abitibi
River, and within a distance of 100 miles of James Bay, will
greatly help to reduce the cost of transportation of building
material. This consideration, along with the discovery of
lignite in that part, and the possibility of rapid developments
in other directions, increase the urgency of having the Indian
educational work placed on a satisfactory basis at the
earliest date possible. The cost of operating a small school
such as that at Moose Factory where the freighting costs are
so heavy, and the per capita earnings so small, falls heavily
on the funds of the Society, and they are extremely anxious
that the situation should be so altered as to make the
income and expenditure more nearly meet than at present.

The new school desired should have a capacity of not less
than 100 pupils and the estimated cost is approximately
$100,000.00.
MOOSE PORT

(a) Hen house.
Estimated cost $150.00

(b) Implement shed.
Estimated cost $200.00.

(c) New closets.
Estimated cost $100.00.

(d) Sundry repairs.
Estimated cost $500.00.

(e) Bread making machine.
Estimated cost $100.00.

(f) One horse.
Estimated cost $300.00.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 24th ultimo, requesting that a typewriter be supplied for the use of the Moose Factory Indian Residential School.

In this connection I have to say that, while typewriters are supplied in the case of a number of our larger Indian residential schools where there is considerable official correspondence, it is considered there is not a like need for this equipment at your school. Dear Sir:

The Principal of our Loose Factory School has directed the attention of our Commission to the urgent need of a typewriter, and the similar need of a horse, and I write to ascertain if your Department will kindly undertake to provide both of these requirements.

In the list of requirements at this School included in the general List submitted to your Department last Autumn, the following items were mentioned:

- Hen house ................. £150.00
- Implement shed ........... 200.00
- New closets ............... 100.00
- Sundry repairs ............ 500.00
- Bread making machine .... 100.00
- One horse .................. 300.00

As the typewriter was not included in the above list, one of the other items could be dropped in order that this very necessary article of equipment may be sent forward. As the per capita cost of operating this School is approximately £274.00 per year, and the grant received from your Department is only £185.00, you will understand the difficulty with which our Society is faced in providing such items of equipment as those I have mentioned. As the horse and typewriter should both go forward by the Hudson's Bay Co.'s steamer from Montreal early this summer, I shall be glad to know if your Department will kindly arrange for the purchase and shipment of the same.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

FIELD SECRETARY M.S.C.C.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

April 23, 1930.

Memorandum:

One Thousand Dollars ($1,000.00) is available for improvements at the Moose Port Indian Residential School. Dr. Westgate now writes regarding the urgent need for a horse and for a typewriter. The Reverend Principal had written regarding a typewriter and, as the school was only a small one, the request was refused. In view of Dr. Westgate's urgent letter, I propose, with your concurrence, to supply a typewriter and to arrange for the purchase of a horse. The Department has been asked to place these on the Hudson Bay steamer from Montreal, early this summer. The Livestock Branch of the Department of Agriculture would, no doubt, secure a horse for us.

[Signature]
Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, April 24, 1930.

ATTENTION: Mr. MacRAE

Dear Sir:

Pursuant to telephone conversation, I have to request that you arrange for the purchase of a horse for the use of the Moose Fort Indian Residential School. The animal might be purchased in or near Montreal and it should be placed on the Hudson Bay Company's steamer which visits James Bay this summer. If your Montreal representative communicates with the Hudson Bay Company, he can learn on what day the boat will sail and could arrange his purchase and shipment accordingly.

The horse should be consigned to

Rev. J. Blackburn,
Indian Residential School,
Moose Factory,
via Hudson Bay Company's steamer from Montreal.

The account, in duplicate, covering the purchase price of the horse and any incidental expenses, should be certified by yourself and forwarded to me for payment. You might have your representative ask the Hudson Bay Company to bill this Department direct for the freight charges. Your representative will learn whether he or the Hudson Bay Company will provide hay for the boat trip.

What is required is an animal for light agricultural work, and your suggestion that it be from 4 to 6 years of age, approximately 1400 lbs., gentle and well broken, is satisfactory to this Department, and your estimate of approximately $800 for the price of the animal is also satisfactory.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Dear Sir:

Our Commission have been requested by the Principal of the Moose Factory School to furnish him with a treadle sewing machine (estimated cost of the Eaton's machine f.o.b. the School, $75.00) - also 200 lbs. white lead, 10 gallons turpentine, 10 gallons linseed oil and 10 lbs. putty, (estimated cost f.o.b. the School, $50.00). At a meeting of our Commission held on the 29th ultimo, I was instructed to ask if your Department would kindly undertake to meet these requirements.

As our Commission have decided not to press for this item of equipment this year, they considered that it would be reasonable, on their part, to ask you to supply the sewing machine and paint instead. If you agree to grant their request in this respect, I shall be obliged if you will arrange for the items mentioned to be shipped by the Hudson's Bay Company's steamer from Montreal.

July 1st, 1900.

Sir,

In further reference to your letter No. 44-6-5,
I have the honor to state that Mr. C.M. Macdonald, received a five
year old mare, which was shipped by Hudson's Bay Co., to Quebec City
on May 11th. In sending in bills Mr. Martinette wrote as
follows:

"Enclosed bill for horse bought from Mr. Henri Deland, L'Acadie,
P.Q., said bill also includes hay bought from Mr. Deland, and his
expenses to take the mare from L'Acadie to shed, 47 Montreal.
I also enclose a bill for the few things I had to buy for that
shipment and for which I paid myself. I have a bill of loading
for only $3; the only thing I could get was the enclosed document
showing that I had delivered the horse to the Hudson's Bay Co.
The mare was in good condition and sound; they told her in order to
ride for the first time she was very quiet; I told the man at
the yard that I would not ride her because she would be
too wild to be ridden at first, therefore I have not allowed
her to be ridden."

The mare cost $100, and the interest paid to allow 5% or
$5.00, and $2.00 for the sale of hay which is $7.00, $0.60
in all, which is to Mr. Henri Deland.

Acting Assistant Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Enc.
I also instructed him to buy two hundred pounds of bran, 
for which is herewith enclosed, also a quilt and a blanket, and 
to pay for them himself. You will find the bills for these articles 
attached.

I am confident that your friend's convalescence will be complete 
in three months and he will be restored to health. In addition, I am 
pleased to inform you that the weather has been cool and pleasant, 
and quiet. I sincerely hope that he will recover his health in 
good condition and be a satisfactory to all concerned.

Your faithfully,

[Signature]

Martinette's address is
6766 Christopher Columbus St.,
Montreal, P.Q.

Dear Sir:

In a letter just received from the Rev. J. Blackmore, A.A., Principal of our Society's School at Moose Factory, Ontario, he directs my attention to the urgent need of one large Pyrene Fire-extinguisher and three small Pyrene Fire-extinguishers, etc. I shall be obliged if you will have the same forwarded to him at your earliest convenience. As there is now a weekly train service on the P. & N.C. Railway from Cochrane, Ont., to Moose Factory which is the station nearest Moose Factory, there will be no difficulty with regard to the transportation of the same.

Rev. Blackmore states that he applied for six fire-extinguishers when the late Mr. Hamilton was filling the position of Indian Agent at Moose Factory, and although his application was approved by Mr. Miller, this equipment was not supplied. Further states that Mr. Tyler, our representative at Moose Factory, at recent, confirmed that the request I have so often made still be revised, etc. I trust that, in view of the great result heretofore, the proper care be able to moving to us.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, relative to the request of the Principal of the Moose Fort Indian Residential School for a grant of $20 to purchase prizes for a school sports' day.

Sir:

I have the honor to inform you that recently, under instructions from the Indian Residential School Commission, I visited their School at Moose Factory.

As you are aware, His Excellency, The Governor General will be at Moosonee between the 8th and 11th Inst., and will, in due course, inspect the Hudson's Bay Post and Anglican School on Factory Island. Having this point in view, I timed my visit so as to enable certain improvements to be made in the appearance of the School, and buildings in good time.

Dr. Tyner, the local Indian Agent, was most cordial in his efforts to help me, but informed me he was in receipt of communication from your Department that no money could be spared for painting and redecorating the School. In fact, he showed me your latest communication dated the 26th of April, #44-6-5, in this connection.

For many years now the Commission have hoped that your Department would be able to erect a larger and more modern school for the benefit of the Anglican Indians on Factory Island, and for this cause much-needed repairs have been neglected. The time has now come when repairs can no longer be withheld, and on my recommendation and report, after a thorough inspection, the Commission have authorised an expenditure of $800.00, to put the School on a satisfactory footing.
The Secretary, Dept. of Indian Affairs - 2  
June 8, 1933.

This considerable sum is, of course, a heavy drain upon their resources, and in spite of previous correspondence, I would once more appeal for the sympathetic consideration of your Department to help the Commission in this absolutely unavoidable expenditure.

In addition to the items already mentioned, the desks in the School are in very poor condition, and I would request, if at all possible, the following may be purchased from the George M. Hendry Company, Toronto:

During the summer of 1938, the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada carried out certain improvements to the house Fort Indian Residential School at Loretteville, James Bay district, in the province of Ontario. The cost of materials and labour amounted to the sum of $600.00. The Missionary Society, through their Field Secretary, have requested reimbursement. The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

I have the honor to inform you that recently, under instructions from the Indian Residential School Commission, I visited their School at Moose Factory.

As you are aware, His Excellency, The Governor General will be at Moosonee between the 8th and 11th Inst., and, will, in due course, inspect the Hudson's Bay Post and Anglican School on Factory Island. Having this point in view, I timed my visit so as to enable certain improvements to be made in the appearance of the School, and buildings in good time.

Dr. Tyre, the local Indian Agent, was most cordial in his efforts to help me, but informed me he was in receipt of communication from your Department that no money could be spared for painting and redecorating the School. In fact, he showed me your latest communication dated the 26th of April, #44-6-5, in this connection.

For many years now the Commission have hoped that your Department would be able to erect a larger and more modern school for the benefit of the Anglican Indians on Factory Island, and for this cause much-needed repairs have been neglected. The time has now come when repairs can no longer be withheld, and on my recommendation and report, after a thorough inspection, the Commission have authorized an expenditure of $900.00, to put the School on a satisfactory footing.
The Secretary, Dept. of Indian Affairs - 2  
June 8, 1933.

This considerable sum is, of course, a heavy drain upon their resources, and in spite of previous correspondence, I would once more appeal for the sympathetic consideration of your Department to help the Commission in this absolutely unavoidable expenditure.

In addition to the items already mentioned, the desks in the School are in very poor condition, and I would request, if at all possible, the following may be purchased from the George M. Hendry Company, Toronto:

| #4        | 22       | "           |
| #2        | 6        | "           |

Blackboard, 19' x 4'

The approximate cost, less freight, of these items would be $300.00.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Dear Sir;

During my visit to this school I have found that it has many needs. I wired to our Commission in Winnipeg to authorize an expenditure of $100.00 to meet some of these, and this authority has been granted. We cannot, however, provide new desks for the classroom, and as these are very greatly needed I sincerely hope your Department may provide them. I spoke to Dr. Tyner, your representative here, about this need, and he is forwarding the Principal's requisition for classroom equipment which includes the desks to which I refer. Rev. Sir:

Sir:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, stating the sizes and the number of each size of desk required for use at the Moose Factory Indian Residential School. It is noted, from the list which you enclose, that the Principal requests 60 single desks, 4 fronts and 4 rear seats.

In this connection I would point out that per capita grant is provided for only 40 pupils at the Moose Factory Residential School, and it is therefore not understood why 60 desks should be required, unless a number of the desks are for use in the day school. I would request that you will advise regarding the number of desks required, stating where they will be used. We will not be prepared to provide seating accommodation for more than 40 pupils at the residential school.

Would it be satisfactory to ship the desks addressed to you, Moosonee, Ont. If not, please state the address to which they should be sent. When your reply is received, consideration will be given to placing the order here.

Your obedient servant,

In order to comply with present regulations, it will be necessary for you to prepare a pay list, in triplicate, for the labour which it is noted amounts to $131.39. The necessary forms for this purpose are enclosed. These pay lists should be receipted by those who were paid for the work, and you should then prepare a voucher, in triplicate, in favour of the Principal of the School if he paid the wages, and attach the pay list to the voucher.

Regarding the accounts from Revillon Freres Trading Company and Hill-Clark-Francois, Limited, it will be necessary to have these accounts in triplicate. If these accounts have already been paid by the Principal they should be receipted. Proper voucher forms, in triplicate, should also be prepared, to which the accounts should be attached. If the accounts are receipted, a cheque will be issued to the Principal, but, if not, cheques will have to be issued to the firms mentioned.

In connection with the account of Hill-Clark-Francois, Limited, it is noted that there is an item reading, "Freight Prepaid - $9.44." It will be necessary to have a receipt from the Railway Company showing payment of this freight.

W. L. Tyer, Esq., M.D.,

March 6, 1926.

The Julien Residential School,
Moose Factory,
Ontario.

Attention: Rev. Gilbert Thompson

Dear Sirs:

We are in receipt of your letter of February 27th, in connection with our invoice of August 28th, pointing out that our first item should have been 160 feet. On checking back to our original invoice this should have been 30 pieces, but apparently when our girls were making the copy this was put down as 60.

We are very sorry that this mistake was made, but would also like to draw to your attention that this invoice was dated August 28th. If your people had received these goods and checked them off they would have found that there were 30 pieces, and this should have been marked on our copy, provided that our original showed 60. No doubt they will still have a record, but this invoice is now over five months old, and should have been paid at least four months ago.

We are changing the item to 30 pieces, and trust that you will be able to trace this, and also that your cheque will be sent as soon as possible.

Yours very truly,

Hill Clan Francis, Limited,

[Signature]

Ottawa, December 4th, 1936.

Dear Canon Gould,

Recently, I had an opportunity of discussing with the Honourable, the Minister, the proposal of the Church of England to erect, at their own expense, a new building to replace the present Moose Fort Indian Residential School.

In the event of your doing so, the Minister is disposed to favourably consider providing per capita allowance for one hundred (100) pupils, if accommodation for that number is available in the new building.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Director of Indian Affairs.

Rev. Canon S. Gould, M.D., D.C.L., D.D.,
General Secretary, N. S. C. C.,
604 Jarvis Street,
Toronto 5, Ont.
Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada

TORONTO 5, ONT., December 18th.

Dr. Harold W. McGill,
Director of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Dr. McGill:

Your letter, dated the 4th inst., file 44-6-1, stating that my proposal to erect at the expense of the Church of England in Canada "a new building to replace the present Moose Fort Indian Residential School" was submitted by you to the Minister and that he "is disposed to favourably consider providing per capita allowances for one hundred (100) pupils, if accommodation for that number is available in the new building;" was considered by the Executive Committee of this Society at its meeting on the 15th inst.

The Executive Committee decided unanimously to proceed this summer with the erection of the building in question on the assumption that the Minister being satisfied of the accommodation provided in the new building, a further letter would be received from him definitely accepting the proposal as submitted by me to you; viz., that the provision will be made for per capita grants, at the existing rate of $200.00, for 60 additional pupils bringing the total provision up from the present number of 40 to 100; this rate to continue unchanged for a period of 10 years after we have secured an attendance of 100 pupils in the new school.

Concerning our ability to obtain 100 pupils, the Bishop of Moosonee, who knows the Anglican Indian population of the District very thoroughly and whom I consulted on the point, states in part in his reply as follows:

"Wherever I have gone during the past three years particularly, I have been besieged with requests from parents to have their children admitted to the Moose Boarding School and have been obliged to say there was no room.... So that I have not the slightest doubt that we can secure 100 pupils for the school at Moose."

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6203, file 467-5, part 2)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES OF CANADA

VERY POOR COPY
January 4th, 1937.

Deputy Minister,

When discussing our Estimates with the Minister and yourself on the second instant, you will remember I mentioned that the Church of England had proposed that, if the pupilage at the Moose Port Indian Residential School were increased from forty (40) to one hundred (100), the Church authorities would be prepared to erect a new building suitable for the accommodation of the increased number of pupils.

Honourable Mr. Grover expressed his willingness to favourably consider the offer of the Church of England and I so advised Canon Gould on the 4th instant.

Canon Gould replied by stating that the Church of England is prepared to proceed with the erection of a new building during the coming summer and requests that, in addition to the increased pupilage, the Department provide the children's desks, blackboards and other minor equipment for the classrooms.

At the present time the Department is allowing grant for a pupilage of $40. The rate per capita at this school is $200. Consequently, the increased per capita allowance would be $12,000. The cost of the desks, blackboards, etc., would be approximately $900.

I would recommend that Rev. Canon Gould be informed that, on the completion of the new building, grant for 100 pupils will be allowed and also that the Department will provide the desks and blackboards.

Director of Indian Affairs.
Dr. Harold McGill

The Principal of the School places the number that would desire admittance to the new school from 120 to as high as 150. There is, therefore, I am convinced, no question concerning an enrollment to the capacity of the school at an early date after it is erected and open.

As you are aware, I think, Mr Orr is now drafting a plan for us which will ensure that the dormitory space provided has the necessary cubic air content conforming to the regulation of the Department.

Under these circumstances, I am assuming that the final and full agreement of the Hon'ble the Minister, is assured and that I may proceed as soon as the plans are completed to take the steps necessary for the erection of the school during the coming summer since the large amount of materials necessary must be delivered at Moosonee for transportation over the ice before the Spring break-up.

It was further understood and agreed between us that the Department would provide the cost - seats, blackboards, etc - of the equipment of the new classrooms; in this case to be provided for in a separate building.

Believe me,

Yours very faithfully,

[Signature]
General Secretary

SG:G
TORONTO 5, ONT., December 31st,
1936.

Dr. McGill,
Director of Indian Affairs,
Booth Building,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Dr. McGill:

Following the receipt from Mr. Orr of outline plans for the accommodation of 100 pupils in the proposed new Indian Residential School building at Moose Factory, I am having the working plans prepared by our local architects. On the completion of their work I propose to award the contracts for the large amounts of material etc.

On reading copy of my letter to you, dated the 18th inst., I note that the word "existing" in the second paragraph was inserted through a mistake and should, in consequence, be omitted.

The main building will measure 36 by 115 feet, and be three storeys in height. The wing will measure 30 by 64 feet providing space for boys' recreation room, laundry, boys and girls wash rooms, on the ground floor; the whole of the second floor being devoted to classrooms.

All the lumber will be cut to size and form in a mill at South Porcupine, shipped to Moosonee and transported over the ice to Moose Factory Island. As soon as the spring thawing of the ground permits the placing of the foundations, the work of erection will proceed with great speed.

As stated in my letter, dated the 18th inst., I am interpreting your letter dated the 4th inst. to mean that on completion of a building with accommodation for "one hundred (100) pupils" departmental provision at a per capita of $200 will be made for ten years for that number. It is because
of my anxiety to exclude any possible occasion in the future of misunderstanding on this essential point that, at the risk of repetition, I am writing this further letter.

Failing any advice from you to the contrary, I shall proceed as indicated above.

With every good wish for the New Year,

Believe me,

Yours very faithfully,

[Signature]

General Secretary.
EX'D.

Ottawa, January 11, 1937.

Dear Canon Gould:

I received your letter of December 31st, with reference to the new Indian residential school which the Church of England proposes to erect at Moose Factory, Ont.

On receipt of your letter of December 15th, I formally placed your request for increased pupilage and seats, blackboards, etc., before the Honourable the Minister. As yet, I have not received his reply, but expect to do so in the near future and will immediately write to you. I would suggest that you hold your plans in abeyance until you hear further from me.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Director of Indian Affairs.

Rev. Canon S. Gould, M.D., D.C.L., D.D.,

TORONTO 5, ONT.—January 27th,
1937.

Dr. McGill,
Director, Department of Indian Affairs,
Booth Building,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Dr. McGill:

Pursuant to our conversation of yesterday morning (preceded by your letter dated Dec. 4th, 1936; my letters dated Dec. 18th and 31st, 1936; your letter, dated Jan. 11th, 1937, and our conversation by long-distance telephone on the morning of January 12th, 1937) it appears to me desirable that the existing situation should be set out in writing.

The interpretation by the Executive of this Society of your letter, dated Dec. 4th, 1936, is set out so clearly in my letters dated Dec. 18th and 31st, that I do not need to do more than to quote the explicit sentence at the close of the first paragraph of the latter letter, viz: "On the completion of their work (i.e., the architects) I propose to award the contracts for the large amounts of materials, etc."

The architects' work was completed and on January 7th (four days prior to the date, Jan. 11th, of your letter) the contracts in question were awarded. Our total commitments under the plan are now in the neighborhood of $30,000.00.

These actions of ours, I submit, are in direct accord with the correspondence, and I trust that we may be favoured, at an early date, with the complementary action of the Honourable the Minister.

Yours very faithfully,

[Signature]
General Secretary.

SG:G
TORONTO 5, ONT., February 4th, 1937.

Mr Hoey,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Booth Building,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Mr Hoey:

On looking into the matter, I find that the current rate of per capita grants for the Moose Factory School is $200.00, not $170.00 as stated in my conversation with you yesterday afternoon. My mistake arose from the fact that in a letter from the Assistant Secretary-Treasurer of our Indian Residential School Commission he had mistakenly quoted the lower figure; on the other hand, the amounts given in the body of the letter showed that the same were made up on the basis of a per capita grant at the rate of $200.00 per annum. My letters in this connection to the Department, therefore, stand as written.

Please accept this expression of my every good wish for the success of your very important work on behalf of the Indian Wards of the Dominion.

Yours very faithfully,

[Signature]
General Secretary.

P.S. I am sending a copy of this letter to Dr. McGill.

Dear Dr. McGill:

It gives me much pleasure to enclose enlargement of my snap-shot of our new buildings at Moose Factory.

From right to left the buildings are:

1. The new Cottage Hospital.

2. The Annex, with outside scaffolding still in position, to the main building. The Annex provides on the ground floor for the laundry, the boys and girls wash rooms and the boys recreation room. The second storey consists of two very large and well-lighted classrooms. A closed and covered passageway of twenty feet connects the Annex with the main building.

3. The main building of the school. This building provides, on the ground floor - Chapel, kitchen and dining rooms for the pupils and staff; on the second floor, dormitories for junior boys and girls, office, and staff bedrooms and sitting room; on the third floor, main dormitories for senior boys and girls, with rooms for supervisors; the fourth floor, or attic, provides sewing room, large recreation room for girls and general storage rooms.

The cubic air-space provided for the dormitories is somewhat in excess of that required by the Departmental regulations.

Believe me,

Yours very faithfully,

S. Reed
General Secretary.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES CANADA

VERY POOR COPY
REPORT OF THE SECRETARY OF THE COMMISSION ON HIS VISIT TO MOOSE FACTORY

NEW BUILDINGS: The two years which elapsed since your Secretary visited this historic centre during the summer of 1935 were busy and eventful ones, and the progress made in that comparatively short time greatly exceeded his expectations. In the establishment of the fully modern Newnham Cottage Hospital, with ten beds, two cots, and one bassinette; and in the creation of a new three and a half storey residential school building with ample accommodation for 100 pupils, the Church of England in Canada has furnished unquestionable proof of her deep and practical interest in all that pertains to the highest welfare of her numerous and devoted Indian people in the Moose Factory and James Bay areas.

Never once, so far as your Secretary has been able to ascertain, since the arrival of John Henry Patterson as Bishop in 1881, has the Church of England failed to provide labourers for this part of the world-wide mission field, and it is surely fitting that the good and glorious work which they began, and carried on so faithfully and so long, should now be maintained and extended by their successors with the increased resources and facilities they have at their command. The double process of maintenance and expansion is admirably exemplified in the work through the provision of those two very necessary and very efficient buildings, and one cannot but devoutly thank God for the abundance of wisdom and help bestowed upon the General Secretary of our Society, whereby he was enabled to find a way of making this provision possible.

THE HOSPITAL: As members have already received the printed pamphlet which furnishes considerable information about the Hospital, your Secretary does not consider it necessary to make any detailed reference to it in this report.

At the time of his visit five patients were in residence, two of them having been brought from Fort George, a distance of approximately 500 miles. As two more were expected to be transferred from the Hospital at Cochrane, there is ground for believing that the operating costs may be fully met by the usual grants for patients as made by the Indian Department.

For the time being, at any rate, Nurse Hockin, who is in charge, and Mrs Sauzier, the House Matron, are quite sufficient to cope with the work, and additional help is not required.

The General Secretary recommends that responsibility for the Hospital be vested in the Commission, in the same way that the one at Hay River now stands, and your Secretary commends this recommendation to the members for sympathetic consideration and acceptance. It is the opinion of the General Secretary that the unification of control of
all the Society's work at this important centre, possesses advantages which should not be disregarded, and he expressed the hope that the members of the Commission would take the same view of the matter.

THE SCHOOL: The new buildings with the annex, the purpose of which will be described later, is pleasing in design, spacious in capacity and substantial in structure. The foundations rest on cement piles with wide footings, and the roofing material is asphalt shingles of the best quality. There is a neat little belfry on the apex of the roof at the east end, surmounted by a cross, and the bell itself purchased by contributions from the local Indian community has an unusually mellow tone. As the exterior of the building is painted a cream colour, with door and window frames in brown, the general effect, when viewed from a distance and against a background of green foliage, is decidedly pleasing.

THE ANNEX: At the east end of the main building (School) (which is 115 feet long by 36 feet wide) and connected therewith by a closed-in passage, there is another building, 64 feet long by 30 feet wide, which provides comfortable space on the ground floor for wash rooms for the boys and girls (each 24 feet wide by 13 feet) the laundry, the light and power plant, and the boiler-room (the boiler is 18 feet by 13 feet.) On the upper floor it provides two well-lighted class rooms, each 30 feet by 30 feet, separated by a partition which can easily be removed when the combined space is required for an entertainment or general assembly.

Your Secretary feels confident that the detachment of the class-room work from the main school building will strongly commend itself to the members of the Commission, as it is in keeping with the policy they have been hoping for some years to have adopted at a number of the other schools under their control.

THE CHAPEL: Of all the rooms on the ground floor of the main building itself, undoubtedly the most interesting and beautiful is the one set apart, and furnished in oak, as a Chapel.

The Chapel is 60' 6" in length, 13' 4½" in width, has a Communion Table, Prayer Desk, and two chairs at the Sanctuary end, and a sufficient number of seats and kneeling boards in the nave to accommodate the staff and a capacity enrollment of pupils. The beauty and dignity of this room are greatly enriched by a window (21' x 11' 2") of stained glass, located on the outside wall directly opposite to the main entrance. In the four
corners of this delightfully and artistically coloured window are excellent portraits of Bishop Horden, Archbishop Macfay, Bishop Anderson, Bishop Rev. John Cass, while a third panel on the left half carries a remarkably fine reproduction of the painting of Bishop Mountain's momentous journey to the Red River. In a corresponding panel near the top of the window may be seen the lady Foundress of the W.A., as she unfolds to the Board of Management, D & F.M.S. the plans which under Divine guidance and protection culminated in the honoured and Dominion-wide organization so well known today. In the centre of the window appears the Saviour of the world, pleasing disciples gathered around various nations, an Indian and Eskimo included, and, in the border on either side of this central group may be seen the official monogram of the M.S.C.C. and the Winchester Cross of the W.A. Few who see this window are ever likely to forget it, and one can only hope and pray that all who worship in this quiet and peaceful place may receive such spiritual benefit from the record upon the memorial window asaries of the heroic men and women of the past, as will enable them to dedicate their own lives to similar great undertakings for Christ in the future. Fastened to the walls on either side of the memorial window, and becomingly framed are reproductions of the two paintings by Margaret W. Tarrant, one of which is entitled "LOVING SHEPHERD OF THE SHEEP", and the other "BEHOLD I SEND YOU FORTH".

Other rooms on the ground floor of the main school building are as follows:

1. Childrens' refectory (50' x 30')
2. Staff dining room (13'4" x 13')
3. Hall (45' x 10') with three furnaces
4. Kitchen and pantry.
5. Store room; and
6. Dairy.

At either end of the first floor are spacious children's dormitories, one of which is 48' x 16' and the other 55'6" x 14'. Connecting these are two passage ways, each 9'4" x 16'7" approximately 4'4" wide. On this floor is located the Principal's office (15'10" x 12'); the staff sitting room (32'3" x 16' 6"); three bed rooms, each 15'10" x 10'); a guest room of the same size; a women's wash room 15'10" x 7'5"; and a Supervisor's room 16'4" x 10'.

The Second Floor has two dormitories each 56' x 38' and two supervisor's rooms, each 13'4" x 9'.

The Attic provides a room for storing clothing; another room for general storage; a recreation room for girls (49'4" x 14'); and a sewing room 16' x 13'4".

All rooms throughout the building are well lighted and storm and screen windows are available for winter and summer use respectively.

FURNISHINGS AND EQUIPMENT. The annex will be heated by two Banner Furnaces, No.333, made by the Galt Stove and Furnace Co., and the main school building by three Banner Furnaces, No. 328, year 1921, made by the same Company. The furnaces in the annex will burn wood, and those in the main school building wood and coal.

A Delco plant, Model No.23-C-1, Serial No.378902, 2500 watts, and 52 batteries will provide the light, also power to pump the water and operate the two Thor washers to be installed in the laundry.
The Water Supply is drawn from the river, with a Delco motor (Model 3747, Serial No. 26,115 volts D.C.) installed in a cement shaft on the river bank to operate the pump, and force the water through a 6" pipe to the school, a distance of some 450 feet. Due care has been given to the question of protecting the pipe against the severe frosts of winter.

There is a pressure, also a hot water tank in the laundry, a jacket heater. A table will be provided, also a stove for heating smoothing irons.

Tables and benches were available for the children's refectory, also a table for the staff dining room. Beds for the dormitories had been ordered, and there appeared to be every indication that the building would be ready for occupation by the end of the current year.

AFFILIATED BUILDINGS - such as a modern stock barn, implement shed, poultry house, pigery, etc. will have to be provided as funds from the Department or some other source become available. The "mission house," or staff part of the old school plant will be left standing and used for storing supplies. A root-house can be secured by putting a cement basement under this building. The Principal estimates that about 50 tons of cement will be required, and your Secretary recommends that the Department be asked to provide this, and the affiliated buildings mentioned.

STOCK. The School has four good horses at present, and these are sufficient for current needs. It has four cows milking, one day, one heifer and one bull. More cows will be required in the Spring.

THE STAFF. The numerical strength of the existing staff, if augmented by one Teacher and one Supervisor, will probably be found sufficient to handle the work of the new and larger school.

THE PRINCIPAL (Rev. Gilbert Thompson, B.A.) is a diligent and capable worker. He conducts three services each Sunday - one at 11 o'clock in the Church at Moosonee, and the other two in the Church near the School, on the Island.

THE PUPILS. The enrolment of pupils at the time of your Secretary's visit was 39, but the daily attendance at the class room was not less than 30. There are Treaty pupils receiving classroom instruction number 23, and there are about as many Treaty Indian children from the Settlement who benefit in the same way. Rev. Louis Sampson, the Teacher, has carried on the classroom quite steadily and faithfully, but it appeared to your Secretary that his qualifications better fitted him for work amongst senior grades, and none of which are to be found at this school. He himself has a keen desire to return to ministerial work and your Secretary advised him to communicate with some Bishops with a view to securing a suitable opening.

T.B.R.W.
TORONTO 5, ONT., November 13th, 1937.

Dr. Harold W. McGill,
Director of Indian Affairs,
Booth Building,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Dr. McGill:

It gives me much pleasure to enclose photographs of the completed Bishop Horden Memorial Indian Residential School at Moose Factory. The photographs are numbered on the back as follows:

No. 1. Front view of building with annex, showing covered way connecting them.

No. 2. Rear view of building and annex, showing fire escape.

No. 3. Completed group of new buildings as a whole showing, from right to left, the Bishop Newnham Memorial Cottage Hospital with the annex and main school building.

No. 4. Side and front of annex, the front of main school building.

No. 5. Interior of Chapel in the main building, showing in the middle of the right wall opposite the entrance, an historical stained glass window. Of this window I enclose separate photograph -

No. 5A. This window represents in the bottom right hand corner, the Rev. John West, our first missionary to Rupert's Land who arrived in the Bay in 1820; next to him, bottom panel,
Bishop Mountain en route by canoe from Montreal to the Red River Settlement, in 1844; bottom right hand corner, Bishop Anderson, first Bishop of Rupert's Land 1848; top left hand corner, Bishop Horden who, as a missionary, arrived at Moose Factory in 1831; top panel, formation of our Woman's Auxiliary in 1885; top right hand corner, the late Archbishop Macdonald of Rupert's Land, who arrived at Red River Settlement in 1865, and whose diocese at that time included the area now known as the Diocese of Moose Jaw; the centre panel represents "Christ the desire of all Nations," with an Indian and an Eskimo in the circle of the kneeling figures.

No. 6. One of the two classrooms forming the whole of the second storey of the annex to the main building.

All the buildings are heated with hot air furnaces; those in the main building being coal burning. The cubic air space provided exceeds the amount in the sketch plans supplied to us by Mr Orr.

I am leaving, I may add, on the 24th inst., for health reasons, on six months leave of absence and expect to return to the office on the 1st of next June.

Yours very faithfully,

[Signature]

General Secretary.

Enc.

P.S. I enclose copy of Dr. Westgate's Report of his visit to the new school.

S.G.
Ottawa, November 18, 1937.

Dear Canon Goulds:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of November 15 with enclosed photographs of the Bishop Morin Memorial Indian Residential School. I found the photographs very interesting and have passed them on to Mr. Hagg and Mr. Phelan. I may say, however, that one mentioned in your letter was missing; namely, the interior of the Chapel.

I am very sorry to hear that you have been afflicted with failing health, but I am glad to know that you have been able to secure a holiday in consequence and hope this will bring about a complete and permanent recovery.

With my very best wishes for a happy and enjoyable holiday season, I am,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Director of Indian Affairs.

Reverend Canon S. Goulds, M.D., D.C.L., D.D.,

Dear Sir:

In line with your request to the Delco Motor Products at Oshawa, and their Mr. Mounts' letter to your attention under date of January 28th, we would quote on equipment for Fire Alarm System and Watchman's Detector Stations for the school at Moose Factory, as follows:

**Fire Alarm System**

System Type SS

Closed Circuit---operation of any station sounds a predetermined code ring four times on all bells in the circuit. This circuit is supervised and is so arranged that if there is any trouble on the circuit such as grounds or short circuits the trouble bell will ring in the Engineer's or Superintendent's office indicating that there is trouble on the line and should be examined and adjusted so that the system will be maintained 100% for alarm purposes.

This system is for operation on 110 volts, D.C.

| Item Description | Quantity | Price |
|------------------|----------|-------|
| Bells #23 - 8" Single Stroke | 11 | $22.95 each |
| F.A. Stations - #1275-2 Surface Type | 7 | $39.10 each |
| Type SS - Control Panel 1 circuit | 1 | $187.00 each |

---

General Open Circuit System

Operation of any Break Glass Station causes all vibrator bells in the circuit to ring continuously until a new glass is placed in the station. This circuit is not supervised, and should be tested at intervals to make sure that there is no fault on the circuit in case an actual alarm is put through.

|------------------|----------|-------|

We would strongly recommend the use of the closed circuit type, which we believe to be the ideal system for fire alarm protection, although as you will note the cost of this equipment would be somewhat higher than the equipment as used in the general open circuit system. We are returning with this quotation two (2) sets of blueprints which were brought into us by the Aladdin People, and on these we have marked on the various floors the locations which we believe would be best suited to give a general coverage of the equipment. The fire alarm bells are marked in white pencil with a circle with a line through it. The fire alarm stations are marked with the letter "F" also in white pencil. These are our impressions of where this equipment should be located from the blueprints themselves, but however, either yourselves or the architect might wish to locate at other points in accordance with the building construction. You might also wish to either decrease or increase the number of stations and bells on anyone floor.

We would quote in connection with Watchman's Time Detector System as follows:

**WATCHMAN'S TIME DETECTOR SYSTEM**

This System consists of a Time Detector located in the Superintendent's office with outlying magneto stations where the watchman calls and puts through his visit on permanent record in the Time Detector.

1 - #78 - 6 Station Time Detector (Without Clock) $141.96 each
1 - #75 - 6 Station Time Detector (With Clock) 295.80 each
3 - #162 - Magneto Stations (Surface) 25.50 each

You will also find the various marks on the blueprint in white pencil, the "X" denoting the magneto station, at which point the Watchman would insert his key into the magneto station into operation. This would register the time at which that particular station was operated in the Watchman's Time Detector shown as a rectangular shape in white pencil with the letter "X".

In the Supervisor's Room on the first floor. In connection with this Watchman's Time Detector System we would point out to you that as it is magneto operated it would have absolutely no connection with your 110 volt D.C. System. The same remarks would apply to the Watchman's Time Detector System, that is, as to quantities and losses as in the fire alarm system.

We are enclosing literature with more information regarding both the fire alarm and Watchman's Time Detector equipment. All prices quoted herein are net, sales tax included.

I trust that we have made ourselves quite clear in connection with the items quoted and detail on them, also you will note in the literature enclosed they give a general wiring diagram in connection with both the open and the closed systems. This detail, of course, would not be necessary insofar as the Watchman's Time Detector equipment is concerned. If there is any additional detail or information which we can supply, we trust you will not hesitate to call on us for such information.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

F.B. Smith/ME.
Supply Sales Division,
Manager.
Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada

TORONTO, ONT., February 12th, 1938.

R.A. Hoey, Esq.,
Superintendent Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Mr Hoey:

The Principal of our Moose Factory School has directed the attention of our Commission to the need of a fire alarm system with station time detectors, and I consulted the Northern Electric Company from whom the lighting system at the school was secured, with regard to the most suitable kind, and the cost of the same. Enclosed herewith is the original of their reply to my letter.

They recommend the closed circuit system described in their letter (page 1) as the System Type S.S. The cost of this equipment would be $715.15. As the six station time detectors would cost an additional $295.80, or a total of $1009.95, I am writing to ascertain if your Department can authorize this expenditure.

As the need cannot be questioned, and as you know the dilemma in which our Society stands at present financially, your help in this matter will be appreciated more than it is possible to express.

Although I am writing this from our Toronto office, will you please address your reply to me at my Winnipeg office.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Secretary of the Commission.
Ottawa,
February 18, 1936.

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 12th instant with reference to the proposed installation of a fire alarm system in the Moose Factory Residential School.

This school was recently remodelled by your Commission and I presume was made as fireproof as possible in view of northern conditions. In addition we make an allowance for a night watchman. No special provision was made in the current year's appropriation for such a heavy expenditure as you request at the Moose Factory Residential School and I therefore regret that favourable consideration cannot be given to your request.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
R. A. Hael
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. T.B.R. Westgate, D.D.,
Secretary, Residential School Commission,
The Bible House,
Winnipeg, Man.

Sup't. Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Your letter of the 16th ultimo, #44-6-5, awaited me on my return from eastern Canada a short time ago, and I sincerely regret the decision embodied therein, not to provide the fire alarm system requested for our Moose Factory School.

When making the request for this equipment as embodied in my letter of the 16th ultimo, I was under the impression that as our Society had made a capital expenditure of approximately $60,000.00 in providing the new school building at Moose Factory, and had therewith, met your Department's request, you would be able to help us to the comparatively slight extent indicated, in the same way that you made a grant of approximately $2,000.00 for equipment at our Aklavik School.

Further, as our Society during the past few years has provided not only the new school buildings at Moose Factory, but new school buildings at Fort George and Aklavik as well, at a total cost of approximately $125,000.00, the request did not, nor does it yet, appear to me to be an unreasonable one.

As you state in your letter that "no special provision was made in the current year's appropriation for such a heavy expenditure as requested at the Moose Factory Residential School", I have been wondering if some of the saving affected by your Department through the non-payment of P.E. grants could not be made available for the equipment in question. For instance, had capacity attendance of pupils been maintained in 1937 at all the Schools administered by our Society, our Society's revenue would have been increased by the amounts indicated in the following list:

Indian Affairs, (RC 10, Volume 6203, file 467-5, part 2)

CANADA
| Location       | Capacity | Average Attendance | Loss   |
|----------------|----------|--------------------|--------|
| White Fish Lake| 50       | 27.57              | $415.11|
| Blackfoot      | 100      | 88.38              | $1889.28|
| Peigan         | 60       | 46.68              | $466.54|
| Lac la Ronge   | 100      | 97.48              | $974.27|
| Elkhorn        | 145      | 142.64             | $200.73|
| Sioux Lookout  | 125      | 99.62              | $546.21|
| Chapleau       | 100      | 92.61              | $1123.66|

Total $10422.80

This heavy loss in revenue, along with the further loss of approximately $10,000.00 through the 5% cut in the grants, will indicate to you the difficulties which confront our Commission in the efficient administration of our Society's Schools, and while there may be some Department ruling to the effect that past grants which are not claimed automatically lapse, I trust that if no such ruling obtains, some of the losses effected last year on grants in this way, may yet be applied to the provision of the fire alarm system requested for Moose Factory.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Secretary of the Commission.
Ottawa, March 7, 1938.

Dear Dr. Westgate:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the first instant, in which you express regret at the inability of the Department to provide the alarm system you requested for the recently constructed residential school at Moose Factory.

I may state by way of comment that negotiations relating to the construction of a residential school at Moose Factory took place before I entered the Department a little over a year ago. It is my understanding, however, that this school was to be constructed and equipped by the Anglican Church authorities and that the Department, in turn, had promised an increase in pupilage from 40 to 100. These negotiations were carried on by Reverend Canon Gould, representing your Church, and Dr. McGill, Director of this Branch.

I note your reference to the funds that might be available as the result of the regulation which permits us to pay only on the average attendance at residential schools. I may state that the average attendance at residential schools is carefully considered when the estimates are prepared from year to year and an amount necessary to pay approximately 50% of the per capita grant payments included. You can readily ...

Rev. T. B. R. Westgate, D.D.,
Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.,
39-43 The Bible House,
Alexander Avenue,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.
can readily see, therefore, that there is no surplus available from this source. In addition to this, an Order-in-council was passed recently, making provision for the payment of an additional $5.00 per pupil to residential schools in the province of Saskatchewan. I regret, therefore, that we have not at our disposal in the appropriation of this year the funds necessary for the construction of a fire alarm system at the Moose Factory School.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

When in Ottawa last November, I discussed with Mr. Phelan the need of cement for the basement of a house at Moose Factory to serve as a storage for vegetables, and was informed payment would be met by the Department if bills were presented before the end of the current fiscal year.

When in Ottawa again last month, I mentioned that the amount of cement required was found to be larger than at first anticipated, but was assured that the promise of payment would not be affected by this fact.

Enclosed herewith you will find the bill from Messrs. Mercier & Shirley, Limited, in triplicate, for the cement delivered at Moosonee, and it will be appreciated if you will send your cheque for the amount direct to them.

Faithfully yours,

CERTIFIED TO BE A TRUE COPY OF A MINUTE OF A MEETING OF THE COMMITTEE OF THE PRIVY COUNCIL, APPROVED BY HIS EXCELLENCY THE GOVERNOR GENERAL ON THE 25th APRIL 1938.

PRIVY COUNCIL

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated 6th April, 1938, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, stating:

That the estimates for the fiscal year 1938-39, Vote Number 169, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, provide an amount of $34,582.00 for new works, repairs and purchase of equipment for the following Church owned Indian Residential Schools:

(a) ONTARIO.
Spanish Roman Catholic Residential School
Moose Fort Church of England Residential School.

(b) SASKATCHEWAN
Thunderchild Roman Catholic Residential School.

(c) ALBERTA
Ermineskin Roman Catholic Residential School
Grouard Roman Catholic Residential School.
Holy Angels Roman Catholic Residential School.
Joussard Roman Catholic Residential School.
St Albert Roman Catholic Residential School.
Sturgeon Lake Roman Catholic Residential School.
Vernilion Roman Catholic Residential School.
Wabasca Roman Catholic Residential School.
Wabasca Church of England Residential School.
Whitefish Lake Church of England Residential School.

(d) NUNAVUT
Aklavik Roman Catholic Residential School.
Aklavik Church of England Residential School.
Fort Resolution Roman Catholic Residential School.
Providence Mission Roman Catholic Residential School.

(e) BRITISH COLUMBIA
Ahousaht United Church Residential School.
Gribben Roman Catholic Residential School.
Christie Roman Catholic Residential School.
Kitamaat United Church Residential School.
Port Simpson United Church Residential School.
St. Mary's Mission Roman Catholic Residential School.
Squamish Roman Catholic Residential School.
That, as these buildings are Church owned, new works, repairs and purchase of equipment constitute a grant and, therefore, the approval of Your Excellency in Council is desirable.

The Minister, therefore, recommends that approval be given for the expenditure at the above-mentioned Indian Residential Schools of the sum of $34,582.00, same to be chargeable to Vote Number 169, 1938-39, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources.

The Committee concur in the foregoing recommendation and submit the same for approval.

E. J. Lemaire,
Clerk of the Privy Council,

The Honourable,
the Minister of Mines & Resources.

Ottawa, May 26, 1938.

Memorandum:

W. M. Bailey, Esq.,
Purchasing Agent.

Some months ago, Reverend T. B. R. Westgate, Secretary of the Indian & Eskimo Residential School Commission, H.E.C.C., visited the Department and requested authority to purchase cement in order to build a vegetable store house at the Moose Fort Residential School. He was authorized to do so but the account only reached us recently. You will note the cement cost $340.40 and was purchased from Morley & Shirley, Ltd., of Cochrane, Ont., who are on the Approved List. Funds for this payment are available in the appropriation for the current fiscal year, and I would appreciate if you would issue a Purchase Requisition, in order that we may pay the account.

Director.
Moose Factory May 26th 1938

Doctor Stone,

Dear Sir,

Canon Gould is at Moose today and we went into the matter of the extra beds for the school. We agree that there would be no advantage in enlarging the building.

We now take into the school pupils with a bad family history as long as they are free from T.B., unless you do not allow us to take these children in there is no need of the extra beds, and if you do not allow us to take them in except as special pupils then we could set aside one of the dormitories for their use only.

The Ontario Government are allowing the hospital to care for halfbeeds so they are enlarging the hospital this summer—two wings of 7 beds each—enlarging the kitchen and bathroom—building a sitting room and installing another bathroom.

I would advise that if we do not have the school for the weak children, we be allowed to admit any child that is at present free from T.B.

Yours truly,

W.L. Tyre

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6203, File 467-5, part 2)

Public Archives - Archives Publiques Canada

VERY POOR COPY
Dear Doctor Tyrer:

From your letter of May 26 it is evident that you wish to use the residential school at Moosonee partly as a preventorium unit. My only comment is that you should watch the school carefully to see that no child remains in it who has tuberculosis in a phase which is a menace to the other children and that those children whom you describe as pupils with a bad family history should have a substantial advantage in the way of feeding, rest, and relief from exertion. If certain dormitories could be set aside for them I think it would be of advantage. This was the object of the other proposed arrangement and it will be so much the better if it can be accomplished without further building.

Yours truly,

E.L. Stone, M.B.,
Superintendent of Medical Services.

W.L. Tyner, Esq., M.D.,
Indian Agent,
Moose Factory, Ont.

WINNIPEG, MAN. August 17, 1939.

R.A. Hoey, Esq.,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

The Rev. Gilbert Thompson, B.A., Principal of our Moose Factory School, has directed the attention of our Commission to the urgent need of a duplicator, such as the one described on the enclosed sheet, and I am writing for the specific purpose of ascertaining if you could supply this item of equipment. It is my understanding that it would cost $75 complete with 24 stencils, stylus, ink, etc.

In addition to the capacity enrollment of pupils who are in residence, there is a large attendance in the classrooms of Day pupils from the surrounding settlement, and the Principal points out that the duplicator would be of great service to the teachers in their classroom work. Further, as many of our Schools keep in touch with the parents of pupils in residence, as well as with graduate pupils, by sending out a monthly letter embodying information of interest to all, the duplicator would be of very great service in more ways than one, and I sincerely hope that you may be able to find some way of providing it.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

TBRW/WH
Secretary of the Commission.

Encl.
Ottawa,
August 24, 1939.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 17th instant in which you submit, for Departmental consideration, a request received by you for a duplicator from the Principal of the Moose Factory Indian residential school.

I hesitate to send forward to the Purchasing Department a requisition for a duplicator such as the one described on the sheet enclosed with your communication. I feel confident that a requisition for a duplicator at this price would not be acceptable to the Purchasing Division. I am, however, sending forward a requisition for a duplicator which, I feel confident, will serve the purpose Mr. Thompson has in mind. It is in use at a number of our schools and has been very satisfactory.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. T.B.R. Westgate, D.D.,
Secretary, Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission, M.S.C.C.,
38-43 The Bible House,
184 Alexander Ave. East,
Winnipeg, Man.

Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada,
Winnipeg, Man., Nov. 25, 1939.

Dr. H.W. McGill,
Director, Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Dr. McGill:

During the discussion of this matter it was suggested and finally agreed that the best course to take would be to build a new and larger hospital and allow the present hospital building, erected in 1936, to be used as the Principal's residence. As this building is conveniently located to the new School, and would serve very well for this purpose, the Committee hoped that the arrangement would commend itself to you and to your Department.

As the existing hospital, however, must continue in operation until a new and larger one has been provided, it was unanimously agreed by the Committee that the provision of the new hospital should be undertaken by the Government.

In support of this view it was pointed out that as the Society had erected the new School at a cost of over $50,000.00, and the existing hospital at a cost of at least $7,000.00, including equipment, it should not be asked or expected to make any further large expenditure for the new larger hospital required.

I was instructed, therefore, to ask you to include in your estimates for the next fiscal year the sum of at least $10,000.00 to build the larger hospital necessary at this centre.

It was the unanimous opinion of the members of the Committee that the residence of the Principal should be provided out of Government funds, and, as the cost of materials and plus freight, wages, etc., for the existing hospital building amounted to not less than $5,000.00, the Government expenditure for the two buildings will be reduced by that amount.

As the Federal Government has recently given very careful attention to the question of improving the health of its Indian wards, and has voted a very considerable sum of money for this purpose, the Committee earnestly hope that this comparatively small expenditure may be made possible next year through the provision of a hospital capable of meeting for many years to come, the medical requirements of the Indians in the Moose Factory and James Bay settlements.

Yours very truly,

T.B.R. Westgate,
Secretary of the Commission.

Moose Factory Oct. 24th 1941

Mr. Thomas,
In Charge Ang. Res. School,
Moose Factory.

Dear Sir,

It has come to my attention that Clarence Corston is acting as Night Watchman at the school.

I do not approve of this man acting as Night Watchman. I cannot think that Mr. Thompson knew the man's history when he engaged him; he was in a hospital for the insane for about two years and at the present time I do not consider his mentality any too stable.

I will sign the voucher for his October pay with a note enclosed informing the Department of my action. If you still keep him as Night Watchman after October 31st I will not be held responsible for his actions as Night Watchman and will not sign any voucher for his wages.

Yours truly,

W.L. Tyrer
Indian Agent.

Mr. Roy,

This man wanted his pay as soon as he topped work and as the situation had no money I paid him, so ill you please send the voucher to me at once.

Yours truly,

W.L. Tyrer

October 17, 1941.

R. A. Hoey, Esq.,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

During my interview with you on the 9th instant I mentioned the urgent need of a mechanical washing machine for our school at Moose Factory, and it is my recollection that I promised to submit a request to you for some help in securing this very necessary item of equipment. The smaller washers which have been in use have been found to be inadequate, and the Principal (Rev. Gilbert Thompson, B.A.) has submitted to our Commission the following recommendations:

The J. H. Connor & Sons Ltd., Ottawa, are willing to supply a "No.1 K.W. Wood Tub Washer with counter shaft, electric motor and wringer. Capacity 36", length over all 69", height over all 56". Price $10.00."

Mr. Thompson states that "This is the smallest machine we could get if we are expected to work economically."

While I am deeply conscious of the financial difficulties confronting your Department at the present time, I am regrettably obliged to state that the Government's decision to reduce the pupilage at the Indian Residential Schools to 92.24% from January 1st of last year, has made it impossible for our Society to meet...
all essential requirements such as this item of equipment out of their present income. Our difficulty has been further increased by the fact that the Society was obliged to install, at very great expense, a septic tank at this school and also to enlarge the intake pipe in connection with the water supply.

Should your Department be unable to meet the total cost of the washing machine recommended by Mr. Thompson, I would earnestly hope that you may be able to make a generous grant towards the cost of the same.

In the list of sums provided in your Estimates for the current fiscal year, and as submitted in Departmental letter of June 30th last #160-2, I note that the sum of $300 is included for general repairs and painting at this school. I had hoped that some of this amount might still be available for the purchase of the washing machine, but the Principal wrote to me in August to say that a large part of this amount had already been used, and that the painting was essential to preserve the fabric of the main school building from deteriorating.

A similar washing machine will be required for our Aklavik School but owing to lack of transportation consideration of this need may be deferred until next year.

Very kind regards,

Faithfully yours,

[Signature]

Secretary of the Commission.
Ottawa,
October 29, 1941.

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 17th instant with reference to a request that you have resolved for a new washing machine for the Moose Port Residential School.

As you were previously advised, an amount of $300.00 was included in the current year's appropriation for repairs, improvements and purchase of new equipment at the Moose Port School. We have had no communication from the Principal with regard to the expenditure which he advises you he has incurred. Consequently the $300.00 is still available. If you so desire I am prepared to recommend to the Minister that this amount be allowed to your Society toward the cost of the washing machine. I regret, however, that we cannot allow any larger amount than $300.00.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. T.B.R. Westgate, D.D.,
Secretary, Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission,
M. S. C. C.,

Moose Factory, Ont.,
May 5th., 1947.

Dear Sir:

For some time I have been attempting to obtain specifications for a suitable chlorinator for the drinking water supply at the Moose Residential School.

Due to the set up of the pumping system, it appears that a pressure type of injector will be required. Three firms have submitted replies to my inquiries - two of whom require further information which is being supplied.

Enclosed is the letter and folder supplied by the Arthur S. Leitch Company Ltd., of Toronto. The equipment illustrated appears to be that required.

I presume the Department will undertake the cost of equipment - probably out of funds set aside yearly for additions, improvements, etc. There is a real need for this installation for there is no doubt that pollution of the Moose River will increase from year to year.

Will you kindly return the enclosure to me after your perusal of same.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

P.E. Moore, M.D., D.P.H.,
A/Sup't. Medical Services,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA.

June 2nd, 1943.

Dear Sir,

Re: Water Supply, - Moose Port Indian Residential School

The Indian Affairs Branch has asked this Service to prepare specifications for a chlorinating unit for your school, but before doing so we should have certain information regarding the conditions under which the equipment will have to operate. This information should include the source of supply, its distance from the school, and bacteriological analyses of the water; also the type and capacity of the pumping unit, whether it is located in the school or in a separate pump house, and whether it is driven by a gasoline engine or an electric motor. It will also be necessary to know the voltage of the electric current available, if any, and if it is alternating current the frequency should be stated. The number of persons served should be given.

Kindly forward this information to the undersigned as soon as possible, so that the necessary specifications may be prepared.

Yours faithfully,

T. S. Mills,
Chief Engineer.

Per:

The Rev. G. Thompson,
Principal,
Moose Port Indian Residential School,
Moose Port,
via Fraserdale, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I have just received your letter of the 1st inst. #72-0-5, being a reply to a letter addressed to you from this office on the 24th ult., regarding payment of the sum of $300.00 for expenditures incurred at our Fort George School.

Your opinion that this account was settled by your cheque #62659 for $300.00 issued on March 4th last, is not correct, as the voucher which accompanied that cheque clearly states that it was for "Supplied purchased for the Moose Fort Residential School". That cheque was issued in response to the request embodied in our letter of December 22nd last. That is the only cheque we have received, and I will be obliged if you will give the earliest attention you possibly can to the request embodied in our letter of the 24th ult. for the $300.00 due in connection with our Fort George School.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

I have your memorandum of the 14th instant, with reference to the small chlorinating unit for the Moose Port Indian Residential School.

In a letter dated May 5, 1948, Dr. T.J. Orford, Indian Agent, wrote as follows:

"For some time I have been attempting to obtain specifications for a suitable chlorinator for the drinking water supply at the Moose Port Residential School. There is a real need for this installation for there is no doubt that pollution of the Moose River will increase from year to year."

You will note from the above that Dr. Orford considers this installation necessary. If, however, you desire us to write for further information, we will be pleased to do so.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Memorandum:

Mr. Phelan,

In reply to your memorandum of the 18th instant, regarding chlorination unit for the Moose Port Residential School, I may say that the excerpt of Dr. Orford's letter of May the 5th, 1942, does not supply the information requested in my memorandum of the 14th instant. My instructions to obtain a complete report on the necessity for the installation and to secure concrete evidence of contamination of the Moose Port water supply were based upon information which was submitted by Departmental technical staff, and which reads in part as follows:

"However, before any further action is taken towards purchasing this equipment we would strongly recommend that some concrete evidence be submitted showing the source of supply (Moose river) to be contaminated. Samples of water should be forwarded here for bacteriological analysis, if such analyses have not already been made, and a sketch showing the location of the intake in relation to any sewer outlets or other possible sources of contamination should be submitted. The locality is remote from any large centres of population and it seems most unlikely that a river of this size would be sufficiently contaminated to require chlorination except under unusual local conditions. If such conditions do obtain, the Department should be informed of them."

Will you please arrange to secure from Dr. Orford the desired information and samples of water or analysis of same.

H. J. DAVIDSON
H. J. Davidson,
Dept. Purchasing Agent.

Ch. N. Davidson,
