OTTAWA,
July 21, 1948.

Dear Sir:

In your letter of May 5 you requested that a chlorinator be secured for the Moose Port Indian Residential School. The request together with the information you forwarded was submitted to our Purchasing Branch and has also been considered by the Departmental technical staff.

The technical staff has expressed the following opinion:

"However, before any further action is taken towards purchasing this equipment we would strongly recommend that some concrete evidence be submitted showing the source of supply (Moose River) to be contaminated. Samples of water should be forwarded here for bacteriological analysis, if such analyses have not already been made, and a sketch showing the location of the intake in relation to any sewer outlets or other possible sources of contamination should be submitted. The locality is remote from any large centres of population and it seems most unlikely that a river of this size would be sufficiently contaminated to require chlorination except under unusual local conditions. If such conditions do obtain, the Department should be informed of them."

It would be appreciated if you would forward the desired information and samples of water for analysis of same.

Yours truly,

Dr. T.J. Orford,
Indian Agent,
Moose Factory, Ont.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Moose Factory, Ont.,
August 14th., 1942.

Philip Phelan, Esq.,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA.

Dear Sir:

Re: Chlorinator for Moose Factory Indian Residential School - Your letter of July 22nd, File 44-6-5

On November 18th, 1941, a school girl developed symptoms referable to a diagnosis of Typhoid Fever. There had been no known contact and possible sources of carrier infection were investigated without result. Diagnosis was positively confirmed by Widal reaction of blood sample sent to Ontario Department of Health.

Water sample taken from the school tap at that time and sent to the Ontario Department of Health was classified as "D" with a count of colon bacilli found in 1 c.c.

I received a letter under date of December 22nd., 1941, from Mr. Hugh McIntyre, Provincial Sanitary Inspector at Kirkland Lake, from which I quote -

"The samples of water which you have had tested give very poor returns ------- I may say the Mattagami River (a tributary of the Moose) has been found to be constantly infected by Typhoid as far North as Smoothrock Falls, and there is a possibility of infection occasionally from the Moose River water in consequence. Such water should not be drunk at any time without boiling."
I received a letter under date of January 10th, 1942, from W.H. Turpel, M.D., D.P.H., Division of Epidemiology, Department of Health, Ontario from which I quote:

"Dr. Berry, the Director of the Sanitary Engineering Division also suggests that you install a small hypochlorinator machine on your pumping system, which will ensure a safe water supply to the school."

The following is quoted from a letter dated February 5th, from Dr. P.E. Moore:

"I believe that there is sufficient endemic typhoid in the North to make it advisable to vaccinate the children in the Residential school. I believe that a small chlorinating machine such as you suggest should be installed."

The following is quoted from a letter dated February 9th, received from Mr. Hugh McIntyre, Provincial Sanitary Inspector:

"I think you have very good grounds for suspecting this source of supply for drinking water (Moose River) in view of the fact that all the sewage from Timmins, Iriquois Falls, Cochrane, Smoothrock Falls, Kapuskasing and Hearst goes into its tributaries. No doubt some considerable distance separates you from these sources of pollution but such steady and long continued pollution is bound to tell in the end, especially as the discharge of paper mill waste tends to kill off fish in these rivers. My opinion is that the river water should not be used unless boiled or chlorinated. I always understood the river water at Moose Factory is brackish, especially at high tide."

The following is quoted from a letter received from Dr. Moore dated February 11th:
"I agree - that in view of the reports on the river water, there it is unsafe to drink and is very probably responsible for carrying the infection that causes your endemic gastro-intestinal disturbances." (Sh. Para dysenteriae Sonne)

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Dear Mr. Hoey:

After receiving your letter of June 30th last, No.160-2, in which you advised that a grant of $500.00 was available for repairs, improvements, etc., at our Moose Factory School, I wrote to the Principal requesting a list of repairs etc. to be undertaken, also a list of the materials required to complete the same. Enclosed herewith is a copy of his reply, and I will be obliged if you will let me know at your earliest convenience if the grant of $500.00 (less the $25.00 already expended) may be used in providing the Septic tank suggested.

No order should be given for any of the materials listed, until further notice, as the total cost will greatly exceed the grant from your Department, and we must know how this is to be provided.

It will be a help to us in deciding whether the building of the tank is to be undertaken or not, if we know whether the grant (now $475.00) can be applied towards this purpose.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I am writing for the specific purpose of soliciting your help in enabling our Commission to retain at their Moose Factory School the services of Mr. John H. Long, the Engineer. In a letter just received from him he states that he had received a notice to report for medical examination and military training, and while he felt doubtful about being accepted for active service, there was a possibility that he might be taken for some form of service.

The Reverend Principal Thompson of our Moose Factory School, when writing to me in this connexion, stated that Dr. Orford had examined Mr. Long, and he thought that "due to the foot defect he would probably be put in category 'C'."

As our Commission, since Canada entered into war, has released approximately fifty staff agents, or nearly one-third of all of their school staffs, they felt that in this way they have made a valuable contribution to the war effort. The finding of other men and women to take their place has imposed a very heavy strain on our Commission and especially on our office staff, and at the present time we have important staff vacancies which we are most anxious to fill. Half of the men who are engineers at our schools have enlisted, and if Mr. Long is taken away for any reason whatever, it may be months before we are able to secure anyone else to take his place. Principal Thompson is relying on him to supervise the installation of the septic tank referred to in your letter of August 24th last, #44-6-5, and I can assure you that any help you may be able to give us in arranging for Mr. Long to remain where he is will be fully appreciated.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Secretary of the Commission.

TBRWIA.
Ottawa, September 8, 1942.

Re: Engineer, Moose Fort
Residential Schools

Dear Doctor Westgate:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 3rd instant, in which you solicit our help in retaining the engineer at the above-noted school.

You will be interested to learn that a number of somewhat similar requests have reached this Branch since the outbreak of war. I regret to state, however, that under existing regulations it is not possible for the officials of this Branch to intervene, either directly or indirectly, in such matters. We have been informed that no exceptions can be made in regard to men called up for military training. It is just possible, of course, that in the case of Mr. Long his physical disabilities will be such that he will experience little difficulty in securing a release. In any event, we are powerless to take any action in cases of this nature.

Yours very truly,

Technical Publication 222

W&T JUNIOR TESTER

Chlorine feed rates are usually adjusted so that there is a slight excess of chlorine remaining after treatment is completed. This excess is referred to as "Residual Chlorine" and can be readily measured to determine that the correct amount of chlorine has been added.

When a chlorine feed rate produces a residual higher than required, chlorine is being wasted and, of course, when the residual is less than that required, the desired results will not be obtained. In the interests of economy and proper chlorination it is essential to adjust chlorine feed rates accordingly.
Proper adjustment of chlorination to meet the seasonal changes in chlorine requirement therefore demands a simple method of determining chlorine residual quickly and with laboratory accuracy.

Because it is simple, easily and quickly performed and because it requires no special chemical or technical training, the ortho-tolidin color comparison test is widely used for this purpose. Ortho-tolidin when added to water containing residual chlorine will develop a greenish yellow or orange color. The intensity of the color developed varies with the amount of residual chlorine present.

To meet the demand for an accurate, permanently reliable, yet inexpensive device for this color test the W&T Junior Tester is of particular advantage where chlorination will be confined to narrow residual limits and where requirements do not warrant the purchase of standards for a complete range as furnished with the W&T Comparator.

This apparatus is furnished with either of two sets of standards. For drinking water chlorination it is customary to use the standards which show residuals of 0.1 parts per million and 0.3 parts per million. For swimming pools and applications where higher residuals are usually in order, a set of color standards for 0.2 p.p.m. and 0.5 p.p.m. is furnished. With either set of standards, it is an easy matter to interpolate the results of any test.

Description

Consisting of a housing which is firmly supported on a broad base, the Tester is made of moulded plastic material which is durable, resistant to corrosion and not affected by either acids or alkalis. Two rectangular sample tubes fit into the housing, one for the sample being tested and the other for an untreated sample. By this means natural color and turbidity in the water are automatically compensated for and a true reading of residual is obtained. An even diffusion of light over the samples is assured by milk glass set in the back of the case. Non-fading, accurate color standards are built into the front of the case with the numbers which indicate the value of each standard. The standards are made of a carefully colored and accurately calibrated glass, permanently maintaining their reliability.

Operating Procedure

Clean both tubes and fill to 10 cc. mark with water to be tested. To one tube containing sample of water, add 0.5 cc of ortho-tolidin reagent, mix thoroughly and place in center compartment of test kit. Allow maximum color to develop—which usually takes from 5 to 10 minutes.

Compare developed color in center tube with glass color standards by placing untreated sample tube first in left hand compartment and then in right hand compartment of test kit. Residual values must be estimated if the developed color lies between the two color standards.

General

Square sample tubes provided with this Tester eliminate shadow interference and all color standards are calibrated for the 13 mm. depth of liquid and the quantities of water and reagent as indicated. It is essential that the correct sample tubes and color standards are used at all times with this kit.

Before taking readings be sure that the glass color standards, the sample tubes and the frosted glass in the back of the case are clean.

Never test samples that have stood in sunlight as the color developed by ortho-tolidin will fade.

CONVENIENCE

Represented in 32 convenient cities, a nationwide organization of Wallace & Tierman specialists in sanitary and industrial chlorination are ready to be of service. They are prepared to offer advice on any phase of the application of chlorine for any purpose. Feel free to call on them or to write direct.

Technical Publication 178

THE W&T HYPOCHLORINATOR

Chlorination of the small water supply, either public or private, where chlorine requirements are small and supervision limited, presents a distinct problem in the field of sanitation. Today, more than 85% of the country's domestic water supply is chlorinated but too many individual smaller supplies have been neglected due to the lack of suitable equipment. The W & T Hypochlorinator has been specifically designed to meet this need. Small in size, easily installed and requiring a minimum of operating supervision, it offers for the small supply the efficient protection of chlorination at the lowest possible cost.

How the W&T Hypochlorinator Operates

The Hypochlorinator consists essentially of a diaphragm pump constructed of corrosion resistant material and so designed that the rate of chlorine application may be easily adjusted to properly chlorinate the water flowing through a pipe line. The fundamental operating principle is outstanding from the standpoint of design and is exclusive with W & T Hypochlorinators. It consists in the use of a balanced diaphragm with a single suction valve and single discharge valve, solution being drawn into the diaphragm chamber on the suction stroke and forced out to the point of application on the discharge stroke. On the delivery side of the diaphragm the pressure is the same as that at the point of application. On the reverse side of the diaphragm, water under full main pressure is allowed to flow into the diaphragm chamber through a non-return control or check valve which confines this water and balances the diaphragm between equal pressures. Pumping is accomplished by application of an intermittent impulse which causes the diaphragm to reciprocate in a manner similar to a pump piston. This principle of operation gives extraordinarily long diaphragm life because of minimum strain on the diaphragm and, in addition, allows the pump to deliver a uniform volume of solution regardless of the water pressure encountered. Control of the pump may be effected either with a small electric motor or specially designed water driven element depending upon existing conditions at the point of application. Manual or automatic control, depending upon the type of installation, can be used on either electric or water driven type and a third type, water driven and meter controlled, will automatically proportion the rate of chlorine application to the water flow. Hence, the W & T Hypochlorinator is readily adaptable to any small water supply whether it be a steady flow, a pumped supply with automatic start and stop, or a variable flow gravity supply.
Electrically Operated Hypochlorinator

The Electrically Operated Hypochlorinator is particularly adaptable for use on small pumped water supplies operated either manually or by automatic start and stop of the pumping unit. The equipment is operated by water under pressure equal to or greater than that into which the chlorine solution is applied and operation is directed by means of a small electric motor. Since water pressure furnishes the major part of the power needed to operate the Hypochlorinator, the electric power required is greatly reduced and the small electric motor used consumes no more than 40 watts—at ordinary rates, a cost for electricity averaging not over 5c. a day. Waste water is also reduced to a minimum and averages no more than a quarter of a gallon per minute.

Rate of chlorine application may be varied by changing the length of the pumping stroke or by the choice of either of two operating speeds, the total capacity range of the apparatus being 36 to 1. Motor and gears are entirely enclosed and operate in an oil bath—hence there is no lubrication problem.

The Electrically Operated Hypochlorinator is designed to operate on any water pressure from 5 lbs. to 125 lbs. per square inch. For pressures below 5 pounds per square inch or where negative pressure exists at the point of application, a special electrically operated unit has been designed which operates entirely on electric power and has no water connections or fittings.

Water Operated Hypochlorinator

The Water Operated Hypochlorinator uses only water pressure for operation, one flow being used to operate the balanced diaphragm and another flow controlling the operation. Since it is entirely independent of electric or external mechanical power it is particularly well adapted for emergency work, for standby or duplicate installation, or for any installation requiring a steady rate of chlorination. The equipment is operated by water under pressure equal to or greater than that into which the chlorine solution is applied, the minimum water pressure being 10 pounds per square inch and the maximum 125 pounds per square inch. By using the pilot principle of design wherein minute mechanical forces are able to operate the equipment with small quantities of water, the amount of waste water is reduced to a minimum and averages not more than one-half gallon per minute. Variation in rate of chlorine application is accomplished by changing the number of pumping strokes per minute and gives a 12 to 1 range. An important advantage of the W & T Water Operated Hypochlorinator lies in the fact that the suction stroke is extremely rapid, requiring only a small percentage of the running time and hence the rate of chlorine application is remarkably steady.

Automatic Hypochlorinator

Because of wide flow variations on small gravity water supplies, an automatic meter driven chlorinator of small capacity has long been in demand. The W & T Automatic Hypochlorinator fulfills the requirements for this type of installation in all respects. Operation is similar to the Manual Water Operated Hypochlorinator but the rate of pumping and hence the rate of chlorine application is directly controlled by a water meter installed in the main water line. Any type of meter in which a shaft turns in direct ratio to the flow of water through the meter may be used, and the chlorine applied will be at all times proportional to the water flow. Variation in treatment is accomplished by varying the length of stroke, for which purpose a control handle and dial are provided on the equipment. The accuracy of the W & T Automatic Hypochlorinator when used with small water meters is outstanding and is due to the important and exclusive principle of design wherein small mechanical power is required to activate the balanced diaphragm pump—an advantage found only in W & T equipment.

### Short Specifications for W&T Hypochlorinator

**TYPE:** The Chlorinator shall be a Manual or Automatic Control Operated Hypochlorinator designed to feed sterilizing solution in the form of hypochlorite for treating a flow of water containing not more than 100 pounds per square inch. The Chlorinator shall be capable of being started automatically when the water pressure falls below a certain point.

**CAPACITY AND MEASUREMENT:** The Chlorinator shall have sufficient capacity of solution to maintain continuously a hypochlorite solution discharge from the Hypochlorinator from maximum to minimum discharge by means of a diaphragm pumping unit.

**DETAILS:** The Chlorinator shall be equipped with a reinforced steel tank of sufficient capacity and effective diameter, preferably in a special top shape to insure freedom from strain and distortion, and shall be constructed of materials which will not corrode or exceed 8 pounds per square inch at all operating conditions. The manufacturer shall state at the time of the sale the maximum capacity of solution discharge from the Chlorinator at pressures at the point of application, namely from 100 pounds per square inch.

**METHOD OF CONTROL:** A. Manual Electrical Control. The Chlorinator shall be equipped with an automatic control device capable of being started automatically when the water pressure falls below a certain point.

B. Automatic Control. The Chlorinator shall be equipped with an automatic control device capable of being started automatically when the water pressure falls below a certain point.

**SUPERVISION OF INSTALLATION:** The Chlorinator shall be installed under the supervision of a qualified person familiar with the proper installation and operation of such equipment.

**SPARE PARTS:** There shall be available for each Chlorinator in addition to the Chlorinator itself, a complete set of assorted gaskets, a new piece all glass section ten eight feet long, and a complete set of spare parts normally constructed of materials which will not corrode or exceed 8 pounds per square inch at all operating conditions.

Memorandum:

THE PURCHASING AGENT

The Schools Branch has had some correspondence with you regarding the chlorinator for the Moose Fort Indian Residential School water supply. A representative of Wallace & Tierman, Ltd., Toronto, called here today and was seen by Mr. Phalen and myself. I believe that Wallace and Tierman supply the majority of chlorinating apparatuses that are recommended by various Public Health officials. They are recognized specialists in this field. The outfit that they quoted on in their letter to you of October 19, of which I received a copy, would be the chlorinator that I would recommend for this school. The price quoted was $495.00 F.O.B. Moose Cree.

I am not quite sure whether it would be necessary to have a man go from Toronto to install it, but rather think that with suitable instructions, someone at Moose Factory would be able to make the installation. This Branch has forwarded previous evidence as to the necessity of putting in this chlorinator as the river water is unsafe to drink and on reports from the Department of Health, Toronto, has been graded unfit for human consumption.

P.S.M.

F. E. Moore, M.D., D.P.H.
Acting Superintendent of Medical Services
Ottawa,
January 30, 1943.

MEMORANDUM

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

RE: Chlorinating Plant, Moose Fort Indian Residential School.

In memorandum of October 28, 1942, you were requested to take no further action with reference to the purchase of the above in view of the fact that we had already expended the major portion of the amount provided in the current year's appropriation for repairs, improvements and purchase of new material at the above-mentioned school.

Additional information received regarding the necessity for a chlorinating plant at this school is reflected in Dr. Moore's memorandum of January 26 in which he strongly recommends the immediate purchase of this equipment.

In our current year's appropriation there is an amount of $1000.00 for maintenance of equipment at church-owned residential schools. It has not been found necessary to expend any of this amount and, if the purchase of the chlorinating plant is approved, it will no doubt be possible to transfer sufficient funds from the amount mentioned to the Moose Fort school in order to provide the sum of $495.00 which is the cost of the chlorinating plant.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

May 31, 19--

Mr. J. L. [illegible]

Dear Mr. L.:

I have just returned from a trip to Moose Factory, where I visited the Bishop Horden Memorial Indian Residential School. During my stay, I discussed the current situation at the school with the Principal, Mr. Thompson. We also had a chance to review the progress made since last year.

The school is in good condition, and the students appear to be well cared for. However, there are some areas that need attention. The Principal has informed me that he will be submitting a report to the Board of Directors outlining these needs.

In conclusion, I am pleased with the overall state of the school and the dedication of its staff. I believe that with continued support, the school will continue to provide a quality education to the students.

Sincerely,

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL,

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT the appropriation for the fiscal year 1942-43, Vote No. 167, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, provides an amount of $1000.00 for maintenance of equipment at Church-owned Indian residential schools;

THAT part of the above amount is required for the purchase of a chlorinating plant at the Moose Fort Church of England Indian Residential School at a cost of $325.00;

THAT, as this building is Church-owned, the purchase of new equipment constitutes a grant and, therefore, the approval of Your Excellency in Council is desirable.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that approval be given for the expenditure of the above Indian residential school of the sum of $325.00, the same to be chargeable to Vote No. 167, 1942-43, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

ARCHIVES PUBLICIÈS
CANADA

VERY POOR COPY
OTTAWA March 4, 1943.

Gentlemen,

Attention Mr. Keith Mercer, Mgr.

We note from your letter of the 3rd instant, that to obtain delivery of the Wilson DES-O Pulsar feeder chlorinator unit for Moose Factory Indian Residential School covered by our purchase order 15134, you require a priority rating of A-3. Our experience has been that it is virtually impossible to secure such a high rating unless the end use of the equipment has a definite relation to the war effort. In this connection I may state that one of your competitors offered to supply a suitable chlorinating outfit if we could procure a priority rating of A-1-J or better.

In view of the above, will you please advise if it is not possible to obtain the required equipment with a lower rating than A-3. Otherwise we may be obliged to consider cancellation of our order.

You state in your tender of Sept. 10, 1942, that the unit is constructed of 60% Canadian goods. Would it not be possible for you to obtain the parts made in U.S.A. by means of a P.R.P. application.

Yours very truly,

H.J. Davidson
Departmental Purchasing Agent.

The Paterson Engineering Co.,
of Canada Limited,
1100 Craig St.E.,
Montreal, Que.
WALLACE & TIERNAN LIMITED

Toronto Office
350 Sorrento Avenue
Mar. 2, 1943.

Mr. P.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Subject: Moose Fort Indian Residential School Water Chlorination

Dear Sir:

Following our letter of Jan. 14th replying to yours of Jan. 11th, the writer had the pleasure around the first of February of further discussing Hypochlorinators with Dr. Moore and your Mr. Phelan.

At that time U.S. priority ratings were required from purchasers of equipment but the situation has now changed and we as a Canadian manufacturer operating under the Controlled Materials Plan, may ship to essential users without the necessity of obtaining priority ratings.

It was my understanding at the time of our discussion referred to above that we would probably be favoured with a purchase order covering one of our Hypochlorinators as quoted on by our letter of Oct. 19, 1942.

May we assure you of our desire to be of the best possible service.

Very truly yours,

WALLACE & TIERNAN LIMITED.

(Sgd.) J.B. Kinney,
Manager.
Dear Sirs,

We have your letter of the 8th instant, outlining the high type of priority required to enable us to obtain delivery and importation of the type DHS-O pulsated chlorinating unit covered by purchase order No. 15134 which we mailed you on the last instant. As the delivery promised is not satisfactory and as it will be impossible for us to obtain the priority asked for, please be advised that purchase order No. 15134 is hereby cancelled.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Departmental Purchasing Agent.

The Paterson Engineering Co.,
of Canada Limited,
Room 304, 1100 Craig St. E.,
Montreal, Que.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES CANADA

VERY POOR COPY
March 18, 1945.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT the appropriation for the fiscal year 1942-43, Vote No. 167, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, provides an amount of $1000.00 for maintenance of equipment at Church-owned Indian residential schools;

THAT part of the above amount is required for the purchase of a chlorinating plant at the House Furt Church of England Indian Residential School at a cost of $400.00;

THAT P.C. No. 61/1930 of March 13, 1943, authorized an expenditure of $250.00 and consequently an additional amount of $150.00 is required;

THAT, as this building is Church-owned, the purchase of new equipment constitutes a grant and, therefore, the approval of Your Excellency in Council is desirable.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that approval be given for the expenditure at the above Indian residential school of an additional sum of $150.00, the same to be chargeable to Vote No. 167, 1942-43, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

March 18, 1943.

MEMORANDUM FOR THE CLERK OF THE PRIVY COUNCIL:

Approval for the expenditure of an additional amount of $100.00 for purchase of a chlorinating plant at the Moose Port Indian Residential School.
Ottawa,
March 15, 1943.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

I enclose Memorandum to Council in connection with an additional amount of $168.00 required for the purchase of the chlorinating plant for the Moose Port Indian Residential School.

The reason for purchasing this plant at the present time was explained to you in my memorandum of February 25 last. At that time the purchasing Branch considered that a suitable plant could be secured for $325.00. Subsequently it was found that this particular plant could not be secured without a very high priority. It was, therefore, decided to purchase a plant at a cost of $425.00. P.C. No. 81/1930 of March 15, 1943, only provided $325.00 and the additional amount of $168.00 is required.

Director.

PP

THE INDIAN AND ESKIMO RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL COMMISSION

June 28/43.

Mr. R. A. Hoey,
Supt., Welfare & Training,
Dept. Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

With reference to your letter 44-6-5 you advised me to write you again with regard to the balance of materials needed to install the septic tank and flush toilet system for this school.

I have been held up somewhat due to the fact that the mill at Moose River Crossing has recently changed hands and some delay was experienced in obtaining an estimate from them of the lumber needed for cribbing for the tank.

I trust that you will find the enclosed in order and will see fit to let us have the materials so that we can go ahead with the installation.

Thanking you in anticipation, I am,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

VERY POOR COPY
Ottawa,
July 3, 1943.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 28th ultimo, enclosing list of materials needed to install the septic tank and flush toilet system at the Moose Fort Residential School. In the current year's appropriation it was only found possible to include an amount of $500.00 for repairs, improvements and purchase of new equipment at the Moose Fort School and, as this is a Church-owned school, we are only allowed to expend the amount specifically provided. We have already purchased equipment for the installation of a chlorinator at a cost of $45.00 and this leaves a balance of $457.00 available. As this is all we can spend, we are requesting the Departmental Purchasing Agent to order the 200 bags of cement and the 400' of 6" vitrified tile. The school management will have to be responsible for the balance of the material.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. G. Thompson,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Moose Fort,
via Moosonee, Ont.

May 30/44

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;

I am returning the cheque for $40.00 made out to me, to cover salary for night watchman at this school for the month of April.

Since I was to be away from here from the middle of May Apr. to the middle of May I made out the requisition before leaving and left it for the Doctor-Indian Agent to sign at the end of the month.

Our night watchman left us unexpectedly on Apr. 26th, and hence we are not entitled to the full $40.00. We should be entitled to $25.75.

I would be much obliged if you would send me a cheque for $25.75 to cover this item.

Thanking you, I am,

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Ottawa,
August 10, 1944.

Dr. T.J. Orford, Indian Agent, Moose Factory, Ont.

I enclose, for your information and whatever action is necessary, the attached report regarding the water supply at the Moose Fort Residential School. This has just been received from Mr. W.R. Edmonds, Sanitary Engineer of the Department of Pensions and National Health.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, July 24, 1944.

Mr. Edmonds, of the Public Health Engineering Division, Department of Pensions and National Health, phoned to say that his Branch had been advised that difficulty was being experienced with water supply at the Moose Port School and that he was proceeding on other business to the area in question tonight, and that he would be prepared to make an inspection and investigation if we so desired.

This was later confirmed by a further telephone call from Mr. G. H. Ferguson, Chief of the Public Health Engineering Division, who added that his department would be glad of the opportunity to perform this service without any cost to us. After consultation with Mr. Phelan, Mr. Ferguson was requested to have Mr. Edmonds go ahead as above mentioned, and instructions have been given accordingly.

A report will be submitted to us in due course. Mr. Edmonds, on arrival at Moose Factory is to get in touch with Dr. Orford and Rev. Gilbert Thompson. Mr. Ferguson added that chlorination places should be inspected by a qualified person about every six months.
